column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18531/homepage_large.8197e16e.jpg|The Vermilion Border|28307.0|Viv Albertine|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rough Trade']|2012-11-07 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:05:02.639201|"

About halfway through ""Shoplifting""
column2: the shortest track on the Slits' landmark 1979 album Cut
column3: Ari Up unleashes one of the most spine-tingling screams in punk history. Until that moment the song has a mischievous air: Viv Albertine palm-mutes an off-kilter chord progression
column4: Palmolive's beat lurches in fits and starts
column5: and Up muffles a shit-eating grin as she whispers to her co-conspirators
column6: ""Put the cheddar in the pocket
column7: put the rest under the jacket. Talk to the cashier
column8: he won't suspect."" It's a song about punking the system in order to eat (""Babylonian won't lose much/And we'll have dinner tonight"")
column9: but it's also a revolt against villains more pervasive than the corner store cashier: the false promises of dole-dependent England
column10: the stereotypical norms of femininity
column11: and the stifling conventions of the late-1970s musical establishment. Up
column12: with her defiant scream
column13: leads a gleefully liberating getaway.

column1: Though Up was arguably the most outspoken Slit
column2: guitarist Viv Albertine was responsible for the jouncing upstrokes that characterized the group's sound. Albertine's anarchic collision of reggae rhythms and abrasive noise made her one of the more innovative guitarists of punk's first wave. Still
column3: while their friends in the Clash and the Sex Pistols were embracing the idea of beaming their subversive messages to the masses
column4: the Slits kept it resolutely uncommercial. (Though it almost surely would have been a hit
column5: they refused to release their terrific cover of ""I Heard It Through the Grapevine"" as their debut single.) Admirable as these DIY instincts are
column6: it's a tiny tragedy of rock history that a song about Viv Albertine (her remote
column7: railway-accessible home + a jilted ex named Mick Jones = ""Train in Vain"") is much more widely known than any song she ever wrote (she composed
column8: among others
column9: the Slits' sardonic anthem ""Typical Girls""). It's a much bigger tragedy
column10: though
column11: that after the Slits disbanded
column12: Albertine claims she didn't touch her Telecaster for 25 years.

column1: But after the Slits' mid-aughts reunion (which was cut short by Up's untimely death a few years later) Albertine started writing again. ""It was like an avalanche
column2: she recalled in a 2010 interview
column3: ""I became like a teenage boy
column4: who had to be in his room playing every day... It was quite strange for a woman of a certain age to feel like this [but] I realized I hadn't known what was going on in myself until it all came flying out from the guitar."" The result of this outpouring of creativity was Albertine's highly personal Flesh EP
column5: released in 2010 on Thurston Moore's Ecstatic Peace! label. Softer and more vulnerable than her work in the Slits
column6: Albertine's solo work tackles themes of love
column7: marriage
column8: and disillusionment with equal parts humor and pathos. And though her solo debut (coming 33 years after Cut)
column9: The Vermillion Border improves upon the EP in almost every way
column10: it's still shot through with the same sense of urgency. True to her first band's uncommercial instincts
column11: it sounds like the work of somebody who picked her guitar back up simply because she had something she needed to say.

column2: ""Confessions of a MILF""
column3: the best song on the album
column4: ping-pongs between repression and release. Documenting an unhappy housewife's inner voice
column5: Albertine whispers the verses' exaggeratedly saccharine melody (""I've peeled the potatoes
column6: there's not much left to do/ Lovely lemon drizzle cake
column7: heat up the fondue"") like a Stepford Wife singing an Oompah Loompah parable. But the longer the song goes on
column8: the more its undercurrent of darkness bubbles to the surface. By its finale
column9: a warping
column10: manically chanted refrain of ""There's no place like home
column11: the song becomes reminiscent of Sleater-Kinney's ""Modern Girl""
column12: a quietly dystopian dream to choked to death on its own fairy dust. Unlike ""Shoplifting""
column13: though
column14: it never provides that moment of catharsis. But its hush only adds to the song's unsettling power. ""MILF"" is an updated take on an idea the Slits always embodied: Punk isn't necessarily about making the loudest noise
column15: but giving breath to the most radical
column16: surprising
column17: and unspoken truths.

column1: Though it doesn't reach the same heights
column2: Vermillion Border at times recalls Marianne Faithfull's mid-career
column3: middle-age masterpiece Broken English. Not every critique is as much of a direct hit as ""MILF""; songs like ""The False Heart"" and ""The Madness of Clouds"" ramble on with variations of themes explored more compellingly elsewhere. But thankfully her wit returns on the hilariously biting ""Hookup Girl"". A fairytale of modern courtship (""I was his forever girl/ Now he's asking me to be his hookup girl"")
column4: it first seems like the song's narrator has it better than the miserably repressed self-proclaimed MILF. But instead
column5: the song unfurls a provocative question: Is hookup culture liberating
column6: or just another gilded cage? Albertine's narrator would probably say the latter: As the affair corrodes into boring sex
column7: she finds herself sighing a lyric that could have been lifted from ""MILF"": ""We don't talk
column8: he doesn't want to know my thoughts.""

column2: irreverent teenager herself when she arrived on the London scene
column3: Albertine knows better than anybody that punk has always been the province of the young (and young men in particular). So even when The Vermillion Border occasionally ambles and falls short
column4: there's still something kinetic and refreshingly subversive about its biting
column5: wizened
column6: and uncompromisingly feminist voice. Nowhere is this felt more viscerally than on the opening track
column7: where over a seething swirl of guitars
column8: Albertine shouts a simple rallying cry
column9: ""I want more!"" It's an affirmation from
column10: in Albertine's words
column11:
a woman of a certain age who sometimes still feels (and shreds) like a teenage boy. 

"|17354.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17354-the-vermilion-border/|7.2|Lindsay Zoladz

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18491/homepage_large.6fb6015d.jpg|Desert Strike EP|30056.0|Fatima Al Qadiri|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fade to Mind']|2012-11-07 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:05:03.344045|"

Fatima Al Qadiri's greatest strength as an artist is her ability to conceptualize a world-- typically a sci-fi fantasy that blends the physical
column2: the spiritual
column3: and the technological-- and beautifully render it with beats. On the 2011 EP Genre-Specific Xperience
column4: she envisioned an atmosphere of dark luxury and conjured a kind of underground new age embodied by the gothic Tropicália of songs like ""Hip Hop Spa"". This follow-up EP
column5: befitting its title
column6: moves into exquisitely violent terrain. ""It's named after a Sega Megadrive game from 1992
column7: based on Operation Desert Storm from the first Gulf War in 1991
column8: Al Qadiri told Ruth Saxelby. ""The record is dedicated to this sci-fi period of my childhood-- surviving the invasion of Kuwait
column9: the war
column10: and then playing a video game based on those events a year later."" It's her best and most affecting work yet.

column2: Al Qadiri creates a new mood and aesthetic while maintaing the essential character of her music. The basic construction is similar to that found on Genre-Specific Xperience and WARN-U
column3: the EP she released under the name Ayshay: Tracks are built using pointedly synthetic versions of steel drums
column4: spectral chanting
column5: organs
column6: and horns
column7: but despite the almost cartoonish texture
column8: the result feels more like sacred music. Topical elements reinforce the militaristic cast-- song titles like ""War Games"" or ""Oil Well"" and sounds of weapons cocked or shells clinking on the floor are not exactly subtle-- but they shade the tone of the project instead of defining it. Each arrangement is a carefully constructed exercise in urgency and tension
column9: from a bloodthirsty kickdrum right out of the gates on the title track to the faux horns on ""Ghost Raid"" ballooning in and out in a way that could menace a band of spirit-possessed army tanks. But in spite of the music's inherent ties to aggressive themes-- war
column10: violence
column11: international strife-- it is not abrasive. Al Qadiri can make this stuff sound uncannily feminine and soothing.

column1: Highly conceptual music always comes with limitations
column2: and it's is difficult to imagine hearing Desert Strike EP outside of a private listening setting. But Al Qadiri makes the specificity work. It's one thing to mine the internet for scattershot cool sounds and throw them all at a wall in the hopes that some will stick; it's another thing to imagine an insular parallel universe and build it from scratch. On the evidence of Desert Strike
column3: Al Qadiri has got a few more worlds in mind
column4:
just waiting to come to life. 

"|17312.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17312-desert-strike-ep/|7.9|Carrie Battan

column2: Brian Eno released a CD called Thursday Afternoon. The hourlong work was the soundtrack to a video piece
column3: a project notable for two uses of technology. One
column4: the video was meant to be viewed on a television placed on its side (there's a YouTube rip out there that requires you to rotate your laptop). And with its 61-minute runtime
column5: Thursday Afternoon was promoted as the first piece to be created specifically for compact disc. Before the arrival of the CD a couple of years before
column6: works of such duration had to be spread across sides. And since Thursday Afternoon was an immersive ambient piece in the classic Eno mold
column7: the idea that you could absorb it uninterrupted in one hour-long session was important.

column1: Thursday Afternoon seemed to drift in place; it was music that seemed not so much ""played"" as ""allowed to exist."" Its structure brought to mind wind chimes
column2: as a handful of individually pleasing elements-- a few notes of piano
column3: some light synth treatments-- knocked around the space arbitrarily but seemed to benefit from the lack of order. Eno's first true ambient work
column4: Discreet Music
column5: from 1975
column6: was his first example of the form; there
column7: he generated a handful of electronic synth tones and allowed them to cycle through chance patterns (the title track from that album also pushed the limits of technology
column8: with over 30 minutes of audio on a single LP side). And now
column9: Eno's new solo album
column10: first created for an art installation
column11: is another. Lux consists of four tracks spread across 75 minutes
column12: but you don't really know where one ends and another begins and it doesn't matter. Like those earlier works
column13: a small number of sounds that complement each other are set loose in a space and allowed to move around in different configurations
column14: with subtle patterns sometimes emerging from the randomness. The most prominent of these sounds is single piano notes played quietly
column15: which further connects the work to Thursday Afternoon in the Eno lineage. But where the 1985 album felt submerged and ghostly
column16: Lux is clear and bright
column17: with the crisp higher harmonics allowed to come through.

column1: The other Eno work that comes to mind with Lux isn't a CD
column2: but yet another boundary-pushing use of technology
column3: and that's his iPhone app Bloom. The basic elements of light
column4: thin drone mixed with piano notes that strike
column5: decay
column6: and play against other notes is also the central idea of Bloom. The danger with a program like Bloom
column7: where Eno creates a generative system that allows the listener to make his or her own ambient pieces
column8: is that it raises the question: What purpose does the artist himself serve at that point? He's possibly invented himself out of existence. But if Lux does nothing else
column9: it suggests that there's a reason Eno's name has become synonymous with ""ambient"" and why his thoughts on the music remain the gold standard.

column1: Thursday Afternoon was assembled to accompany a ""visual painting"" and Eno studied art
column2: and it's best to think of his music using the language of design-- the colors used
column3: their proportions
column4: how they are laid out and balanced in the space. Eno is brilliant at getting things just so. So Lux has a mix of space and sound that feels right; no one element dominates or becomes grating over the course of 75 minutes
column5: even though all repeat over and over. Piano notes linger
column6: there are light plucks on what could be a harp
column7: and everything is bathed in Deep Listening-levels of reverb. While it accomplishes Eno's long-stated goal of changing the mood and feel of a room
column8: ""tinting"" the atmosphere
column9: it refuses to enforce any feeling in particular.

column1: It's easy to forget that Eno's ambient work doesn't always fit his strict definition. Music for Films sounds like it-- it's very suggestive of particular feeling-- and the brilliant Ambient 4: On Land conjures an entire landscape
column2: one filled with swamps and strange creatures. But Lux is squarely in the tradition of music that can be ignored but holds up (sometimes just barely) to closer scrutiny. It turns any living room into an art installation where interesting things may or may not happen
column3: and its lack of direction and specificity is in its own way brave. Sometimes it's hard to not say anything; Brian Eno is doing just that
column4: once again
column5:
and beautifully. 

"|17303.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17303-lux/|8.0|Mark Richardson

column2: Andi Toma and Jan St. Werner of Mouse on Mars have mixed traditional instrumentation with electronic textures that range from warm (1995's Iaora Tahiti) to brittle and disjointed (2001's Idiology). The ability to surprise and keep their followers on their toes made Mouse on Mars' work enthralling and impossible categorize.

column1: Their refusal to stay in one place could also make them seem out-of-step in a charming way. But if you zoom out a little
column2: you can see a gradual and defined path Mouse on Mars have taken over the past 15 years. The pair's forward chug came to a head on this year's excellent Parastrophics
column3: which was made to sound
column4: in St. Werner's words
column5: ""as digital as possible."" It was a dense
column6: colorfully overstuffed album that found St. Werner and Toma aligned with electronic music's current maximalist sound while still retaining their sense of themselves.

column2: Mouse on Mars' second release this year
column3: is a companion piece to Parastrophics and has a similar approach. But where Parastrophics' gestation was long and involved
column4: WOW was conceived and recorded in a matter of weeks. The relative ease is apparent in the music. There's still a lot going on here-- at 33 minutes
column5: even a deep listen feels like being smacked with a whirlwind of ideas-- but the longer compositions' raw elements are allowed more space to linger and develop. Here
column6: Mouse on Mars focus on a deconstruction of the wonky
column7: oddball bass music common to Modeselektor's Monkeytown imprint. ""We are still essentially the free jazz part of Monkeytown
column8: St. Werner told The Stool Pigeon in February of this year. ""We never really liked electronic dance music before
column9: but now we like some.""

column2: ""DOG""
column3: is a fine example of how Mouse on Mars riff on an established idea. The track starts with a few simple
column4: eerie tones before settling into a ruddy bassline that practically squeaks against the speakers. With every repetition of that figure
column5: something new happens-- a cluster of high-pitched video game sounds
column6: a sly change in rhythm
column7: what sounds like a jet engine being sucked into another jet engine. Finally
column8: only the track's original skeleton is recognizable
column9: and you get a sense of just how much it has morphed.

column2: but it's still an enjoyable twist on what else can be done with the already malleable world of bass music; once again Mouse on Mars refuse to stay in one place
column3:
but they almost always head somewhere interesting.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18442/homepage_large.dfbb9088.jpg|Too Late (Box Set)|30759.0|Trop Tard|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sacred Bones']|2012-11-06 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:05:05.179189|"

The debut cassette tape by French cold wave act Trop Tard is decorated by a poorly Xeroxed photograph featuring two of the band members wearing comically oversized sunglasses. It's possibly the least appropriate image they could have chosen to help illustrate how the music inside sounded. That album
column2: titled Photodrame
column3: is so claustrophobically downbeat that it makes the band's most obvious inspirations (early Cure
column4: Joy Division) seem positively sprightly in comparison. Photodrame is included in full on this box set from Sacred Bones
column5: which includes the band's second record
column6: Ils Étaient 9 Dans L'Obscurité
column7: plus a compilation album of rarities. Trop Tard's name translates as ""Too Late
column8: providing a near-perfect title for this collection
column9: mainly because it's taken around 25 years for this material to get a proper reissue
column10: but also because it missed the 21st-century cold wave resurgence by at least a couple of years. Truly they are a band out of time.

column2: but it bears hallmarks that stretch back to the previous decade. The squalling ball of compact energy at the heart of Cabaret Voltaire's classic synth-abuse track ""Nag Nag Nag"" is occasionally mirrored
column3: although Trop Tard were operating on a strict guitar/bass/drum machine set-up at the time. The overall sound appears to be a consequence of two forces colliding. For one
column4: there's a punk-like amateurishness to the playing. Philippe Lixtre's bassline on ""La Mort Est Humaine"" is so loose and unrefined it feels like you're witnessing a musician learning to play in real time. Secondly
column5: this was a home recording
column6: with the tape hiss lending an appropriately decaying atmosphere to songs like the rare English language venture ""Johnny Is a Loser"". Sadly
column7: it's unlikely we'll ever find out Trop Tard's true motivations. The people behind this music remain cloaked in mystery
column8: with Sacred Bones only releasing this set by negotiating with the remaining living member through a third party.

column1: One thing abundantly clear from Photodrame is that a large stack of pent-up anguish was offloaded into this music. The vocals from Fabien Doe are uncomfortably raw
column2: from the Birthday Party howl drilled into the center of ""Le Chant Des Martyrs"" to the sheer surliness of ""Ma Folie Se Dessiner"". That sense of collapse
column3: of witnessing someone pushed to the brink for their art
column4: is something the band polished up when they got a chance to move beyond their debut. Ils Etaient 9 Dans L'Obscurité
column5: released just a year later
column6: is a pro effort in comparison. The playing and singing are both vastly improved
column7: in the process removing some of the unease from their work. But the payoff is more satisfying here. ""Les Anges D'Aujourd'hui"" is artfully threaded between the bedsit pining of Soft Cell and the screaming guitar sound of Magazine
column8: while ""Maman"" is masterfully drunken
column9: hinting at frictional territory Trop Tard could have explored had the band enjoyed a greater shelf life.

column1: The fact that Ils Etaient 9 Dans L'Obscurité was an end that should have been a beginning is
column2: of course
column3: a big part of the appeal. Short-lived bands that leave a giant question mark behind allow us to create imaginary future narratives in out heads
column4: places where acts like Trop Tard further honed their potential and reached out to a wider audience. But the underlying picture that emerges with repeat plays of Too Late is one of a band that was a little too damaged to function beyond the tiny coterie they attracted. It's not hard to figure out that the mind behind the bleak ""Les Rêves De Peur"" from Ils Etaient 9 Dans L'Obscurité was ill-equipped for success of any kind. Even upbeat tracks like ""L'Analyse"" and the positively violent ""Mort D'Une Ame"" are plunged into the black by Doe's tormented vocal passages
column5: where he slurs and sobs and whines around the edges of every word. Many of the lyrics are sung in French
column6: but someone without knowledge of the language can easily grasp the intent
column7: so great is the emotion that bleeds from every syllable.

column1: Trop Tard's failings emerge through the lack of variation in their work
column2: through a bloody-minded determination to remain mired in a place of discomfort. When the songs don't quite work
column3: such as on the additional disc of rare and unheard material belonging to this collection
column4: there's something defiantly teenage about it
column5: like you've just walked in on a sulking adolescent picking holes in his sweater. That's a danger any band operating at this level of despondency potentially faces
column6: but Trop Tard mostly get the balance right over the course of Too Late. The fact that they dropped into a hole and disappeared suggests they may have had a lack of confidence in their art
column7: but there's also a nagging feeling that this wasn't a band built to survive the business end of the industry. It's difficult to picture a group with such a world-weary weight on its shoulders doing promo
column8: making videos
column9:
signing contracts. Too Late finally provides some space to get that immovable ache out into the world.

A number of Bristol artists have soundtracked the early morning waning of post-club buzz over the years. Vessel
column2: part of Bristol's Young Echo collective
column3: feels like someone who's been there and experienced those hours many times over. Vessel is one of many monikers used by Bristol resident Seb Gainsborough
column4: who has gained some momentum via a series of 12""s released over the past year. None of those offered an indication of just how wide open his vision would become on this debut full-length. His music falls roughly into the tenuous category of ""non-dance dance music
column5: although he's not averse to constructing tracks that are eminently danceable. This album's ""Court of Lions"" offers up a quietly euphoric type of mazy techno that feels made for huge sound systems.

column2: 2011's Wax Dance EP occasionally circled the plastic haze of chillwave
column3: perhaps offering a clue as to why Gainsborough ended up releasing Order of Noise on Tri Angle. Many of those rougher edges were smoothed over on the title track of the Standard EP from earlier this year
column4: although Order of Noise goes some way to reclaiming them. Gainsborough's music as Vessel has already gained comparisons to Actress
column5: and it's not hard to see why. Like R.I.P.
column6: this is an album that requires listeners to put in some work
column7: to extract their own sense of logic and rhythm from its scattershot surface. The path from the leaden bong fug of ""Stillborn Dub"" through to the light and bloopy ""Lache"" isn't apparent at first
column8: especially as the latter veers off on so many tangents; around the midway point
column9: it feels like an entirely separate track has encroached
column10: ushering in a whole wave of contrasting feelings.

column1: That particular part in ""Lache"" offers a useful entry point into Order of Noise as a whole
column2: highlighting how adept Gainsborough is at subtly warping his vision in unexpected ways. It's the type of approach that can easily end up unfocused
column3: with separate strands set in motion that end up dangling in the ether. But tiny motifs emerge that tie everything together. The processed sighs that pockmark ""Silten"" give it a sluggish feel
column4: something that loops around again later in the barren slo-mo grind of ""Villaine"". And Gainsborough is fond of stretched-out mood pieces. ""2 Moon Dub"" is the embodiment of that malaise at finding a club winding down for the night after endlessly plodding through puddled streets under the promise of something better. ""Aries"" goes even further
column5: dredging up feelings of desperate 4 a.m. glances between strangers across a rapidly emptying bar.

column1: There's no overall sense of narrative to Order of Noise
column2: but the depth of the production leaves itself open to interpretation. Dig past the early Warp stylings of ""Scarletta""
column3: and there's an intriguing mesh of industrial noise and balmy ambience. Some of those tweaks occasionally bear an Aphex-like fondness for tinkering. On ""Plane Curves"" it initially sounds like Gainsborough has mixed a percussion loop far too high in the mix
column4: only for it to become a wonderfully cantankerous center on multiple plays. That desire to bring agitation into an unexpected realm is a particularly Bristolian trait
column5: whether it's in Mark Stewart's aggro-funk workouts or through Portishead adding an unanticipated analog bite to their sound circa Third. Order of Noise subtly pulls on similar feelings of antagonism
column6:
in the process splitting open some welcome cracks in a well-traveled path.

Making honest art can be terrifying; with 2
column2: Montreal-based Mac DeMarco's second release this year
column3: it feels like he's jumping into the deep end. On DeMarco's other 2012 record
column4: the EP Rock and Roll Night Club
column5: he tinkered with yacht rock

column2: 2 goes right for the gut. DeMarco writes about life-- both the heavy moments and the mundane ones-- with economy and newfound grace. He's still not entirely upfront
column3: but he has a knack for building songs where the realness of his subject matter lies just below the surface. In a Pitchfork guest list from earlier in October
column4: DeMarco cites Jonathan Richman as a role model

column1: Opening track ""Cooking Up Something Good"" is a strong example of his approach. A loose instrumental vamp slides into a greasy guitar line
column2: as his laconic
column3: sleepy voice delivers subtly heartbreaking observations. ""Mommy's in the kitchen
column4: cooking up something good/ And daddy's on the sofa
column5: pride of the neighborhood"". When the chorus comes in (""Oh
column6: when life moves this slowly/ Oh
column7: just try and let it go"")

column1: As the song progresses it becomes clear that what initially felt like an ode to the frustrating teenage days of struggling against your suburban surroundings is actually about a father figure manufacturing drugs in the basement. ""Cooking Up Something Good"" is about boredom and sadness and our skewed perception of time
column2: but it's also about family secrets and how we construct emotional escape hatches to get away from the inescapable realities of blood ties. This careful world-building continues across the entire album
column3: sometimes with a lighter touch. DeMarco's thinly veiled honesty shows up prominently on ""Ode to Viceroy"" where
column4: over an unsettling guitar flange that fizzles into a flat shimmer

column6: but never quite gets there.

column2: DeMarco's vocal deadpan starts to sound weary and wise. On ""My Kind of Woman""
column3: he effectively makes a prom love song that will never get played at any actual prom-- it oozes beautifully simple and direct sentiment: ""You're my kind of woman/ And I'm down on my hands and knees begging you please
column4: baby
column5: show me your world."" That last line
column6: ""show me your world
column7: returns to the concept that DeMarco and the people he sings about are all living
column8: breathing entities
column9: not blank slates to project emotion on. When they're gone from DeMarco's life
column10:
they still exist. It doesn't really get more honest than that.

Rappers who come up through the mixtape circuit have two choices when it comes time for their major label debuts. On the one hand
column2: they can try to please their core fanbase by sticking to their established sound. The downside of this approach is that it may stunt their ability to grab a larger audience. (It also leaves them open to accusations of asking fans to pay for a record that is basically a well-mastered mixtape.) The other option is to go full pop and embrace the new collaborators and sounds that a big budget has to offer
column3: a path associated with disrespected sellouts (B.o.B.)
column4: MCs mired in self-loathing (Lupe Fiasco)
column5: and rappers that tried to go pop and failed anyway (Wale's first act).

column1: There are exceptions. Artists like Drake and J. Cole have made better
column2: more accessible versions of the early songs that first got them buzz
column3: and Nicki Minaj plays both sides of the field. Waka Flocka Flame was smart enough to capitalize on his timing simply by turning a proposed mixtape into a debut album
column4: and
column5: most recently
column6: Kendrick Lamar used his unwavering artistic vision to essentially subvert this game entirely. But this is still a thin line for artists to walk
column7: one so difficult that good-to-great major label rap debuts now feel like a minor miracle.

column1: So maybe Dreams and Nightmares is something to celebrate
column2: even though it's imperfect. After navigating that push-pull
column3: Meek Mill has emerged with an album that is distinct in both voice and sound and also plays to his strengths. It is tense and dramatic
column4: with variations of piano constituting the bedrock of the album and Meek rapping passionately even by his own standards.

column2: anger
column3: empathy
column4: and glee into a wave that hits immediately and forcefully
column5: especially on the album's first two songs. On the opening title track
column6: he raps unabated for nearly four minutes
column7: tracing lines from his come-up in Philly to strip clubs in Miami and back
column8: over a beat that morphs into menace halfway through. It's a track that best distills Meek's singularity; hurt oozes from his voice and words
column9: illustrating rap's literal and spiritual roots.

column2: of wanting to stay humble and true while still stunting. Sneering talking heads and confused elitists use that struggle as a weapon against the music: How can this music
column3: and these artists
column4: be taken seriously when they brag about throwing money at strippers? The genius of Meek's music is that he embodies
column5: fleshes out
column6: and answers the rapper's dilemma.

column2: are palpable and plainly articulated in his music
column3: and it makes the best of Dreams and Nightmares (including ""In God We Trust"" and ""Believe It"") feel eminently vital. He is as much a truth-teller as lyricist
column4: and this singular viewpoint and delivery have both been carried over from his mixtapes. It extends to ""Traumatized""
column5: a track where Meek addresses his father's killer while illustrating exactly how treacherous his upbringing was for him and those around him. Where some rappers coast
column6: Meek's mere existence feels earned.

column2: the album loses steam with a quarter of the way to go. ""Tony Story Pt. 2"" is the follow-up to the stunning storytelling track from Dreamchasers
column3: but this version lacks its precision and is bogged down by a chintzy Boi-1da beat. ""Who You're Around""
column4: featuring Mary J. Blige
column5: marks the point where the album becomes syrupy and maudlin. Some songs that appear earlier on the album (""Maybach Curtains""
column6: ""Young Kings"") borrow the orchestral bloat of Rick Ross
column7: and could've been replaced by up-tempo bangers à la ""House Party"" or ""Burn"" on which Meek has made his name.

column2: Meek has made the move from mixtapes to the majors with a solid vision. Whether he can maintain or strengthen that in the future is an open question
column3: but this is music that immediately hits emotionally and physically while lingering in your thoughts long after you turn it off. Dreams and Nightmares is the type of thing rap will always need
column4:
even when it's in flawed form.

If the recent appetite for artists like Nicolas Jaar
column2: Actress
column3: and Andy Stott has anything to tell us about the taste of dance music's more studious set
column4: it's that fitful and filthy are in
column5: and streamlined and tidy are out. This development is neither sudden nor surprising-- the swapping of sleek sounds and tidy quantization for more distressed sonic textures and complicated time signatures has been a throughline of pretty much all electronic music for the past three or four years. But it's a difficult enviornment for someone with as crisp an aesthetic as Michael Mayer.

column1: Mayer may be among the more celebrated of the last decade's dance personalities
column2: but he doesn't slot quite so easily into this current landscape. That's partly because the louche
column3: tasteful
column4: and continental sensibilities that defined his best work don't seem like dominant ideologies in dance music anymore. Perhaps correspondingly
column5: it also feels like his ambition and energy have waned. Over the last few years
column6: Mayer's label Kompakt has settled into a comfortable but unremarkable groove
column7: working roughly the same corners of the same circuit for what seem like ever-diminishing returns. Meanwhile
column8: Mayer's solo work has been so sporadic and incremental that his Discogs page might as well be covered in moss.

column1: Mantasy is Mayer's first original full-length in eight years. Considering such a lengthy absence
column2: you'd be forgiven for wondering if he might come back with something dramatically different
column3: but he doesn't take any big swings here
column4: nor does he seem to worry much about stretching beyond his own aesthetic bounds. Detractors will argue that in 2012 his kind of touch sounds more middle-aged than craftsmanlike
column5: and
column6: frankly
column7: they'll be right. In that way
column8: I suppose Mayer is kind of a litmus test for modern dance music listeners: So long as the idea of ""middle-aged"" isn't total anathema to you
column9: you'll find something to like here.

column1: Even though it operates under the familiar laws of Mayer's universe
column2: Mantasy's appeal largely comes from how self-contained and individual each cut is; whether it's a fidgety horror show theme (""Lamusetwa"")
column3: a moody nod to Jan Hammer (""Mantasy"")
column4: a bouquet of harp trills and birdsong (""Baumhaus"")
column5: or a skronky jazz workout (""Rudi Was a Punk"")
column6: each of these 10 tracks aims at a distinct and concrete idea. Which isn't to say that all of them hit.

column1: As with the tepid rhythm exercise ""Neue Furche"" and the aforementioned ""Lamusetwa""
column2: Mayer's tendency to dial things like promisingly outre sounds or rhythm sections requiring muscle toward tastefulness instead of coarseness means that he has a frustrating default tendency toward the middle of the road. On other tracks
column3: though
column4: such as the perfectly pitched ""Rudi"" or the ""Billie Jean""-aping highlight ""Wrong Lap""
column5: which manages the neat trick of containing some pretty nuanced sounds while also sounding huge
column6:
you're reminded of how the right amount of restraint in the right places can still lead to unexpected magic.

column3: tightly harmonizing in the chorus for one of the record's prettiest moments. Singles ""SYH"" and ""Yoro Diallo"" carry more urgency
column4: the latter sounding like Foals bent slightly out of shape. Again
column5: well-knitted vocal harmonies help the song feel easier to love on first listen
column6: without compromising on the screwed sonics they mine so effectively elsewhere.

column2: though
column3: Good Don't Sleep drifts too far in the wrong direction and coasts too much on vibe. And if there's one thing Egyptian Hip Hop aren't yet
column4: it's good editors. But what the record lacks in brevity and nous it just about makes up for in the thrill of not quite knowing where Egyptian Hip Hop are leading you. Good Don't Sleep finds them holding a mirror up to their early work
column5: eager to reverse any youthful misstep. Where Hewett once impersonated an interesting voice (namely that of Robert Smith) he now sounds older and more confident. Their early
column6: punky tunes carried flourishes of post-DFA dance music
column7: whereas the songs here are now imbued with modern electronic music's more liquid
column8: experimental spirit. Egyptian Hip Hop now sound like the band they dressed up so well as at first: weird
column9: otherworldly
column10:
and exciting.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18514/homepage_large.db3742a3.jpg|Eternal Champ|30577.0|Sweet Valley|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|"[""Fool's Gold""]"|2012-10-31 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:05:19.930044|"

Eternal Champ is the second release Wavves' Nathan Williams and his brother Joel ""Kynan"" have put out in the past three months
column2: and it's initially unclear as to what it ""means"" for Sweet Valley. Are we to take it as a sign of commitment to the project
column3: especially in light of the two-plus years that have passed since Wavves' King of the Beach? Or is it an indication that the Williams brothers can just crank this stuff out like it's nothing? As an actual piece of music
column4: Eternal Champ mostly just reminds you that Nathan's proven to have a quick learning curve. While it doesn't parallel the leap he made from Wavvves to King of the Beach (or even Wavves to Wavvves for that matter)
column5: it's a more impressive
column6: diverse
column7: and genuinely artistic endeavor than its enjoyable but slight predecessor.

column1: Eternal Champ feels more like a proper full-length
column2: where Stay Calm was presented as a incomplete-by-definition ""beat tape."" In addition to a generally darker tone
column3: this album just sounds heavier. It delves into slower tempos and chillier textures
column4: and the segues feel as important as the tracks proper.

column1: Sweet Valley may not be particularly original but they do show a knack for knowing when to mix styles and when to collate: Lead-off ""One"" has impressive range
column2: morphing from the more stoned iterations of late-90s southern hip-hop to Three 6 Mafia's fight music. It bleeds right into ""Where Will I Go""
column3: which throws in Lex Luger's trademark lightcycle windup before drifting off into the tropics. From there on out
column4: the Williams brothers set their sights on clear targets and hit the mark. Their style doesn't stray far from the blazer's choice of hip-hop producers-- Clams Casino (""Stone"")
column5: Dilla (""Bros Beyond""
column6: ""Sentimental Trash"")
column7: recent Alchemist. The vocal sample on ""Motorcycle Renegade"" is similar enough to Action Bronson and Party Supplies' ""Thug Love Story 2012""
column8: to suggest that Eternal Champ was probably only a few months in the making
column9: but the adaptability is admirable.

column2: always enjoyable
column3: and never hits an errant beat
column4: it's worth asking what exactly the endgame is for Sweet Valley. Do they want to do more than soundtrack skate videos? Granted
column5: even if they never release another note of music
column6: they've exceeded the expectations one might have for a beatmaking side project from Wavves. But what's lacking here is a sense of stakes-- the ""millennial who smokes weed and plays video games"" thing isn't exactly underrepresented right now. But Williams is the guy who used ""I'm just having fun with you"" as a mission statement
column7:
so it's probably not a pressing concern. Sweet Valley feels like the Williams brothers using their free time to soundtrack yours.

"|17334.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17334-eternal-champ/|6.6|Ian Cohen

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18394/homepage_large.84813896.jpg|Psychedelic Pill|4693.0|Neil Young|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warner Bros.']|2012-10-30 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:05:20.415670|"

The signature Crazy Horse move is The Huddle. No matter how big the stage
column2: Neil Young
column3: Billy Talbot
column4: and Frank ""Poncho"" Sampedro will inevitably find themselves tightly packed in front of Ralph Molina's drums
column5: bobbing and flailing in such close proximity that it's a miracle they never crack guitar necks. It's an aggressively insular move for a band playing to thousands
column6: an unambiguous signal that the feedback storm they are conjuring is often more about them than us.

column1: That self indulgence is the beating heart of each time Young deigns to bring the Horse back out of the barn
column2: even as the decision excites his fanbase like no other. To the point
column3: the latest Crazy Horse reunion was announced with the leak of an instrumental jam on the chords to ""Fuckin' Up"" and ""Cortez the Killer” that ran over 37 minutes. Then there was the first official leg of the comeback: Americana
column4: where Young fed old-as-dirt traditionals such as ""She'll Be Coming Round the Mountain"" into the Crazy Horse engine
column5: followed by an arena tour that filled nearly half the setlist with unreleased material.

column1: But Psychedelic Pill might be the most accurate studio portrayal of The Huddle yet. Three songs gallop past the 15-minute mark
column2: and the opener ""Driftin' Back"" approaches a half hour
column3: quickly weeding out the faint of heart. They are the three longest songs ever released by Young (if you don't count Arc) and they feel like it. ""Driftin' Back""
column4: in particular
column5: is nearly trance-inducing as it locks onto the same chord progression
column6: interrupted only occasionally by mini-rants about hip-hop haircuts and mp3 sound quality.

column2: playing with Crazy Horse is playing it safe for Young: You know exactly what you're going to get
column3: and there are none of the pleasant surprises of 2010's excellent loop-dabbling Le Noise. One song
column4: ""She's Always Dancing""
column5: even sounds like the band just took an instrumental rehearsal of ""Like a Hurricane"" and added a new vocal track over the top-- which is good enough to make it the second best jam on the record. ""Ramada Inn"" is paint-by-numbers Crazy Horse
column6: indistinguishable from any of their late-period outings beyond its refusal to end.

column1: It will also surprise no Neil Young fan that most of the songs here are about aging
column2: continuing a roughly 50-year streak of obsessing over getting old. So much of Psychedelic Pill is Young looking back
column3: from the long-married couple of ""Ramada Inn"" to the classic rock name-dropping of ""Twisted Road"". He even reminisces his way back to the cradle
column4: with ""Born in Ontario""
column5: a brief country-rocker that's a welcome breath-catcher
column6: even though it bears a giant hole in the shape of deceased longtime collaborator and auxiliary Horseman Ben Keith's slide guitar.

column1: But Neil's particular flavor of nostalgia has always been a little on the sour side. When he references the Woodstock Generation
column2: he tends to do it with a scowl
column3: angry about the failure of the hippie dream even as he still clings to its promise. Psychedelic Pill suggests a softening of that harsh stance
column4: particularly on the saccharine ""Twisted Road"" with its irony-free shout-outs to Dylan and the Dead and the distracting ""trippy"" effects that ruin the title track.

column2: the album's final epic
column3: ""Walk Like a Giant""
column4: scrawls a jagged line through that cuddly history with a single chord change
column5: coming immediately after an immensely dopey verse about how Neil and his friends were gonna save the world. In fact
column6: ""Walk Like a Giant""
column7: is easily the best studio Crazy Horse performance since Ragged Glory. Once again
column8: the formula is unchanged-- it even swipes pretty heavily from the ""Hey Hey My My"" riff-- but between the verses the Horse is whipped until it foams at the mouth. Everything great about Neil Young
column9: electric guitarist
column10: is on full display
column11: his singular tone veering from feral growls and feedback to blistering fury while the other three egg him on with subtle
column12: perennially underrated counterpoint.

column1: Despite the patience required to get there
column2: the track underlines the greatest trick of Neil Young's long career: that his most self-indulgent mode can also be his most crowd-pleasing. At this point
column3: the ""these old guys still know how to rock!"" angle for Crazy Horse is itself old enough to collect Social Security. But there's enough life and fuck-you attitude left in Psychedelic Pill to remind a listener that ""it's better to burn out than to fade away"" wasn't necessarily about dying young
column4: so long as you avoided phoning it in. If circling the wagons is what it takes to keep Neil Young's fire raging
column5:
then just be happy he lets us pay to watch.

"|17213.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17213-psychedelic-pill/|7.0|Rob Mitchum

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18396/homepage_large.2071c60e.jpg|Bossalinis & Fooliyones|29865.0|Main Attrakionz|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Young One']|2012-10-30 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:05:21.346978|"

Gearing up for the release of Bossalinis & Fooliyones
column2: rapper MondreM.A.N. (one half of the Main Attrakionz
column3: along with partner Squadda B) told FACT
column4: ""We don't feel like dancing
column5: we don't go to parties
column6: and we don't make no party music."" Following the trajectory of Main Attrakionz's career
column7: which has produced a multitude of free solo and collaborative mixtapes hinged on celestial samples and irreverent rhymes
column8: it's not a terribly surprising statement. Wedged somewhere between Bay Area peer Lil B's prolific and ever-expanding thought balloons and the spacey introversion of chillwave
column9: ""cloud rap"" was viewed as the antithesis of party rap
column10: a music that made little sense outside of a weed-fogged
column11: wi-fi enabled bubble built for one.

column1: This was a big part of cloud rap's appeal
column2: but any music built on the fickle whims of the web is vulnerable. But on releases like their 2011 breakthrough 808s & Dark Grapes II and Squadda B's I Smoke Because I Don't Care About Death
column3: Main Attrakionz proved to be relatable and able to adapt to new sounds. Here on their proper full-length debut
column4: a sound in danger of stagnation has been brightened and reconfigured in appealing ways.

column2: hedonistic
column3: and vaguely introspective as their previous efforts
column4: Bossalinis & Fooliyones at times sounds downright bombastic thanks to its embrace of earthly influences. Taking it to the club might be taking it a little too far
column5: but the springy opener ""Green on Sight"" and the addictive ""La Piñata"" bring to mind house parties
column6: parking lots
column7: and late-night convertible joyrides. Squadda and Mondre put a lot of work into getting their unconventional sound noticed
column8: and it's obvious as to why they would want to hold onto their outsider status. But it's hard for them to mask just how much fun they're having
column9: and the feeling is infectious.

column1: Main Attrakionz have never been great rappers
column2: and sometimes that's a problem: ""I can't complain I'm doin' my thing
column3: I mean I'm in my lane/ I can't complain I'm steady getting' paid
column4: I'm sippin' the drank
column5: seems to be the motto. But thanks to a crack team of mostly unknown producers
column6: the recurring themes of money
column7: smoke
column8: girls
column9: and hustle are cast in a flattering light. Despite there being 13 producers spread over 17 tracks (Chicago space cadets Supreme Cuts and the ubiquitous Harry Fraud get two at-bats)
column10: Bossalinis & Fooliyones sounds sonically cohesive and consistent. The duo's laconic flows feel tailor-made for off-the-cuff game spitting
column11: and tracks like highlight ""Cloud Life"" get a boost from producer Joe Wax's amorous slow-burn. ""LFK"" (which stands for ""Lo-fi Kings"") finds the two riffing on UGK and providing their own take on all things Houston. And Fraud
column12: as if trying to provide a minimalist companion piece to current hit ""Function""
column13: helps assist the hometown anthem single ""Do It For the Bay"".

column1: Too bad that what follows marks a significant drop-off in quality. The problems start with ""Superstitious""
column2: which features a usually reliable Zaytoven on auto-pilot and a phoned-in Gucci Mane verse. Tracks like ""Love Is Life"" and ""Cloud Body"" are boilerplate cloud rap
column3: feeling lifeless against the harder-hitting material. Other songs simply suffer from being too corny (the melodramatic ""Wings"")
column4: or too leaden (""Bury Me a Millionaire""
column5: which features name-drop puns that even Game wouldn't go near). The real problem might just be that
column6: having been so mixtape-oriented for so long
column7: Main Attrakionz haven't developed the necessary editing skills. By the time you get to ""Wings""
column8: you still have 20 minutes left in a nearly 70 minute album.

column2: there's something obviously charming about Main Attrakionz. They're transparent and often entertainingly aloof-- in the same FACT interview
column3: Mondre admitted to not even knowing what chillwave was. So Bossalinis & Fooliyones is a testament to honesty and effort. Here are two guys who clearly love to rap and work hard at it
column4: taking a style they can call their own
column5: and presenting it in a more user-friendly way. More often than not
column6:
they make it work.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18384/homepage_large.0c704ca8.jpg|Prins Thomas 2|7602.0|Prins Thomas|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Full Pupp']|2012-10-30 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:05:22.160465|"

The Norwegian producer Prins Thomas navigates an odd conceptual space: he is a classicist
column2: a conservative
column3: but one adherent to artists and styles that were
column4: by definition
column5: exploratory and indefinable. Thomas is again a passive adventurer on his second solo album
column6: Prins Thomas II
column7: on which he continues to explore foggy krautrock
column8: hippie jazz
column9: and space disco.

column1: Prins Thomas II jettisons his debut album's guitar-aided motorik expeditions in favor of slow
column2: worming dance grooves. This was intentional: Thomas abandoned the live drums and bass that powered his first collection in favor of drum machines and synthesizers. It's a curious choice-- the world does not lack for slow-disco synth enthusiasts-- and as a result II is more diffuse than its predecessor and contains less gnarly
column3: Michael Rother-inspired grit. Thomas excelled for years as an edits guru
column4: so he has to know that II is too slow and linear for dancing; it's more likely to make you tap your foot and unconsciously nod your head.

column1: Thomas' compositions don't build so much as perpetually unwind; when he adds a bassline or twirls a new melody
column2: it doesn't reach toward an apex so much as remind us that
column3: yes
column4: we are still strolling downhill toward an undefined moment of rest. This is Thomas' neatest trick as a producer but it's also the undoing of Prins Thomas II
column5: which provides little to rally around or grasp onto. In an interview with Red Bull Music Academy
column6: he admits that he's never had an ""Inspector Norse""-type hit
column7: which... yeah. Thomas specializes in this type of lay-in-the-cut disco but it would be nice to see him reach for the brass ring occasionally.

column1: The 13-minute ""Bobletekno"" is the album's centerpiece-- we know because Thomas reprises its tittering
column2: aluminum-foil drums later on as ""Bobletekno (Permiks)""-- and an example of Thomas using drum machines to add detail to his bold melodies. They are an aggressive
column3: echoing patter throughout; when he reprises the song
column4: he presents the rhythm sans accompaniment. He offers a similar trick on the sparse ""Bom Bom""
column5: which presents a standard Thomas rhythm in repose
column6: highlighting the subtle congo thwacks. These tracks
column7: which play like a photo-negative version of the rest of the album
column8: present a possible path forward for Thomas
column9: space disco without the disco. (In the Red Bull chat
column10: Thomas is touchy about the term ""space disco
column11: but it's unavoidable until he offers tracks that avoid it.)

column2: II leaves Thomas in much the same place his debut did: as a producer predisposed to coloring inside the lines. We're left with some pretty pictures for our refrigerators and some worthwhile domestic jams
column3:
but little to be excited about.

"|17203.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17203-ii/|6.3|Andrew Gaerig

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18449/homepage_large.03f9a634.jpg|Landing on a Hundred|739.0|Cody ChesnuTT|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Vibration Vineyard']|2012-10-30 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:05:22.720170|"

On ""What Kind of Cool (Will We Think of Next)""
column2: the Atlanta-born
column3: Tallahassee-residing soul crooner Cody ChesnuTT ruminates on a question that has driven the music industry for decades. As a sultry
column4: self-conscious slab of smooth
column5: Memphis-style soul
column6: the song itself doesn't quite feel ""next
column7: but that's not the point. Its power comes from its source: ChesnuTT's got experience on the other side of the equation. In 2002
column8: as the internet and web were ready to redefine DIY promotion
column9: ChesnuTT was working his humbly titled 36-track debut The Headphone Masterpiece any way he could
column10: to anyone he could find. He slipped it into stereos at random L.A. parties
column11: and gave his number to equally random people at malls
column12: inviting them to come back to his place for listening sessions. He'd been kicking around the scene for a while (long enough to get pulled onstage to pose at a 2002 Strokes gig in L.A.)
column13: and the demo soon wound up in ?uestlove's hands. When Masterpiece highlight ""The Seed"" was remade into the best song on the Roots' LP Phrenology
column14: ChesnuTT and his album were instantly all kinds of ""cool"" and ""next.""

column2: and music nerds rushed to crown the album Sign O' the Times on Alien Lanes' budget. ChesnuTT was courted by major labels
column3: copped a four-star Rolling Stone review that called him ""a new breed of American troubadour
column4: and was featured in the Guardian as part of a piece that (bizarrely) suggested he was the ""new Hendrix."" Until the release of Landing on a Hundred
column5: Masterpiece's legacy was further defined as the sole release from the guy who subsequently disappeared
column6: save a brief appearance in Dave Chappelle's Block Party and a quietly issued 2010 EP. In this regard
column7: it's not just ChesnuTT's beautiful falsetto and lightly-scuffed tenor that recall Terence Trent D'Arby-- both were unconventional R&B prodigies with no shortage of swagger
column8: who managed to drop off the pop map soon after their highly-praised debuts. According to ChesnuTT
column9: his disappearance was planned: to start a family far away from music's exhausting business end. Landing is an apt reflection of an artist restarting after several years
column10: but without sacrificing the eccentricity that initially made him such a compelling figure.

column1: Recorded in part with a 10-piece band in the same studio where Al Green cut ""Let's Stay Together""
column2: Landing largely situates itself in the early-1970s soul tradition of Green and Curtis Mayfield-- no matter how personal or political
column3: the music is never too far from the pulpit. Opening cut ""'Till I Met Thee"" is positively beatific
column4: ChesnuTT's scratched-out funk guitar alternating with a rich brass backdrop that lends the refrain an earthy gospel overtone. ""Under the Spell of the Handout"" is a dizzying trip through conflicting impulses that never tips over into the finger-wagging implied by the title. ChesnuTT's at his best when he can let his own contradictory spirit move him-- that's what Headphone Masterpiece did
column5: in bulk-- and on ""Handout"" he begs to be let in ""the caste"" one second
column6: and asks ""what am I feeding on"" the next. Hundred is occasionally wayward
column7: but you can't expect ChesnuTT
column8: even as a father of two in his mid-40s
column9: to ever play it straight.

column2: but they give the album much of its vitality. On ""I've Been Life""
column3: he channels Muhammad Ali (""Since my birth/ I've been the greatest attraction on the earth"") while shouting out an alphabetical roll-call of each African nation. The result sounds designed to slot between the Crusaders and James Brown in the ""Zaire '74"" music festival accompanying the Ali/Foreman ""Rumble in the Jungle."" On the peppy late album cut ""Don't Wanna Go the Other Way""
column4: he rides a galloping bassline until it breaks
column5: incorporating puffs of breath as a primary rhythmic component. Lyrically
column6: he seems to be talking to the younger Cody (""Oh
column7:
frustrated young man/ Still carrying that load"") while actively pushing himself to remain on a righteous path dotted with temptation. It's good advice: all the better because he seems to be heeding it.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18519/homepage_large.124bf625.jpg|Explore|30825.0|GRMLN|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Carpark']|2012-10-30 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:05:23.331621|"

From the Beach Boys to Dr. Dre
column2: from War to X
column3: from Guns N' Roses to Kendrick Lamar
column4: southern California has inspired more great driving music than any other part of the country. And so it goes for 19-year-old college student and occasional surfer Yoodoo Park
column5: who first started recording short
column6: melancholic guitar-pop songs as GRMLN two years ago for his own enjoyment while cruising around in his car. GRMLN's debut EP
column7: Explore
column8: collects seven of those tracks
column9: which flit in and out over the course of 15 breezy minutes. It's a solid but slight record made by an artist who could produce something more substantial should he discover grander ambitions.

column1: Based on Park's preference for pointillist guitars and subtly driving surf-rock rhythms
column2: it might have been easier for him just to play Real Estate or Beach Fossils CDs in his car
column3: rather than make his own variation on the dreamy
column4: nostalgic music those groups have come to personify. Explore's first single
column5: ""Coral""
column6: certainly doesn't break any new ground in the sad guy/sunny melody school of songwriting. For two minutes a circular guitar riff and stiffly syncopated drum beat set the tone for Park's moony deference for the ocean and the big
column7: bright sun setting over it. ""It's all right
column8: he sings in the chorus
column9: which is about as decipherable as he gets on Explore. Park sings in a soft voice somewhere between a murmur and a sigh
column10: preferring to let jangly six-strings and ping-pong basslines articulate the emotional core of his songs.

column1: While the guitars immediately jump out of the otherwise spare and direct songs on Explore
column2: it's the brittle yet surprisingly nimble rhythm section that ultimately sticks. The drum part on ""Depressions"" is little more than a lightly tapped snare
column3: but as the song settles into a hypnotic
column4: relatively extended groove that pushes to nearly three minutes
column5: Park exhibits a proclivity for quietly unfolding soundscapes that could really beguile if he ever gets a bigger recording budget. Conversely
column6: the stripped down ""Live.Think.Die"" never really goes anywhere
column7: as Park trills pleasantly over his unaccompanied guitar for a few minutes before suddenly stopping.

column1: Explore suggests that while Park can produce listenable songs that do right by their influences
column2: he's still an inexperienced talent in the process of finding his own voice. The album-closing ""Patio"" sounds weirdly like a left-coast Bon Iver
column3: with its ethereal acoustic strumming and falsetto vocal. It's a derivative curveball that pushes Explore in a more generic direction. Park is better off building on the emotional quality of his recent cover of Ben E. King's ""Stand By Me"". Like the most affecting parts of Explore
column4: Park's ""Stand By Me"" is old fashioned
column5: predictable
column6: and probably shouldn't work as well as it does. But Park's guileless open-heartedness is naive in the best possible sense. If he can combine that feeling with more sophisticated songwriting
column7:
he might have something.

"|17338.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17338-explore/|6.5|Steven Hyden

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18386/homepage_large.a77eb974.jpg|Luxury Problems|22792.0|Andy Stott|['Electronic']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Modern Love']|2012-10-29 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:05:23.993455|"

Andy Stott took his time getting here. The Manchester producer spent a good part of the last decade turning out solid tracks under his own name and under the alias Andrea. Though he always returned to dub techno
column2: he flirted with a range of genres
column3: from juke to house to dubstep
column4: and some of his music was very good. But Stott never quite zeroed in on a unique voice. That changed in 2011 with the release of two short albums
column5: Passed Me By and We Stay Together. Stott left behind the quicker tempos of dance proper
column6: and slowing down allowed him to sink deeper into his music
column7: where he found a new world of atmosphere and texture. Passed and Stay were heavy records that highlighted something new about the expressive power of bass. Dub techno
column8: stretching back to its origins with the early-1990s Berlin project Basic Channel
column9: tends to view the low end as a mysterious black sludge. Where bass in Skrillex-style EDM is a precision weapon
column10: with drops punctuating the tracks and jacking up the mood in an instant
column11: the bottom octave in dub techno is more of an enveloping presence. It's murkier
column12: more oppressive
column13: colder
column14: something you wade through and push against. Which is why the inertia of the relentless 4/4 beat signifies energy whatever the tempo.

column2: Stott found an unusual musicality in deep
column3: foreboding bass. His music throbbed with the sooty remnants of industry and had obvious appeal for those interested in dark ambiance of any stripe; its all-consuming nature gave him a new audience beyond the realm of dance music. With his new album
column4: Luxury Problems
column5: he adds a few more wrinkles
column6: and his music has become simultaneously more complex and more accessible. Working with operatically trained vocalist Alison Skidmore (Stott met her as a student when she taught him piano)
column7: he's humanized his sound
column8: made it more beautiful and richer on the surface while further accentuating its dark heart. The new dynamic leads to another big leap forward for the producer.

column1: Skidmore's voice is a versatile instrument in its own right
column2: but Stott's looping and processing gives it even more flexibility. Though Luxury Problems has a consistent overall mood
column3: the feel and structure of the individual tracks vary quite a bit
column4: and the pieces featuring Skidmore find her singing pulled into all kinds of interesting shapes. The album opens with her in her most glassy and ethereal
column5: as repetitions of her singing a single word
column6: ""touch
column7: float through space like soap bubbles. The ""ch"" phoneme is looped and becomes the hi-hat on the track
column8: and gradually the sounds assemble themselves into a ghosted version of a conventional dance rhythm. But when Stott's machine bass pulse enters just under halfway through
column9: we realize we're in for a world of serious contrasts: ""Numb"" is delicate and gorgeous but has an undercurrent of menace
column10: and the tension between these qualities is the record's essence.

column1: If ""Numb"" is Skidmore at her most spectral
column2: ""Hatch the Plan"" finds her sounding more grounded
column3: almost in the mode of a singer-songwriter. The choral-like layering on ""Plan"" brings to mind School of Seven Bells and even Throwing Muses. But it's the longest track on the record and is purely instrumental-- mostly a deeply unsettling mix of bass churn and machine noises-- for its first two minutes. That it moves from pure soundscape to something close to a proper song is further evidence of Stott's confidence; none of these tracks feel like they have to be any one thing
column4: they're always growing and changing and defying expectations.

column1: ""Lost and Found"" has a similarly melodic approach
column2: unspooling in a Middle Eastern mode and bringing to mind Dead Can Dance at their most subtle. We can hear Stott drawing lines between 4AD-style gothic new wave and dub techno
column3: building bridges between sounds and ideas based on his understanding of the elements and moods that connect them. Elsewhere
column4: on ""Expecting""
column5: he goes further into abstraction
column6: constructing an intensely dark and ominous atmosphere that bring to mind the ice-cold isolationist drone of Thomas Köner. The excavation of electronic music history takes a more unusual turn on ""Up the Box""
column7: which plays with a snippet of what sounds like the ""Amen"" break. But the familiar splash of jungle snares and cymbals is transformed by Stott into something of his own own
column8: as he mixes the tricky rhythms with his now undeniable bass signature
column9: a groaning maw flecked with distortion that feels like it's rattling everything within earshot. Stott has a rare ability to pull sounds from different places and fit them into his album conception.

column1: Two records from the past offer antecedents for Stott's breakthrough: Luomo's Vocalcity and Burial's Untrue. It's not that Luxury Problems sounds like either of these releases-- the mood and textures are vastly different in each case. But there's a spiritual connection between the three
column2: all of which found producers working within the confines of a specific genre of electronic music discovering a way to turn their music inside and out and broaden its appeal through the manipulated voice. But if Vocalcity was a digital refraction of house music and Untrue took early UK dubstep as a jumping-off point to express post-club emptiness and yearning
column3: Luxury Problems is more internally focused
column4:
an evocative and immersive soundtrack for a sustained look within. It's the headphones album of the year from a producer with a long history who has come into his own.

column2: 'Metal'

'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Neurot']|2012-10-29 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:05:24.522710|"

""Our legacy can only be assured if we continually burn down the past and plant seeds in the ashes
column4: proclaims Neurosis guitarist-vocalist Steve Von Till in a trailer for the band's latest album
column5: Honor Found in Decay. It's got a nice ring to it
column6: but might not be the best description of the veteran Oakland group's M.O. Sure
column7: Neurosis' work has evolved over the course of a 27-year career-- from the gritty metallic punk of 1987's Pain of Mind to the harrowing post-hardcore prog of 1993's Enemy of the Sun and on to the majestic art doom of their current phase-- but the progression has been gradual
column8: a series of seasonal shifts rather than fiery upheavals. That unhurried pace has helped make the band into a redwood of the underground
column9: a model for Mastodon
column10: Isis
column11: and countless other crews of metal-oriented aesthetes.

column1: So don't go into Honor Found in Decay expecting an abrupt left turn. The crushing
column2: luminous
column3: texturally resplendent suites here take their place alongside three Neurosis LPs' worth of similar material
column4: from 2001's A Sun That Never Sets through 2007's Given to the Rising. Like those releases
column5: Honor draws as much on gothic folk and unstable
column6: sample-accented ambience-- respective hallmarks of solo records by Von Till and fellow guitarist-vocalist Scott Kelly
column7: and Neurosis' soundscape-focused alter ego
column8: Tribes of Neurot-- as on the band's signature doomy catharsis. (Honor is also the fifth Neurosis album in a row recorded by Steve Albini
column9: whose stripped-down aesthetic helps bring a sense of intimacy to the band's inherent grandeur.) At the same time
column10: this latest effort is a highlight of the recent Neurosis discography. Despite brilliant moments on each
column11: the previous three LPs at times seemed epic in length only; they didn't fully reward the endurance required to sit through them. The band remedies that on Honor. Like every Neurosis full-length of the past two decades
column12: it's packed with long songs-- three out of seven clock in over 10 minutes-- but there's less slack here than before; for the most part
column13: these are purposeful journeys.

column2: opener ""We All Rage in Gold"" and closer ""Raise the Dawn""
column3: are also the shortest. These pieces sum up how the record conveys an expansive feel while minimizing fuss. More importantly
column4: they straight-up rock. After a quick mood-setting intro
column5: ""We All Rage in Gold"" kicks into a badass midtempo groove-- the closest Neurosis has come to boogie-- with Kelly growling ruefully on top. The dynamics drop
column6: but only briefly; soon
column7: the full band roars back for one of its trademark sludgy climaxes
column8: elevated by synth player Noah Landis's soaring violin simulations. ""Raise the Dawn"" is similarly gripping. A straightforward quiet-to-loud transition sets up Honor's single most righteous moment: a swaggery sludge-blues refrain
column9: over which Kelly sneers
column10: ""All the rest have fallen on/ Returning the sun."" This shrewd curveball ends the record on a triumphant note.

column1: Honor's longer tracks are hit-and-miss. ""At the Well""-- like ""Raise the Dawn""
column2: a staple of the band's live sets since late 2010-- is a textbook Neurosis epic
column3: formulaic but effective. The track stretches out from Von Till's dark-troubadour opening into elegiac doom
column4: growing gradually more intense. When the drums drop out six minutes in
column5: it's a dead giveaway for the torrential burst that follows; still
column6: the shift is a stunner. Like seasoned horror directors
column7: Neurosis know how to shake you up while abiding by convention. In contrast
column8: ""Casting of the Ages"" lacks a narrative arc. Like the Neurosis equivalent of a power ballad
column9: the track follows a straightforward whisper-then-roar format
column10: simply trudging on until it ends. A song like this makes it easy to miss the more feral sound of Enemy of the Sun and 1992's Souls at Zero
column11: records that privileged phantasmagoric sensory overload over tidy compositional logic.

column2: the next track
column3: ""All Is Found...In Time""
column4: reestablishes tension. Here
column5: the band sets aside brooding in favor of geeky psychedelic intrigue. Drummer Jason Roeder's tom-tom-heavy pummel leads the group through a cosmic-prog overture
column6: which segues into a bluesy half-time heave; then Landis' Pink Floyd-style synths point the way to a kitschy yet ominous interlude. When the intro returns with a jolt
column7: the ground seems to rush away
column8: as though a shuttle simulator had malfunctioned
column9: blasting the listener into deep space.

column1: Moments like these help make Honor Found in Decay feel like a fresh start
column2: even though the band's core palette hasn't changed. The record doesn't abandon the moody sprawl of the band's last few full-lengths
column3: but it does help restore urgency to an aesthetic that seemed in danger of growing soporific. It's become common to refer to Neurosis as post-metal
column4:
as if the band had outgrown the primal allure of the riff. Honor refutes that idea. It's a record that proves these grizzled artisans still know how to flex their muscles.

""Matthew Friedberger requests fan's screenplays and videos
