column3: the 45-track ""opera"" that is Matricidal Sons of Bitches. That misplaced apostrophe accidentally says an awful lot: Since the Fiery Furnaces released I'm Going Away in 2009
column4: their most accessible album to date
column5: Matthew Friedberger hasn't exactly been on a charm offensive. He entered into a bizarre
column6: one-sided
column7: and intolerably lengthy internet fight with Thom Yorke and Beck
column8: and between January 2011 and January 2012
column9: released eight solo records
column10: each performed on a single instrument in order to demonstrate the ""Cretan-Lacedaemonian principle
column11: where ""every group of instruments is against every other group of instruments
column12: every instrument is against every other instrument
column13: and
column14: finally
column15: every instrument is against itself."" He appears to have invented the principle
column16: and you'll struggle to find anyone who stuck around for all eight records. (This was while his sister
column17: Eleanor
column18: released her gorgeous
column19: underrated solo debut
column20: Last Summer.) It's easy to interpret his behavior as a mission to whittle his fans' number down to single digits.

column1: In an interview with Under the Radar magazine subtitled ""Breaking the Law of Diminishing Returns"" from October 2011
column2: Friedberger
column3: who now lives in Paris
column4: opined that as older artists become more or less comfortable with writing to fit their songwriting character
column5: their audience often becomes less comfortable with the fact. ""They don't say
column6: 'They're so confident. They're really exploring what they're able to do. They're testing the boundaries.' Bullshit like that. They say the other bullshit like
column7: 'They're self-indulgent. They're pretentious.'"" Acceptance or rejection; you get the impression he doesn't care for either. Somewhat pointlessly
column8: I sometimes think about a game where you try to lose every Twitter follower you have
column9: but without being actively hateful or idiotic; doing so in a calculated fashion to be as off-putting as possible. Matricidal Sons of Bitches would be very good at this game.

column1: The concept here (though it really only exists on paper) is that Matricidal Sons of Bitches is a four-part opera about
column2: you guessed it
column3: mother-snuffing sons. The four parts are titled
column4: ""LADIES-IN-WAITING--waiting forever""
column5: ""BRAND-NEW-MOTHERS--trying it out""
column6: ""EXPECTANT FATHERS--in for a surprise""
column7: and ""DYING ON THE SIXTH SIDE""
column8: and the atmosphere is suitably ominous. Opening song ""The Neighbors"" features a French woman describing (in English) the members of her family she has hated
column9: none more so than her mother
column10: a revelation backed by a huge thunderclap. There are drawings of bog-eyed men on the album's cover-- Peter
column11: Charlie
column12: Perry
column13: Marco
column14: Julian
column15: and the baroque-haired Michael
column16: presumably the sons-- on the back of which it says
column17: ""Neither written nor produced nor directed by Matthew Friedberger."" It is immensely difficult to listen to start to finish. You know how people wear Trout Mask Replica as a badge of musical endurance? Van Vliet just got usurped.

column1: What puts listeners in a difficult spot is that
column2: no matter how infuriating it gets
column3: Matricidal Sons of Bitches is clearly the product of serious compositional intention; it's not an accidental mess. Friedberger has a tremendous skill for creating snippets of what sound like old classics that never existed in the first place: ""But at the Door; Is it Him?""
column4: ""The Next Morning""
column5: ""As If in the Car With the Kids""
column6: and ""Lying on the Sixth Side"" sound like theme tunes to family TV specials broadcast in Hawaii in the 1950s. ""Frustration by the Boulevards"" and ""Drifting Down the Alleys"" are so authentically like the soundtracks to wartime socials that they should have their own signature dance move. These pieces stutter and stop before their natural conclusions
column7: making them feel like samples for the Avalanches to come in and repurpose
column8: and they're full of beautifully warm
column9: playful piano that seems made to soundtrack charming stop-motion mechanisms and families singing together. It's a kind of compact
column10: cuckoo-clock portrait of togetherness. Which
column11: given the record's murderous concept
column12: was only made to be destroyed.

column1: Friedberger's renderings of situations where dangerous scions lurk can be extremely evocative. ""Tell Me What it is You Want
column2: Boys"" veers between sounding like an old blues 45 and someone sucking ghosts through the holes of a violin that's played many a cursed tune. (It also manages to sound like the ""Peanuts"" music played in ""Arrested Development"" when George Michael is particularly crestfallen.) The title track is a 42-second long
column3: hypnotic meeting of abrasively bright synthesizer and watery harp blooms that feels like an invitation to dine with a sea beast in his cave
column4: and
column5: by the way
column6: you're dessert.

column1: There's a limited palette here that's perhaps meant as some kind of conclusion to the single-instrument records
column2: which is interesting in theory
column3: but too often seems like Friedberger filled a Casio keyboard with his own monstrous presets and jabbed away until some kind of song came out. Worst of all is when he picks the setting marked ""sounds from space."" ""Pursuit
column4: Less Acute"" is a rasping attempt at Wagnerian intergalactic bombast that brings to mind a dying Darth Vader trying to hum his own once-menacing theme. As the record progresses
column5: Friedberger continually and insistently deploys the sound of a dry
column6: choked explosion
column7: the kind used to convey the words ""error"" or ""do not pass"" or ""YOU HAVE FAILED START AGAIN"" on a video game.

column1: Songs rarely end with any resolution; instead stopping dead and veering into the next turn unannounced. The fragmentation of the Books' loosely comparable Music For a French Elevator remained compact and coherent; Friedberger
column2: on the other hand
column3: thinks nothing of interrupting a flurry of lovely harp strums with an unbearable
column4: high-pitched drone
column5: only to return to the harp again seconds later. Combined with the record's main motif
column6: repeated to a madness-inducing extent-- a piano clank surrounded by a gray drone that waxes and wanes to various degrees-- the constant feel of blocked paths and missed turns brings on the kind of stomachache that usually occurs when your GPS packs up in a maze of backwater lanes.

column2: Matthew Friedberger comes across like the Andy Kaufman of indie rock
column3: though these days he's less an outlier of the field than an errant baseball thwacked miles beyond its borders. Is he more interested in the process of challenging people's expectations or sustaining a career? It's hard not to feel that he's pissing on his chips with each successive release
column4: but the intent behind what you could term his professional self-destruction renders the piss and chips a more artisanal dish
column5:
though it's unlikely to curry much favor.

Be prepared for a desperate Hollywood type catching wind of John O'Regan's story and turning it into a heartwarming dram-com that you will avoid at all costs. The elevator pitch goes like this: Hospitalized with debilitating Crohn's disease and estranged from his struggling
column3: blue-collar indie rock band
column4: a young man spends his confinement ""learning how to reinvent [his] body"" and transmogrifies into self-styled pop sensation Diamond Rings. Cue the gender-bending
column5: rainbow-colored makeover
column6: the bubblegum glam-rock songs made almost entirely on GarageBand
column7: and the YouTube videos whose amateur choreography bravely and embarrassingly emphasizes the man's awkward and angular physicality. The soundtrack would make it worthwhile
column8: though: Confessional and relentlessly melodic
column9: ""All Yr Songs""
column10: ""You Oughta Know""
column11: and nearly everything else on 2010's Special Affections functioned as guileless musical therapy
column12: a genuinely inspiring record about transcending emotional and physical stagnation.

column2: Diamond Rings has far surpassed the still-active D'Urbervilles as well as O'Regan's previous Casio-pop duo Habitat
column3: signed to a major label
column4: and started performing live as a four-piece band. And for better or worse
column5: Free Dimensional feels like a sequel
column6: more professional
column7: calculated
column8: and occasionally satisfying
column9: ultimately lacking the anything-goes magic that called for a sequel in the first place. On some level
column10: O'Regan's aim on his second LP is similar to that of his fellow Canadians Japandroids. Like Post-Nothing
column11: Special Affections was a surprise hit that generated a lot of its resonance from a total lack of pretension; this was music made out of personal necessity
column12: with no idea if anyone was actually going to hear it. Having witnessed the effect of these records on live crowds
column13: both try for something more universal that repeats the trick of the original while amplifying it. But whereas Celebration Rock successfully threw its arms around an ever-widening audience
column14: Free Dimensional does something trickier
column15: which is focus so much on the capital-s Self that O'Regan gets taken out of the picture completely. As you can tell from the titles-- ""I'm Just Me""
column16: ""Hand Over My Heart""
column17: ""(I Know) What I'm Made Of""
column18: ""Stand My Ground""
column19: self-empowerment
column20: self-esteem and staying true to oneself are the name of the game
column21: and the lyrics are presented with a lack of specificity that allows the listener to think of themselves every time O'Regan sings the word ""me.""

column2: but it's also a mistake. While O'Regan's story wasn't essential to Special Affections
column3: it did manage to give powerful context and emotional ballast to what otherwise could've been fairly fluffy songs. O'Regan's songwriting hasn't changed much and the machinistic approach here reveals the limitations that weren't apparent in a 10-song debut. For one thing
column4: so many of his lyrics follow the same AAB/CCD pattern (""I don't know how to get where I'm going but I know I'm growing every day/ And if I fall I'll get back into it cause I know I'm doing it my own way
column5: and so forth) that it ultimately makes Free Dimensional feel more like a word puzzle app than an artistic exercise
column6: everything O'Regan says restricted to a small number of melodic contours or rhyme schemes. This is problematic since he is consciously drawing from the most basic elements of pop lyricism; after a while
column7: the endless new hearts and fresh starts feel like the same old rut.

column2: Free Dimensional importing most of Special Affections' compositional tactics wholesale means that it's going to have some economic and catchy hooks no matter what. The sound isn't as novel as it was three years back
column3: but Diamond Rings is forever distinguished by the brawny register of O'Regan's vocals. Trade in the white denim for blue
column4: and he could join Divine Fits without missing a beat. His best songs function like ""Since U Been Gone"" in reverse
column5: starting with the idea of mega-budget pop and filtering it through Strokes-esque
column6: New Wave rock. The most guitar heavy-track here
column7: ""Runaway Love""
column8: recalls the surging highlights of Diamond Rings' past largely because it's a minor rewrite of ""Something Else"" and ""Wait & See"".

column1: The video for subsequent one-off single ""Show Me Your Stuff"" gave the impression that given the proper monetary freedom
column2: Diamond Rings could and would go full-on Dr. Luke
column3: Max Martin or RedOne. While co-produced by Damian Taylor (Robyn
column4: Björk
column5: U.N.K.L.E.)
column6: Free Dimensional doesn't go far enough to become undeniable; it's an upgrade from the Tinkertoy sound of Special Affections
column7: but they still sound like an incremental upgrade
column8: Lego constructions rather than the gleaming skyscrapers they need to be. The big moments are knowing winks and post-production graft: ""I'm Just Me"" co-opts the surge of an EDM drop into its chorus
column9: ""Day & Night"" is modeled after Gloria Estefan's ""1-2-3""
column10: and while the rap section of ""(I Know) What I'm Made Of"" is likely intended to be along the lines of those wedged into ""Hangin' Tough"" or Bobby Brown's ""Don't Be Cruel""
column11: you still have to hear O'Regan rap. You'd think the namedrops of bell hooks and ""Buffalo Stance"" would disarm any critical faculty
column12: but when he ends it snarling
column13: ""don't you ever even think of tryin' to [BLEEP!] with me
column14: it's more proof that frothy pop recreations from acts with indie backgrounds are often prone to wincing self-awareness.

column1: Though Free Dimensional is proud to be out of step both sonically and personally
column2: in a strange way it loops back into a new kind of currency alongside the pop-star self-actualization of Grimes
column3: Robyn
column4: or Carly Rae Jepsen that's found currency amongst those who would identify as ""indie"" listeners. As much as they draw from the style and sound of 80s teen-pop
column5: they crucially embody the appeal of its accompanying ""starmaking"" accessories such as in-mall concerts and ""record your own song!"" karaoke booths: This could be you. It strikes a balance between the power of relatability and the transformative power of pop music-- the songs draw you in
column6: the image stokes your imagination
column7: and their down-to-earth personalities makes pop-star self-actualization far more realistic than it does in the form of Lady Gaga or Beyoncé
column8: i.e.
column9: people you could really only ""be"" on Halloween. O'Regan understands that
column10: but he's missing half the equation here. Free Dimensional is an homage to certain styles of pop; what made Special Affections such an unexpectedly powerful document was how it managed to be a tribute to pop itself
column11: more specifically the literally life-altering capacity of it. That's a great story and one worth retelling
column12: but while Free Dimensional shows O'Regan ready for his close-up
column13:
the lack of depth results in the album title's pun becoming Diamond Rings' first truly ironic statement.

Like so many rock stars before him
column2: Interpol frontman Paul Banks launched a solo career as an outlet for music he felt he couldn't make with his band. But Banks' work under his original solo guise
column3: Julian Plenti
column4: was essentially in the same vein as Interpol's hooky
column5: glowering post-punk. Now he's dropped the Julian Plenti façade and is recording under his given name
column6: even going so far as to call his new record Banks. The suggestion seems to be that we're finally going to get some real
column7: unfiltered Paul Banks this time around. But Banks presents an artist who has matured but hasn't established a strong sense of individual identity.

column1: The Interpol of its iconic post-9/11
column2: early 2000s Turn on the Bright Lights period was
column3: if not a dance band
column4: then a coke and Red Bull nightlife outfit. The atmosphere was dark
column5: but the tempos were electric and celebratory
column6: sprinting into rain and rubble-streaked New York City streets with the abandon of survivors determined to chase away demons and seek out fun while it still can be had. Banks
column7: in contrast
column8: is sluggish
column9: unsteady
column10: and ultimately noncommittal about forward motion.

column1: Paul Banks worked on Banks over the course of two years during free time on the road with Interpol. As Banks told Drowned in Sound
column2: the songs started out as a diversion
column3: offering a form of release and entertainment as he endured the boring monotony of touring on a big-time rock tour. But the enthusiasm doesn't come through. The album is a pea soup of gray synths
column4: middling mid-tempo rhythms
column5: and Banks' ghost-of-goth's-past vocals. On ""Over My Shoulder""
column6: a syncopated
column7: clattering beat comes to tortured
column8: lurching life
column9: but the whole operation is so joyless that it's rendered impotent. Ditto for the trip-hoppy opener ""The Base""
column10: where Banks' flat
column11: monotone vocal drones over an anemically grinding guitar like a last breath about to rise from a barely pulsating body.

column1: Banks telegraphs a deep sense of gloom and ennui brought on by the patina of middle age. If Paul Banks once made music designed as a soundtrack for staying out all night
column2: he now sounds like a guy who'd prefer to turn in by 10. But acting more grown-up doesn't necessarily make Banks seem any wiser. On ""Paid For That""
column3: he awkwardly reaches for insightful introspection about the aging process
column4: musing—in his trademark lyrical Esperanto-- that ""sometimes I think I coexist with me/ And one side makes me old/ And one side makes me struggle/ I was on the night shift/ I said I'll never learn to fight like this."" That line is crystal clear compared with the confounding melodrama of ""Young Again""
column5: which includes one of Banks' all-time head-scratchers: ""Jobs are disgraceful/ They tick like suffering from a clock.""

column1: But the main problem with Banks isn't the muddled words
column2: it's the uninvolving music. Some of the tracks simply aren't given the chance to reach their potential: ""No Mistakes"" and ""I'll Sue You"" aren't great songs necessarily

column4: say
column5: Interpol) that could give them a groove and a stronger sense of purpose. But Paul Banks' primary concern with Banks seems to be with creating a uniform mood of malevolence. The pretty ""Arise
column6: Awake"" and the demented ""Young Again"" achieve this reasonably well
column7: but they hardly play to Banks' strength
column8: which is mining pop gold out of the contrast between the inertia of his polarizing vocals and swift
column9: assured music. When the music is as stationary as Banks is
column10: the result is unsurprisingly static.

column2: some of the material on Banks would be weak even with better presentation
column3: like the instrumental ""Lisbon""
column4: which is inoffensive background music and not much more. The best song by a mile on Banks

column7: ""the liquid guitar line of 'Summertime' is enticingly familiar-- a welcome reminder in all the hodgepodge that Banks' music has specific good qualities."" In other words
column8: the best parts of Banks are the ones that most resemble Interpol
column9: rather than the stabs at spooky
column10: old-guy mope-pop that comprise most of the record. In that respect
column11: this album fails as a valid statement outside of the confines of Banks' band. But as sour as Banks ultimately is
column12: it doesn't automatically preclude him from having a worthy solo career. He could potentially forge a new direction away from Interpol
column13:
just not this direction.

No one believes themselves to be evil. The killer keeps pet pigeons. The thief drops change in a bum's cup as karmic reimbursement. Even Lucille Bluth would occasionally shed a tear if she could spare the moisture. Maybe Baudelaire put it best: the Devil's greatest trick is convincing people he doesn't exist. But Baudelaire never dealt with Ikea parking lots
column2: petroleum executives
column3: or Reddit trolls.

column1: Tobacco's greatest trick is reminding people that not only does the devil exist
column2: he keeps a Pittsburgh address. Since Black Moth Super Rainbow came to attention with 2007's Dandelion Gum
column3: the band's demon-throated frontman has mastered the art of sounding sinister. He's so upfront with his intent that the group's new Kickstarter-funded album Cobra Juicy has a song called ""I Think I'm Evil"". He also named himself after the most pernicious herb since hemlock.

column2: you can point to any number of metal bands or horrorcore rap groups who have brandished the triple six as a way to sell records and satisfy their evil urges. What's unique about Black Moth Super Rainbow is the balance achieved between the grotesque and the beautiful. This is not as easy as it sounds. Descend too deeply into darkness
column3: and you run the risk of becoming fright-night schlock. Lean too delicately on seraphic chords and melodies and you lack menace. And should you lack the pop sensibilities
column4: your satanic majesty's request can get exhausting. Examine the more underwhelming moments of the Odd Future catalog to see what happens when N.E.R.D. never quite meet nihilism.

column2: Black Moth Super Rainbow have been unfairly tarred as gimmickry. This stems from several reasons. First
column3: there are the names sounding straight from an un-purchased Adult Swim pilot. Tobacco
column4: Iffernaut
column5: Ryan Graveface
column6: Bullsmear
column7: and the Seven Fields of Aphelion. Ex-members include Father Hummingbird and Power Pill Fist (who presumably left to join Danny Brown's Bruiser Brigade). Then there's the band's semi-anonymity and penchant for shrouding themselves in darkness
column8: wearing masks
column9: and performing backed by 80s aerobics videos. Yet it's mostly the voice. Tobacco uses a vocoder on every song. This isn't the Teutonic turtle-necked modulation of Kraftwerk
column10: the mad-scientist whimsy of Bruce Haack
column11: or the funky lothario of Roger Troutman. This is when the robot supposed to solve your problems goes awry; it's the musical equivalent of the animated automatons at Itchy & Scratchyland attacking the Simpsons.

column1: Slot Black Moth Super Rainbow as psychedelic at your own peril. There are no yawning guitar solos and the songs rarely slink past the four-minute mark. Black Moth Super Rainbow triangulate early Beck and the Air of the ""Kelly Watch the Stars"" era. But neither cognate flashes the crooked smile of Cobra Juicy. Even the title itself seeks to pair the contradictory ideas of vitamins and venom.
Opening track ""Windshield Smasher"" features vocals that sound like gorgons moaning
column2: paired with synthesizers that sound like they got bubble gum got stuck in the gears. The drums snap like the trap floor at a hanging. They are a band explicitly antithetical to the idea of Rap Genius. They've always been purposely obfuscating
column3: but Cobra Juicy's lyrics are even more difficult to decipher than usual. It is pop as Rorschach blot. You hear what you want bubbling out of the murk. Yours ears absorb toxic effluvia about kissing gasoline and shattering glass. Devil's Night finally gets the soundtrack that D-12 could never deliver.

column1: ""Hairspray Heart"" finds Tobacco wailing about ""sucking all the poison from a snakebite"" and ""a fucking diamond falling from my fucking eyes"" over freeway underpass-dirty drums and rainbow sherbet synths. ""Psychic Love Damage"" is swooning ballad that might be the closest BMSR come to romantic
column2: but even then
column3: the lover's smiles ""wreck"" him. ""We Burn"" channels folk singer era Beck
column4: if he was abducted and forced to entertain Xenu and John Travolta.

column2: ""I Think I'm Evil""
column3: ""Gangs in the Garden"" might be the song that best encapsulates the helter-skelter aesthetic. There is synth bass
column4: a beat that could soundtrack a robbery at a roller rink
column5: distorted guitars
column6: and vocals that channel the voice of the snake in the Garden of Eden. All this would be schtick if not for Tobacco's ever-improving pop gifts. Wait for the bridge at 1:20 of ""Blurring My Day"" when the chaos relents for a few seconds like a confession metaphysically wiping away weeks of sin. If this is psychedelia
column7: it's only in the sense that each song replicates the intensity of the trip: the suicidal lows and the love-is-everything highs.

column1: This might be BMSR's most accessible effort
column2: but if you couldn't get past the vocoder and voodoo before
column3: it's unlikely that you will now. This is a cult
column4:
one large enough to raise over $100K to fund this record-- led by a man advocating cutting Kool-Aid with cyanide and always inviting new members.

column2: in a matter of months

Goat's World Music feels as assured and unfussy as folk music.

It might seem strange to toss the word ""patience"" around when discussing the work of Oren Ambarchi
column2: especially considering the rapidity with which he released recorded music in 2012.  But there's an unflappable air about the Australian musician

column4: where he can indulge wildly creative urges and find multiple outlets willing to put them out into the world. Connected is the latest of those
column5: a five-track album released with fellow Australian musician and artist Robin Fox
column6: with Kranky the lucky recipients of their work. The title is taken from a work by dance company Chunky Move

column1: It's to Ambarchi and Fox's credit that there's no sense of these pieces serving another purpose

column1: The colossal nine-minute opener ""Standing Mandala"" was used to preview this album

column4: perhaps a swollen torrent of distortion hidden around the corner
column5: or a wrong-footed chord change looming on the horizon. Those things never arrive. Instead
column6: the song is cut abruptly just when it feels like it might be reaching some kind of climax. Ambarchi and Fox clearly aren’t interested in ""destination."" This is music that's all journey
column7: no resolution. ""Game of Two"" circles in place in a similar way to Neil Young's Dead Man score
column8: where distended guitar chords are simply allowed to be. The lack of forward momentum makes everything feel suspended in time

column1: Repetition is the pivot around which Connected turns

column6: retaining their sense of composure by pulling the listener back to a feeling of stasis. Connected is far from being the first record to make a virtue out of spinning in place

a feeling of two musicians utterly dominating their craft.

Patrick Stickles announced Titus Andronicus' upcoming North American tour by proclaiming ""PUNK IS BACK."" column3: and you get the feeling their intent was to make a one-take road dog album. At that they've succeeded. But Local Business also marks the first time the band seems like it's holding something back-- like there is a Plan B.

If you know nearly anything about black metal
column2: you know about Gaahl: That's the sunken-cheek frontman of infamous and inconsistent Second Wave crew Gorgoroth in the 12-page spread of Peter Beste's coffee table-bound collection of photos
column3: True Norwegian Black Metal. And that's Gaahl leading the book's same team up a snow-covered mountain to visit the home of his forefathers in the subsequent Vice documentary of the same name. The crew worried that the towering and reserved singer was leading them to their demise-- a somewhat reasonable concern
column4: as he'd rather recently been convicted of beating an older man while telling him he intended to turn his figure into a human sacrifice. And a year before the sentence
column5: Polish authorities nearly jailed ""the most evil man alive"" for a Gorgoroth concert that included butchered animal parts and nude women suspended from crosses. And yes
column6: Gaahl is the first openly gay frontman of a black metal act. Memorable enough?

column1: But neither Gaahl nor longtime bassist King ov Hell (his real name is Tom
column2: if that makes you more comfortable) has been in Gorgoroth since late 2007. In fact
column4: the pair lost a big-deal lawsuit to Infernus
column5: Gorgoroth's founder
column6: for the rights to the band and brand. God Seed-- Gaahl
column7: King
column8: and a minor-star team of two guitarists
column9: a drummer
column10: and electronics guru Geir Bratland-- is the result of that legal defeat. ""God Seed represents the will to grow
column11: the will to be the super man so to speak
column12: Gaahl said of the somewhat laughable handle (and Gorgoroth song title) in 2009. ""I think it's a suitable name for what we will represent in the future.""

column2: if growth is the goal
column3: God Seed squarely accomplish the aim on their proper studio debut
column4: I Begin. Apart from the controversies and stories you might have heard about Gaahl both in and out of corpse paint
column5: he leads an expansive
column6: able genuinely interesting retreatment of the primal stuff that made Gorgoroth matter here. Opener ""Awake"" rumbles open with true Norwegian ferocity
column7: drums cascading by riffs written in miniature and projected in panoramic. But relentlessness isn't the chief asset or aim of God Seed
column8: so ""Awake"" consistently zigs and zags
column9: shifting tempos and temperaments enough to plow beyond any ensconced Gorgoroth rut. Organ solos intersect with electronic washes
column10: and Gaahl-- never the most versatile man in metal-- shifts from a blood-curdling scream to a fist-pumping bark at will.

column2: ""The Wound"" is as savage as anything its predecessor attempted during the last decade
column3: but its circumspect nods to stoner metal and krautrock offer new gumption. During ""Alt Liv""
column4: God Seed occasionally downshift into ritualistic throb
column5: with Gaahl delivering sinister invocations alongside King ov Hell's throbbing bass. Though those segments sometimes border on Godsmack-style tribalism
column6: they do position God Seed well outside of Second Wave confines. Closer ""Bloodline"" flirts with the same industrial deconstructions as Blut Aus Nord and Ben Frost
column7: its melody and beat reflected and refracted by broken bits of sound. No
column8: these three-to-five-minute tracks don't claim to be Enslaved epics or the philosophical revisions of some stateside black metal acts. But when Gaahl rasps in a near-whisper or when the keyboards lope with the esprit of a carnival ride during ""Aldrande Tre""
column9: God Seed’s push beyond the comfortable becomes as exciting as it does obvious.

column2: God Seed emerge from an enviable and lamentable position: They possess a pedigree that
column3: to many
column4: makes them matter instantly-- and a strange
column5: long face that makes them singularly recognizable. But quality control was never a Gorgoroth talking point
column6: and some will be prone to dismiss God Seed simply because of Gaahl and King's tenure in that band. Gaahl's backstory and rather paradoxical views as a gay black metal bandleader who has both expressed support for fascists and seemed rather approachable give him a sort of freak-show status
column7: too. But turning back just to the nine tracks of I Begin
column8:
God Seed sound like a native Norwegian act reinvigorated by these new circumstances. It would be a stretch to call I Begin a breakthrough for a fresh quinet; it would be dismissive to not consider it perhaps as the start of one.

Natasha Khan has said her third album as Bat for Lashes is partly inspired by studying her own family history. This is informative. Her father
column3: a trainer for the Pakistani national squash team
column4: left suddenly when she was 11
column5: and his departure casts a shadow on the fairytale drama of Bat for Lashes' debut
column6: 2006's Fur and Gold. Yeah
column7: but one of the guys Khan's dad coached? Her cousin
column8: Jahangir Khan? He went on to become a six-time world champion and basically his sport's equivalent of a Pelé or Michael Jordan. You don't need Natasha's Ancestry.com password to know there's competitive drive in her blood.

column1: That's her up there in The Haunted Man cover art. Naked
column2: un-retouched
column3: and un-made-up
column4: with a similarly naked man draped around her shoulders. The suggestion is that her follow-up to 2009's lavishly sensual Two Suns is more intimate and stripped bare
column5: and sure enough
column6: there's less reverb on Khan's voice
column7: and the lyrical concerns have moved from an otherworldly New York to the English countryside. But what the Ryan McGinley-shot art most closely shares with the music you'll find within is that it's at once striking and enigmatic-- and artfully constructed.

column1: Some albums sound effortless. The Haunted Man sounds like effort magnificently realized. The rawness of feeling is achieved through equally raw ambition. Bat for Lashes' sophisticated blend of art-rock grandeur and synth-pop directness again carries echoes of 1980s luminaries like Kate Bush and the Cure
column2: gleaming with autoharp
column3: Abbey Road-recorded strings
column4: and a continuing exploration of electronics. Spacious
column5: boldly orchestrated
column6: and emotionally rich

column8: and one of the year's most beguiling albums.

column2: Karate Kid-nodding ""Daniel"" won Britain's Ivor Novello songwriting award. The potential hits here are just as overpowering. ""Let's Get Lost""
column3: the sumptuous slab of goth-bubblegum Khan did with Beck for 2011's Twilight: Eclipse OST
column4: was a promising sign of what to expect. On slinky
column5: guitar-centric ""All Your Gold""
column6: Khan is the one who's haunted
column7: but it only takes a few listens before Gotye's awfully similar smash sounds fleshless in comparison. ""Marilyn"" adapts the 1950s matinee-idolatry of Lana Del Rey to a dream-pop production worthy of its ""silver screen
column8: with a staggering
column9: spectral bridge-- and several instrumental contributions from Beck (plus arranging by ex-Ash member Charlotte Hatherley).

column2: the less likely singles here are as darkly enigmatic
column3: sonically curious
column4: and thematically textured as their equivalents on Two Suns. The centerpiece is the title track
column5: with its ""Scarborough Fair""-tinged male choir marching up that distant hill. ""Yes
column6: your ghosts have got me
column7: too/ But it's me and you
column8: Khan replies
column9: summing up the album's main conceit: the way previous experiences can twist our current relationships. On M83-gauzy
column10: Dave Sitek-assisted opener ""Lilies""
column11: though
column12: ""the figure of a man"" answers a life-affirming
column13: womanly prayer. Druid-like male voices on ""Oh Yeah"" introduce the poised yet passionate exultation of a narrator ""in bloom."" As on the album cover
column14: Khan's music can acknowledge the female body without reducing it to sex-kitten cliché.

column2: if the last album was about contrasts-- between two suns
column3: two lovers
column4: even two sides of the narrator's persona-- then The Haunted Man is defined by balance
column5: between the bare and the polished
column6: between the communal and the personal
column7: and between the respective ghosts haunting our personal interactions. Compromises can lead to breakthroughs: ""Where you see a wall
column8: I see a door
column9: Khan sings on ""A Wall""
column10: another Sitek-backed
column11: baroque synth-pop anthem. By the restrained yet intricate closing lullaby ""Deep Sea Diver""
column12: which meets the bar set by Two Suns' collaborative finale with famously reclusive crooner Scott Walker
column13: Khan finds a compromise for two people separated by masks: ""Darling if you can't see out/ You know that I can hear you shout."" They're together
column14: alone
column15: shaking through.

column2: ""Laura""
column3: is also the most transcendent. With a gently orchestra-kissed piano-and-voice arrangement
column4: this goosebump-inducing collaboration with the former Lizzy Grant's ""Video Games"" co-writer Justin Parker is the clearest example of how Bat for Lashes perches on the fulcrum between indie-associated sincerity and pop-oriented savvy. We'll never know Laura
column5: really
column6: but we can feel what it might be like to know her. On an album with more names in the credits than Khan could ever use for song titles (also including Portishead's Adrian Utley
column7: among many others)
column8:
the greatest testament to her strength of will might be just this: She has added a new unforgettable character to pop's family tree.

Andy Butler's Hercules and Love Affair project probably needed to throw a good party. Last year's Blue Songs offered streamlined
column3: moody
column4: and frequently muted dance-pop
column5: studiously treading the disco/house tightrope in the service of a higher cause of emotional
column6: songwriterly dance-pop. By contrast
column7: Butler's entry in the DJ-Kicks series pledges itself openly and unabashedly to debauched
column8: dancefloor-centric old house music
column9: in all its sped-up
column10: chunky and percussive glory.

column2: on countless DJ mixes from an endless succession of eclectic
column3: strip-mining DJs who've trod these spangled boards over the past decade or so? Well
column4: yes. And it's less a problem of the well running dry-- the supply of half-forgotten dance classics and would-be-classics for DJs like Butler to liberate seems inexhaustible-- than of maintaining the shock of the new-old. Like a well-crafted TV show whose later seasons are doomed to repeat in mildly new constellations the same storylines and relationship dynamics
column5: disco and early house revivalism has reached the stage where
column6: even if the tracks aren't familiar
column7: the music's character arc certainly is: the now-faded futurism
column8: the bloated sonic excess
column9: the sudden U-turns from deeper-than-deep obscurantism to unabashed populism
column10: the single-minded splendor of the disco and carnality of the house. It's a vibe that the Glimmers had already conquered seven years ago
column11: and Playgroup's Trevor Jackson more than 10.

column2: DJ-Kicks seems destined
column3: even content
column4: to offer another pitch-perfect parade of retro dance-pop signifiers. This approach is typified by Hercules and Love Affairs' own stately ""Release Me""
column5: whose tumbling Chicago house piano
column6: chattering percussion
column7: grainy orchestral synth hits
column8: and smooth Bananarama vocals seem to hit every retro dance-pop button simultaneously. Their formal stylistic diversity notwithstanding
column9: early inclusions such as the primitive
column10: overstuffed UK house of Rhythm Mode:D's ""Can You Feel It (Reach to the Top)"" and the by turns stern and silly new beat of Fax Yourself's ""Strut Your Techno Stuff"" simply entrench the emergent collage: scenes from a dozen great parties from the late-80s/early-90s interzone-- though
column11: of course
column12: it's not immediately apparent what would be wrong with such a thing.

column1: But there's a broader and more interesting idea being promulgated here that doesn't become clear until the disc's middle third
column2: which alights on a winning streak of bumping New York garage (Klubb Kidz's ""Don't Want to Hurt You (Skool Flava Dub)""; the Solution's ""Feels So Right""; Cloud 9's ""Do You Want Me"")
column3: peaking with DJ Duke's darkly stuttering ""Love Don't Come Easy (Power Dub)""
column4: which deploys a series of fractured diva invocations over a mysterious bassline and deliberately rudimentary
column5: flailing snares. Much more than on his own productions
column6: Butler's mix leans hard (and progressively harder) into 90s house's clattering counter-rhythms
column7: the skipping snares and bustling hi-hats and general sense of so-wrong-it's-right rhythmic awkwardness that becomes less about the cheerful exhumation of retro signifiers and more about the science of dancing-- a concern that feels modern regardless of the timestamp on the music that gives voice to it.

column1: In its final stretch DJ-Kicks pursues this target with less regard to questions of old versus new. In the contemporary corner
column2: Haze Factory's ""A Bit of Redemption"" fashions a jaunty tango strut out of a mordant techno synth melody
column3: while In Flagranti's ""Magojiro"" concocts a fluttering and disorienting boogie
column4: like a caffeine-wired update of Cultural Vibe's ""Ma Foom Bey"". But more fully modern than both is Jump ""Chico"" Slamm's confounding
column5: intoxicating ""second wave"" Chicago obscurity ""Feel Free"" from 1993
column6: all relentless machine loops
column7: bustling house syncopation
column8: and effete
column9: sighing vocals-- familiar ingredients combined in a manner that renders them utterly alien.

column1: While it's always startling to stumble across a 20-year-old tune that still sounds totally fresh
column2: I can't help but feel it would be even more exciting if ""Feel Free"" was new
column3: a signpost of where we might go next rather than a snapshot of a path not travelled. Still
column4: in its focus on the past's knack for concocting rhythms that dance around (rather than to) the beat
column5: DJ-Kicks makes a decent case for retracing our steps. If Butler falls slightly short of convincing that this particular brand of old will be made new again
column6:
it remains hard to find fault with his survey of all the fun we could have had.

The new millennium has seen indie kids finally investigating metal as if it were part of their heritage
column2: rather than as if they were facing down a hostile army doing unspeakable things behind enemy lines. Despite their relatively high profile with false-metal media outfits
column3: though
column4: grindcore titans Pig Destroyer have ferociously exempted themselves from any crossover discussion
column5: all without doing much more than being themselves. The reasons why that kind of resoluteness would keep them outliers should be obvious if you know what ""grindcore"" means. If not
column6: the first four tracks of Book Burner are a pretty good crash course: You shouldn't need more than four minutes to figure out if this band is for you.

column2: we get saturation-sprayed by the kind of rasping scream that will keep some future ear-nose-and-throat specialist in cushy golfing weekends. Frontman J.R. Hayes has one of the best and most convincing lunatic presences in metal. Even if he's a pussycat in his home life
column3: when he's psycho-raving on record he turns into the guy on the subway you hope would move along to the next car. Presence is important for outsiders when dealing with a genre where some of the biggest stars ""sing"" like a troubled digestive tract. Pig Destroyer have loads of it thanks to Hayes
column4: a desperation and rage they manage to communicate like actual desperate and angry humans
column5: rather than relying on played-out metal scariness.

column2: the tempo on those four opening statements is obviously set at ""insane
column3: and only occasionally notched down to ""mosh
column4: with new
column5: presumably non-cyborg
column6: drummer Adam Jarvis doing stop-on-a-dime swerves and shifts that only programming should be able to pull off. It's Jarvis' first record with Pig Destroyer
column7: and he wastes no time in introducing himself to the fold: The third track
column8: ""The Underground Man""
column9: which lasts all of 32 seconds
column10: is just awesome
column11: a senses-battering overload that manages to both swing and clobber. It's as if Jarvis
column12: who also plays in the deathgrind band Misery Index
column13: took about six hardcore songs he'd been tinkering with
column14: all of them at different speeds
column15: and then decided
column16: hey
column17: why not just slam them all together without once losing the groove. When it's over you feel like you just staggered off a broken tilt-a-whirl.

column1: Maybe you should give it to track five though
column2: because that's when guitarist and band mastermind Scott Hull unleashes the first of many sick-ass riffs that any lover of heavy guitar could understand
column3: a woozy swamp-muck strut that could quite plausibly be called anthemic. Hull's own affinity for perverse grooves is another reason for Pig Destroyer's improbable sense of swing between the full-frontal assaults. Despite their commitment to total destruction
column4: PD's guitar does offer a ton of familiar pleasures
column5: little blurts of fierce thrash or low-down Southern boogie
column6: with the few seconds of righteous evil that close out ""Eve"" being both typical and exemplary. It's just that we really are often talking literal seconds to grab onto. And though he clearly invested many childhood hours studying metal's unholy texts
column7: Hull's just as interested in making sounds like a swarm of killer bees squeezed into your ear via a turkey baster. So yeah
column8: this is still music with zero intention of meeting the non-extreme audience halfway.

column1: Book Burner is Pig Destroyer's fifth album
column2: and despite a five-year gap since their last record
column3: the epochal Phantom Limb
column4: and the addition of a new drummer
column5: it's the work of a long-haul
column6: tour-honed grindcore unit in frightening control of its caustic materials and even more caustic philosophy. Like a Hollywood stunt choreographer let loose on a demolition derby
column7: Pig Destroyer attacks these minute-and-change bursts of chaos with dominating precision. Even when they ride out a groove
column8: like riff-monster ""Baltimore Strangler""
column9: it's more like breaking a bad horse than enjoying a friendly gallop. Plus
column10: the title alone should let you know the kind of blasted emotional world we're inhabiting here. Think one of those max-out-the-credit-cards underground horror films made by and for obsessives: Book Burner is utterly ugly
column11: thoroughly alienating stuff that doesn't give half a shit if you can stomach its musical and spiritual violence.

column1: It's also one of the best rock albums of the year
column2: though maybe it should come with a sticker that reads ""abandon hope of rockin' good times
column3: all ye who enter here."" And Pig Destroyer even have qualities to please those who go to metal for its ""avant"" qualities as much as the abuse. If even the most room-clearing metal can get praised for its sonic adventurousness in our texture-obsessed times
column4: for a grindcore band-- extreme metal often at its furthest-out extreme of rawness and ragged production-- Pig Destroyer have an incredibly rich sound. The addition of noise dude Blake Harrison for the last couple of records has given the music an extra horrible-blare layer of gnarled electronics. And despite the band's famed lack of bass guitar
column5: the weight of Hull's typically low-end-intensive production job reattaches the heaviness to a genre where too often the pursuit of speed leaves everything tinny and weirdly weak.

column1: The one thing that's hard to deny is that Book Burner's even less user-friendly than Phantom Limb
column2: which wasn't exactly a freindly how-do. It's like PD decided to take the innovations of Limb-- the massive and unashamed riffage
column3: the body-bruising weight-- and apply it to the chewed-and-chopped frenzy of their first few
column4: more traditionally grind LPs. One thing for sure though is that PD continue to play with an invention and intensity that sucks the breath out of fans
column5: a dedication to both grind's visceral appeal and shaping it into new forms that puts them leagues beyond most of their peers. It's that raging conviction
column6: the totalizing whomp of their sound
column7: one you can feel in your gut as much as hear
column8: that makes them powerful
column9: above and beyond however much their sense of rock groove and rock drama nudges their genre's self-imposed boundaries forward.

column1: So PD put this crazed and hateful stuff together with as much smarts as any high-brow metal band
column2: but also with an end-of-their-rope furty that's more Jake LaMotta punching prison walls than John Petrucci doing Rimsky-Korsakov-for-idiots. There's a queasy joy you feel in your lizard brain with heavy music played with PD's can't-be-faked physical force. Their aggression seeps into you like an unwanted
column3: but eventually not-unpleasant sickness. Maybe that's not your bag. It's not a lot of people's bag. But if it is
column4: Book Burner is seriously cathartic. However convoluted things get
column5: you still wanna pump fist and bang head
column6:
even if you're not always sure when you should be doing so.

During the last five years
column2: I've probably spent more money collecting the musical output of Dominick Fernow than that of any other musician. As the wildly prolific Prurient

column4: he webbed static through a tangled haze of broken drums

column14: Fernow has issued a veritable flood of music during the last 15 years. At this point

column2: at least

column8: tangent-prone techno. His best work yet under the name comprises Ornamented Walls

column11: they bounce around in halls of broken sounds

column1: Ornamented Walls isn't an LP so much as a collection of material you might have missed and an addendum of tracks you don't want to miss. The 23-minute A-side is actually a reissue of an earlier digital EP built from live rehearsals for ""Operation Neptune Spear""
column2: the code name of sorts for Vatican Shadow's live premiere in Los Angeles in May. (If discography-obsessive detail is your thing

column4: in a cassette run limited to 17.) The second half
column5: though
column6: combines six tracks recorded shortly thereafter but not yet released. The pieces on both sides plunder the same sonic premise-- beats tumbling through claustrophobic nightmares
column7: arriving at one punishing terminus or another.

column1: But it's telling that Fernow fits twice as many tracks onto the B-side in roughly the same amount of time. During the A-side's rehearsal workouts
column2: Fernow is processing digital samples through a cassette system and manipulating them again on the other side. There's a sidewinding sense of indeterminacy here
column3: then
column4: where a theme appears and sometimes quickly vanishes for good
column5: the precipitate of a restless mind and process. ""Operation Neptune Spear Part 2""
column6: for instance
column7: creeps through subterranean bass and a lazy
column8: long drum sample until
column9: without notice
column10: Fernow splices in the sound of a Jordanian man singing. It soon fades away
column11: replaced by a blown-out sequence of beats and bass that seem salvaged from an all-night rave.

column2: though
column3: he works one idea over until reaching a definite and logical end
column4: whether that takes eight minutes or only one. The backside's first and longest piece
column5: ""Cairo Is a Haunted City (Mythic Chords)""
column6: builds steadily
column7: with several strands of drone (alternately harsh
column8: soft
column9: damaged
column10: and warm) wrapping slowly around a militaristic march; think Emeralds rerouting their typical ascendance through urban muck. The relatively brief ""India Has Just Tested a Nuclear Device"" unfurls as a lulling invocation
column11: with war drums softly rattling alongside shooting stars of faded electronics. Closer ""Boxes Were Wired to Batteries Then Loaded Into a Brown Toyota Cargo Truck"" shifts the action to the sampled drums. The already broken rhythm trips over itself every so often
column12: eventually tumbling toward an oblivion of repetition as the gauze of noise beneath vanishes. If Side A is open-ended exploration and Side B is closed-system execution
column13: Ornamented Walls is provocative manifestation of the same unresolved and unlimited approach that Fernow has used throughout his career.

column1: Both for its use of jarring imagery and subverted symbols and its unfailing willingness to nest one genre's sounds within another's modes
column2: Dominick Fernow's body of work is a study in implicit transgression. In the heyday of Prurient
column3: for instance
column4: he'd dismiss claims that the project was the result of his interests in black metal; this was about noise and electronica
column5: not about pissed bros in corpse paint. And now
column6: although Vatican Shadows depends upon traditional electronic elements (or the dismantling thereof) like beats and keyboards and samples
column7: the various pushes and pulls of his other experiences are exactly what make Ornamented Walls so intriguing. Listen for the creep and sudden punishment of black metal at the back half of ""Operation Neptune Spear Part 1""
column8:
or the relentless insistence of power electronics during ""Yemeni Telephone Number"": Ornamented Walls is not only an enticing new entry for Vatican Shadow but also a continuation of the overwhelming oeuvre that preceded it.

Sky Ferreira's rise has been just short of meteoric: She teamed up with Miike Snow's Bloodshy & Avant after their brief window of crossover fame at the age of 15 and commissioned a track or so each from professionals like Swedish indie popper Marit Bergman and serial songwriter Ryan Tedder. There was some music shelved and some routine image trouble
column3: but she scrabbled her way back to square two with the help of more professionals: Dev Hynes of Blood Orange and Shirley Manson of recently revived Garbage. Now her protostar is brighter than ever and she's earned one of the biggest cult hits of the year. On her new EP
column4: Ghost
column5: she's settled into several mutually exclusive styles of music. It's official: she's the year's next big latent potential.

column1: None of this is entirely fair to Ferreira. It says a lot about both her talent and tenacity that she's even managed this much of a comeback when every major label and producer has a basement cluttered with the discarded half-debuts and dozens of demos that never even made it that far. It helps that she's got connections from before and during her industry time
column2: and that they're easily spun into anecdotes (her mentor
column3: Michael Jackson! Her partner in vodka-bottle scandal
column4: Katy Perry!). It helps that all those singles
column5: hits or not
column6: gave her residual name recognition. It helps that she shows candor about it
column7: on Twitter and to tastemakers. It helps that she's got her alt-fashion and modeling gigs-- ever more necessary as industry demands layer multi-platform experience and brand support on artists like tiered skirts. And it helps most of all that Ferreira's spent the years since her debut cultivating an impeccable
column8: or at least impeccably marketable
column9: sense of taste. She's called her upcoming album more of a collection of that taste than a statement of an album. And though she's spoken elsewhere about how developing artists aren't encouraged to curate those collections as often as inherit them from someone else's drawer
column10: everything on Ghost sounds like something Ferreira does genuinely like.

column2: it seems
column3: adds up to a veritable nostalgia feed. ""Lost in My Bedroom"" burbles over with details
column4: sounding as if Ferreira's actually lost in about 10 synthpop songs playing at once
column5: three of which came from John Hughes movies and two of which are ""Dancing on My Own"". Her voice disappears into the mix as if she's disappearing into a one-girl
column6: mattress-jumping dance party
column7: and as soundtracks to those go
column8: this is as gleeful as any. Earlier on
column9: Jon Brion assists with ""Sad Dream""
column10: which flitters from the mundane (""I hear your call and I let my phone ring.../ I listen to the stereo play"") to the mythologizing (""I live by my own laws
column11: I stick to my guns"")
column12: from calypso to folk
column13: from the warbled vocals of certain Brion acolytes to the more petulant
column14: wailing sort. It never quite lands on a chorus
column15: but it never quite needs to; the hesitation fits the subject matter. The same can't be said
column16: alas
column17: of ""Ghost""
column18: Ferreira's alt-country track. The songwriting's evocative enough
column19: and Ferreira emotes with enough stirrings of yearnings
column20: but they sound more aspirational than heartbroken. She's crying out for someone
column21: but not as loudly as the track cries out for its Emmylou Harris.

column1: Nobody's asking Ferreira to be an alt-country singer
column2: though. She fares better and sounds far more comfortable on tracks like the Manson-penned ""Red Lips"". It's essentially a Garbage B-side shorn of a pre-chorus
column3: and it wears its concept as brightly as its colors
column4: but Ferreira sells it with a distant
column5: almost tossed-off vocal. There's distance in Hynes' ""Everything Is Embarrassing""
column6: too
column7: but a different sort. Where ""Red Lips"" is haughty
column8: this is sullen; where Ferreira snarls out the former's chorus
column9: ""Embarrassing"" sees her really dancing on her own
column10: her melody too plaintive
column11: her vocals too understated
column12: and the beats too hazy to register much beyond resignation. It's not a come-on
column13: as some have written
column14: nor is it the anthem it's clearly trying to become (and that the inexplicable overproduction on the Ghost re-recording seems to try to make it). It's a gift to everyone more apt to mumble ""I wouldn't bother"" than attempt a diva kiss-off
column15: and it oozes relatability
column16: which may be her greatest strength.

column2: certainly her stylishness
column3: but even more than those
column4: it shows her empathy. At this point

from a human-sized dance song. It probably won't be a coincidence either if that's the trait to grant her staying power.

It's important to note that Autumn Bird Songs is not new material. Jason Molina made these recordings of just himself and an acoustic guitar several years ago
column2: before he abruptly canceled a tour with Will Johnson
column3: before he shuffled between hospitals and rehab centers
column4: before his health problems led to dire financial problems (like many musicians
column5: he had no insurance)
column6: and before he started working on a farm in West Virginia raising sheep and chickens. Anyone who approaches the material looking for insight into his condition may end up reading too much into the lyrics and possibly missing the point of this modest release.

column1: This mini-album accompanies the book From Blacksheep Boys to Bill Collectors
column2: which includes artwork by William Schaff and writing from Will Sheff
column3: John Darnielle
column4: and Darren Jackson (the songs are also available for separate digital download). Published by the Savannah-based Graveface Records
column5: it's an intriguing mix of the musical and the visual
column6: especially since Schaff and Molina both emphasize the handmade and the homespun in their individual media. Written for the project when it was devised several years ago
column7: the songs have the feel of woodcuts
column8: stitched samplers
column9: shadow boxes
column10: and rough pencil sketches. Much less elaborate than Schaff's creations
column11: they're essentially demos
column12: capturing ideas and moments with no regard for crisp fidelity. The click of the recorder is audible after most songs
column13: and a roomy hiss pervades opener ""Heart My Heart"" and ""A Sad Hard Change""
column14: creating an eerie sustain for his strums and evoking another presence there in the room with him. Perhaps it's the ""my love"" he addresses on ""Shore to Shore"". ""The ocean
column15: my love
column16: was not enough
column17: he sings. ""The nightingale rose but her soul could not.""

column1: It's unclear whether this demo sound is the result Molina intended or simply one step toward fleshing them out with Magnolia Electric Co. or some sympathetic collaborator
column2: but it does lend the collection a cohesive quality similar to 2006's Let Me Go Let Me Go Let Me Go. Molina sounds good in this setting
column3: his voice well suited to the creaky intimacy. He sings like he's telling old secrets
column4: with a sharp shiver in his notes
column5: and the mood is that specific Molina flavor of somber that ties all of his records together. With only eight songs running 22 minutes
column6: Autumn Bird Songs is a slight collection-- a 10"" rather than an LP-- and yet there's something compelling about that slightness
column7: which echoes Molina's preoccupation in ghosts and spirits.

column1: He peppers these lyrics with familiar references to hauntings
column2: plains
column3: highways
column4: and wings-- all emblems of big ideas about travel and rootlessness
column5: turmoil and security. In other words
column6: Autumn Bird Songs continues a detailed emotional cartography he began 16 years ago with Songs:Ohia. While it may work best as a complement to Schaff's artwork-- or
column7: more fittingly
column8: as an addendum to Magnolia Electric Co.'s 2007 box set
column9: Sojourner-- this release underscores the enormity of Molina's absence these past few years
column10:
as well as the promise of his return.

Before Prince Paul came on the scene in the mid-1980s
column2: rap beats were mostly made from flipped funk and disco breaks and booming 808 drum machines and not much else. But with his work on career-defining albums by 3rd Bass
column3: Big Daddy Kane
column4: Queen Latifah
column5: and especially De La Soul
column6: he demolished established ideas of what rap beats were and could be
column7: radically broadening the form's sonic horizons with collages of samples lifted from psychedelic pop bands
column8: obscure jazz outfits
column9: kids' records
column10: and anything else he could get his hands on. In the process he laid down a foundation that producers from the Bomb Squad to Kanye and beyond have built upon
column11: and helped considerably to further the argument that hip-hop deserves to be considered an art form every bit as much as rock does.

column1: That aesthetic daring is what's earned Paul a permanent spot in the hip-hop history books
column2: but he's also responsible for another innovation that's become deeply woven into the form's fabric
column3: although to a much more ambivalent response from listeners: the rap record skit
column4: wherein the musicians take a break from making music to show off their comedic talents
column5: engage in ersatz phone sex
column6: or threaten their competitors more directly than they can in song. The hip-hop skit has gotten a lot of bad press over the years
column7: mostly because a lot of rappers are way less entertaining when they're not rapping
column8: but ever since De La's 1989 3 Feet High and Rising
column9: Paul's been working to elevate it to an art form.

column1: In fact beginning with mid-career high points like 1999's A Prince Among Thieves and So…How's Your Girl? (the former a solo album and the latter a collaboration with fellow producer Dan the Automator under the name Handsome Boy Modeling School) his skits have been just as important a part of his records as the ambitious music surrounding them. Paul uses his skits to tie together the individual songs into concept albums ranging in subject matter from the vicissitudes of a career in the music business to extended riffs on references to an obscure and long-canceled sitcom
column2: and to help make the whole far more entertaining than a concept album deserves to be.

column1: Negroes on Ice may be the apotheosis of Paul's skit-centric approach to making albums. Creating alongside his son P. Forreal-- a DJ
column2: MC
column3: and beat maker in his own right-- music makes up just half of the album by track listing
column4: and just over half of its run time. The rest of the record is given over to an epic spoken word story by P. Forreal that begins with him waking up next to his girl and ends almost an hour later
column5: having in the meantime traversed the length and breadth of New York City being pursued by the police and a gang of Jamaicans
column6: driven a Scion xB Scarface (""the rapper"") edition through a gay pride parade
column7: won a speedwalking race
column8: eaten a dolphin
column9: punched several dozen people (including his best friend
column10: a few cops
column11: and a dead helicopter pilot)
column12: and encountered Pusha T
column13: Akon
column14: Jimmie ""J.J."" Walker
column15: Steven Seagal
column16: and a busload of other celebs and semi-celebs
column17: before (spoiler alert) robbing a bank and flying to Africa to work in the kitchen of a Chinese restaurant. It's something like Grand Theft Auto IV reimagined by a young pop-culture-obsessed rap fan buzzing off a junk food binge.

column1: In a flip on the usual format
column2: it's the songs on Negroes that serve as interludes to the skits. Putting together a skit-free version of the album in an iTunes playlist means missing out such LOL-worthy episodes as P. Forreal boatjacking a highly customized amphibian vehicle from Yung Joc
column3: but it's a solid collection of music nonetheless. For someone with such a long and prolific career
column4: Prince Paul has yet to release an out-and-out clunker
column5: and although he's in his mid-40s his music still exudes the same enthusiastic energy as the material from nearly two decades ago. The beat to ""Pixel Hero"" is built around a nasty polyphonic keyboard riff and the kind of breezily funky drums that Paul helped to introduce to hip-hop
column6: while the drum programming on ""I'm a G"" nods to the double-time rhythms of today's pop-rap even as a dizzily catchy piano line goofs off on top of it.

column1: And while at this point P. Forreal is a slightly more accomplished storyteller than he is a rapper-- I bet he'd be a great standup-- he and a cast of little-known rappers like Breeze Brewin
column2: T. Harris
column3: and Soce the Elemental Wizard all deliver solid performances laced with a casual
column4: slightly surreal sense of humor that pairs perfectly with the beats
column5: and flows that indicate they've spent some serious time studying the Native Tongues scene Prince Paul was once part of. And if the ridiculously clever text-speak flow on ""Textual Healing"" is any indication
column6: P. Forreal could easily establish a career independent of his pops.

column1: Negroes on Ice is a funny record
column2: but it's also a sneaky one. It bills itself as a goofy father-son collaboration with a bunch of no-name MCs in tow
column3: and doesn't even note on its track listing the guest voice over appearances by Ice-T and Chris Rock
column4: who could probably double the sales of the record by himself if it did. In fact it seems to do everything it can to come off like a throwaway album
column5:
which you might think it is up until the point where you find yourself hitting play on it over and over again.

Look up for just a second at that ""Siltbreeze; 2012"" there. Doesn't that just make all the sense in the world? After a few failed dalliances with a couple of the indie world's heavier hitters-- two for Matador
column3: one for Merge-- Ohio lo-fi distorto-poppers Times New Viking have returned to Siltbreeze
column4: the Philly-based fuzz-peddlers behind the band's first couple of LPs
column5: Dig Yourself and Present the Paisley Reich. Not that they've changed all that much in their time apart;  sure
column6: 2011's fitfully satisfying
column7: comparatively scrubbed-sounding Dancer Equired was a stark reminder how well all that grime has served them through the years
column8: but those Matador LPs had all the grisly vitality of anything that came before them. Still
column9: even at Matador
column10: the fit wasn't ever quite right
column11: a problem of expectation more than output; this is a band with a song called ""Try Harder"" that seemed to sneer at the very concept of effort
column12: and even at their catchiest
column13: they've never been an easy sell. It's not Interscope or anything
column14: but when you're a band on Matador or Merge
column15: you've gotta move a few units. On Siltbreeze-- sometime-home to Harry Pussy
column16: Psychedelic Horseshit
column17: and the Thomas Jefferson Slave Apartments-- though? Pressure's pretty much off.

column1: And Over & Over finds Times New Viking sounding like a band with nothing left to prove. The six song
column2: just-under-14-minute Over & Over doesn't give itself a lot of time to fuck around. But fuck around it does
column3: blasting through a few tunes worthy of the best-of and a couple of scraps they could've left on the basement floor. ""Middle Class Drags"" is the winner here
column4: a brash
column5: immediate power-popper that belongs in the same breath as past triumphs like ""Devo & Wine"" or ""Move to California"". Beth Murphy and Adam Elliott's vocals seem to be punching Jared Phillips' guitar square in the face
column6: but the bordering-on-triumphant hook at its center blasts through the din the way a Harley peels out of a church paking lot
column7: a perfect balance of song and snarl. For all its stray slack (""falling further behind and still sleep in
column8: they prescribe)
column9: ""Sleep-In"" has plenty going for it
column10: and in it
column11: too: The accidentally-on-purpose hook's effortless enough
column12: but everything else-- rollicking keyboards
column13: caterwauling guitars-- fall all over themselves
column14: a pile of ankles and elbows in the form of a song.

column1: ""Y2K2"" pulls back the rubber band as far as it'll go
column2: but they never quite let it snap; by the end
column3: the tension from all that built-up skronk gets stuck in the back of your neck. Sweet relief: ""Future With Girls"" is all whiplash. With its half-dozen tempo changes
column4: a truly nauseous organ line
column5: and a false ending or two
column6: its all-over-the-place construction seems to mirror the push and shove of the shitty relationship half-described therein
column7: but it's just more song than two lousy minutes could ever hope to contain. Still
column8: it's impressive how tidily Over & Over goes in righting most of the wrongs of Dancer
column9: considering how untidy it is. There's an underlying warmth to songs like ""Telephone Wires"" and closer ""At the Bars"" that seems to've carried over from that LP
column10: but unlike the comparatively staid Dancer songs
column11: Over & Over's not afraid to get weird.

column1: Over & Over keeps its stakes on the manageable side
column2: short
column3: and loose
column4: and profoundly uninterested in any kind of statement-making. But that whiff of modesty
column5: coupled with their return to a label better suited to their ambitions
column6: is sort of a statement in and of itself. You're either in or out with Times New Viking; they're too obstinate
column7: too sadistic
column8: the smart-dumb shit they talk in their lyrics too obtuse (and obscured by static) to not trying most people's patience. Which means they're far better off making slight but satisfying records like Over & Over for few obsessives than they are trying to figure out how the hell to get their uncompromising music over to a bigger crowd. For another band
column9: Over & Over's outright refusal to go for the gusto might represent a kind of defeat. For these guys
column10: it feels like a sorely needed restart. Let those other bands chase their audiences; if you need Times New Viking
column11:
you know where to find them.

column2: Goodbye Falkenburg
column3: Welsh pop fops Race Horses entrusted themselves with the modest but commendable task of honoring the madcap legacy of ancestral countrymen Super Furry Animals and Gorky's Zygotic Mynci. Now
column4: they're ready to take on the rest of the British isles: Furniture handily displaces the loopy 60s-psychedelic and 70s-glam influences of their debut for a bright 80s New Pop sheen and the skyscraping grandeur that defined mid-90s Britpop. But the shift is philosophical as music as it is sonic: Where Goodbye Falkenburg spoke of love and courtship in cheeky
column5: suggestive language
column6: Furniture-- in the arch
column7: observational tradition of ABC and Pulp-- uses its sleek sophistication not just to gloss over the straight-faced tales of emotional woe described within
column8: but as an analogue to the procedural
column9: commoditized nature of modern romance.

column2: frontman Meilyr Jones sounds the death knell for a failing relationship by declaring
column3: ""We are furniture."" By that token
column4: listening to Furniture feels not unlike flipping through an IKEA catalog-- it's easy to get lured in by the pretty surfaces and marvel at the inventiveness at play but
column5: after a while
column6: a certain sterility starts to take hold. At least Race Horses ease you into the album's more despairing worldview-- from the outset
column7: the band is game to play up the knowing contrast between what's being said and how they're saying it. The aforementioned chorus of ""we are furniture"" is delivered less as an insult than a cathartic first step toward post-break-up liberation
column8: while on the winsome ""Mates""
column9: Jones begs an ex to revert to the platonic terms of their pre-hook-up friendship. And in lieu of a new post-reunion Pulp album
column10: we have ""Sisters""
column11: which vividly evokes both the breezy
column12: pop-romantique flair of His N Hers and Jarvis Cocker's voyeuristic
column13: borderline-pervy intimations.

column1: But while it's inevitable that a young band brimming with manic energy will buckle up and simmer down
column2: on Furniture
column3: Race Horses' rapid maturation can feel a little jarring: The synth-speckled piano march ""Nobody's Son"" boasts the kind of instantly anthemic chorus that could spark a football stadium full of cigarette lighters
column4: but it's also the most incongruous track here
column5: as it sacrifices the band's peculiar personality for arena-rock proficiency. And their attempts to get serious yield mixed results: While ""Bad Blood"" successfully channels its anxieties through an intensifying
column6: start-stop structure and ticking synthetic cymbal effect
column7: the equally agitated ""My Year Abroad"" and ""See No Green"" are bogged down by overwrought
column8: repetitive choruses. So it's fitting that this transitory album
column9: preoccupied as it is with romantic upheaval
column10: should close with an somber
column11: affecting piano ballad titled ""Old and New""
column12: with an extended one-chord outro that effectively conjures the titular state of purgatory
column13:
and the difficulty of letting go and moving on. It's a sentiment that applies equally to Furniture's emotionally stagnant protagonists as to Race Horses themselves-- it's better to attempt great strides and risk stumbling than to get left in the dust.
