There are two basic reasons why composers like Philip Glass end up getting remixed: rhythm and repetition. Glass' most identifiable music is simple
column5: or so it seems: Play a chord
column6: break it down into its constituent notes
column7: and repeat the notes in hypnotic succession. If there's another instrument playing
column8: they're probably playing the same notes in a different order. At the foundation of the music
column9: there's what's called an ostinato. One way to think of it is as a bassline; another
column10: in the words of a clever Wikipedia contributor
column11: is a riff. When his music changes
column12: it changes subtly and methodically: One note in the sequence altered here
column13: another there. Over the course of a few minutes it can change completely
column14: but there's no one point where you can mark the change as having taken place. It's hard to think of a Glass composition that doesn't work this way. At least one man with an electric piano has posited it as an almost scientific truth.

column2: Glass did with live musicians what a lot of techno and electronic-music producers ended up doing with sequencers
column3: samplers
column4: and other mechanical ways of ordering sound. Like techno
column5: his music operates on the simple principle that if you've been seeing zeros flashing on a screen minute after minute
column6: seeing a one will seem very dramatic. This
column7: again
column8: comes back to repetition: Unless our environment stays the same for a little while
column9: there's no way we'll be able to perceive difference. If Glass' music is romantic
column10: it's the kind of cool
column11: godlike romance of watching ants in an ant farm
column12: or streams of pedestrians from the window of an office building: the romance of distance
column13: of pattern
column14: of busy movement made to look transparent and organized.

column1: At some point in the past year
column2: Glass approached Beck about putting together a group of artists to remix his music. In a quote that mirrors the deceptive clarity of his music
column3: he told the New York Times
column4: ""I'm interested in what happens to music when other people use it. Whereas there are composers who don't like anyone to touch their music
column5: I think people should because they do things I can't think of."" Beck obliged
column6: and now we have Rework.

column1: Some of the source material here will be familiar even to passing Glass fans. Cornelius
column2: for example
column3: works with the opening section of 1982's Glassworks (which in Glass' own words was intended to get his music across to ""a more general audience"")
column4: while glitchy L.A. producer Nosaj Thing uses parts of ""Knee 1""
column5: the opening section of the recently revived opera Einstein on the Beach-- probably Glass' most famous piece of music.

column2: whether or not the music is familiar doesn't matter as much as what the interpreters do with it. It's easy to imagine how this could have gone badly. (<a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d3y_Fay4SBQ&feature=BFa&list=PL28FC18A72DB2D1D6"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">In fact
column3: some intrepid people on the internet have already tested out just how badly it could have gone.) Glass' innovations have percolated so far through the world of contemporary music that a lot of the contributors here-- Tyondai Braxton
column4: Dan Deacon
column5: Cornelius
column6: and Pantha du Prince-- can
column7: as Pitchfork contributor Brian Howe put it
column8: remix him and still end up sounding more or less like themselves. As a result
column9: a lot of what's here doesn't really demonstrate what they can do to Philip Glass
column10: but what Philip Glass has already done to them.

column1: Would it surprise you to learn that Beck's contribution-- a 21-minute collage called ""NYC: 73-78
column2: -- is disorientingly
column3: almost astonishingly good? Maybe. Probably. How or why this is the case is unclear. I doubt even the staunchest Modern Guilt defenders would say that the records he made after the millenium were better than the records he made before it. (Ironically
column4: the turning point was Sea Change.)

column2: ""73-78"" feels like a long period of time collapsed into a single
column3: dreamlike space. Beck's voice drifts in and out like a melancholic choirboy over whole series of passages spanning Glass' career
column4: from full-band compositions to solo piano ones; from the churning
column5: machinistic side of his sound to the spare
column6: meditative one. There is some drum machine
column7: and then there isn't. Glass has always been identified as a New York City composer
column8: and his music has always articulated big-city feelings with uncanny elegance: the loneliness of them
column9: the grandeur of them
column10: the lonely grandeur of them; their violence and their comfort
column11: their threats and seductions; the way they can feel incomprehensibly big and claustrophobically small.

column1: Beck repeats the same line in different parts of the piece: ""I was living in a wasteland
column2: dominated by these maniacs."" The words-- wasteland
column3: maniacs-- are violent
column4: but his delivery is gentle. This is what time does: It takes a fact and softens it. It heals. By the piece's restful end
column5: it almost feels like a survivor's diary: the sound of someone going in and coming out
column6: changed.

column1: I refer back to that Glass quote
column2:
about the possibilty of another artist taking his music and doing something with it that he would've never thought of. ""73-78"" doesn't feel like Philip Glass-- it's too drifty and unbound. It's something completely different. It's also leagues beyond what anyone would reasonably expect from a project like this. The rest isn't.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18428/homepage_large.422ee04b.jpg|Cee Lo's Magic Moment|910.0|Cee-Lo Green|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Elektra']|2012-10-18 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:05:49.680276|"

Magic Moment is not a place where Cee Lo Green has arrived by virtue of evolution. An album of strictly Christmas fare
column2: it is the work of Cee Lo the entertainer
column3: a brand extension of his pop-persona witnessed every week on ""The Voice""
column4: America's best worstmazing singing competition show
column5: where he is a coach/judge. If you were hoping for Cee Lo bringing in Big Gipp and putting the Dungeon Family treatment to ""Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer""
column6: you best look elsewhere for that freaky yuletide.

column1: That is not to say that Magic Moment isn't a pleasure to listen to. It is! Especially if you are fond of Christmas standards and loud singing. As Green said of himself recently
column2: ""No one does soul like Cee Lo Green."" It's true. No one else on contemporary pop radio carries the torch for true soul singing and vintage R&B hooks like he does. On Magic Moment
column3: Green does a lot of broad-strokes Motown updates (""White Christmas""); the triumphant production
column4: a locomotive backbeat paired with sleigh bells
column5: is a veritable tribute to Phil Spector's classic 1963 holiday comp A Christmas Gift For You From Phil Spector.

column1: It would seem that Magic Moment is the work of pop-savvy Green gunning for the kind of hits that a regular album of his would not provide. There is something here for everyone
column2: or perhaps rather
column3: every standardized radio format; if Green is gunning for holiday omniscience from now until the end of Christmas
column4: he has plotted a sure and failproof course with Magic Moment. There is the playful jazz shuffle-cum-melismatic exercise of ""Baby It's Cold Outside""
column5: featuring Christina Aguilera
column6: the heavy Christian mojo of ""Mary
column7: Did You Know?"". The avec Rod Stewart ""Merry Christmas
column8: Baby""
column9: its airlessness cementing a hallowed space on Lite FM from now until the sun swallows the Earth. Magic Moment's most curious collaboration is with the Muppets on his original
column10: ""All I Need Is Love""
column11: which is built on a sample of their beloved ""Mahna Mahna"".

column1: Green's singing here is not his most nuanced; he's singing at the middle-low end of his range
column2: not in his trademark reedy voice. There is a lot of loud
column3: full-bore belting. It's a little showboaty and on occasion his voice threatens to overpower the song itself (""Silent Night"")-- perhaps a bit of pandering for ""Voice"" viewers who only know him from the show
column4: which is a cavalcade of over-the-top
column5: soulful shouting. Still
column6: not a note of Magic Moment rings false. Green sounds like he really has been waiting all year to trap unsuspecting people under the mistletoe; clawing his presents open like a wolverine. He's so motherfucking cheery he makes Burl Ives seem like Michael Gira.

column2: it's the album's melancholy moment that is its most magic-- Green's faithful rendering of Joni Mitchell's ""River""
column3: from her 1971 folk masterpiece
column4: Blue. It's barely a Christmas song
column5: a rueful break-up ode that cribs a bit of ""Jingle Bells"". He trades the original's piano for a Wurlitzer and matches Mitchell's mournful alto; a rare moment of restraint that illuminates the span of Green's talent. Coming a mere three songs after a jubilant-bordering-on-spastic version of ""Run Rudolph Run""
column6: it feels like a bit of a hat tip
column7: reminding us that despite all this Christmas ham
column8:
the closet freak is still in there somewhere.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18362/homepage_large.236ca817.jpg|Dept. of Disappearance|6067.0|Jason Lytle|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Anti-']|2012-10-18 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:05:50.405569|"

Jason Lytle's second solo album begins much like his first solo album
column2: with a veiled statement about the state of his career. On the title track of 2009's <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/13037-yours-truly-the-commuter/""><i>Yours Truly
column3: the Commuter
column4: he claims he was left for dead: ""I could give two shits about what they said/ I may be limping
column5: but I'm coming home."" At the time it sounded like he was still bristling over the breakup of Grandaddy
column6: the Modesto-based band that soundtracked Lytle's weird tales of space miners and lovelorn robots. The lines were vague enough
column7: however
column8: that you could appreciate the renewed sense of mission without getting caught up in any potential intraband politics. On ""Department of Disappearance""
column9: which likewise opens and sets the tone for an album of the same name
column10: Lytle explains
column11: ""I'll crawl into the mountains
column12: I'll fall into obscurity/ A phantom on the landscape
column13: a memory of what used to be."" Is this an ultimatum of some sort? And is the titular institution really a secret society of veteran musicians from the 1990s
column14: still tooling around years after their breakthrough albums and playing to dwindling audiences of aging fans? If Yours Truly announced Lytle's return
column15: Department of Disappearance sounds like a musician embracing obscurity as perhaps the natural outcome of a career whose chief subject has been emotional
column16: mechanical
column17: and ecological entropy.

column1: There's nothing worse than an artist waxing bitter about his career
column2: and to his credit Lytle doesn't sound self-pitying or entitled to more than his current lot. But Department of Disappearance does sound strangely complacent and monochromatic
column3: offering no twists on the technorganic aesthetic he's been plying since Grandaddy were still a bedroom act. The album toggles between the mountains of Europe and the badlands of the American West
column4: as Lytle indulges a bit of emotional mountaineering on ""Last Problem of the Alps"" and ""Matterhorn"". Geographically
column5: this is new terrain for him
column6: but musically Lytle is walking in his own footprints. He's climbed similar hills before
column7: both with Grandaddy and as a solo artist. Once again he fashions widescreen panoramas out of instruments seemingly ill suited for the job: chintzy synths evoking Bierstadt landscapes
column8: grotty guitars tracing the country's inexorable westward progress
column9: saccharine strings coloring in complex feelings.

column2: of course
column3: Lytle's thing. And it's a good thing. He's done what few artists possess the vision or the tools to accomplish: He has devised a new combination of styles and instruments into a sound that is immediately recognizable as Lytleputian
column4: and perhaps more impressively he has fashioned a unique perspective from which to write about himself and the world-- specifically America in all its mythic strangeness. Last year's reissue of Grandaddy's second album
column5: The Sophtware Slump
column6: reminded us how vibrant and weird that voice could be
column7: and Department of Disappearance has the distinct disadvantage of following up that release
column8: which provides an unflattering point of comparison for familiar
column9: almost boilerplate songs like ""Somewhere There's a Someone"" and ""Hangtown"". If once he imagined a new world defined by millennial fears and technological detritus
column10: on ""Willow Wand Willow Wand"" and ""Get Up and Go"" the naivety sounds forced
column11: the sense of whimsy merely workmanlike.

column2: however
column3: there is a peak. ""Young Saints"" sets an uneasy tone with its creeping vocal melody
column4: disembodied drums
column5: and dark intimations of mortality: ""Your ex-girlfriends
column6: lost pets
column7: and dead friends
column8: he sings in his trademark deadpan. ""No
column9: they won't be hanging out with you again. You are gone!"" It's intense and disquieting
column10: yet it's the one song where Lytle sounds most present
column11: with no character
column12: robotic or otherwise
column13: to absorb or soften those fears of absence. Similarly bleak
column14: ""Your Final Setting Sun""-- which was
column15: according to Lytle
column16: inspired by Cormac McCarthy-- recounts a killer's final taunts to a dying man: ""I know you loved your life
column17: but say goodbye
column18: this is your final setting sun."" Has Lytle ever sounded so cold-blooded? So musically malevolent or so emotionally hardened? As the drums barely keep pace with the frantic keyboard themes
column19: his vocals take on a menacing quality that we've never heard from him before and that quite frankly I didn't dream he could muster: It's a bracing moment and completely unexpected
column20: both the album's biggest risk and its biggest reward.

column1: Then Department veers into the valedictory closer ""Gimme Click Gimme Grid""
column2: and we're back on sadly familiar ground. This is exactly the type of mock-epic album closer that Lytle does almost too well. Think ""So You'll Aim Toward the Sky"" off Sophtware Slump or ""The Final Push to the Sum"" off Sumday. But it sounds absolutely anticlimactic sequenced after ""Your Final Setting Sun""
column3: which suggests a much more inventive and exciting artist than we get throughout most of the album. That song says more about Lytle's career than any veiled lyric could: If he can't push himself in new directions
column4: he'll be stuck at his desk job
column5:
pushing paper for the Department of Disappearance forever.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18427/homepage_large.4a3da830.jpg|The Feeling|30746.0|Naomi Punk|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Captured Tracks']|2012-10-18 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:05:51.063526|"

Olympia/Seattle's Naomi Punk are at least partly inspired by their grunge forbearers. The genre's basic elements are well-represented: The sludgy erosion over the guitars
column2: the drums blasting with machine-grade heaviness. Since the old formula goes ""one part metal
column3: two parts punk
column4: and one part psychedelic weird shit
column5: it's not a stretch by any means to consider Naomi Punk a grunge band. And while they're clearly a part of a long lineage of bands taking their influence from the Seattle rock scene of the early 1990s
column6: Naomi Punk's songs are not cheaply manufactured recreations of Soundgarden or even TAD.

column2: originally released on vinyl and now being issued by Captured Tracks digitally and on CD
column3: captures the trio studying the grunge rulebook just to tear it in half. Naomi Punk's approach to grunge is one of deconstruction and rebuilding in different places with fewer parts. Most of the album's songs change tempos at the drop of flannel
column4: breaking into a dense wall of meticulously controlled chaos. Guitars are not delivered with a steady stream of chords; they come in blasts along with the crash cymbal
column5: often at irregular points in the song. There's almost a need to keep up with them rhythmically over the first few listens
column6: because the phrasing of the chords and beats zig zag through a motley course
column7: unintentionally using empty space as every bit the weapon their guitars and drums are.

column2: Naomi Punk seem to be working under a template like slowcore
column3: art-punk
column4: or no wave played at half-speed. They've given themselves a narrow palette to work with in this sense
column5: but The Feeling's funeral-march tempos and unrelenting heaviness don't detract from what makes the album compelling. Aside from three quasi-classical guitar interludes
column6: the record comes packed top-to-bottom with total bruisers
column7: and for most of its 35 minutes
column8: the music is hitting you with pummeling force
column9: every bit as visceral as your favorite punk album from this year. Most of the songs come with a cathartic breakdown of some sort
column10: whether it's the rollicking finish of ""Trashworld"" or the chorus of ""Burned Body"".

column1: Not only does The Feeling connect on a purely visceral level
column2: it's got plenty of emotional resolve. For a band whose poppiest song's titled ""Burned Body"" and for all of the lyrics about charred flesh and self-immolation
column3: Naomi Punk are good at injecting a bit of hope and optimism into their music. ""I am the sun/ I am the shooting star"" goes the opening lyric of ""The Spell"".

column1: The title track takes that optimism and shoots it into anthemic territory. Playing out like the battle scene climax of your favorite war movie
column2: ""The Feeling"" starts out scaling back to hold the tension
column3: but rolls into explosion after explosion. The chorus
column4: the sedate tease of the middle eight
column5: and then the climax-- ""And now I know that I can find a way""-- triumphantly rise above the din. Monolithic and seemingly impenetrable at first
column6: The Feeling has a number of these moments
column7:
subtler details that offer plenty of rewards for whoever can stand being pummeled for almost 40 minutes.

"|17248.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17248-the-feeling/|7.6|Martin Douglas

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18417/homepage_large.50e10d9d.jpg|Zodiac EP|30656.0|Zodiac|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Vase']|2012-10-18 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:05:51.665965|"

Six months ago a Canadian producer named Jeremy ""Zodiac"" Rose seemingly pulled back some of the veil of secrecy that's hovered around the Toronto-based future-R&B project the Weeknd. Rose alleged in a Vice interview that he was responsible not only for the druggy
column2: dreamy blueprint that defined the project's sonic identity
column3: but that he also came up with the louche condo-rat persona that singer Abel Tesfaye adopted when he took the Weeknd name. Rose was credited on the trio of songs posted to YouTube that first drew attention to the Weeknd when Drake reposted them
column4: but although two of his compositions made it onto Tesfaye's career-launching debut album
column5: House of Balloons
column6: his name didn't appear anywhere on or around the finished album.

column1: Tesfaye's kept typically silent about the accusations. Rose
column2: on the other hand
column3: has made a few follow-up comments that indicate he's happy to leave behind his situation's dramatic aspects in order to enjoy the perks of his post-Weeknd notoriety
column4: namely the attention being paid to his first solo recordings
column5: a five-song EP for fellow Canadian beat maker Jacques Greene's Vase label.

column1: Given Rose's claims of ownership to the Weeknd's trademark sound and mood
column2: it's close to impossible to listen to Zodiac without holding it up against the 70% of House of Balloons that he didn't have a hand in
column3: as well as its two sequels
column4: all of which were arranged by credited producers Doc McKinney and Illangelo. It's a tantalizing prospect made frustrating by Zodiac's brevity-- just under 18 minutes-- compared to the 2.5 hours worth of material that Tesfaye
column5: Illangelo
column6: and McKinney released in 2011. Still
column7: there's enough material to make a few comparisons.

column2: Rose is a much less disciplined and proficient musician than Tesfaye's current favored producers. This isn't a bad thing
column3: and Rose has admitted in his interviews that he isn't an adept player. Illangelo and McKinney may have the better grasp on pop song structures
column4: but their heavily mannered Weeknd productions can sometimes get stiflingly stylish
column5: whereas Rose's lack of technical knowledge means he doesn't even know which lines he's supposed to be coloring in. That element pays off in the same kind of wild
column6: throw-anything-at-the-wall energy that you find in early recordings by Brian Eno
column7: who at the time didn't really know what he was doing either.

column1: The EP starts off with Rose backing up his claim on the Weeknd's trademark sound and mood on a pair of songs
column2: ""Girlgirlgirl"" and ""Come""
column3: that do the sleazy nocturnal decadence thing as well as anything in the latter's catalog
column4: although with a rawness that makes up in sonic texture for what it lacks in terms of speaker-bumping polish. But for such a short recording Rose shows an impressive range
column5: dipping into quasi-classical piano-based ambient landscaping with 89-second-long ""Loss Config."". The remaining two songs offer two contrasting takes on Caribbean-inflected post-R&B-- ""So Soon We Change"" is a bedroom jam overlaid with psychedelically bright washes of color
column6: while ""138"" is darker
column7: glitchier
column8: and more like dancehall night in a cyberpunk novel.

column1: Just as it's difficult to compare Rose's productions with McKinney and Illangelo
column2: it's equally as hard not to imagine how the material on Zodiac would have sounded with Tesfaye on it. Jesse Boykins III's vocal on ""Come""-- the only non-sampled singing on the EP-- gets close to Tesfaye's presence
column3: but there's something a bit too clunky and self-consciously Weeknd-ish about his performance. (Then again I'm not sure if Tesfaye could keep up with Rose's vision for ""Loss Config."" and ""138"".)

column2: then he got screwed out of most of the benefits others gained from a sound he helped invent. Then again Zodiac is an addictive little record
column3: and he's still growing as a musician at an impressive rate. Recently he signed a songwriting deal with indie mega-producer Paul Epworth's Wolf Tone label
column4:
and he says he's going to use the opportunity to get better at playing instruments. He's only 23. He's going to be fine.

Pinback bring to mind clockwork: Individually
column2: Rob Crow's guitar and the accompanying drum machines and live percussionists are crisp and sucked dry of reverb
column3: precisely ticking like second hands. Collectively
column4: Crow and bassist Armistead Burwell Smith IV don't overlap so much as interlock like gears and cogs
column5: all doing their part in establishing a consistent momentum. It's also true in the larger
column6: metaphysical sense that you can ""set your watch"" to Pinback. No matter how quickly time flies metaphorically
column7: Pinback keep their own internal pace
column8: independent of all outside noise occurring in the typically long gaps between their full-lengths. So it makes sense that
column9: despite being five years in the making
column10: their fifth LP
column11: Information Retrieved
column12: turns out to be another chance to identify What Pinback Do
column13: celebrate it
column14: and also acknowledge its limitations.

column1: Though it lacks the overt seasonal appellations of Summer in Abbadon and Autumn of the Seraphs
column2: Information Retrieved does follow the chronology of its immediate predecessors into the feel of the wintry months. But as with previous openers ""Non-Photo Blue"" and ""From Nothing to Nowhere""
column3: ""Proceed to Memory"" gets Pinback's blood pumping just fast enough to lead you to believe this might be the album where they push for urgency over nuance. The lattices of palm-muted guitar and bass are instantly identifiable as their own
column4: though it's chestier than usual thanks to a pleasingly strident vocal performance from Crow. Otherwise
column5: the highlights typically function like illusions: Crow's melodies are almost subliminal as opposed to hummable
column6: and whether it's the seemingly gaudy Cap'n Jazz-like riff that opens ""Glide"" or the handclapped breakdown of ""His Phase""
column7: everything is more aerodynamic than it initially sounds. A good Pinback song can feel like hopping aboard an already moving vehicle.

column1: They still don't sound remotely like any other band besides Three Mile Pilot
column2: with whom they have shared members
column3: and granting listeners the ability to recognize that after a long hiatus often results in warm initial receptions for Pinback LPs. But this almost always wanes since there isn't a lot of wiggle room in the niche they've created for themselves. ""Should it be so hard to have a nice day?"" Crow bays during ""Diminished""
column4: faintly funky and faintly jazzy in the way Pinback's piano-led songs are. And sometimes listening to Pinback
column5: it does feel like having a nice day or any kind of base pleasure is something that has to be micromanaged within the sterilized environment they create. There are faster Pinback songs
column6: but none that really rock-- ""His Phase"" comes closest
column7: mostly because if it were distorted and pitched down an octave
column8: you could imagine Crow's Goblin Cock side-project stealing it.

column1: Lending a critical ear to Crow's lyrics for any sort of indication of what motivates this band can prove perplexing. They're not quite stream of consciousness
column2: but a good Pinback song can make you think you've snooped on a conversation already in progress. And here
column3: there's a strange computerized syntax to a lot of them
column4: taking after the record's robotic title: ""I might fall/ I might break down/ But no one can outstyle you there
column5: Crow offers on ""Drawstring""
column6: sounding too stoic to even sweat. On ""Sherman""
column7: he threatens
column8: ""Your thoughts are horrible/ You will be punished for them."" As Information Retrieved cruises towards its end
column9: the mere title of ""Denslow
column10: You Idiot!"" pops for a band that never favors any sort of musical exclamation points-- dig deeper into its arrangement and you mostly just find drily delivered Colin Meloy-isms: ""You infantile cad/ You must have gone mad to be so vile
column11: ""Revising these texts is a brazen sin/ This infraction just will not keep.""

column1: There are obviously benefits to Pinback's consistency: If Information Retrieved is your first experience with the San Diegans
column2: it might be your favorite album of theirs. If it isn't
column3: there's a fine distinction between the two ways of reading
column4: ""great
column5: more Pinback."" As with the most recent Sea and Cake record
column6: there's something inherently nostalgic about Information Retrieved delivering exactly what you'd expect. While it's something of a palliative for people tired of the news cycle surrounding Grimes or Odd Future or whatever
column7: there's also the sense of it being a vestigial remnant of a time when ""indie"" could imply something more serious and studious
column8: less attention-seeking but often standoffish. As a result
column9: it's a reunion with an old friend
column10: but not necessarily a close one. For half an hour
column11:
you think ""why don't we do this more often?"" until it ends and you remember how frustrating they can be.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18426/homepage_large.61b474eb.jpg|The Iconic EP|30420.0|Icona Pop|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Big Beat']|2012-10-17 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:05:55.372430|"

In a pop landscape where turned-up-to-11 is the new quiet (thanks
column2: Skrillex) and a handful of familiar faces dominate the charts
column3: what does a group of newcomers have to do to turn heads? ""I Love It""
column4: the summertime smash from Swedish duo Icona Pop
column5: found a winning answer: GO BIG. Penned by UK goth-pop It girl Charli XCX
column6: ""I Love It"" sounds like ""Since U Been Gone"" rewritten on a keyboard with the caps lock jammed
column7: and Caroline Hjelt and Aino Jawo deliver line after anthemic line like a t-shirt cannon pointed at the cheap seats. ""I threw your shit into a bag and pushed it down the stairs
column8: they shout in unison
column9: perfectly capturing the spectacularly apocalyptic joy of a first night out after a breakup. ""I crashed my car into the bridge
column10: I don't care!"" Pounding
column11: glitter-flecked production from Patrik Berger (who produced fellow Swede Robyn's already-classic ""Dancing on My Own"") evaded the inevitable ""Where's the drop?"" by crafting an entire track that is basically just two-and-a-half minutes of drop. ""I Love It"" is textbook pop perfection: a track so mood-transforming
column12: so replayable
column13: and so endlessly gratifying that anybody who dared wonder this summer if Icona Pop had another one of these up their sleeves should have been answered by an out-of-office auto reply: ""Check back after Labor Day.""

column1: As Icona Pop ready their full-length debut for a 2013 release
column2: The Iconic EP gathers together ""I Love It"" along with a few previously released singles to show the strides they've made since their enjoyable if somewhat generic four-track EP
column3: Nights Like This. From the self-empowered subject matter (by my count
column4: four of these six songs would make appropriate soundtracks for glitterbombing your ex on a dance floor) to the Immaculate Collection-sized hubris of its title
column5: the Iconic EP is a more assured collection of songs that sheds some light on what sets Icona Pop apart from their Swede-pop compatriots. They're sort of like a photo-negative of the Knife circa Deep Cuts; instead of teasing out the dark imagery in supposedly wholesome feelings of love and desire
column6: Icona Pop turn pain into cathartic party-rock anthems.

column1: Though ""I Love It"" stands head and shoulders above everything else Icona Pop have done to date
column2: a few other tracks on the Iconic EP approach its brilliance. ""Manners""
column3: which was first released on the Nights Like This EP and later as an extended single with eight remixes
column4: is still their second-best song. Its slinky verses and signature infectious
column5: shout-along hook (""You better reconsider! You will never do better! There is no one like me!"") are fused together by a steely
column6: robotic beat
column7: making ""Manners"" sound a little like Kraftwerk assembling an Ace of Base hit. It's followed by the sunbursting ""Top Rated"" (originally the double-A-side on the ""Manners"" single)
column8: yet another kiss-off to a domineering partner (""You put yourself on top and that just makes me slip and slide
column9: and see my color fade""). The track gleams and pulsates like a minor key version of ""Starships""
column10: which means it gets explosively cathartic once the chorus hits: ""Try to take me down
column11: I'll be right up... Always been top rated
column12: you think you can change it?""

column2: the lyrics get clunky enough for you to wish that Charli XCX could co-write every Icona Pop song
column3: or at least be on call for edits. ""Good For You"" has a decent melodic hook that gets unfortunately muddled by a lyrical tongue-twister-- ""You love my love
column4: you're never gonna find better love/ You hate my love because you're dead without it."" It's a far cry from the streamlined sloganeering of ""I Love It""
column5: whose every line felt like something that belonged on a billboard. ""Ready for the Weekend""
column6: on the other hand
column7: feels a little too streamlined-- the indistinct lyrics and pitch-shifted
column8: helium vocals scrub away Icona Pop's signature sound. It's the EP's only true misfire
column9: a wannabe club banger that insists a little too hard and momentarily misplaces Icona Pop's effortless cool.

column1: The Iconic EP is neither self-consciously artsy enough nor American pop-radio-ready to play directly to either side of the pop/indie divide
column2: but Icona Pop are emerging at a time when it's starting to feel as though artists like them don't have to make that sort of choice anymore. They don't have to look far for role models: Robyn's made huge waves with her heartfelt fembot-pop and hasn't had to compromise the eccentricity of her vision
column3: and Charli XCX seems to be charting a similarly individualized course as she preps her debut LP. Add in the mounting influence of K-pop's neon dreamscapes
column4: and this inventive and promisingly liberated moment in pop seems like something Icona Pop are primed to seize. When we interviewed them for our Rising feature this summer
column5: the pair ticked off a wide array of influences
column6: from M83 to Prince to Britney Spears
column7: before Hjelt declared
column8: ""You can do whatever you want and call it pop!""

column1: The moments when Hjelt and Jawo sing solo seem fewer
column2: or at least more forgettable
column3: than the times they sing-shout together
column4: but it's not to Icona Pop's detriment-- it's kind of what they're all about. In the same way that Robyn songs like ""Dancing On My Own"" and ""Dancehall Queen"" embody female independence and self-sufficiency
column5: Icona Pop project something oddly unrepresented in pop music right now: female friendship. As I was reading about the recent Nicki-vs.-Mariah blow-up and thinking about how much the media still love a good ""catfight"" narrative
column6: watching interviews with Icona Pop felt like a breath of fresh air. They met on a night not so unlike the one immortalized in ""I Love It""-- Jawo had just been dumped

Rudi Zygadlo is a funny one. The Glaswegian vocalist and multi-instrumentalist's second album Tragicomedies is a maze of confusion
column2: contradiction
column3: and epiphany. Don't get me wrong
column4: it's good-- vastly superior to his 2010 debut effort
column5: Great Western Laymen-- yet it requires a patient ear
column6: because to fully engage is to embrace the aural equivalent of a carpet being pulled out from underneath you over and over again. Not any old carpet
column7: but the most ornate
column8: antique Persian rug: Tragicomedies twists and turns luxuriously and theatrically
column9: shredding skins in a looping cycle that runs the gamut of emotion from poignancy to parody.

column1: There are moments of great beauty and befuddling disconnection
column2: often within the same song. Lead single ""Melpomene"" is the key to the album's peculiar appeal: A spirit-lifting classical piano recital that swells like a wave at high tide suddenly drops to a vocal break that smacks of disappointment. The change of pace and timbre disturbs
column3: but then a breeze whips down and we're off again
column4: lifted above and away in an ivory spiral. Once the dust from the jarring juxtaposition settles
column5: it makes sense: The song is more beautiful because of that moment of discomfort. Our emotions don't do seamless segueing
column6: Zygadlo seems to be saying
column7: so why should melody-- music's most persuasive narrator-- submit to unnatural
column8: neutered neatness? He signals as such with the title. Melpomene is one of Greek mythology's greatest muses
column9: most commonly associated with tragedy
column10: but her roots lie with watching over melody.

column1: Zygadlo takes many melodic risks on Tragicomedies but doesn't always come up trumps. ""Black Rhino"" is the album's bull in the china shop
column2: a clumsy interlude that feels more than a little naive. ""Waltz for Daphnis"" sounds like a a barbershop quartet crashing a tea dance
column3: in a teeth-grindingly awkward way. That said
column4: the hits far outweigh the misses. ""Russian Dolls"" is a densely layered elastic pop song
column5: veering off course enough to beguile yet snapping back seductively into shape at the last possible second. In stark contrast
column6: ""The Domino Quivers"" is a brooding
column7: bittersweet number that pushes his dubstep beginnings to experimental folk territory
column8: and it's all the better for it. ""Persephone"" is music box pin-perfect. ""The Deaf School"" has a digital funk edge and includes perhaps my favorite modern xylophone bridge
column9: so delicately pretty yet potent enough imbue the rest of the song with its energy. It's those few transient
column10: transformative seconds that we hang on for.

column2: a deeply transformative
column3: intrinsically tragicomic moment hangs at the heart of the album. An accident in Berlin
column4: in which Zygadlo fell through a window and was found by a stranger
column5: which would be slapstick if it wasn't so nearly tragic
column6: is the subject of ""Tragicomedy"". ""You saved my life/ How embarrassing/ You saved my life/ How mortifying
column7: he sings
column8: then a moment later: ""A bloody window/ A broken human."" The song's regret springs from his failure
column9: in the chaotic moment
column10: to thank his stranger-savior. And yet he seems aware of the humor in the situation
column11: the ridiculousness of it. That sense of the ludicrousness of life runs throughout Tragicomedies. It's what gives it its spark and forgives its slip-ups. What remains
column12: however
column13: is his boldness
column14: and his attempt to stretch
column15: successfully for the most part
column16:
mainstream ideas of melody.

column7: be careful if you can

Letting Up Despite Great Faults is really the perfect moniker for this L.A.-via-Austin dream-pop outfit
column3: one that draws attention to its modest intents while demanding a certain ideological investment: Even the act of uttering the band's full name in casual conversation requires a commitment to proper diction. Despite their deceptively daydreamy demeanor
column4: they're a band that makes you work for it. While their second album
column5: Untogether
column6: strongly suggests their definition of an existential crisis amounts to not being able to decide whether their favorite New Order song is ""Age of Consent"" or ""Thieves Like Us""
column7: frontman Michael Lee keeps his hushed
column8: delicate voice at a considerable distance
column9: forcing you to wade through the songs' fuzz-covered jangle and bright synth shimmer to get at their emotional core.

column1: At a time when like-minded contemporaries such as M83 and the Pains of Being Pure at Heart have revealed the commercial potential-- or at least steady festival guarantees-- that can be mined from mid-80s British underground sounds
column2: Letting Up's commitment to their forebears' downsized dimensions and twee-as-fuck temperament seems positively defiant. The band gets considerable mileage out of simplicity: Untogether comes fully stocked with the sort of minimal but richly melodic Bernard Sumner-esque guitar patterns (""Scratch""
column3: ""Take My Jacket Pauline"") and dry-iced
column4: strobe-lit Hacienda flashbacks (""Postcard""
column5: ""Bulletproof Girl"") that make for pure indie pop catnip. And despite working within intimate
column6: drum-machined parameters
column7: the band evinces a greatness of depth to its sound-- upon hearing the baritone guitar hook underpinning the effervescent opener ""Visions""
column8: it's natural to mentally substitute in a cello line.

column1: But while Letting Up are game to mix up their production palette-- the stuttering breakbeat chorus of ""The Best Part"" practically verges on drum'n'bass-- the impact of these 10 songs is dulled by Lee's uniformly smeared
column2: sighing vocals
column3: which are too verbose to serve merely as texture
column4: but too sedate to convincingly communicate the interpersonal narratives seemingly at play here. Whether the lyrics call for a tender affirmation like ""the best part is you
column5: or a biting rebuke like ""I can't believe you said those things to me
column6: the mood is one of constant
column7: hazy-headed serenity; even the secondary vocals of keyboardist Annah Fisette prove to be more of a complement than a counterpoint
column8: a squandered opportunity to introduce some he-said/she-said tension. Ultimately
column9: listening to Untogether feels a lot like receiving a particularly pressing phone call from a significant other in the middle of student-disco dancefloor: You assume what's being said is important and impassioned
column10:
but it's hard to fully connect with the message.

A compilation of unreleased songs and rarities culled from the past five years
column2: Daughter of Cloud could be described as a record geared exclusively toward hardcore Of Montreal fans. Except every Of Montreal record lately seems geared toward a continually shrinking base of diehards. The Athens
column3: Ga.
column4: band has sunk deeper into a rabbit hole of conceptually dense
column5: erratic

column11: psychedelia

column13: musical or otherwise.

column1: A collection of leftovers and buried treasures from Of Montreal's recent period of artistic decline hardly seems enticing
column2: and yet Daughter of Cloud is good enough to justify not completely writing them off just yet. Two of the best tracks-- the spacey country number ""Feminine Effects"" (graced with a beguiling lead vocal by Rebecca Cash) and the fractured dance-pop hip-swinger ""Psychotic Feeling""-- were relegated to a Record Store Day release (in a slightly different version) and an obscure EP respectively. Which is a shame
column3: because they demonstrate that Of Montreal's mastermind Kevin Barnes is still capable of sticking with a single musical idea per song and carrying it out extremely well.

column1: The same goes for other standouts on Daughter of Cloud
column2: including the fantastically poppy acid folk of ""Micro University"" and the beautifully icy ""Noir Blues to Tinnitus""
column3: which moves along on a stunning robotic pulse that Barnes lets slowly unfold and breathe for more than five minutes
column4: without forcefully cramming in three time-signature changes
column5: screaming multi-track vocals
column6: or violently vomiting strings. ""Our Love Is Senile"" is another keeper
column7: with the core tools in Barnes' arsenal-- a disco bassline
column8: snappy guitar lines
column9: aloof dandy vocals-- plied with uncommon focus and restraint.

column2: Daughter of Cloud is a reminder of how good Barnes can be when he imposes discipline on his outsized talent for producing groove-heavy
column3: tuneful psych-rock songs. Unfortunately
column4: Daughter also has plenty of examples of what happened to Of Montreal's music once Barnes grew bored with discipline
column5: and decided to follow his muse blindly down whatever needlessly convoluted avenue it took him. Sizeable swaths of Daughter consist of tracks that simply do not cohere; ""Steppin' Out"" and ""Partizan Terminus""
column6: like so many Of Montreal songs lately
column7: are mini-suites composed of elements that could be developed into several other
column8: better tracks if Barnes didn't just cram them together.

column2: Barnes is a gifted songwriter
column3: musician
column4: and performer capable of making any kind of music he wants
column5: and he's been indulged by those around them to do just that. But
column6: as much of Prince's recorded output illustrates
column7:
absolute freedom to pursue every creative whim no matter how misguided doesn't always (or even frequently) result in mind-blowingly brilliant music. Sometimes it just keeps you locked inside your own head. Daughter of Cloud accurately depicts an artist who has pushed his artistic license to its very limit. It also makes a convincing argument for the virtue of accepting some of those pushed-aside limitations.

column3: the latest full-length from noted boundary-pushing experimental electronic musician Amon Tobin (working here under the pseudonym Two Fingers)
column4: opens with a throbbing sawtooth bassline
column5: breakneck rhythmic turnarounds
column6: and a wobbling midrange synth lead; a baffling move considering that those are the unmistakable trademarks of Americanized dubstep. Tobin has made his name on nearly two decades of highly technical sound manipulation
column7: like the intricately tweaked field recordings that have made up most of his recent output
column8: so a listener initially confronted with ""Stripe Rhythm"" might suspect that the brainy
column9: meticulous knob-twiddler might be having a laugh at the expense of his own reputation as a brainy
column10: meticulous knob-twiddler. Further exploration of the record confirms this suspicion.

column1: Stunt Rhythms is less a fully realized album than a collection of experiments where Tobin messes around with pop music idioms that his snobbier fans might find beneath him: arena EDM
column2: grime
column3: hip-hop. Overall it's like flipping through the sketchbook of a respected conceptual artist only to find it full of expertly rendered pornographic cartoons. Whether it's a unique opportunity to peek into a talented musician's creative process or a throwaway collection of sonic gags depends on your tastes.

column2: Tobin never treats the styles he's dabbling in with condescension. While he toys with listeners' expectations in each of the genres he tackles
column3: he always shows respect for their aesthetic frameworks. When he pushes a style's sonic boundaries
column4: he litters his tracks with nods to some of its defining sounds-- the Beasties-worthy cowbell in the grime-rap hybrid ""Snap""
column5: for instance
column6: or the impressively gnarled synthesizer wub-wubs on the more EDM-leaning tracks. In most of the areas where he's experimenting
column7: a song can live or die based on the novelty of its individual sounds; Tobin's expert ability to warp synths and samples into compellingly twisted one-of-a-kind shapes means most of his genre workouts actually work out.

column1: The cost of all of this casual experimentation is a lack of focus that touches nearly every cut on Stunt Rhythms. Most of the songs clock in close to three minutes
column2: and while this brevity prevents them from overstaying their welcome
column3: it also doesn't leave them much room to go anywhere. Most repeat one or two parts a couple of times and then simply end. This can be frustrating when the song fragments point somewhere interesting. ""Sweden""
column4: with its smeary low end
column5: and ""Defender Rhythm""
column6: which evokes the arcade-era video games
column7: could both work as backing tracks for a sufficiently daring rapper
column8: but if they had something like a defined verse-chorus-verse structure they'd be monsters. On the other hand ""Magoo""-- whose bumptious rhythm
column9: pinched funk keyboards
column10: vowel-y synth croaks
column11: and oblique titular reference seem to suggest Tobin's best Timbaland impression-- gets out of the way just before it starts to get irritating.

column2: Stunt Rhythms has obvious appeal to certain kinds of listeners: DJs of a certain bent have some breaks to work into their sets
column3:
and established Amon Tobin fans will walk away with a new perspective on an established artist. Everyone else will likely want to stick to the more fully realized stuff he releases under his given name.

column12: laudably restrained
column13: risk-averse Earlimart LPs that winds up earning most of its flaws from Earlimart's pursuit of flawnessness.

column2: with Espinoza making ""one last request: forget the past."" It's advice he doesn't seem particularly keen on taking; lest you doubt Earlimart's bona fides when it comes to pop history

column5: and
column6: curiously

column8: and ""I'm Safe Inside"" has a bit of that overcast Summerteeth vibe. But System Preferences is so well-steeped in its influences-- capital-P pop
column9: mostly of the California- or chamber- variety-- it rarely sounds too much like anybody for very long. But therein lies the problem: the melodies at the heart of System Preferences' songs-- warm
column10: uncomplicated

column1: Espinoza's studio know-how's been the saving grace of many a lackluster Earlimart tune going back at least as far as their 2003 peak Everyone Down Here
column2: and he leaves every surface on System Preferences sparkling. Woozy mellotrons and flickering harpsichords play around the edges; each sound's treated or troubled in some way or another. While tarting up their lesser songs has gotten Earlimart through some rough patches in the past
column3: lots of System Preferences' trickery ends up working against it; the fingerpicked flutter of ""Sweater Weather"" and the single-lane power-pop of the horribly named ""Internet Summer"" are both so bright
column4: they're blinding
column5: and many songs feature just a wisp of a countermelody you wish they'd have run with instead of burying in the back of the mix. Still
column6: System Preferences' abundance of surface pleasures give you something to go on when the songs themselves don't; the downtrodden shuffle of ""Crestline
column7: CA."" starts out promisingly enough
column8: but when it slumps into its chorus in an almost grudging fashion
column9: its dazzling arrangement's about all you're left with. ""Lovely Mary Ann""
column10: a psychedelicized post-doo wop number in the vein of Paul McCartney's ""Oh Darlin""
column11: feels like a copy of a copy; you can make out the outlines
column12: but much of the definition's gone. Espinoza's running his high everydude voice through a lot less processing on System Preferences; they wind up sounding like guide vocals
column13: rough outlines in serious need of some personality. If nothing else
column14: this album makes it clearer than ever that Murray's the better singer here
column15: and her two lead vocals-- ""10 Years
column16: ""Get Used to the Sound""-- all but run away with the album.

column1: An orchestral swirl eventually swallows closer ""Over Andover""; birds chirp
column2: a folder is dragged into an electronic dustbin
column3: followed by the familiar slurp of the ""Empty Trash"" sound. This is a dare; Espinoza and Murray know their music isn't fit for one-and-done consumption
column4: that its merits tend to reveal themselves with a little patience. But
column5: while prolonged exposure's been good to past Earlimart LPs
column6: it's not really the case with System Preferences. In pursuit of sophistication
column7: everything's gotten so carefully contoured
column8: so rounded off at the edges
column9: that you just kind of slide right off of it. While it's never less than pleasant
column10: it's rarely all that much more. The overly fussy
column11: played-too-safe System Preferences seems to be begging for a bit of Earlimart's old weirdness
column12: an oddly placed bridge
column13: a couple of bum notes
column14: a ""Burning the Cow""
column15: something. Without it
column16:
this record winds up feeling a little too perfect for its own good.

Around the turn of the millennium
column2: Godspeed You! Black Emperor were the right band at the right time. They arrived with their debut album
column5: when the speed of technology was accelerating
column6: genres were being shuffled
column7: and people were thinking about where music might go. Godspeed
column8: a loose and mysterious collective from Canada (guitarist Efrim Menuck seemed like the leader
column9: but they preferred to be received as a unit) with an anarchist political bent who fused Ennio Morricone
column10: minimalism
column11: found sound
column12: and metal-inflected noise
column13: presented one intriguing possibility.

column1: The group stayed busy during its initial run-- by 2002
column2: when they released Yanqui U.X.O.
column3: they had put out three expansive full-lengths and a long EP-- and then they put Godspeed on the shelf and went away for a while. If they'd never gotten back together and had never released another note of music
column4: it wouldn't have mattered. Their legacy was secure. But Godspeed started playing live again in 2010 and
column5: just as it was when they first came on the scene
column6: they filled a hole in music that we either didn't know existed or had forgotten about. Then
column7: two weeks ago
column8: came the surprise announcement of a new album
column9: Allelujah! Don't Bend! Ascend!
column10: their first in exactly 10 years. Once again
column11: their timing is impeccable. If Godspeed around the turn of the millennium felt like a band of the moment
column12: now
column13: in a time of rapid cultural turnover and bite-sized music consumption
column14: they feel out of step in a very necessary way.

column1: It's tempting to look at Allelujah! through the lens of politics
column2: especially since Godspeed themselves have so often encouraged this viewpoint. When we last heard from them on record
column3: it was a year after 9/11
column4: the invasion of Afghanistan was well underway
column5: and the war in Iraq was just around the corner. We were settling into a decade that was
column6: from an American perspective
column7: defined by two wars started by an increasingly unpopular president and an inflating economic bubble that would pop just as he was leaving office. Their music and presentation drew some of its energy from this anxiety. So listening to new music from Godspeed now-- during an election season
column8: when the wars and the aftermath of that economy are still being argued every day by two presidential candidates grappling with the legacy of the early 2000s-- you can't help but allow the political moment to shape how it's heard.

column1: But the focus on the band's politics obscures something important: Godspeed You! Black Emperor are making art
column2: not writing editorials. And the fact that they are making art gives them leeway to do things that wouldn't work in the context of pure rhetoric. It allows them to find magnificence in destruction and build an aesthetic out of decay and loss. So for all their political slogans
column3: pointed titles
column4: and references to global doom
column5: engagement with Godspeed's music can feel exceedingly personal. When listening to their music
column6: I'm not necessarily thinking about the downtrodden transcending their place in the capitalist hierarchy or the end of the world; I'm thinking about the idea of transcendence
column7: the raw grace of noise
column8: and the tragedy of endings. Godspeed's music works so brilliantly because it can be abstracted and scaled
column9: blown up into an edifice that towers over a continent or shrunk down to something that feels at home in a bedroom. So mapping the contours of their grand music onto your own ordinary life can feel both natural and inspiring.

column2: ""Mladic"" and ""We Drift Like Worried Fire""
column3: have been part of the band's live repertoire since 2003. So the record feels in one sense like Godspeed taking care of unfinished business
column4: presenting existing music from their influential run in a context that showcases its full force and power. Taken together
column5: those tracks serve as a 40-minute summary of everything that made this band great. ""Mladic"" is all gloom and menace
column6: building from an opening vocal snippet
column7: adding pings of guitar
column8: strings that saw away in a Middle Eastern mode
column9: and dark clouds of feedback. This is the Godspeed that learned so much from the pummeling repetition of Swans and the fiendish drama of metal. There's not exactly hope in a track like ""Mladic""
column10: but there is a kind of darkly shaded catharsis. Godspeed have never sounded quite this heavy
column11: and it's especially impressive in how far it can veer from the themes that hold it together without losing the thread.

column1: ""We Drift Like Worried Fire"" is the flip-side of ""Mladic""
column2: both literally and figuratively. For all their grim black-and-white roadside imagery and scenes of destruction
column3: it can be easy to overlook just how joyful Godspeed's music can be. Built around a simple guitar motif consisting of just a few notes
column4: ""Worried Fire"" is one of those accruing pieces that gathers one element after another for 10 minutes until it's so gorgeous you almost can't take it. And at exactly that moment
column5: Godspeed pause and then push the music over the top with an explosion of guitar that snaps everything that came before into focus. ""Worried Fire"" is music that makes you forget about politics and the machinations of the record business and the bullshit of internet chatter and brings you into singularity with the sheer beauty of their sound
column6: music to make you cry with a smile on your face. When it's playing
column7: the rest of the world goes away for 20 minutes.

column1: ""Worried Fire"" is also the kind of song that Godspeed's early peers (Mogwai
column2: Dirty Three) as well as the bands that followed (Explosions in the Sky
column3: Mono) write with some regularity
column4: but they never quite hit these heights. Godspeed have always been about more than volume
column5: more than just addition and subtraction. And if Yanqui found them getting a little too close to their descendants
column6: Allelujah! makes clear that Godspeed will always own this sound. Few can match their feel for arrangement or sense of structure. And the two shorter tracks on this album
column7: ""Their Helicopters' Sing"" and ""Strung Like Lights at Thee Printemps Erable""
column8: are evidence of their infallible ear for texture. They're both rich
column9: dense drones
column10: ""Helicopter"" an especially thick mix of feedback and accordion while ""Strung Like Lights"" is airier and more unstable
column11: not unlike the locked groove that came at the second side of their debut F#A#∞.

column1: In one of the many inserts that came with the vinyl version of that debut
column2: there's a diagram that takes the form of an architectural blueprint. It's called ""Faulty Schematics of Ruined Machine [to Scale]"" and it contains a drawing with four axes marked as Fear
column3: Hope
column4: Desire
column5: and Regret and text describing elements of the diagram in cryptic and desperate language. One paragraph highlights a drawing of a tape loop connected between a distant satellite and a broken tape machine
column6: a loop ""so long it was rocketed thru atmosphere by wigged-out Soviet Cosmonaut... it will take three lifetimes to hear in its entirety."" Godspeed use tape loops
column7: both live and on record
column8: and the key visual element of their shows involves the projection of 16mm film loops by collective member Karl Lemieux. For this band
column9: there's always been something appealing about repeating cycles and rituals-- sounds and images that vanish over the horizon and then come back around again
column10: like the trains that roll by their practice space at Hotel 2 Tango. Planets orbit
column11: people are born and die
column12: and music has a moment and then vanishes before returning again. And so it goes with Allelujah!
column13: an album of music that is both new and old from a band that we thought we might never hear from again
column14:
one we should appreciate while we can.

For a guy whose band is often held up as the epitome of beta-male wimpiness
column2: Benjamin Gibbard writes a lot of mean songs; not passive-aggressive
column3: but genuinely cruel. Death Cab For Cutie managed to pull off ""Cath…""
column4: ""Styrofoam Plates""
column5: and especially ""Tiny Vessels"" because Gibbard rarely writes in a way that makes you think he's talking about himself; Codes & Keys generated most of its lyrics from autobiography
column6: and it's the happiest Death Cab album. This sets up Former Lives in an interesting way. It's the first LP Gibbard is releasing under his own name and also the first music he's released since a very public split with Zooey Deschanel
column7: the inspiration for much of Codes & Keys
column8: which is now an album that's actually way more interesting in hindsight. If there was ever a time for Gibbard to get mean and get personal
column9: it's here. Instead
column10: Former Lives collects 12 songs that span ""eight years
column11: three relationships
column12: living in two different places
column13: drinking then not drinking
column14: but somehow feel impersonal
column15: like their main goal was to sound like they could come from someone other than Ben Gibbard.

column1: It's probably coincidental that the cover art of Former Lives bears a strange resemblance to that of 2008's Narrow Stairs
column2: though the juxtaposition of these two records does help elucidate Gibbard's shift in songwriting as a solo artist. In 2009
column3: he attempted to connect with a darker
column4: more intoxicated source of inspiration by communing with the spirit of Jack Kerouac at Big Sur on One Fast Move or I'm Gone
column5: a collaboration with Son Volt's Jay Farrar. On Former Lives
column6: he travels further down the 101 for Los Angeles and specifically the Largo nightclub
column7: agora for the city's mature singer-songwriters and their accomplices
column8: people like Aimee Mann
column9: Jon Brion
column10: and Grant Lee Phillips. They're often called ""classicist"" and ""mature"" artists
column11: and with the glaring exception of Fiona Apple
column12: carry themselves more like artisans than artistes.

column1: Mann is one of the L.A.-based well-wishers who contribute to Former Lives
column2: and from the outset
column3: it feels like Gibbard is trying to make them feel at home. The minute-long intro ""Shepherd's Bush Lullaby"" has a couple of lines that are tempting to read into (""As you sleep an ocean away/ Know that I love you/ My every thought is of you/ The clouds are beginning to break"")
column4: yet the focus is entirely on its comparatively outré a cappella harmonies. Same with ""Dream Song""; lyrically
column5: it's pure Gibbard
column6: a winding yarn of a couple's sleep states that deals completely in the unsaid and never leaves the space between his own ears. But the tack pianos
column7: stuffy Britpop shuffle
column8: and up-front vocals recall the production on Elliott Smith's ""Los Angeles"" album Figure 8
column9: the one where his jones for canonical songwriting similarly left his usually candid lyrics prone to glib formula. Likewise
column10: on the he-said/she-said
column11: post-marital post-mortem of ""Bigger Than Love""
column12: Mann's voice is ingrained with typically hard-won wisdom and disappointment
column13: whereas Gibbard sounds like he has since the beginning
column14: which is to say
column15: boyish and innocent; the dissonance in age makes for an inspired
column16: but miscast duet.

column2: the songs on Former Lives boast an undeniable melodic sense. Even as he shifts from his typically elliptical songwriting to more structure-bound forms
column3: he never sounds overly fussy. It makes Former Lives a brisk listen even when the songs themselves aren't particularly innovative; ""Lily"" and ""A Hard One to Know"" are Gibbard's shots at silly and sweet McCartney-styled love songs that are ephemerally enjoyable and vanish on contact due to an aggressive lack of specifics. Especially with ""Lily""
column4: you're tempted to sub in a pretty similar first name so that puffy lyrics like ""Lily's the Pacific Ocean and I'm standing at her shore"" can scan as something other than puffy poetry.

column2: ""Teardrop Windows"" boasts a superb
column3: instantly memorable verse melody and a conceit that's wholly Gibbard's own; granting Seattle's Smith Tower the capability of being catatonically depressed might initially appear like the most blatant example of Gibbard's self-conscious attempts to be selfless
column4: but then again
column5: here's a guy who was able to survey the entire dissolution of a relationship in the time it took to look in his glove compartment. It's a shame he has to tack on ""he's lonely just like me and you"" to underline what was a fairly obvious premise. Even more blatant is ""Oh
column6: Woe"" which tries to personify sadness in the same manner as the National's ""Sorrow"" did
column7: but ends up zealously overwritten and equally underdeveloped.

column1: And that's really what Former Lives comes down to
column2: that Gibbard's eight years of solo writing is content to manifest as an application into Largo's Singer-Songwriter Finishing School rather than anything that packs the idiosyncrasy
column3: resonance
column4: or mannered experimentation that he's capable of. Whereas Gibbard uses gloopy metaphor and cloying rhyme within Death Cab to open up new possibilities for emotional expression
column5: Former Lives employs the same methods to ultimately insulate songs that don't have much of a core. You don't get to really know the subject of ""Duncan
column6: Where Have You Gone?""; you feel happy for Gibbard that he's getting to work with Aimee Mann. The ambiguity of Gibbard's southern sojourn ""Something's Rattling (Cowpoke)"" leaves you little to connect with other than the wafts of Tex-Mex horns. Who knows if this would've been better or far worse had Gibbard gone all Heartbreaker on us
column7: but I can't help but remember his cruelest line to date when it comes to Former Lives' pretty vacancy: It's beautiful
column8:
but it don't mean a thing to me.

The music made by Matmos has a distinctly corporeal hue. Sometime Pitchfork contributor Drew Daniel and his partner M.C. Schmidt entered operating rooms to sample liposuctions
column2: plastic surgeries
column3: bonesaws
column4: and other medical procedures for their 2001 album A Chance to Cut Is a Chance to Cure. Their work has been constructed from bowed rat cages and the slow plod of feet traipsing through a box of gravel; it's far more tactile than anything usually described as ""electronic"". Even earlier tracks such as ""It Seems"" and ""Schluss"" (from Matmos) were so abundantly expressive it felt like they were stretching into the physical world. With The Ganzfeld
column5: a three-track EP released as an extension of the central concept of their forthcoming LP The Marriage of True Minds
column6: Daniel and Schmidt have plunged inward for inspiration. This is music based around a series of parapsychological experiments conducted by the pair
column7: an attempt to turn cognitive behavior into something tangible to funnel into their work.

column2: the ambition here is bold
column3: both in the base concept and its execution. Two of the three tracks are pulled from the psychology sessions
column4: hinting at the density of thought and vision to follow. This EP is named after a strain of testing for ESP devised in the 1930s
column5: the same experiment the duo adapted for their tests: They conducted experiments over a four-year period in which test subjects were blasted with white noise in a state of sensory deprivation. Daniel attempted to transmit the concept of the band's new album into their minds
column6: with his subjects' resultant thoughts forming the basis for the music on The Marriage of True Minds. If this release can be used as a barometer of what's to come on the full length
column7: expect something strung up between Wagnerian grandiosity and delirious cacophony
column8: executed with the brilliant detail of prior Matmos recordings.

column1: ""Very Large Green Triangles (Edit)"" resides in the same kind of gloriously aloof space Trevor Horn often sought out with his ZZT productions-- Propaganda's imposing ""Dr. Mabuse"" comes to mind. There's also a playful sense of exploration
column2: occasionally mirroring the musical foibles that Dieter Meier and Boris Blank bring to Yello. It suggests The Marriage of True Minds is a surge toward a much bigger place than Matmos have worked in before. If so
column3: it's a fitting change
column4: and one that mirrors the scope of the prep work undertaken. But the near 13-minute ""Just Waves"" hints that the broader strokes may not be easily palatable. It's mostly constructed from voices piled on top of one another
column5: creating a feeling akin to standing in the corner at a party and listening to conversations overlapping with one another
column6: crafting their own peculiar forms and rhythms in the process.

column1: Matmos have made a career out of trading in those kind of contorted notes and figures
column2: so it's disappointing to find the rote club reworking of ""You"" at the heart of this EP. There's nothing about it that ties into the work elsewhere
column3: providing a jarring and unwelcome detraction from the program. It always feels like Matmos spend a great deal of time thinking about their approach
column4: taking one step forward then diagrammatically mapping out how that step was taken to determine how they can put a different spin on it. ""You"" may be lacking in that
column5: but when ""Just Waves"" is stripped down to a single voice
column6: it's a pleasingly perplexing sensation
column7: brought about because it actually feels less logical than the battering ram of intersecting dialogue that preceded it. The ability to draw a sharp outline around the unfamiliar
column8: to draw definition from abstraction
column9: is something Matmos excel at
column10:
and this EP suggests all the pieces are in place for The Marriage of True Minds to extend that strand in beguiling ways.

Young Dro is an unspectacularly spectacular rapper. He's humbly astonishing. How to explain this guy? He's more agile
column2: more playful
column3: and more confident than most; almost everything that comes out of his mouth sounds catchy
column4: even when he's just ranting semi-incomprehensibly in skits about how fresh he is. The ""should be famous"" line is a tired one

column7: (""Shoulder Lean"")

column1: The Local Rapper Who Just Can't Get Over is everywhere
column2: in every city-- here in NYC
column3: we have Jadakiss
column4: their grumpy-uncle patron saint

column6: Peedi Crakk) to Chicago (Bump J) to L.A. (Kurupt

column7: partly thanks to the involvement of DJ Burn One
column8: an Atlanta rap producer with an unwavering devotion to the heavier
column9: humid end of Atlanta's heritage. The two previously collaborated on Future Legends
column10: Vol. 2; with Burn One curating
column11: Young Dro's occasional reliance on cheap-sounding beats disappears.

column1: Dro can loop rings around any wide-open
column2: Southern beat you give him: If you hand him an instrumental made up of just a few bleeps and an 808 clap

column4: he will make it feel like a piece of Silly Putty in seconds. <span>If you sit him back in a plush piece of after-party VIP-room rap (""On Set"")

column6: colorful slang
column7: and the occasional paper-cut-size confessional (""Momma get sicker
column8: she need a liver"") and his sense of rhythm is mind-boggling. When he flexes effortlessly into double-time

column1: When Young Dro gets soulful or quiet
column2: he sounds a little less comfortable: ""She Gone"" is a slightly awkward remorseful-player song
column3: ""Dreamer"" a slightly strained achiever's anthem. But when he just lets his mind and mouth fly

column5: he sets up the line ""supermodel bitches flying down from New Zealand"" just so he can rack up a series of increasingly dazzling slant rhymes for  it: ""my boo vegan"" and ""a pound of new tree
column6: and"" are two highlights. It's like watching someone pound you in Words With Friends while simultaneously cooking dinner and moonwalking. It seems unfair
column7: somehow. All said
column8: Ralph Lauren Reefa is one of his strongest tapes in a while
column9: showing him at his lyrical
column10: funny
column11: vivid
column12:
local-hero best.

You'd be forgiven for thinking that New York experimental metal quartet Car Bomb were a Meshuggah tribute band. The interplay between guitarist Greg Kubacki and drummer Elliot Hoffman does feature a lot of that tight mechanical syncopation that Meshuggah have made a career out of. That conjoined gunfire staccato is unmistakable. There are imitators
column2: and there are groups who understand the essence
column3: the soul of a group and build upon that distinctive sound. Car Bomb fall in the latter group. Centralia
column4: Car Bomb's debut from 2007
column5: displayed the Meshuggah influence greatly
column6: and while it's still prevalent on their new self-released record
column7: w^w^^w^w (pronounced “w click w”)
column8: Car Bomb are branching out and becoming their own group.

column2: but it gets to breathe more on w^w^^w^w. Vocalist Michael Dafferner is largely responsible
column3: as he has a voice for radio but also plays in an extreme metal group. Dafferner's ""woos!"" at the beginning and end of ""Finish It"" suggest a playfulness not found in their comparably harsh
column4: but less flexible peers. Some of the best technical groups
column5: like Rush

column8: let the listener know that despite their wide-ranging influences and knowledge of theory
column9: they can still be pretty silly guys at heart. Car Bomb aren't as cheeky
column10: but there are still shades of absurdity that can elicit a chuckle or two. On closing track ""The Seconds""
column11: the band has never been more accessible. Like most of the songs
column12: it leads off with the dependable robotic attack
column13: then 2:04 hits and you might think you've stumbled upon a lost Deftones chorus. ""Seconds"" eventually breaks into Kubacki employing acoustic guitars under the electric chords building
column14: almost as if the album needed an ambient section. There are similar Deftones-esque moments on ""Magic Bullet"" and ""Lower the Blade""
column15: more songs that could exist in a parallel universe alternative-rock station. Still
column16: these clean vocal parts sound alien and foreign amongst all the clanging and slamming. It's not as if the band is hesitant to utilize less abrasive sounds
column17: they just mold them to fit with the overall chaotic
column18: futuristic nature of their compositions.

column2: the pounding lock-step rhythms are still the core of the band
column3: and w^w^^w^w ranks among the year's most unrelenting records. ""The Sentinel"" immediately bombards you with that chokehold; there's no premonition to prepare you for what's to come. Those rhythms carry the majority of the record. Car Bomb have cited IDM (Intelligent Dance Music) as an influence
column4: and Kubacki's leads are the most readily apparent aspect of this. His Digitech Whammy abuse is best manifested on the lead breaks on ""Sentinel""

column10: but it's always just the right amount. At 50 minutes

column1: Car Bomb started off on Relapse but didn't quite get the attention that label tends to garner. Whether or not the group's musical growth is tied to their break-off with Relapse
column2:
they clearly did not need the label's support to make such progress. Meshuggah were on Ozzfest once; Car Bomb may get a shot at Rockstar Mayhem if things play out like that.
