The brilliant hardcore band Converge have been around a long time
column2: though you might not guess it from the manic energy crammed into their eighth album
column3: All We Love We Leave Behind. If you go beyond the amped
column4: break-neck intensity and listen to the compositions
column5: it becomes clear the Boston band is nearing the 25-year mark: You don't just show up and write songs like this.

column1: One of the quartet's not-so-secret weapons is Kurt Ballou
column2: the guitarist (and backing vocalist
column3: bassist
column4: keyboardist
column5: etc.)
column6: who happens to be one of the most well-regarded engineers in heavy music and an endless tinkerer who'd build a snare from scratch if it meant getting the sound he needed. The central core of vocalist/in-house artist Jacob Bannon and Ballou-- along with bassist Nate Newton and drummer Ben Koller
column7: who both joined in 1999-- have been together long enough to know each other very well
column8: and to play almost entirely to their own strengths. As such
column9: there's never a dull moment across AWLWLB's 38 minutes. It's all peaks.

column1: The record is the logical followup to 2009's Axe to Fall
column2: my favorite record that year. Axe included a large supporting cast of friends and fellow travelers from Cave In
column3: Disfear
column4: Genghis Tron
column5: the Red Chord
column6: and Neurosis. It ended with a seven-minute song that seemed to include them all. When I spoke with Converge frontman Jacob Bannon a few weeks ago about AWLWLB
column7: he said Axe to Fall had been the ""collaborative concept taken to the extreme."" This time
column8: it's just the band and the watchful ear of Ballou. As Bannon put it
column9: ""There's no artificial distortion
column10: triggers
column11: or Auto-Tune on this album. It's all organic
column12: it's real sounds that capture the way the band performs live.""

column1: From opener (and first single) ""Aimless Arrow"" onward
column2: the music here is mostly fast
column3: compact
column4: and coiled. That's Converge in general
column5: but they've distilled the elements to even tauter extremes this time. The technical mastery is mind-blowing
column6: as is the way they manage to squeeze in brutal melodies and hooks. The vocal lines seem to be woven into the guitars
column7: to which they've also added a bluesier feel
column8: a detail that reminds me of the classic post-Negative Approach Touch and Go band Laughing Hyenas-- or even the Jesus Lizard. It's a streamlined
column9: live-sounding collection that can feel like one giant kick to the head. But they know when to give
column10: take
column11: and plop in a slow-grind blues riff. Tracks overlap and echo. When they slow things down to a momentary crawl with the album's longest song
column12: the five-minute doom ballad ""Coral Blue""
column13: it's like a chair's been pulled out from behind you. You get that in the middle of the two-minute ""Empty on the Inside"" as well as the instrumental ""Precipice""
column14: an interstitial piece with piano
column15: clean guitars
column16: psychedelic soloing guitars
column17:
and deep-factory/chain-gang percussion. ""All We Love We Leave Behind"" picks all of that up gorgeously.

As overwhelming as AWLWLB may be on first listen
column18: it's really not all speed. There's a thing people say about young professional quarterbacks
column19: about how they need experience before the game ""slows down."" You get that on this album
column20: too. In my interview with Bannon
column21: he said: ""I feel that the current generation of listeners of heavy music are progressing a bit past their gateway bands and are digging deeper than they used to and understanding more abrasive and complex music and art. It's like being around an unfamiliar language long enough that it eventually begins to make sense."" I agree with this
column22: and it's the reason why Converge are a band with plenty of fans who weren't close to being born when the band formed in 1990.

column2: there's plenty for older audiences
column3: too-- aging
column4: death
column5: decisions
column6: punk as a way of life
column7: and the way these things preoccupy you when you go past 30 are largely what this album is about. (It all opens with ""Aimless Arrow""'s ""To live the life you want/ You've abandoned those in need""). Bannon describes the grizzled two-minute anthem ""Shame in the Way"" as a song about ""feeling fragmented from the traditional concept of family."" He adds
column8: ""As I've gotten older
column9: I've worked on mending the things I can
column10: while being conscious of the things I can't repair."" You get this on the genuinely moving title track
column11: too. Bannon calls it ""an open letter to the things that I feel I've left behind in order to pursue an artistic and musical direction in my life."" He says it was inspired in part by the death of his beloved dog
column12: Anna Belle
column13: but there's a lot more than that here: It's a classic hardcore anthem
column14: one that looks at the decision to live a life in a particular way
column15: and it might bring you to tears if you hear it right. Really
column16: more than the past couple of Converge albums
column17: AWLWLB feels like a hardcore record.

column1: We live in a period of compression
column2: where there's more stimulation and less time for reflection-- but we're also continually presented with a repackaged
column3: slightly off past. Nostalgia is music's biggest seller
column4: it seems. The thing is
column5: underground bands that formed in 1990 are often getting back together in 2012 for reunion tours
column6: not eighth albums. The irony of the title
column7: of course
column8: is that Converge are also a lesson in not leaving behind what matters. ""Predatory Glow"" ends the record with the lines: ""Let the future know/ I won't be there tomorrow/ Let the past know/ I gave them my all/ I'm aching for an end/ Grown thinner every day/ I bow down to you/ Extinguished youth."" When I asked about the song
column9: Bannon explained: ""I am far from an 'old' person in human terms
column10: however I've spent over half my life immersed in the punk rock and hardcore community. I am not wholly defined by that as a person
column11: but it is something that has been part of me for a long time.""

column2: until he dies. AWLWLB is an example of building on and mastering the music you loved when you were younger-- something that became more than music
column3:
ultimately-- so that it has a chance to grow old with you without becoming any less vital.

column6: which feature Earl Sweatshirt and Frank Ocean
column7: respectively

column3: whether he's playfully pawing at your face with sampled guitars on ""P2"" or pounding out radio-ready synth melodies as on ""Astro""
column4: is fantastic. His beats are mostly built from the noise up

column5:
and that's something it never quite seemed they would be.

Heavy metal and the church have always been uneasy bedfellows. While ""Christian metal"" is somehow still a thing
column2: its converse is far more prevalent. Satan worship is nearly a given in certain subgenres (lookin' at you
column3: black metal) and a near-universal scorn for religious dogma fuels a good number of thrash
column4: death
column5: grind
column6: and otherwise records. Simply enough
column7: Jesus is not our homeboy. That's why an entity like Sabbath Assembly puzzles as much as it intrigues-- those unearthly purveyors of both darkness and light are not only welcome
column8: but celebrated in joyous hymn. To be fair

column10: but the intent is more sinister than any Gorgoroth recording. Sure
column11: garbled odes to Baphomet are cool and all

column13: and Sabbath Assembly tap into that rotten inner core in a disarmingly palatable way.

column1: The addition of Throbbing Gristle's Genesis P-Orridge as ""High Priest(ess)"" (or narrator
column2: if you hate fun) adds a wild element to the proceedings. Her dry
column3: matter-of-fact proclamations about the nature of love
column4: death
column5: God
column6: and Satan float in and out of the flowery arrangements like an old black crow worrying a brace of songbirds. Taken out of context
column7: these songs sound sweet
column8: gentle
column9: and utterly innocuous; once their esoteric origins are factored in
column10: though
column11: there's something about those clear notes
column12: jaunty gospel shuffles
column13: and heavenly uplifted voices that's downright unnerving. It's a bit of a headfuck listening to poppy tunes that wouldn't have been out of place in the opening minutes of the dreaded Catholic school classes of my youth
column14: and yet those clear
column15: angelic voices are singing sweetly of Lucifer and the end of days. ""Christ
column16: You Bring the End"" is not exactly ""The Lord's Prayer""
column17: but then again
column18: the Gnostic rhetoric of the Process Church of the Final Judgment inhabits realms that stretch far beyond that homely little church in Tabernacle
column19: New Jersey.

column1: This is Sabbath Assembly's second recorded outing
column2: and one that comes as a bit of a surprise to anyone who paid attention to their first release and the ensuing spate of live shows and festival appearances that followed. At first
column3: it seemed as though Restored to One would be marked down in the book of rock history as a one-off project
column4: albeit one of its more intriguing entries. Even founder and helmsman David Nuss seemed unsure about the band's future in inteviews
column5: but as it's become apparent
column6: there's plenty more source material to mine and corners of the world to invade with song and strangeness. ""Ye Are Gods"" features a new singer
column7: Jamie Myers (Hammers of Misfortune
column8: Wolves in the Throne Room) whose breathy
column9: saccharine vocals replace Jex Thoth's more throaty delivery.

column2: conveyed through lyrics and proclamations
column3: so Myers' voice is front and center. The musical accompaniment meanders through genres and decades
column4: taking a hit of 60s psychedelia here
column5: gently ripping off Coven there
column6: raising up to gospel heights and cruising back down into poppier territory. Oddball neofolk acts like Nest
column7: Lasher Keen
column8: and the Moon Lay Hidden Beneath A Cloud seem to serve as an inadvertent influence
column9: and while groovy classic rock forms the bedrock
column10: Nuss and guitarist Imaad Wasif play around with all manner of tones and sounds to achieve that eerily mellow vibe. ""Exit"" opens with a moody organ overture before going full-on Pink Floydian stomp
column11: while ""We Come From the One"" is all creepy bongos and ominous spoken word. ""Bless Our Lord and Master"" starts off with tinny chimes and a warm-voiced chorus
column12: then builds into unexpected bombast before fading out into the delicate
column13: thrumming folk of ""We Give Our Lives"". ""Christ You Bring the End"" is a nearly acoustic ode to the bringer of doom
column14: and the mass keeps going-- but you're still on the edge of your seat instead of asleep on your pious grandma's shoulder.

column5: dry note. Sabbath Assembly clearly chose to close the ceremony in this fashion in order to throw one last spotlight onto their purpose and source material. The message is everything

its messengers have once more done a fine job doing God's-- and the Devil's-- work.

column11: and acquaintances: a scene partly driven by a competitive spirit to outdo what they would hear from their peers on the air or in the club

column5: Spyro is already a veteran: His first Rinse mix came out in 2009
column6: he serves as DJ for Tinchy Stryder (like Dizzee Rascal

column2: it wasn't a sure thing that Ladyhawk were going to release another album. The Vancouver four piece was destined for cult status
column3: haunting bars as hometown heroes

column5: getting high out of my mind

column2: No Can Do feels slight

Trash Talk's 119 comes with a narrative that's as old as the dichotomy between the mainstream and the underground. The ferocious Sacramento hardcore band rose to national prominence on the strength of its last two records-- 2010's Eyes & Nines and 2011's Awake EP-- which shored up underground punk tradition with the straightforward evangelism of bare-knuckle Luddites. Trash Talk didn't push the hardcore envelope
column2: and that was the point: their job was to keep the flame going by spitting gasoline into its dying embers.

column4: the Sony-distributed label founded by the controversial L.A. rap collective. The association with Odd Future suits Trash Talk's hyper-aggressive
column5: hyper-angry
column6: hyper-male music

column7: say

column10: however

column1: Pawlowitz hasn't stepped back from The Traveller's rhythmic hinterlands so much as worked to reterritorialize those spaces within more conventional techno settings. But The Killer makes the most immediate case yet for Shed's decision to chart a course through (rather than with or against) the currents of contemporary techno. If only all headscratching felt so good.

Weapon are an atypical band. Blackened death acts are a dime a dozen
column2: but the really good ones are more difficult to find. Even among that elite group
column3: the pickings get slimmer as ideas get staler and the same riff seems to surface almost as often as that one awkward guy from Chem class who never quite learned to take a hint. Now
column4: enter Weapon. Even within a field populated by those who take pride in slicing against the grain
column5: founding vocalist/guitarist Vetis Monarch and his cohorts reach as far outside the box as they can without turning their backs on the subterranean darkness from whence they came. On 2009's Drakonian Paradigm
column6: they set their sights on greatness
column7: with 201o's From the Devil’s Tomb they took aim
column8: and now
column9: on Embers and Revelations
column10: they pull the trigger.

column1: While the highly listenable From the Devil's Tomb was a loose
column2: depraved affair
column3: steeped in the atmosphere and elements of its Canada-based
column4: Bangladesh-born creator's Eastern upbringing (summed up perfectly in the serpentine ""Lefthandpathyoga"")
column5: its successor is more of a challenge. It's leaner
column6: more focused
column7: and utterly relentless
column8: with riffs sharpened by genuine hatred and Satanic conviction. Vetis takes the lead role when it comes to guitars and vocals
column9: but he's now joined by second guitarist Rom Surtr
column10: whose skill is felt in the complex
column11: engaging structures of the songs. The drumming is inhumanly precise
column12: executed by the Disciple (formerly of influential Canadian black metal experimentalists Rites of Thy Degringolade) and Kha Tumos' basslines sport a rich
column13: resonating tone that menaces as much as it anchors. The chemistry between the band's members is apparent
column14: and the attention to detail is near-fanatical.

column2: almost startlingly pretty opening salvo of ""Liber Lilith""
column3: gone are the stealthy
column4: slinky melodies and exotic scales that once served as Weapon's primary defense against being lumped in with those of a more homogenous ilk. They've replaced these elements with vitriol and venom. ""Embers and Revelations"" is a snarling beast
column5: all punishing intensity and manic leads. There are moments of murky
column6: churning simplicity
column7: like the malevolent dirge of ""Disavowing Each in Aum"" or doomy middle passage on ""Grotesque Carven Portal""
column8: and a few sparse but effective
column9: not to mention beautifully rendered
column10: moments of calm (most notably heard in the first few moments of album closer ""Shahenshah""). At its core
column11: though
column12: the album is black/death
column13: despite its refusal to stay shackled to such a colorless descriptor. Those genre lines blur
column14: and those elements that belong to Weapon-- and only Weapon-- cannot be contained. To make it easy on a casual metal listener
column15: imagine a particularly unholy blend of Belphegor
column16: Melechesh
column17: Nile
column18: Watain
column19: and Behemoth. Now add in some Master's Hammer worship and vintage Morbid Angel appreciation
column20: tattoo it with Kali's name
column21: hand it a knife
column22: then leave it to die on an unnamed street corner in any hot

column1: Embers and Revelations revels in Satanic majesty and sensuous filth. The lyrics
column2: delivered in Vetis' largely decipherable mid-range growl
column3: range from pure nihilism to sexual perversion and the despoilment of the sacred. His Eastern roots and Satanic faith surface once again
column4: and there is a strangely poetic feel to the deviance and inhumanity of Vetis' words
column5: made all the more unsettling by how clearly they resonate. On ""Liber Lilith""
column6: for example
column7: he invokes the antithesis of feminine virtue like so: ""Vile temptress
column8: Goddess ov Drakon! Initiator of perversion in mankind!/ Let the phalli of murderers glow within Thy orifice of defecation/ O
column9: ravishing Queen of noxious blood!/ He who repudiates Thy pulsating cunt/ Shall yield to strangulation by the severed
column10: umbilical cord of a fetus.""

column1: Weapon's Relapse debut has garnered them far more attention than their past releases
column2: and their recent spate of touring alongside Marduk and 1349 went a long way toward raising their profile in the states
column3: but one gets the feeling that this is only the beginning. Ember and Revelations is an addictive listen
column4: and a dangerous one at that: In Weapon's world
column5:
Satan lives and humanity is divided into those who walk with him and those who cower before him. When's the last time you prayed?

""My favorite time was around when the sun came up
column2: Boston-based musician Ricardo Donoso recently recalled when discussing the dance parties he attended as a youth in Brazil. ""The music got slower... the floor would be much emptier and
column3: more often than not
column4: you were surrounded by amazing landscapes."" Those memories serve as a good description of Donoso's solo synth work. It's a kind of dream-state dance music
column5: filled with rippling light and vivid atmospheres
column6: and devoid of hard
column7: four-on-the-floor beats. In fact
column8: there are no drums in Donoso's pulsing tunes. All the rhythm-- and there's a lot of it-- is created through timing and momentum.

column2: Donoso's second solo album
column3: has roots in his dance/techno background
column4: but stretches toward the minimalist flights of Terry Riley
column5: the Kraut trance of Cluster
column6: the spaced-out arpeggios of early Oneohtrix Point Never
column7: and film scores like John Carpenter's horror themes or Tangerine Dream's bubbling soundtracks. Donoso is familiar with genre-crossing-- he's played drums in improv-jazz and avant-metal groups
column8: and his duo Perispirit veers toward all-out noise. But he melds these strains naturally
column9: never jamming them together or grasping for superficial variety.

column2: the 10 songs spread over these two LPs are pretty simple. Each starts with a basic
column3: insistent synth figure
column4: which slowly overlaps with similar lines while simultaneously gathering chords and accents. But as active as these tracks are
column5: they are rarely dense and never blurry. Donoso uses space and staccato to maintain clarity; everything he's doing is always out in the open. And though he's into repetition
column6: he also has a knack for song structure. Each tune progresses with discernible shifts that create drama in loops of tension and release.

column2: those loops intertwine with looser abstraction. On ""Chemical Structures""
column3: a reflecting synth riff spawns crescendos without wavering from its solid cycle. Similar waves course through ""The Bow and the Lyre""
column4: but Donoso continually adds rippling echoes
column5: the sonic equivalent of pelting a lake with different-sized pebbles. Most remarkable is closer ""Renunciation""
column6: whose swarm of small sounds creates a bright buzz
column7: like a symphony of crickets coaxing a sunrise.

column1: Which again suggests that Donoso's music evokes the morning end of an all-night party. The title
column2: Assimilating the Shadow
column3: itself seems to allude to that surreal time when the sun fades in
column4: swallowing the darkness as it rises. But according to press notes
column5: it's a reference to Carl Jung's claim that ""everyone carries a shadow."" That works too-- there's an undercurrent of foreboding in these compositions
column6: an ominous sense that danger lurks on the horizon of Donoso's rolling sounds. Yet nearly every moment is also calm and soothing
column7: as easy to zone out to as it is to get chills from. Perhaps that's the strength of his music-- as simple as it sounds at first
column8:
repeat listens reveal something wider and deeper going on.

If their debut was any indication
column2: Tame Impala's second full-length

column5: they've failed and ended up with something more fascinating. Sure
column6: there's merit to the countless groups and scenes that seek out the right tube amps and compressors and microphones in order to create flawless period pieces. They're often called ""revivalists
column7: even though the actual term is wasted on them. Are they really breathing new life into this form by keeping it cryogenically frozen in ideas nearly a half-century old? Tame Impala prove far more exciting because
column8: by maximizing the use of the available technology
column9: they tap into the progressive and experimental spirit of psychedelic rock
column10: and not just the sound.

column1: Tame Impala did something similar on 2010's Innerspeaker
column2: and they might be open to ""Same Impala""-type jokes if the expanse of psychedelic rock were something you'd be expected to move on from after one record. Lonerism does make the kind of tune-ups that typically generate a lot of second LP plaudits: It's leaner
column3: more propulsive

column5: and less beholden to its influences. But Lonerism's genius manifests itself in Tame Impala's ability to figure out a way to integrate the concepts of electronic music-making without resorting to ripping off the breakbeat/Beatles template of ""Setting Sun"".

column1: Leader Kevin Parker doesn't sound like an electronic producer
column2: he just thinks like one. He sees his songs as blank canvases rather than boxed-in verse/chorus structures while emphasizing fluidity
column3: constant motion
column4: and textural evolution. You could spend the entirety of opener ""Be Above It"" letting your ears luxuriate in the diversity of tactile sensations-- the subliminal whisper of the title becomes a rhythm track
column5: a barreling drum break is severely tweaked to sound like an oncoming rush of bison
column6: a flanged guitar wobbles like neon Jello
column7: and Parker's laconic
column8: slightly echoed vocals pulls the whole thing together. Lonerism could go anywhere from that point
column9: which is confirmed by the majestic song that follows
column10: ""Endors Toi"". Follow the regal path of the lead synth or tilt your ears towards the righteously loud drum rolls that sound like masterfully chopped Bonham/Moon samples. I'm reminded of Radiohead's stated goal on ""Airbag""
column11: which was to recreate Endtroducing..... in real time
column12: or what DJ Shadow himself has been trying to do ever since in terms of merging the rarest vinyl grooves with your stony older brother's record collection.

column1: Those are the first two songs on Lonerism
column2: and it's bold to lead off with seven minutes of mostly instrumentals. Yet for all of the sonic trickery
column3: Tame Impala are anchored by the righteous aspects of classic rock. They're throwbacks in the sense that they operate from a pre-punk perspective where each musician has the chops and confidence to be capable of soloing
column4: and the singer and the drummer were cranked loud as hell. Yes
column5: Parker does sound like John Lennon. Many athletes pattern their golf swings after Tiger Woods
column6: their batting stance on Barry Bonds
column7: or stick out their tongue while taking a jump shot like Michael Jordan. It means little if you don't have the skills to connect and perform.

column1: More important is how Parker writes melodies that are instantly memorable
column2: that rise and fall with beautiful simplicity and give what are fairly basic and relatable sentiments heft. Lonerism lacks a chorus that instantly pops like ""Solitude Is Bliss""
column3: which is an issue only if you think the best melodies necessarily need to appear in the middle of the song. You'd be hard-pressed to find hooks as catchy as the verses during the run that spans ""Music to Walk Home By"" through ""Elephant""
column4: and while none initially stands out as the kind of hit that might push Tame Impala to bigger festival stages
column5: the cumulative effect means Lonerism might.

column2: the above is all well and good for the people who might use Lonerism to EQ their hi-fis. Does it make you feel anything? On Innerspeaker
column3: Parker sang
column4: ""You will never come close to how I feel
column5: so what's the emotional component to Lonerism? Though Parker's lyrics are plainspoken and occasionally a little elusive
column6: Tame Impala's two records are called Innerspeaker and Lonerism
column7: some of their songs go by titles like ""Solitude Is Bliss""
column8: ""Why Won't They Talk to Me?""
column9: ""Island Walking""
column10: and ""Mind Mischief"". You get the idea of where Parker's head is at
column11: or more to the point

column1: That's a fairly common concern in this realm. You think about most of the technophile
column2: prog-rock opuses of recent decades and most sound like spiritual heirs of King Crimson
column3: Pink Floyd
column4: or Black Sabbath; records like Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness
column5: Kid A
column6: and The Moon & Antarctica tell the listener that their state of being is forced upon them
column7: by shadowy governments
column8: by heartless technology
column9: by an uncaring god. It justifies the headphones-bound quarantine. What distinguishes Tame Impala is how they are able to explore the emotional difference between being alone and being isolated. Jayson Greene described Parker's voice vividly as ""like someone trapped John Lennon's vocal take from 'A Day in the Life' in a jar and taught it to sing new songs."" In terms of a mentality
column10: to me it's more along the lines of ""I'm Only Sleeping""
column11: embodying and advocating a wakeful and passive state of psychedelia.

column1: Lonerism derives much of its philosophical and musical pleasure from this interaction of micro and macro. Tame Impala stack vocal and guitar harmonies on the loveably hungover ""Mind Mischief""
column2: and then Parker and co-producer Dave Fridmann take control of the mixing consoles and shake the whole thing up like a snowglobe. A similarly fun trick happens on ""Apocalypse Dreams""
column3: which builds the momentum of a bouncy Northern Soul groove up to a peak before the mix abruptly cuts off and spits them back into a panoramic
column4: HD jam.

column1: All these rich sounds serve as an alternate take on anticipating technological encroachment
column2: that humanity and technology aren't necessarily at war. You feel small while listening to Lonerism
column3: but in a way that makes you appreciate how man
column4: machine
column5: and Mother Nature can harmonize. Lonerism is portable and joyous in an unforced way
column6: a soundtrack for the times when you're walking downtown and look up at a collection of skyscrapers
column7: or driving through a mountain pass on an interstate or even looking at a Ferris wheel next to an ocean thinking
column8: ""Holy shit

how did this all get here?""

column1: If Cale had brought more memorable songs

column6: relaxation
column7: yoga & shiatsu."" Below the text

column1: Woo have at least 10 albums; It's Cosy Inside is only one of four that I've heard

column1: ""Ambient"" is a word usually used to describe albums that create wide-open spaces: the sky
column2: the desert
column3: the highway at night
column4: etc. Even Brian Eno's imagined airport-- from 1978's Music for Airports-- is a place of wide tunnels
column5: high ceilings
column6: and windows all around. The difference between Woo and most ambient music is scale: It's Cosy Inside is a domestic album whose map is drawn in its song titles: ""Wallpaper""
column7: ""No More Telly""
column8: ""End of the Attic""
column9: ""It's Cosy Inside"". It gets as far as ""Downtown Suburbia""
column10: then turns around (and note that this is downtown suburbia). But the album's limited imagined space is also what makes it so wonderful and disorienting: Like the second side of Animal Collective's Sung Tongs
column11: It's Cosy Inside stakes itself on the premise that the most cosmic and revelatory experiences you'll ever have will all happen between your house and the backyard.

column1: Most of it is made with acoustic guitars
column2: gently strummed and run through effects pedals that make them sound slinky and liquid. Sometimes
column3: clarinets come in. Melodies are pretty
column4: sweet
column5: almost sing-songy

column7: they ebb out. Knowing how little to play in situations like this is probably more important than knowing how much to play

column10: music as mist.

column1: Music this strange certainly has the right to present itself as serious
column2: mystical shit doing all kinds of serious
column3: mystical investigation. It's to Woo's credit that they don't. Every level of It's Cosy Inside-- from the cartoonish front cover to the song titles to the sound itself-- is chipper and inviting. They're just two smiling brothers in sailor hats making quiet guitar ooze for you to get massaged to. I first heard about them from the reliably interesting Mutant Sounds blog about five years ago. ""Hello
column4: one of the post's comments read. ""This is my first ever blog-- how exciting to be talking to the computer-- we went to visit a crop circle last week just outside Barbury Castle in Wiltshire

column6: yeah-- ""pretty exciting."" The post
column7: of course
column8:
was signed by Mark Ives-- half of Woo.

The physical journey traveled by Franco Falsini
column2: founding member of Sensations' Fix

column6: and his fondness for innovation
column7: for exploring curious notions

column12: and a series of unreleased outtakes

column14: including prog

column1: The open-ended approach Falsini took to his art makes it difficult to easily classify Sensations' Fix
column2: but the disparate nature of his output is also a big part of the appeal. Anyone randomly picking up an album by the band could be transported into one of many worlds. Falsini's 1975 solo album
column3: Cold Nose
column4: was allegedly a soundtrack to a film about cocaine. Excerpts from it are included here
column5: although no tangible evidence of the film's existence is forthcoming. Most of their music is instrumental and heavy on the electronics Falsini was obsessing over at the time

column7: the band's label

column9: ended up releasing three Sensations' Fix albums in one year
column10: partly due to the unusual contract Falsini had signed with them. Clearly this is a group that left a delirious trail of orchestrated and accidental confusion in its wake.

column2: bombarding people with myriad stylistic turns over a brief span of time

column6: and via Daniel Lopatin dropping a track by the band into a FACT mix. What's striking about Music Is Painting in the Air is how easily you can trace the central aesthetic of many future bands and genres through it. The bass-heavy ""Left Side of Green"" bears the spidery cadence of post rock; ""Dark Side of Religion"" is an unnervingly precise proto-Spacemen 3 cut; ""Cold Nose Story"" acts as a precursor to the fuzzy yearnings of Bristolians Flying Saucer Attack; ""Fortune Teller"" predates Ben Chasny's astral-folk projections as Six Organs of Admittance by many decades.

column1: It might be a stretch to cast Falsini as some kind of indie rock soothsayer
column2: but it's clear from this collection that he was testing out ground that would later be explored in a great deal of depth. He was never satisfied to run in place
column3: to root the Sensations' Fix sound in one of many areas that was then (and
column4: in some cases
column5: still is now) ripe for exploration. Partly that can be explained by the era in which he was working. Falsini's liner notes explain how he was one of the first musicians to gain access to the MiniMoog
column6: which he describes as ""a tool to forward our sound into the future."" That Falsini never had a clear idea what his own musical ""future"" held is both his biggest strength and weakness. A greater exploration of the echo-y loops that make up ""Moving Particles"" could surely have led to a moment of inspiration not far from Manuel Göttsching's E2-E4. The fact that he didn't get there
column7: choosing many other avenues to explore instead
column8: led him to somewhere incredibly fractured but no less fascinating.

column1: There are no easy inroads into the Sensations' Fix sound-- something this compilation neatly addresses by laying everything out in a self-confessed ""arbitrary yet inspired"" non-chronological order. The approach to pulling everything together for Music Is Painting in the Air was as anarchic as the spirit in which it was conceived

It's hard to know what to make of New York duo MS MR at first. Partly it's deliberate. Like more and more would-be breakout acts

column2: MS MR's first proper EP

column4: via Tumblr.) But that's not the only reason these songs sound instantly familiar. The bands they've been compared to are somewhat more telling
column5: although none fits exactly. A little more sashay and they'd be Poliça; more rapture and they'd be Florence; throw in some trolling and they'd be Lana. Their closest analogue

column10: confident
column11: or spooky as is called for. She'll turn a folk curtsy for a sparrow metaphor
column12: strut her melisma through a verse like the Sugababes' Siobhan Donaghy
column13: or give up words entirely; the one commonality is that they're always a shade too vulnerable
column14: too clear in a busy mix

column16: lost but compelling.

column1: This effect works best when the lyrics merit such illumination

column4: specifically a relationship wrecked out of fear. ""Welcome to the inner workings of my mind
column5: so dark and foul I can't disguise
column6: Plapinger sings
column7: and if it's melodramatic
column8: the fog of reverb certainly backs her up. There's more levity on ""Ash Tree Lane""
column9: a march set to brass and a wordless hook that'd be exuberant in any other context
column10: but then Plapinger gets to singing again about plagues and wrong choices
column11: eventually cutting the whole thing off with a gasp after--again-- ""my mind's a mess."" ""Bones"" isn't as strong; the pile of fractured guitar and strings works well enough

column13: and the lyrical admission ""marinate in misery like a girl of only 17"" doesn't excuse the clichés of teenage misery: empty churches
column14: broken dreams paired with silent screams

column2: that's ""Dark Doo Wop""
column3: a title that might as well have been kept on reserve behind glass labeled ""Break in Case of Aesthetic Drought"". The throughline is simple

column5: so you might as well stick around. It's simple enough to execute
column6: too; all you need are a few diffident doo-wops and coquetry on ""that's my man
column7: and as for the part where the world burn
column8: burn
column9: burns
column10: the juxtaposition's obvious on its own. But it only works if it's delivered with a preacher's passion
column11: or at least with Skeeter Davis' pathos. MS MR deliver

column14:
and a sonic fog that buries any lingering pleasantries.

While a completely accurate count is near impossible
column2: the three musicians who make up Rangda-- guitarists Sir Richard Bishop (Sun City Girls) and Ben Chasny (Six Organs of Admittance)
column3: and drummer Chris Corsano-- have between them appeared on somewhere in the neighborhood of 200 albums
column4: recorded with dozens of different collaborators. With artists this prolific it is never certain how long any particular collaboration or project will last; and in 2010 when the three released False Flag
column5: their debut as Rangda
column6: it was not immediately clear if this was to be a one-off album or the work of an ongoing group. But musicians with this much experience are also able to recognize when they've struck upon a special combination
column7: and their second album Formerly Extinct confirms Rangda to be an active
column8: cohesive band of the highest caliber.

column2: False Flag sounds like a bit of a feeling-out process
column3: as the three musicians
column4: each with his own well-established voice
column5: blast noisy improvisations and rifle through ideas as they learn how best to mesh their eccentric styles. On Formerly Extinct that process is completed
column6: and Rangda sounds like a band that knows exactly who they are and what they want to do together. Forgoing noisier digressions
column7: every track on the album is taut and sinewy
column8: with the musicians listening to one another and anticipating each other's moves as if they were sharing limbs. For now at least
column9: Rangda have settled into a sound that seems very much an idealized hybrid between Six Organs of Admittance and the more song-oriented moments of Sun City Girls
column10: with the album performing the weird magic trick of sounding about as you might expect it to while still being filled with surprises.

column2: whose work as a solo artist and with the Sun City Girls
column3: as summarized by Marc Masters
column4: has continually defied all possible boundaries
column5: Formerly Extinct might be one of his most straightforward and song-centered albums to date. Even ""Silver Nile""
column6: the album's lone long-form piece
column7: is crafted with an entrancing
column8: slowly unwinding melody as Chasny's and Bishop's guitars patiently circling one another like a pair of desert vultures. As is always the case with Bishop's work
column9: vague Eastern and North African echoes abound on such tracks as ""Idol's Eye"" and ""Majnun""
column10: with Chasny able to match whatever accent Bishop chooses to adopt.

column1: There have always been two main risks whenever such veteran improvisational musicians as these play together: Either someone will tend to hog the ball while the other players are reduced to the role of mere accompanists
column2: or else everyone will be so disinclined to step on each other's toes that nobody actually makes any memorable moves at all. The most remarkable thing about Rangda
column3: then
column4: is their music's balance. No one player ever dominates any given song
column5: and whenever either Chasny or Bishop steps forward to take a solo
column6: the other works with Corsano to keep things continually engaging in the background.

column1: Whenever a trio is able to achieve a balance like that
column2: it usually means there is some world-class drumming going on
column3: and that is the case with Corsano on Formerly Extinct. Rangda's songs are oddly built creatures
column4: filled with enough abrupt time changes and strange meters for me to wonder if any of this might qualify as math-rock. Throughout the album Corsano is able to keep everything moving so deftly his playing seems almost nonchalant
column5: his rhythms continually churning and roiling but never sounding particularly flashy or show-offish.

column2: it also drops a few tantalizing hints of what might still be to come from Rangda. On ""Tres Hambres""
column3: with its sly nod to ZZ Top
column4: Chasny and Bishop volley a circular riff back and forth between the speakers with a dazzling ease
column5: and on the brief ""Goodbye Mr. Gentry""
column6: I can't help but get visions of classic Minutemen songs in my head
column7: and it leads me to wish for a track or two where these guys fuel the amps and rip into a straight 4/4 psych-rock monster closer to what Chasny does with his Comets on Fire crew. But that's just me getting greedy; for now it's enough to know that
column8: with Formerly Extinct
column9: Rangda not only prove themselves to be a going concern as a band
column10:
but that they might just be starting to really hit their stride.

Since his debut in 2010 with the outstanding ""Sure Thing""
column2: the young Los Angeles singer/songwriter Miguel has been something of a for-the-R&B-heads-only sleeper star. He showed up armed with a guitar
column3: an endearing croon that is both virtuosic and everyman
column4: a coiffed haircut
column5: and a slightly retro sensibility. His voice is an elastic thing that's rarely used to excessive effect; he avoids the histrionic R. Kelly worship of so many of his compatriots in favor of the school of smooth Sam Cooke ad-libs. And though his lyrics are full of silly puns and earnest platitudes
column6: he takes sex very seriously: He's a happily-married man in a genre full of lascivious bachelors
column7: and his best music radiates maturity
column8: self-assured and confident but rarely showy. But despite his obvious talent
column9: he hasn't quite been able to break through to a wider audience.

column2: All I Want Is You
column3: was flanked with some stellar singles but weighed down by a lack of identity as he flitted from producer to producer. It sounded like he couldn't decide whether he wanted to be a Salaam Remi faux-nostalgia crooner or a smart hip-hop crossover star
column4: and the indecision hung over the record like a cloud (it didn't perform well commercially either). He returned earlier this year with a free trio of EPs under the self-conscious title of Art Dealer Chic
column5: showing a newfound entrepreneurial sensibility and a streak of independence. Those mostly self-produced songs at times sounded like rough sketches
column6: but they made it up for it by sounding personal and liberated from the demands of the industry. Free and widely available
column7: they earned him some well-deserved re-examination. They also contained his best songs to date. And now
column8: with his second full-length
column9: he's delivered on that early promise.

column2: also found on the first Art Dealer Chic EP. It's one of the giddiest love songs of the year
column3: a track where ecstatic infatuation is hemmed in by Miguel's understated vocal dexterity
column4: and this album feels like its proper context. He rockets off into falsetto for irresistibly brief moments
column5: and a new outro spirals elegant
column6: trained vocal gymnastics around the song's chorus. ""Adorn"" also showcases Miguel's secret weapon: modesty. It's definitively
column7: deceptively simple
column8: a nugget of concentrated sunshine
column9: and not necessarily all that original. But I'll be damned if it doesn't pull you in and make you feel it.

column1: That touch of modesty colors most of Kaleidoscope Dream. There's the tender ""Use Me"" where he admits being nervous about having sex with the lights on. Even more affecting is the acoustic murmur ""Pussy Is Mine""
column2: which deflates masculinized hip-hop tropes with insecurity
column3: pleading
column4: ""Tell me that the pussy is mine/ 'Cause I don't wanna believe that anyone is just like me."" The sentiment turns sardonic on the Ryan Leslie-like jaunt of ""How Many Drinks?""
column5: where gorgeous falsetto verses are offset by uncertain pleas of ""I don't wanna waste my time.""

column2: lightly psychedelic production buffers the record's more barebones moments
column3: and Miguel's precocious vocals take flight on the bombast rather than drowning in it. Standout ""Do You..."" unfolds in an ethereal cloud of synth
column4: voices streaming like angelic choirs before stumbling into a verse buoyed by its own euphoria. Not many singers could get away with lines like ""What about matinee movies/ Pointless secrets/ Midnight summer swim
column5: private beaches/ Rock
column6: paper
column7: scissors/ Wait! best outta three!"" It's the stuff of unbearable rom-com montages
column8: but Miguel's playful delivery brings it over. He's the rare vocalist who makes you feel what he's singing about
column9: even when his lyrics can be transparent. When he wants to sound deadly serious
column10: he's on the verge of tears; when he's happy
column11: he's practically laughing as he sings.

column1: Kaleidoscope Dream has elements of the sort of tasteful R&B record that the Grammys love
column2: but much like Beyoncé's 4
column3: it cuts through its own statuesque stateliness with raw emotion reined in by an ever-present sense of professionalism. And it succeeds in part because it sounds like Miguel's album and no one else's. There are no intrusive guest appearances
column4: and the record sounds even less of its time than the first
column5: reveling in its own contextual vacuum with abandon. Though there are some unexpected choices. Like ""Don't Look Back""
column6: which is propped up by grand synth runs before melting into an interpolation of the Zombies' ""Time of the Season"". That song's musky psychedelia is a good example of the record's overarching theme
column7: the highly sexualized seen through the lens of the eager and innocent.

column1: When Miguel isn't accompanied by glossy synths
column2: the music is all about intimacy. Take ""Arch & Point""-- with a simple rasp
column3: strum
column4: and metronome
column5: it sounds like it was recorded in the very bedroom it's ostensibly taking place in. ""When it feels this good then it just comes natural
column6: he insists
column7: and there's not a better ethos for where his career stands at this point. Emerging unscathed from middling mainstream performance
column8: Kaleidoscope Dream sounds
column9: at its utmost
column10: natural and easy
column11: an artist set free to do what he wants and proving himself every bit the unique voice his debut seemed to deny. It's respectful of tradition
column12: quietly ambitious
column13: and deeply personal
column14:
a wonderfully considered album from an artist who was starting to seem a lot like a forgotten gem in the wake of mishandled promotion.

column2: she rejected the notion that their music somehow warranted external attention. ""I didn't see the point of doing shows because it seemed like nonsense for me being the centre of attention for 30 or 45 minutes
column3: she explained in a 2011 interview. ""Isn't it a little pretentious
column4: or even dangerous
column5: to expose yourself like this?"" And three years before
column6: in an interview with Pitchfork

column6: she explores the creation myth of the salamander

column3: too. Across the album's 62 minutes

column5: keyboards
column6: drums
column7: and drum machines weave together horizontally

column9: Alight in Ashes suggests something of a ritual

column11: tones dangling as lures to woo you into whatever lifestyle Beaulieu proselytizes. During ""Arsenikon (Faded in Discord)""

column13: moldering away/ Flowing out of our own body/ Evil expels evil
column14: she sings

column16: those vocal circles wrap into an unavoidable vortex. You want in. And though Beaulieu stays silent during the instrumental ""Burnt Offerings""

column1: Even at its most aggressive (opener ""Set Water to Flames"" flashes out in a wall of sound backed by heavy military drums) or slightest (see the simply distorted whorls during ""Disease of Fear"")
column2: every sound on Alight in Ashes feels of a piece. Beaulieu and de la Moth create and sustain an atmosphere that becomes its own spotlight and

outside factors like influences and contemporaries seem momentarily too distant to consider.

Space Zone is the debut album from 18-year-old David Davis
column2: aka Young Smoke. The Chicago-based producer is inextricably tied to his hometown's faster-than-fast and repetitive genre of footwork; Davis is one of the producers linked with Chicago's Flight Musik collective
column3: which is headed up by DJ Diamond
column4: who issued a solid footwork album under that name on UK label Planet Mu. That imprint has spent the last several years making a case for footwork as a genre that transcends functional dance music
column5: in part through their Bangs & Works compilation series; Davis contributed two songs
column6: ""Psycho War"" and ""Wouldn't Get Far""
column7: to last year's second installment. Both fit nicely within footwork's sonic constraints; the former is all cinematic strings and maniacal metallic-popcorn percussion
column8: while the latter rides an inspired vocal lick and throws it through various levels of filter.

column2: it's understandable to think of Davis as a footwork producer
column3: but Space Zone is something different. The record finds Davis using the genre as a launchpad into weirder territory. The brown-sound frequencies and tightly looped rhythms are still present
column4: but they're placed lower in the mix to dampen their intensity. On a few tracks
column5: you barely notice that they're there at all. Space Zone also shows that Davis has a neon-streaked sense of humor. The title track features a warm
column6: melodic voice intoning
column7: ""Welcome to the space zone
column8: as lasers and video-game explosions bounce off of rubbery walls. Elsewhere
column9: you get claustrophobic klaxons
column10: blastoff noises
column11: launchpad countdowns
column12: and robotic voices issuing warnings about ""countermeasures."" After a particularly stoner-friendly run of cuts on the album's backend
column13: a more traditional footwork number arrives in the form of ""High Den a Mother Fucka"". Its title underscores the fact that the target audience for this thing probably wouldn't be able to move their feet very fast without doubling into a wheezing cough.

column1: Space Zone's closest analog in modern dance music may be Zomby's epochal Where Were U in '92?
column2: trading that album's 'ardcore fixation with a focus on hard-hitting juke. Both records showcase a freewheeling ADD-addled sense of speed
column3: with idiosyncratic sounds peppered throughout to keep it fresh. So it's ironic that Davis' most intriguing work comes when he slows things down
column4: from the placid synths and drippy rhythmic squelch of ""Space Breeze"" to the dreamy synth drift of ""Liquid Drug"". Here Boards of Canada is the obvious comparison
column5: not so much in actual form but in how he creates cloudy billows of atmosphere that retain a basic level of engagement.

column1: Davis is young and Space Zone sounds like the work of a young artist. A promising young artist

column3: melody-minded Da Mind of Traxman. But ultimately these releases have different aims. While Traxman's expression of songcraft matches and
column4: at times

column6: Young Smoke's not trying to push things forward. Instead
column7: he's trying to take the genre somewhere it hasn't really gone yet

column9: giving his productions more space and room to breathe

column11:
but joining him on the ride provides its own level of fascination.

After more than 15 years as a producer with some of music's biggest names
column2: Nigel Godrich has been working with some comparative unknowns in 2012. Earlier this year
column3: he lent his distinctive touch to Brooklyn indie outfit Here We Go Magic's third album
column4: A Different Ship; now comes the debut album from a new band of Godrich's called Ultraísta. The group consists of Godrich and Los Angeles-based producer/drummer Joey Waronker
column5: who've worked together on and off since Beck's 1998 album Mutations
column6: including time in the Thom Yorke's side project Atoms for Peace. Vocalist Laura Bettinson
column7: whom they recruited after seeing a loop-heavy performance from her electronic pop project Dimbleby & Capper
column8: rounds out the band.

column1: Those with knowledge of these artists' CVs won't have much trouble hearing their individual contributions to Ultraísta's smooth
column2: krautrock-indebted synth pop. Waronker's tumbling rhythms are central
column3: while Bettinson's layered vocals weave easily through and around the viscous synths. But it's ultimately Godrich's show
column4: as Ultraísta's electronic squiggles and tight production bring to mind his work on Yorke's own solo set
column5: 2006's The Eraser. Yorke's album had a distinctly gloomy
column6: threatening tone

column2: Ultraísta's atmospheric consistency turns out to be its biggest flaw. Almost every track adheres to the same formula: a complicated drum pattern to open followed by some synths or treated piano and then by Bettinson's voice
column3: which is progressively looped and layered until the track's end. Once you've heard one of these songs
column4: you've heard the entire record. And the dullness is driven home by Bettinson's voice
column5: which is competent but lacks distinctiveness. Here and there she shows some versatility
column6: like when she mixes a whisper with a holler on ""Bad Insect"" and conveys palpable desperation through on ""Our Song"". But generally
column7: her smoky vocals sound cut-and-pasted from one of those chillout compilations that's clogged up many a used-CD music store section. She's not really saying much lyrically
column8: either; the album's lyrics were collaboratively written by the trio
column9: and as such they possess a factory-churned facelessness
column10: consisting mostly of clichéd imagery and weightless invocations of passion.

column2: however
column3: is missing the point. The group's clearly more concerned with making great sounds and creating a distinctive vibe than they are with making lasting statements. Taking that into consideration

column5: I couldn't help but think about another album from a side project spawned by a high-profile British musician-- this year's >>
column6: from Portishead member Geoff Barrow's knotty excercise in rock-deconstruction

column10: talking recently to Consequence of Sound on Ultraísta's modest aims: ""We've got a reason to be here and essentially it's just the entertainment and the fun of being able to do this-- it's a luxury
column11: really. I mean I could be working at a fucking dry cleaners
column12: you know what I mean?"" From this perspective
column13:
the question with Ultraísta isn't so much ""Why?"" as it is ""Why not?""

With instrumental music that's droney or noisy
column2: titles are often open-ended
column3: or at least don't convey much literal information about the sounds within. But the names of the two albums by Sarin Smoke-- a guitar collaboration between Tom Carter (Charalambides) and Pete Swanson (Yellow Swans)-- are actually instructive. 2007's Smokescreen was generally spacious and minimal
column4: at times sounding like it was recorded behind a veil. Vent
column5: on the other hand
column6: is bold and upfront sounding. Very little is cloaked or held back
column7: and the lack of restraint feels purposeful. When Carter and Swanson dispense their searing guitar strains
column8: it sounds like they're getting something off their chests.

column1: Not that this is angry or fervent music-- in fact
column2: Vent and Smokescreen are linked by a common sense of thoughtful calm. Carter and Swanson are more interested in absorbing each other's sounds and advancing their conversation than racing to a loud finish line. Even when things get super dense-- which happens at least once in all six tracks-- there's a serenity to the proceedings
column3: a feeling that the pair is as focused on the decaying trails behind its guitar pyrotechnics as the initial sparks that caused them.

column2: in the form of a few fuzzy detonations in opener ""Atmen Ein"". But they are patient explosions
column3: more likely to massage brainwaves than spike adrenaline. Here and throughout the album
column4: Carter and Swanson are like lab technicians studying the effects of guitar abstraction on human physiology. Sounds pulse and scratch like needles scraping out a polygraph pattern; shards of distortion and overload beep and blip like a blurry heart monitor. There's also a sky-staring stoner vibe-- parts of Vent are like psych-rock solos freed from songs and lit up
column5: similar to Bardo Pond's farther-out journeys or Neil Young's feedback collage
column6: Arc. As with those precedents
column7: Sarin Smoke's sound has a lie-on-the-floor languidity
column8: but it's never sleepy. If anything
column9: it wants to stone you awake with its busy
column10: forward-moving noise.

column1: Forward motion has been a constant throughout the careers of both of these men (Carter is so future-focused he's already back to performing not long after a serious bout with pneumonia; proceeds from the sales of Vent go to his relief fund). And both of their careers have covered so much ground that it's tough to choose which portions are represented here. If pressed
column2: I'd say Swanson's playing recalls the star-beam guitar so effective on 2011's I Don't Rock at All
column3: while Carter has climbed similar mountains on Charalambides' Joy Shapes and Historic 6th Ward. But with Vent the pair has gone a good ways to carving out its own shared history
column4:
one that will hopefully continue.

In the introduction to Tiny Beautiful Things

I cannot think of two words that better sum up the strange powers that the Mountain Goats frontman has spent two decades and a small shelf's worth of LPs tirelessly honing. ""Radical"" because the space he's carved out in the musical landscape (""I hide down in my corner
column7: because I like my corner
column8: he seethes on the opening cut of his latest album
column9: Transcendental Youth) stands a sizable and defiant distance from what's cool. His songs hinge upon lines (""Every dream's a good dream
column10: even awful dreams are good dreams if you're doing it right"") that would run the risk of sounding like the inspirational posters that lined the walls of your 9th grade English teacher's classroom if Darnielle delivered them with anything less than the tenacity of a rabid dog playing tug-of-war for the last bone on earth. And ""empathy"" because the degree to which he inhabits his characters is so thorough that it's a little disorienting. We are talking about a guy who has written from the perspective of a 4th-century Danish peasant
column11: a gun-clutching Macon County outlaw

column13: and a moon-dwelling cannibal and has still somehow tricked most people into thinking that he is ""a confessional songwriter.""

column1: Since retiring his boombox and committing to a full-band sound in 2002
column2: Mountain Goats albums have roughly fallen into two categories
column3: what I'll sort-of-inadequately call ""tight concept"" and ""loose concept."" The former are bound by narratives or formal conceits-- That Record About The Painfully Slow Dissolution of A Marriage (Tallahassee)
column4: That Secular Record About The Bible (The Life of the World to Come)
column5: That Record About What Happens When Junkies Living In A House Together Stop Being Polite And Start Getting Real (We Shall All Be Healed). The latter category-- records like Heretic Pride and All Eternals Deck-- is more of a mixed bag: They don't quite have the blunt impact of the tighter concept albums
column6: but the upside is that they give Darnielle's imagination some room
column7: freeing him to whip around from consciousness to troubled consciousness. And Transcendental Youth
column8: the Mountain Goats' latest
column9: is a fine example of that latter category. As they hide out from the cops
column10: root through garbage
column11: peer paranoid through the blinds
column12: and dig their nails into their hands just for something to do
column13: its protagonists are linked not by place or time but by a particular spiritual stance-- crouched and desperate
column14: but waiting patiently for a sliver of light.

column1: For as attuned as Darnielle is to the desperation of the everyman
column2: his music's humanism extends to honoring the pathos of famous people. (A sampling of song titles from All Eternals Deck: ""For Charles Bronson"" and ""Liza Forever Minnelli."") Two of Transcendental Youth's best songs-- both of which rank among the most searing and immediate things he's written since The Sunset Tree-- were inspired by troubled musicians who didn't live to see better days. Darnielle wrote ""Amy aka Spent Gladiator 1"" after Amy Winehouse died
column3: but he says the song is for ""all the other Amy Winehouses in the world who aren't famous
column4: whose deaths go uncelebrated."" With its driving
column5: obstinate tempo and pithily life-affirming proclamations (""Do every stupid thing that makes you feel alive"")
column6: ""Amy"" is one of the more anthemic songs the Mountain Goats have put to tape
column7: and it has potential to become a staple in the band's fabled and cathartic live shows. It's perhaps the highest compliment one can bestow upon a Mountain Goats song to say that it has lyrics that would feel really good to scream at the top of your lungs in a room full of hundreds of other people who are also screaming at the top of their lungs; by that measure
column8: ""Amy""'s chorus of ""Just stay aliiiiive"" ranks pretty high.

column2: on the other hand
column3: whips us back in time to 1968
column4: where Frankie Lymon is in a Harlem studio putting the finishing touches on a song called ""Seabreeze"". Darnielle has a knack for the fine balance between hyper-specificity and universality
column5: and the power of ""Harlem Roulette"" comes from the way it whiplashes between external banalities (""Just a pair of tunes to hammer out/ Everybody's off the clock by 10"") and hulking
column6: private tragedies (a beat later: ""The loneliest people in the whole wide world are the ones you're never going to see again."") It's also a song about the gulf between appearance and reality: Someone who'd seemingly achieved a great deal and tons of adoration at a young age can still be one of the loneliest people in the world (Stars! They're Just Like Us!)
column7: and what seemed like an ordinary studio session became
column8: in retrospect
column9: tragic. Lymon went home from the studio
column10: took his first hit of heroin in years
column11: and
column12: at the age of 25
column13: overdosed.

column1: The debate's been raging since 2002: At this point it's safe to say that there will always be people who think the Mountain Goats' urgent

column7: and Megafaun and admiring his 60s-inspired compositions). They're a fitting addition because

column10: as well as the muted
column11: stunning closer ""Transcendental Youth"". ""Sing
column12: sing for ourselves alone
column13: Darnielle commands
column14: and the horns shine like sunsets or sunrises

column2: Transcendental Youth doesn't have the consistency of the Mountain Goats' strongest records

There's always been a Rosetta Stone quality to the pop song cover. Hearing a group's version of an established tune can reveal things about each via comparison
column2: like setting a decoder ring to the proper coordinates between two acts. When I heard that Field Music were applying their prim British Invasion melodies and jazz-derived rhythms to a set of interpretations
column3: I dialed in my hopes to the usual suspects: the Kinks
column4: Sparks
column5: something from The Lamb Lies Down on Broadway
column6: perhaps
column7: maybe an early Talking Heads cut
column8: a take on Kraftwerk's ""The Model""
column9: or XTC's ""Making Plans for Nigel"". I didn't imagine Syd Barrett's ""Terrapin"" or Leonard Cohen's covered-to-death ""Suzanne""
column10: nor the Ringo-sung White Album cut ""Don't Pass Me By"". Expectations successfully subverted
column11: the Field Music Play… compilation
column12: which pulls together these and five other covers
column13: manages to be more than worthwhile
column14: while teaching two important lessons about the group's approach. Musically and curatorially
column15: the duo are undeniable music pragmatists with an impossibly dry sense of humor.

column1: The pragmatism extends beyond the compositions and to the reasons for even considering some of the cover choices. The duo is reluctant to call Play an album; the majority of these versions were done for other projects. The well-trod modern standard ""Suzanne"" and left-field choice ""Terrapin"" were done for special issues of Mojo Magazine. As for the latter
column2: David Brewis told me via email that he was much more in favor of covering Barrett's ""No Good Trying""
column3: but it had already been scooped up by J. Mascis. That would explain the approach they took to ""Terrapin""-- a folksy dirge far outside of their wheelhouse-- shoehorning it into the group’s twangy take on George Harrison-styled classic rock. Their version of Roxy Music's ""If There Is Something""-- originally recorded for a School of Language B-side-- is a more successful translation. They swap out the glam pioneers' bluesy swagger for hospital corners and modernist lines
column4: but manage to retain the original's sense of self-aware oddness
column5: while highlighting the similarities between Brewis' and Bryan Ferry's vocal styles (perhaps a result of their geographical affinity).

column1: But even when the covers here are a matter of picking from the leftovers
column2: Field Music manage to create original versions invested with their own arid humor. Two cuts
column3: originally issued as a 7"" for 2012's Record Store Day
column4: are drawn from the Pet Shop Boys' classic Actually
column5: complete with with a tongue-in-cheek title (<i>actually
column6: nearly) and re-appropriation of the original album's cover photo. The thematic connections shared by PSB and Field Music are a revelation in their own right
column7: but it certainly helps that the Brewises nail their version of the ever-great ""Rent"". It's not just a matter of the groups' mutual perspective that links love with financial necessity
column8: either: ""I ended up singing it as half gay love story and half love/hate open letter to Field Music itself
column9: Brewis told me. ""You pay my rent
column10: but only just.""

column1: The highlight from Play is easily the duo's version of the Beatles' anti-classic ""Don't Pass Me By""
column2: which would seem like an ironic jab at the British pop canon were it not a lemon-into-lemonade scenario in which they took a funny and quite inventive approach to the Fab Four's catalog. Also selected from the already picked-over for a Mojo compilation
column3: the Brewises took the Residents' approach to the tune
column4: mixing in elements from throughout the Beatles' discography. On the chorus
column5: they lapse into ""Don't Let Me Down""
column6: in a hilariously literal gambit. Listen closely (it's worth it)
column7: and you'll also hear bits of ""Blackbird""
column8: ""A Day in the Life""
column9: ""Strawberry Fields Forever""
column10: and ""Yer Blues"". Here lies the lesson of Play
column11:
and one of the core truths of Field Music's rewarding discography: There is dark humor and interesting angles-- even joy-- to be found in basic realities and mundane commitments.

This is a quality he shares with the very different Ricardo Villalobos: By pulling back and giving his meticulously-constructed elements room to breathe

column11: harmonically rich runs and the spare opening is breathtaking. Thundercat's expressive bass work also adds character to the comparatively thick title track
column12: as a gong and handclaps flow continuously like water over rocks while an unstable Dilla-fied keyboard wedges in between the beats. But even here
column13: when there's more going on

column2: it changes in feel
column3: but the shifts are organic. If the tracks in the opening section bring to mind an abstraction of spaced-out jazz
column4: elsewhere Ellision conjures the blocky colors of videos games. See the thick 8-bit synths in ""Sultan's Request""
column5: the curlicue melody in ""Putty Boy Strut""
column6: the simple refrain of the title track
column7: which makes me think of a digital hero on a quest. These lighter moments are careful and reserved. You can feel Ellison putting a smaller frame around each individual part.

column1: The hushed world Ellison has constructed here is hermetic and internally focused
column2: even for him
column3: and the album's guests don't break the spell. The featured players meet Ellison on his turf and adapt to the landscape of the record. Erykah Badu's connection to Flying Lotus' broader aesthetic is readily apparent
column4: as her sense of mystical earthiness is grounded in tradition but free to wander outside of it. On ""See Thru to U""
column5: she does away with soul singing in its formal sense and allows herself to become an instrument. The result is a satisfying melding of creative personalities but it wouldn't work on an Erykah Badu album-- it's too vaporous
column6: too unconcerned with personality. The same goes for Thom Yorke's contribution on ""Electric Candyman""; Ellison turns him into a ghost
column7: which makes perfect sense.

column2: Until the Quiet Comes is disarming at first. It sometimes feels like an experiment in how much can be stripped away while still sounding like Flying Lotus
column3: but the reduction offers a new perspective into what Ellison is about. Los Angeles and Cosmogramma brought to mind the L.A. that thrives on acceleration. The energy here is just as strong
column4: but it's concentrated into a smaller space. So while this might be Flying Lotus' most accessible record
column5: it's less about being pleasant and more about deep focus. Each of these 18 tracks tends to introduce one or two emotional or musical elements and meditate on them for a brief time before easing back into silence. Quiet is a series of suggestions or clues and it always feels just out of reach
column6:
but that leaves a lot of room for the listener. The surface is a gorgeous invitation to return and see if you can figure out what it all means.

Nobody does maximalism like Patrick Wolf. Calling his music theatrical is accurate but only just; if the stage is the metaphor
column4: Wolf's albums call for massive prosceniums
column5: with hundred-strong casts
column6: meticulous set pieces
column7: and props flung in from the wings. The aesthetics may vary
column8: from Lycanthropy's assemble-at-home crafting to The Bachelor's repurposed metalwork to Lupercalia's lavish polish
column9: but the scope is always titanic. If you're a fan
column10: this is likely why: Wolf spares no sound
column11: vocal gnash
column12: or string flourish if there's emotional or narrative payoff to be had. If you're not
column13: there's probably nothing more Wolf could be doing to change your mind. Maybe that's why the main decision he made on his 10th-anniversary album
column14: Sundark and Riverlight
column15: was to do so much less.

column1: Sundark and Riverlight is a double album containing re-recorded versions of Wolf's songs. One disc designated for troubled songs and one for happier ones. In practice
column2: this sorts The Bachelor to the front and Lupercalia to the sunny back porch. It isn't quite a greatest-hits compilation
column3: though it's mostly singles and fan favorites. Nor is it precisely an acoustic album
column4: though that's mostly how these songs differ. It's more like a retcon
column5: or as Wolf calls it
column6: a make-under: stripping the old material of its frippery to reveal how
column7: Wolf has said
column8: it was meant to sound. ""There was a conscious rebellion on this album against the digital age of auto-tune and mass produced electronic landfill music
column9: Wolf wrote to accompany the album's release<i>
column10: echoing comments he'd made around the release of Lupercalia. It's a curious statement from an artist who's never much relied on or even acknowledged Auto-Tune and one whose music has been thickly electronic (if not exactly mass-produced) since album one. But it's benign. Wolf's hardly the first to anchor this rationale to an unplugged album
column11: nor is he even alone this month. (Tori Amos's Gold Dust
column12: the same idea in the same broad genre
column13: came out within the week.) There's a certain cachet to baroque recordings that New Romantic synthpop doesn't have; it's a play to redefine oneself not as a singer-songwriter but a singer-composer.

column1: If only more composing went on. If this is how Wolf's songs truly look
column2: Sundark and Riverlight is like the thumbnail version: everything compressed
column3: details lost. What might sound cavernous with the right acoustics sounds merely pleasant on recording
column4: taking angst-wracked songs and turning them into something more suited to catches of melodies you'd hear passing a storefront. In these thinner arrangements
column5: Wolf's voice-- among his greatest assets-- sounds overegged
column6: and he knows it; his howls and growls are mostly subdued
column7: as if he's trying to keep it down for the very nice PA lady who just told everyone to turn off their cell phones.

column1: This works when the songs were orchestral ballads already (""London"")
column2: or when the details lost cluttered what might as well have been orchestral ballads (""Teignmouth""
column3: ""Wind in the Wires""). It works for much of the Lycanthropy material
column4: because if you forget Wolf's statements
column5: it's easy enough to imagine this really is how these songs sounded inside his head as a teenager. And it works when Wolf's composing at his normal scale
column6: like ""Bluebells""
column7: which gets darker when written for cello and piano
column8: or ""The Libertine""
column9: whose startled-orchestra arrangement is the only unquestionable improvement here.

column1: What's less successful is when Wolf takes exuberant songs and tranquilizes them. If you played the Sundark version of ""Oblivion"" for someone uninitiated
column2: then the original
column3: they'd think the first was the demo. A lone guitar picks through the bones of The Bachelor's original arrangement; you'd expect the violins at least might have stayed
column4: being both rustic and frantic
column5: but no. And Wolf's vocals
column6: though not tentative
column7: come off like laying guide marks for where the full version would insert guttering or conviction or Tilda Swinton. ""Vulture""
column8: another Bachelor track
column9: replaces the gnashing percussion
column10: panting strings
column11: and general masochistic frenzy of the original with sedate piano pleasantries; there's no blood left in its dead meat. Lupercalia fares little better. ""Together"" takes two ideas from the original (the seconds-long classical guitar flourish at the beginning and the curtsying strings at the end) and deflates everything else. ""House"" excises all the rejoicing strings and most of the joy of the original; it's like a midday nap the day after a besotted honeymoon
column12: which is fair enough as an interpretative choice but far less interesting.

column1: Sometimes the changes are just baffling. ""Bermondsey Street"" takes a song that worked because of its simplicity
column2: its word-precise juxtaposition of two affairs
column3: and smothers it with noodling spoken-word interludes; it's the exact opposite of what Wolf said he was trying to do. If the goal of Sundark and Riverlight was to prove Wolf's repertoire has songwriting merit beyond the layers of mythology and biography and reinventions
column4: it's an unqualified success; on its own
column5: every arrangement is entirely thoughtful and praiseworthy. It just wasn't necessary. These songs can make it alone
column6:
but they could be-- and have been-- so much better.
