There's something fascinating about how singers' voices change as they come to terms with their innate gifts and limits
column2: honing in on whatever is essential about themselves. Sometimes it happens by slow erosion
column3: like Leonard Cohen's voice growing less beautiful and more wise
column4: or the brass leaching off Richard Buckner's to reveal a deeper layer. Sometimes it happens through trauma
column5: as when Levon Helm lost his voice to throat cancer and then miraculously got it back
column6: intact but scarred
column7: giving his old songs a second life. And sometimes
column8: a vocalist who has been feigning something gathers the courage to be himself: Think of how Ghostface has relaxed into the high
column9: limber whine of his natural register
column10: divulging so much more character than the lower
column11: stiffer tough-guy timbre he used to cultivate. All three of these learning processes bear fruit in Don't Be a Stranger
column12: American Music Club frontman Mark Eitzel's best record since 2001's The Invisible Man.

column2: the cultiest of on-again off-again alt-rock survivors
column3: have been refining their studious brand of Americana-- which emphasizes old-fashioned strains of jazz
column4: lounge music
column5: popular song
column6: and hard rock-- for 30 years
column7: so Eitzel's voice has had plenty of time to weather. A heart attack in his recent past didn't change his voice the way Helm's cancer changed his
column8: but one suspects that it catalyzed the third
column9: most significant development here. Brushes with death have a way of clarifying people's self-images and drives-- basically
column10: of cutting through the bullshit. On Don't Be a Stranger
column11: Eitzel remains as moony and self-lacerating as ever. He still gets into an oracular mood when hanging around with barflies on Main Street USA. But he dials down the tin-megaphone bluster that
column12: even at its best
column13: could feel strained in American Music Club. Now he revels in the delicate inner elements of his voice rather than growling over them
column14: and sounds more natural and inviting than ever.

column1: Eitzel is funny in that peculiarly Eitzel way when describing how this record came about. He took his ""horrible demos"" to ""poor long-suffering"" Merge Records
column2: who replied
column3: ""Oh Mark. Really?"" Merge relented after a friend of his manager who had won the lottery loaned the money to hire producer Sheldon Gomberg and make a studio recording of the songs. They were first conceived for an abandoned American Music Club album
column4: whose long-term guitarist Vudi joins Eitzel here. The windfall paid for a tasteful
column5: sometimes vivid backdrop that favors rich acoustic instruments. There are intimations of Spanish guitar throughout
column6: most interestingly conceived on ""Break the Champagne""
column7: where tremolos are implied with a Marxophone. The BooHoo Institutional Choir-- presumably
column8: some people who happened to be around-- adds intriguingly dark-colored harmonies.

column1: Allowing his voice to latch more directly than usual to the mobile cadences of jazz and soul
column2: with the soft honk that was always latent in his croon tenderly magnified
column3: Eitzel channels a number of unsuspected singers across Don't Be a Stranger
column4: like Billie Holliday on ""I Love You but You're Dead"" and Antony Hegarty on ""Costume Characters Face Dangers in the Workplace"". Standout track ""Oh Mercy"" could almost be a Bill Withers song
column5: with a smoky vocal line cracking over a cyclic minor melody
column6: and it lays out a perspective to which the album often returns: that of the ghost at the feast. As ever
column7: Eitzel observes other people having fun while fretting about political iniquities and personal inadequacies. The difference is that his tone
column8: formerly accusatory
column9: has softened and turned inward. It's that of someone presiding at a dark corner table
column10: bemused by his own views
column11: rather than proselytizing on a plywood stage.

column1: The lyrics of Don't Be a Stranger are in the one-sided conversation form that Eitzel likes
column2: with reams of subtly altered clichés abruptly slipping off-register into idiosyncrasy or hostility
column3: as when he sneers out of nowhere on ""Costume Characters""
column4: ""I did not mean to scare your sad little brat."" The delicate ardor and tenuous conviction that typify that album are most sentimentally expressed on the gently swaying piano ballad ""All My Love"" and most honestly on ""We All Have to Find Our Own Way Out"". There are moments of wry irony
column5: as when Eitzel sings
column6: ""The guitar was pure evil like the engines on a jet
column7: over gentle nylon strings on the strikingly written roadhouse fable ""I Love You but You're Dead"". But even when the lyrics edge on generic
column8: as they sometimes do
column9: Eitzel's singing draws me in. If Leonard Cohen's voice is a story about the passage of time and Levon Helm's is a story about losing what is most precious to you
column10:
Eitzel's is about the circuitous roads we take in search of ourselves. It's moving to hear him seem to arrive.

For the first six minutes of their first new record in four years

On their previous and perhaps best album
column2: 2010's Help Me Name Melody
column3: Austin's Weird Weeds followed two sonic threads. One strand spun well-crafted melodies with pithy
column4: haiku-like lyrics. The other traced untitled
column5: looping instrumentals
column6: heavier on repetition than verse-chorus structure. As the quartet carefully balanced those complementary halves
column7: a whole emerged-- one in which the parts depended on each other to give the album a compelling flow.

column1: Striking that balance couldn't have been easy
column2: but for their follow-up
column3: Weird Weeds assigned themselves an even more challenging task. On this self-titled album
column4: they attempt a similar weave with just a single thread
column5: sticking solely to unnamed instrumentals. It's a risky choice
column6: as the band's knack for repetition and restraint could grow tedious without vocals
column7: producing music with a blankness to match its lack of titles. But The Weird Weeds is abundantly engaging
column8: revealing a confident
column9: committed band that doesn't need to artificially vary its sound to hold interest.

column2: that sound evokes various strains of post-rock: the slow cycles of Slint
column3: the meditative patience of Labradford
column4: the dusty vistas of latter-day Earth. But Weird Weeds' devoutly repetitive approach is distinct. The band-- and drummer Nick Hennies in particular-- is well-versed in modern minimalism
column5: and knows how to build tension from the momentum of repetition. Whenever they could go for an effortless crescendo in the vein of groups like Mogwai or Mono
column6: they hold firm
column7: locking into hypnosis rather than pushing emotional buttons. Not only does this give the music a longer-lasting effect-- it also means that when Weird Weeds do swell
column8: the impact is greater because of the patience it took to get there.

column2: The Weird Weeds is all about patience. Tracks one through four are slow and determined
column3: marching through patterns with transfixing dedication. Just when things seem to have settled into an infinite loop
column4: a lone bass drum lurches forward in the background. That beat persists into track five
column5: bursting into shiny
column6: interlocking guitars (including one played by guest John Dieterich of Deerhoof). This shift swings the album toward the bright and upbeat
column7: as the band finds beauty in the curves of repetition. In doing so
column8: they remind me most of Pell Mell
column9: a band that wasn't mentioned much in the 1990s post-rock boom
column10: but whose subtle hooks deserved more attention.

column1: The album's arc from patience to brightness is as natural as an orbiting planet
column2: but Weird Weeds do that one better at the end
column3: stuffing a miniature solar system into one seven-minute track. True to form
column4: this closing piece builds intensity not through change but momentum
column5:
starting with a four-note guitar figure and slowly adding accents and atmosphere. The simple drama recalls Papa M's more melancholy moments-- but don't let all these comparisons distract you. What matters most about The Weird Weeds is how it furthers this band's stature as the kind that others should be compared to.

The most surprising thing about YOKOKIMTHURSTON is that it took until 2012 to happen. Thurston Moore and Kim Gordon have long been vocal cheerleaders for #TeamYoko
column2: whether enlisting their daughter Coco to ""cover"" one of Ono's earliest scream experiments (""Voice Piece for Soprano"") on 1999's SYR 4: Goodbye 20th Century
column3: or penning fan-letters-as-song (""Ono Soul""
column4: from Moore's 1995 solo effort
column5: Psychic Hearts)
column6: even though they don't seem to be big fans of Double Fantasy. Ono
column7: for her part
column8: has welcomed interaction with her various alt-rock progeny-- most notably on 2007's indie star-studded remix collection Yes I'm a Witch-- but the fact that an artist who averages a couple of new albums per decade has devoted a full-length collaboration to Kim and Thurston suggests that indie rock's perennial power couple must hold a special place in her heart. After all
column9: what are Sonic Youth if not the modern manifestation of the avant/rock ideal that Yoko and her late husband John Lennon forged with Plastic Ono Band-- a symbolic
column10: spiritual kinship reinforced by the fact that Sonic Youth played their first gig
column11: in the East Village
column12: mere months after Lennon's murder uptown.

column1: But if a collaboration between these three was inevitable
column2: its timing is uncanny: It represents Moore and Gordon's first musical release together since announcing their separation after 27 years of marriage. While it would be overly presumptuous to believe that Moore and Gordon's union here has any bearing on the future of their relationship
column3: it's heartening that they've chosen to spend this moment of their lives with Ono
column4: a woman who understands all too well the difficult dance between creativity and matrimony. As such
column5: YOKOKIMTHURSTON is not so much a decibel-bursting showcase for the Queen of Noise and her unruly understudies as a conversation between intimates speaking in tongues and tangles-- a voyeuristic glimpse into a private
column6: discomfiting exchange.

column1: To underscore the clandestine nature of this meeting and instantly ward off casual onlookers
column2: Ono spends the first two minutes of opener ""I Missed You Listening"" demonstrating the entire emotional range of her voice-- from baby-cute cooing to demon-possessed laughter to orgasmic ecstasy to the panic-attack terror of someone whose anesthetic has worn off mid-surgery. It's a move that immediately establishes the album's lawless environment. But
column3: as the song jabbers past the nine-minute mark without introducing any significant changes
column4: you realize the philosophy here is one of understated anarchy.

column1: Composed mainly of Ono's instinctual reactions to Gordon and Moore's spidery guitar scrapes
column2: and of Ono's hushed
column3: spoken-word interactions with Gordon-- YOKOKIMTHURSTON feels both exhaustively sprawling and claustrophobically hermetic. Its six tracks average 10 minutes each
column4: but don't so much chart an evolutionary course as stubbornly linger on a sensation of creeping unease. Even as the album turns considerably noisier and gnarlier in its final two pieces (the tortured mantra ""Let's Get There"" and the 14-minute apocalypse ""Early in the Morning"")
column5: there's little in the way of release or resolution; it's the same sense of stasis projected on a louder
column6: uglier scale. That said
column7: the latter track acquires something resembling a dramatic arc if you interpret Gordon's repeated gnashed-teeth grunts of ""my townhouse!""-- and Ono's horrified reactions to them-- as a comment on the price of an Upper West Side brownstone.

column1: These vague conceptual cues are all you have to work with in trying to comprehend the purpose of these pieces. The rare moments of clarity announce themselves with all the subtlety of a title card in a silent film: amid the hysterical shrieks of ""I Missed You
column2: Listening""
column3: Ono pauses to advise us
column4: in rather self-explanatory fashion
column5: ""trust your intuition."" But even some clearly spoken passages take time to reveal their logic: ""Running the Risk"" begins with the trio playing word-association with newspaper headlines as if engaged in some after-dinner party game but
column6: as the contrast between Moore and Gordon's tabloid-worthy one-liners (""GOPs abandon babies
column7: ""It's all about the party
column8: ""secrets from a stylist"") and Ono's more worldly concerns (""the biggest fish face a little risk… of being cooked"") becomes increasingly apparent
column9: the piece comes to encapsulate how frivolous chatter often drowns out serious discourse in our 140-character universe.

column2: the hindsight significance of Moore and Gordon's participation in this project (which was recorded months before their split was made public) overshadows the real rocky-romance story of this album: that of Ono's relationship with her muse
column3: which remains stormy even as she approaches her 80th birthday. It's all laid bare in centerpiece track ""Mirror Mirror""
column4: in which Ono fesses up to her imperfections and insecurities while Gordon gives a disembodied but reassuring voice to the reflection staring back at her
column5: their eerie exchanges playing out over Moore's deceptively serene psych-folk strums. At the track's outset
column6: Ono plainly admits
column7: ""I'm an intrinsically nervous person
column8: I'm nervous every day
column9: every minute... but at the same time
column10: I am an extremely relaxed person. Every day
column11: every minute
column12:
I love being daring."" YOKOKIMTHURSTON is nothing if not a noble but exceedingly arduous attempt to translate that perpetual state of splendid agitation into sound.

David Levesque's debut as Levek might top even Kanye West's Cruel Summer in terms of missing its optimum release window. Now the guy's from Orlando
column2: so perhaps he doesn't realize that most people have taken their parties indoors at this point. Shame
column3: too
column4: since this thing is not only the kind of affably stoned baked goods that could take a barbecue's chumminess to the next level
column5: it's pretty much exactly the kind of guest you'd want there
column6: too: He brings nothing but the most chill vinyl; if he doesn't have anything nice to say
column7: he doesn't say it; he doesn't try too hard to impress his will on others; and he leaves before he wears out his welcome. We can agree these are all fantastic qualities in a vacuum
column8: but do they make for great art? That's where the admittedly ample charms of Look a Little Closer are subject to debate. It deals in a lot of tensions for a record that isn't particularly tense itself: How does an artist signify commitment with such a laidback sound? How does one present his own perspective while foregrounding his adaptability? How can one grow to love a record whose main goal seems to be blending in?

column2: even Levesque seems to be grappling with those questions on the job. He's described the sound of Levek as ""Mickey Mouse tribal
column3: which is an oppositely opportunistic descriptor for such a kind and guileless album
column4: though maybe there's charm in how it's one that reads like it's trying to grab blog hits from 2010. Either way
column5: Levesque's self-appraisal is hilariously off-base-- there is a certain kind of Disneyficaton in how his globetrotting explorations focus on softer and safer sounds. But there's almost nothing ""tribal"" about Look a Little Closer as floor toms
column6: hard polyrhythms
column7: and unhinged yelping are nowhere to be found amongst the high thread-count folk tapestries and wine-spilling light funk.

column1: You can sense Look a Little Closer as a projection of a gentle soul uninterested in the physical or philosophical properties of rock
column2: mostly because its dominant sounds are gentle renderings of soul music. If you've been on a straight indie rock diet
column3: Levek can calmly guide you through international flavors
column4: though he's more interested in replication than fusion: ""Canterbury Bell"" and ""With a Slow Burn"" are freak-free Ren-folk both charmingly ornate and fussy
column5: yet they ultimately feel more like vehicles for Levesque's exquisite fingerpicking than any sort of expression. His high and feathery wisp of a voice keeps up admirably with the winding chord progressions
column6: though the melodies fail to find many memorable turns. In between
column7: ""Terra Treasures"" is a nimble bossa nova that's admirable in showing Levek's range
column8: but ultimately feels pro forma
column9: like a pair of jeans he wore right off the rack.

column2: but without any sort of personal watermark on it
column3: Look a Little Closer gives as many opportunities to tune out as it does to chill out. ""Muscat Mingle"" goes all in with its South American signifiers-- talking drums
column4: flutes
column5: shakers-- and though its damp analog sound keeps it away from Putomayo sampler territory
column6: it's too stuffed to really groove. The vocoder-laced ""Can't Buy This Love"" and ""Solemn Feeling Forever Healing"" are texturally pleasant
column7: lite-jazz workouts so airy they dissipate on contact. Perhaps more than a perspective

That was a realization for one artist; this feels more like a beginning. As for the title of Look a Little Closer

Levesque could be on to something if he takes his own advice.

column7: adding a potent centrifugal force to the song rather than another linear one. And one of the best moments comes on ""Between Monuments"" when it unexpectedly bursts into a world-shaking homestretch with stomach-dropping portamentos in the viola. The recurrence of long

Lupe Fiasco doesn't give you anything straight: Not a verse
column3: a simile
column4: or a song

column8: darting mind

column6: unbounded ability.

column2: strident beats like ""Unforgivable Youth""

but it's one of few places on the album where Lupe allows himself to seem truly human.

column1: Nü Sensae's approach feels like a cut-and-paste message-in-a-bottle from the early 1990s: the hysteric vocal ferocity of Babes in Toyland's Kat Bjelland; the unpredictable artistry of early Sonic Youth; the violent corners of post-hardcore noise à la Unsane. column7: harrowing attack: shrill
column8: full-throated roars that are improbably visceral. Here
column9: and throughout
column10: Lukic flips between coarse
column11: grating shrieks and a hovering
column12: emotionless style that channels Kim Gordon. It sounds both schizophrenic and seamless
column13: anchoring the band's studied loud-quiet shifts. Sundowning's contrasted vocals create a friction that increases the album's velocity

column3: barely-there instrumentation with peculiar
column4: far-off harmonies. The album's introductory instrumental ""First Born"" conjures a slow
column5: haunted sense of isolation
column6: like peaking through the door to a musty old house
column7: suspecting it's empty but imagining the potential horrors inside. ""Tyjna""
column8: meanwhile

column10: anxious
column11: and ultimately thrilling track sung in Lukic's native Serbian

column2: a broadcaster asked Pitout about a t-shirt he wore in a picture online: ""GIRLS INVENTED PUNK ROCK
column3: NOT ENGLAND
column4: the popular Kim Gordon shirt. The reporter inquired as to what Pitout thought women and non-straight men bring to punk. ""Personally
column5: I'm a gay male
column6: and I really relate to female punk musicians
column7: he said. ""There's something inherently angry and punk about growing up a girl
column8: or gay
column9: or feeling like you don't fit into the top seat in society."" Nü Sensae
column10: despite their loud and endearingly torturous qualities

column12: and Lukic's roars force you to reckon with what's raw inside yourself.

column2: I went running with this album. I happened upon a young man clad in a very different sort of shirt: ""Cool story babe. Now make me a sandwich."" Dumbfounded
column3: I paused
column4: and started towards him; took a photo
column5: told him squarely to fuck himself
column6: and moved away. Which is to say
column7: bands like Nü Sensae can offer valid lessons for living; stay mad
column8: make something of it. And they also offer reminders that so long as pricks like that guy exist

column11:
liberative punk.

For better and worse

That task actually seems feasible for a band with enough gumption to lift its name from <a href=""http://www.philtar.ac.uk/encyclopedia/indon/toraj.html"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">an ancient

column1: But the nerviest thing Aluk Todolo have done to date is to record and release their latest album

column2: though

the unwieldy mission is mostly accomplished.

The first time you hear Lightning Bolt's music

Brian Gibson's bass and Brian Chippendale's drums lash out in such a dizzying flurry that there’s barely time to sort out what’s happening in one track before they’ve moved on to the next. Their music is something like an auditory version of Chippendale's visual art. His comics
column3: like Ninja and Maggots

column1: Lightning Bolt's music has grown gotten tighter and brawnier over the years

column3: and a big part of why they've become a festival draw. Their balance between traditional heaviness and crazed time signatures gets even regulation rock dudes sloshing warm beer on each other. As awesome as that evolution's been

column1: Which isn't to say they're not also going to test the patience of the less noise-inclined

A reliquary is a place where the past is sealed away and stored. But the past isn't a place that Daniel Lopatin ever seems to easily position in his music when he works under his Oneohtrix Point Never guise (his other projects are a different story). He may use it as a reference point
column3: as with his emulation of the vintage Fairlight cut-ups favored by the Art of Noise included on last year's Replica
column4: but OPN's material mostly feels like a slow
column5: untethered drift into a tentative future. Music For Reliquary House
column6: his half of this split LP with fellow celebrator of change and lover of pseudonyms Jeff Witscher
column7: aka Rene Hell
column8: is taken from an installation/performance piece conducted by Lopatin and video artist Nate Boyce. It's coarse and challenging

column10: In 1980 I Was a Blue Square
column11: which begins in conflict and ends in a form of serene resolution.

column1: Music For Reliquary House is a logical extension of the path traveled by Replica
column2: and it pushes those ideas to extremes. A noise resembling a circular saw slashing through metal punctures the ""Stone of Spiritual Understanding""

column5: but that doesn't invalidate the material. The first half of the wonderful ""Midday"" feels like someone just opened up a box full of manic chatter
column6: letting it flood out into the world in a burst of expression before a familiar wave of ambience ties it down to a loose structure.

column1: Structure is something Rene Hell brings once the baton is passed. A looped piano roll opens his side
column2: living up to his promise of making something partially influenced by ""mid 20th century classical music."" Bursts of willful antagonism zoom into sporadic focus throughout In 1980 I Was a Blue Square
column3: neatly tying it to what came before. A festering glitch rises up around those piano rolls on ""Meta Concrete""; ""The Bridge"" veers close to complete disintegration. But Hell's central role
column4: in the unlikely event that these two artists mapped this out conceptually
column5: is to provide a dose of introspection following the ragged disemboweling provided by OPN. ""Qi"" is a doleful elegy stretched out over six minutes
column6: forming one part oppressive death march
column7: one part tilt up toward the sky. That's indicative of Hell's work here
column8: providing a big mesh of emotional and stylistic contrasts
column9: helping add to the general feel of being pushed and pulled in multiple directions at the same time.

column1: Lopatin says his material on Music For Reliquary House is ""a series of hallucinatory informatic assaults"" inspired by the modernist sculptures of David Smith
column2: Anthony Caro
column3: Isamu Noguchi
column4: and Tony Smith. It's reminiscent of Stereolab's 1995 collaboration with artist Charles Long
column5: Music For the Amorphous Body Study Center. It's a similar musical digression
column6: pulling on fibers of already extant ideas
column7: taking them to a place ill-suited to the traditional album format. So it's appropriate that Lopatin decided to release it this way

column9: then gelling them with the work of another artist similarly active in underground circles. For Lopatin and Hell
column10: it purposefully muddies the intent behind work that already leaves a wildly disorienting imprint
column11: that accrues an unusual type of weight by positioning outright hostility right on top of humor
column12: anger
column13:
and tranquility.

When Israeli musicians Gal Aner and Jordan Czamanski met in a jazz trio setting in Haifa

column6: jazzy or jackhammering
column7: acidic or flashback-struck (audition the hallucinatory breakdown of ""Deep Blue Meanies"" off their second effort)
column8: tweaking dance music's tropes just enough.

column1: But their musical ambitions began to crown last year when they released a single on Brooklyn's idiosyncratic dance imprint
column2: Golf Channel. ""Unleash the Golem Pt. 1"" was a brooding and glowering 16 minutes
column3: darker than anything else the duo had attempted

column1: No longer constrained to one side of a 12"" dance single

column3: adventurous and confounding sides of the year. ""Stoplight Loosejaw/Diatoms/Backwash"" is a 15-minute suite that begins with Czamanski hammering out low-octave piano chords with the sustain pedal down
column4: the tones left to waft and commingle with a migraine throb
column5: and effervescent gurgles as aleatoric as something Ricardo Villalobos might deploy. But whereas Villalobos presents a disorienting sense of stasis in his productions (or as a recent review put it: ""like watching traffic"")
column6: the mood here shifts minute by minute
column7: the compound volatile rather than stable. After the nuclear submarine-deep bass goes code red
column8: the piano re-enters-- this time as percussive and plinking as one of John Cage's prepared pianos-- a brief glimpse of sunlight behind black thunderclouds. Nearing eight minutes
column9: the synths distort and then turn blissful for a few moments and then menacing once again. And then there arise live drums and an unexpected bluesy guitar lick at the coda-- courtesy of Aner-- that will further confound expectations.

column1: A primitive drum machine pulse and more of Aner's guitar make for a Cluster-like respite on the brief ""Rogue Wave"" before one of the album's strangely satisfying experiments

Juju & Jordan sound content to play.

column2: R.E.M.'s fifth album

column4: contained something no one ever expected to hear from the Athens band. It wasn't the Wire cover or Steve Berlin's saxophone skronking through ""Fireplace"". It wasn't Michael Stipe singing what purported to be a love song
column5: which he had sworn at one point never to do. The record packed an even bigger surprise: an actual radio hit. Before the year was over
column6: ""The One I Love"" had peaked at No. 9 on the Billboard singles chart
column7: and this was back when that meant something. It was R.E.M.'s first foray into a mainstream crowded with hair metal bands
column8: mall-pop acts
column9: and AOR interchangeables. Few of these acts would survive the decade
column10: but this unlikely smash signaled only the start of the group's prolonged ascent.

column2: who had more in common with Wire than with then-popular Peach Staters Georgia Satellites
column3: find a spot in the public consciousness alongside U2
column4: Guns N' Roses
column5: and George Michael
column6: who all more or less owned 1987? R.E.M. cultivated an air of mystery that extended from their music (the obscure lyrics
column7: the refusal to lip sync in videos) to the packaging (mismatched tracklists
column8: head-scratching instructions to ""File Under Fire""). And ""The One I Love"" was an odd choice for a hit: Peter Buck's guitar possesses a rich
column9: strange grain that charges the song with vague menace
column10: especially when he unspools that psych-rock solo
column11: and the mosaic hook itself is split between Stipe shouting ""Fire!"" in an empty theater and Mike Mills adding a descending countermelody. Lyrically
column12: the song is one contradiction twisting into another: ""This one goes out to the one I love/ A simple prop to occupy my time."" Twenty-five years later
column13: it remains nearly impossible to parse the implications of that particular couplet; on the other hand
column14: 25 years later
column15: it's still worth trying
column16: as the latest in Capitol Records' reissue series proves.

column1: If 1985's Fables of the Reconstruction was their most self-consciously Southern record to date and 1986's Lifes Rich Pageant their most overtly political
column2: Document maintained both their regional self-definition as well as their indirect social engagement
column3: even going so far as to sample Joseph Welch reprimanding Joseph McCarthy. (""At long last
column4: have you left no sense of decency?"") The album is a prolonged meditation on the idea of labor
column5: opening with ""Finest Worksong"" before teasing out the implications on ""Welcome to the Occupation"". The defiantly chipper ""Exhuming McCarthy"" opens with the clack of Stipe's typewriter
column6: connecting the work of the band with that of the journalist
column7: and even ""Fireplace"" is less about the dance party than the preparations for it: ""Hang up your chairs to better sweep
column8: clear the floor to dance
column9: Stipe sings
column10: twisting his lines with each repetition until the entire building has been dismantled in an act of constructive destruction.

column2: R.E.M. never sound openly angry or at all condescending here. They may not have had day jobs by then
column3: but they saw their art as labor and their labor as art. Engaging with politics and social issues in their music emboldened and arguably ennobled them
column4: although this lyrical mission didn't alter their general approach to their work. The band's democracy was not only a professional strategy but a musical one as well: R.E.M. always worked best when the four members had equal representation in the songs
column5: and producer Scott Litt helps them find the right balance. Bill Berry is still the backbone
column6: a one-man rhythm section that allows Mills to play ingeniously melodic basslines. Stipe continues his trajectory toward extroversion
column7: bending his voice into a reedy sneer on ""Lightnin' Hopkins"" and rattling off a weird history of the 20th century on ""It's the End of the World As We Know It (And I Feel Fine)"". That may be his best vocal performance
column8: spirited and goofy and ecstatic. The album's most direct line-- ""I'm addressing the realpolitik
column9: from ""Exhuming McCarthy""-- may also be his funniest; this was
column10: after all
column11: the man who made a virtue out of mumbly obscurity.

column2: from the chiming fanfare that opens ""Finest Worksong"" to the sludgy trudge that closes ""Oddfellows Local 151"". He sounds intent on summing up more than three decades of rock guitar in these 40 minutes. Jangle was only the base from which to venture into surf
column3: post-punk
column4: country rock

column6: despite the thematic throughline

column2: saying Document is their weakest indie-label release is like saying Mothra was the least of Godzilla's foes: That big bug could still level Tokyo. Even five albums into their career

""has been engaged.""

When the Pet Shop Boys made their appearance at the closing ceremonies for this year's Olympics

At a Tame Impala show in Paris two years ago
column2: Melody Prochet
column3: French pop aficionado and multi-instrumentalist for the band My Bee's Garden
column4: became intrigued by the Aussie psych-rockers' scuzzy sonics. She struck up a conversation with the band's Kevin Parker after the show about how he achieved the band's signature
column5: blown-out bass sound in particular
column6: and a while later he asked My Bee's Garden to support Tame Impala on a European leg of their tour. Though her own band's sound was clean and somewhat precious
column7: Prochet remained drawn to the Tame Impala aesthetic. So when she decided to go solo
column8: she asked Parker to produce
column9: and to push her out of her comfort zone a bit. ""I tend to write songs with pretty chords and arpeggios
column10: and I was kind of boring myself
column11: she recalled. ""So I asked Kevin to destroy everything.""

column1: Mission accomplished. Recorded mostly at Parker's home studio in Perth
column2: the resulting self-titled debut from Melody's Echo Chamber is a record of psych-tinged pop with just the right amount of thematic darkness and grime around the edges. Prochet has a way with melody and a voice that places her among the top-tier graduates of the Trish Keenan and Laetitia Sadier school of dream pop
column3: but it's Parker's signature production that helps this record transcend its forever-in-vogue 1960s pop influences. (""This record was my dream sound
column4: Prochet said in a recent interview. ""I've tried for years to get it but finally found the right hands to sculpt it."") Full of immersive textures that give off an echoey depth and prismatic riffs that tumble through space
column5: Parker's production grants this record its own laws of gravity.

column1: The record's best songs tease out tension between soft and hard edges-- a combination of beauty and brittleness. Excellent lead-off single ""I Follow You"" pairs an exquisitely sugary melody with a fuzzy
column2: syncopated riff
column3: while the dreamy ""Crystallized"" detonates in its final moments into a kraut-y electro freak-out. Beginning with a toy-soldier beat and warmly warped synth tones
column4: ""You Won't Be Missing That Part of Me"" blooms into one of the record's best moments
column5: a kiss-off song that flips the usual script and takes the perspective of the heartbreaker rather than the heartbreak (""Because I lied with all my heart
column6: because it's time to change my life... Hold on
column7: you'll see it won't be that hard to forget me."") Parker's production is perhaps at its most stunning on ""Some Time Alone
column8: Alone""
column9: on which Prochet's arpeggios rain down like a chandelier being hit with a sledgehammer in slow-motion.

column1: The shards occasionally prick: ""Mount Hopeless"" is fittingly gloomy
column2: and there's even a song about post-plane crash cannibalism called ""Snowcapped Andes Crash"". But for as odd and chilling as that song sounds on paper
column3: it falls flat in execution
column4: languishing on a Side B that doesn't quite have enough ideas or surprises to save from some repetitive lulls. Prochet hasn't quite figured out how to do anything interesting with the macabre that lurks somewhere in this record's sound
column5: and it leaves you wishing she'd explored Melody's dark side a little more
column6: à la Broadcast's creepy masterpiece Tender Buttons. Of course
column7: Prochet's melodies can't quite fill the Broadcast-shaped void left in the wake of Keenan's untimely death
column8: but Melody's Echo Chamber is one of the more satisfying records to bear that band's influence in recent years. For a collaboration between a songwriter and a producer who helped push her to the outer limits of her vision
column9:
Melody's Echo Chamber is an impressively immersive debut.

Shamelessly infatuated with Cologne geniuses
column2: Kingston greats
column3: and New York cult heroes
column4: Tussle have never had a wholly unique sound. But they've definitely had a signature style. Taking off from dub's radical reduction of reggae to bass and noise
column5: post-punk's DIY appropriation of funk
column6: and krautrock's hairy perversions of academic electronics
column7: Tussle's minimalist beat contraptions were take-it-or-leave-it stark
column8: and occasionally indistinguishable. But they definitely felt like the work of one specific unit. And their live-in-a-room reconstructions of Classic Moments in Left-Field Rhythms always had a garage band grit and art-rock wonkiness that gave them the potential to be more interesting than their more bound-to-the-dancefloor peers.

column1: But they delivered on that potential a lot less often than you'd have liked them to. It wasn't exactly that if you heard one Tussle record you'd heard them all. But when those rhythms went slack
column2: it could sometimes feel that way
column3: considering the minor cosmetic mutations the band's sometimes arid
column4: always instrumental
column5: and all-beats-all-the-time attack had undergone since 2004's Kling Klang. It's hard to sell such stern and unchanging stuff to anyone but drum obsessives after an EP or two. Usually melody-free and sometime abstracted to the point of losing the funk entirely
column6: it's easy to tune out when instrumental avant-dance records feel by-the-numbers rather than driven by some itchy compulsion that translated to the feel of the beats themselves.

column1: The interesting twist on Tempest is that Tussle have seriously sweetened their sound. They may open with two forbidding slabs of digital dub-- the warm bass and corroded sonics suggesting a Jamaican studio outfitted with a souped-up Atari-- but for the most part this is the most luscious music Tussle have ever put their name to. The sound is always hazy or crisp just when it needs to be. JD Twitch of Optimo gives this new Tussle's more orchestrated
column2: more ornate sound an appropriately voluptuous sheen
column3: but he's not gaudy about it. Tempest is an oasis of carefully deployed glitz after the desert-like emptiness of some of Tussle's past records.

column1: And for a band that could come off like a bunch of groove-obsessed acetics
column2: never resorting to excess (like songs) when they could bear down on the crisp interplay of drums and bass
column3: much of Tempest is downright maximalist
column4: at least in context. ""Eye Context"" is a kitchen-sink epic that throws in playground handclaps
column5: disco whistles
column6: prog keyboard whimsy
column7: manic cowbell
column8: New Order bass
column9: hardcore rave stabs
column10: and stuttering old-school techno drums. But it also manages to arrange that potential chaos into something resembling a song
column11: with peaks and valleys
column12: thrills and lulls
column13: mood shifts and memorable moments. In other words it courts an audience beyond people obsessed with snare patterns
column14: and it's the album's obvious highlight. But even the second-tier tracks try a little harder than usual. When they look back to their old off-kilter live drumming on ""Lightly Salted""
column15: Tussle seemingly discover how expansive that egghead funk can feel if you suddenly add some sweet and sour texture

column2: much as it tries to escape Tussle's self-imposed Serious Dance Band limitations. They're still a group content to tastefully collage retro styles into almost-new and usually just-good-enough rhythm tracks rather than commit to the hard work of coining hooks
column3: crafting melodies
column4: or penning emotionally resonant lyrics. In other words
column5: any of the less cerebral and more visceral stuff that makes dance music work as well in your home and heart as in the club. And at the same time
column6: they're not willing to risk the alienation of true experimentation

column1: One of Tussle's biggest influences has always been Liquid Liquid
column2: and they invited a couple of Liquid Liquid members to guest on Tempest. Comparisons to that monumental New York unit don't do any favors for Tussle. On their handful of epochal early-80s singles

however sharply their cymbals are recorded.

Funk: It's what we talk about when we talk about minimal. The idea

column4: Afrika Bambaataa

column1: It was the release that followed Minimal Nation
column2: however

column4: but it was pock-marked with jazz and made sidelong glances at house. It's a concept-- Hood isn't even getting out of bed if there isn't a concept involved-- that he returned to again in 2000 and yet again this year
column5: with Motor: Nighttime World 3. Like many of his Detroit peers
column6: Hood has been a media-shy recluse (the last info I could find had him living in a small
column7: unnamed Alabama town)

column9: ambitious full lengths from each of the past two years

column1: Motor is reportedly inspired by the documentary film Requiem For Detroit

column7: nickel-plated simplicity of his mid-90s work; Motor is his most composer-ly work to date and without qualification one of his finest. It's a rangy
column8: diverse set

column2: but in the past the space between his beats has felt compressed
column3: cabin air allowed only so nothing suffocates. Motor is more generous. The tracks here unfurl luxuriously
column4: taking in big
column5: deep breaths and exhaling slowly. The younger
column6: more militant Hood might have bristled at this softness; the older Hood understands that softness is required. Indeed
column7: Motor is often ethereal and cinematic: the lush push/pull of ""The Exodos""
column8: the gutty music box ""The Wheel"". ""Slow Motion Katrina"" is one of the most beautiful techno tracks of the year
column9: a chopped and screwed siren laying groundwork for electric pianos to dawdle and spin.

column2: at roughly 79 minutes
column3: is too long by half
column4: but there's little else to complain of. Hood has been increasingly interested in longform
column5: narrative techno

column8: but it relies on the same blueprints: spartan rhythmic patterns
column9: no fat

it can't help but find some beauty in the wreckage.

'Pop/R&B']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Sub Pop']|2012-09-24 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:06:59.792946|"

It makes sense that Dum Dum Girls thrive in short form. Though they've turned into a versatile band comfortable in an array of styles
column3: their roots are in garage rock
column4: a sound that has a long history of mining the potential of brevity: It's a genre built on a foundation of singles
column5: whose holy text is aptly titled ""Nuggets""
column6: and whose philosophy is summarized by a song that went ""I hope I die before I get old."" Though Dum Dum Girls' latest EP
column7: End of Daze
column8: has a handful of gothic influences
column9: its all-killer-no-filler concision feels like a tribute to the spirit that they've have been riffing on since their debut
column10: I Will Be. Unhurried but not a beat too long
column11: End of Daze is a confident and comprehensive showcase for everything Dum Dum Girls do well
column12: from luxuriant
column13: moody ballads to driving
column14: melodic guitar pop-- and after 18 minutes
column15: it punches the time clock like somebody who just declared checkmate: Your move
column16: every other band trying to sound like this.

column1: This isn't the first time an EP has marked a turning point in the Dum Dum Girls' run. Last year's terrific
column2: four-song He Gets Me High EP introduced a newfound Chrissie Hynde-like depth to Dee Dee's voice and new-car glimmer to the Girls' formerly lo-fi sound. It was a collection of cheery
column3: upbeat songs about infatuation
column4: except for the closing track -- a cover of the Smiths classic ""There Is a Light That Never Goes Out"". Bold is the band that thinks it can bring something new to the song that's launched a million mascara tears
column5: but Dum Dum Girls pulled it off in grand style. Sandy's kick drum towered 10-stories high and Dee Dee sold the track's jet-black drama
column6: uttering her chilling delivery of ""I want to see people and I want to see life"" like a member of the walking dead. Now
column7: on End of Daze
column8: they're now penning some dark gems of their own.

column1: ""I've dreamed a death/ It's mine tonight
column2: Dee Dee drawls on the opener ""Mine Tonight""
column3: which smolders slowly and purposefully for a minute and a half before bursting into a panoramic blaze. Like Only in Dreams
column4: Daze is an exploration of the feelings triggered by the recent death of Dee Dee's mother. But while many of the songs on Dreams painted grief with a palette of simple descriptors and easy rhymes (""There's nothing to say/ At the end of the day/ I'm wasting away"")
column5: Daze expresses these emotions with more depth. Tears fall ""from desert eyes
column6: home is ""a sweet prison
column7: and both Satan and Icarus make cameo appearances. The lush
column8: cavernous sonics produced by loyal Dum Dum Girls collaborators Richard Gottehrer and Sune Rose Wagner echo this step forward
column9: too. Sonically and lyrically
column10: Daze does Dreams one better by blowing personal sorrow up to a mythic scale.

column1: From ""Mine Tonight"" to the wonderfully brooding cover of Scottish new wave duo's Strawberry Switchblade's ""Trees and Flowers"" (""I hate the trees and I hate the flowers
column2: and I hate the buildings
column3: the way they tower over me"")
column4: there's not a weak song in the bunch. But the last two in particular are perhaps the best Dee Dee's ever written. Dripping with conviction
column5: longing and remorse (and set off by an instantly transfixing opening line: ""I want to live a pure life"")
column6: ""Lord Knows"" has a melody so perfectly gratifying that you'd swear you've heard it before. And in some ways
column7: you have; it quotes the chord progression of ""Crimson and Clover""
column8: right down to the chiming riff that punctuates the end of each line in the verse. But ""Lord Knows"" inhabits its influences so fully and with such conviction that this familiarity only makes it that much more magnetic. It taps into the strange sorcery of the greatest rock'n'roll songs
column9: possessed with the power to set the world in slow motion for four commanding minutes.

column2: on the other hand
column3: kicks earth back into its orbit. A distorted riff quivers
column4: and then Sandy's echoey
column5: galloping beat drives the song forward. It is a song about the moment when your grief becomes portable
column6: the necessity of continuing to mourn but also carrying on. It's a simple
column7: emotionally sophisticated line from a band not generally lauded for their lyrics
column8: but
column9: coming at the end of a smartly sequenced narrative about darkness and redemption
column10: its conclusion is that much more affecting: ""Doesn't dawn look divine?""

column1: Garage rock is also a genre of quick burnouts
column2: its best compilations scattered with one- or no-hit wonders whose most explosive fireworks burned bright for three minutes before vanishing altogether. So perhaps the most profound way that the Dum Dum Girls have transcended their influences is the simple fact that they've stuck around
column3: pushed past their limits
column4: and gotten that much better. End of Daze is their best release. Much more than a stop-gap between LPs
column5:
it's succinct but irrefutable proof that this band's dynamite has a long fuse.

Inside the world of contemporary techno
column2: Ricardo Villalobos is a guru: Fans worship him
column3: skeptics think he's a crackpot
column4: and he doesn't seem to care much either way. Parts of his discography read like Spinal Tap for dance music: In 2006 he released a track that looped Serbian brass bands for about 37 minutes
column5: and a year later
column6: he made a mix for the London club Fabric consisting entirely of new Ricardo Villalobos productions
column7: which is like giving a toast at someone's else's wedding about your own marriage. Halfway through the mix
column8: a woman starts angrily delivering her opinions on how to deal with chicken giblets. Then the big Japanese drums come in. From where
column9: it's unclear. In Villalobos tracks
column10: all doors are trap doors. The music he makes is loose
column11: chaotic
column12: and highly detailed
column13: but the overall effect of it is like watching traffic: In the end
column14: nothing really happens. His gift
column15: though-- and this is where the worshipers start to worship-- is that a different kind of nothing seems to happen every time.

column1: His output from 2006 to 2012-- which is basically the moment he waded into the deep end-- is a catalog of extremes: On the one hand
column2: you get these long
column3: linear
column4: endlessly unfolding pieces of music like his Fabric mix; on the other
column5: you get 37 absurdly repetitive minutes of Serbian brass bands. Dependent and Happy-- a series of five vinyls or one CD that picks up where the Fabric mix left off-- is his most substantial solo release in five years
column6: and basically an extension of the kind of music he started making on the Fabric mix. Over the course of its 80 minutes
column7: we hear people talking
column8: cars honking in the street
column9: and someone playing the bongos. Naturalistic sounds blend into synthesized ones
column10: and synthesized sounds imitate the natural world. Villalobos wanders in to play a few notes and then disappears again.

column1: There comes a point in listening to his music that almost any sound feels like it might belong. That's the exciting thing about it. That's the disorienting thing about it
column2: too. Dependent cements a slow evolution from left-field house music to something like sound collage or electroacoustic composition pinned to a house beat. Every element is carefully managed
column3: but the outcome mimics that haphazard feeling of real life. And like life
column4: Dependent moves in a straight line. Whatever repetitions are there feel accidental
column5: like a trick of perception. (Your brain
column6: after all
column7: craves patterns
column8: and will make them whether you like it or not.) Even drums-- techno's anchor-- can vary from bar to bar
column9: sprouting weird extraneous noises as they go.

column1: Given the open nature of the music
column2: the tracks that seem easily excerpted from Dependent are also the ones that feel most out of place while listening to it as a whole. ""Put Your Lips""
column3: for example
column4: is as good a place as any to sample what it is Villalobos sounds like in 2012
column5: but when it comes up int he course of the album it feels self-contained-- a strange quality when the beauty of the music is how radically open it sounds. In the end
column6: it's the looser tracks that form the album's backbone. When I first put the needle down on ""Tu Actitud""
column7: I thought the record had been cut wrong. The music seems to start in medias res-- like it's always been there
column8: but you
column9: the listener
column10: just fell into it.

column1: I hesitate to be prescriptive about these things
column2: but both the vinyl and digital experiences are great in their own ways: Digitally
column3: you can just let the music run
column4: which can be more hypnotic; on vinyl
column5: having to change sides every 12 minutes or so is a constant reminder of just how substantial the set is. Over the past few years
column6: Villalobos has become almost mystically preoccupied with sound. ""There is a fairly strictly limited range of frequencies available for the production of electronic music
column7: he mused in a 2011 interview
column8: surrounded by very nice-looking speakers that resemble the bells of trombones. ""When you 'marry' these with all these acoustic recordings that have all these atmospheric spaces
column9: it is in some ways a complementation of the things that electronic music lacks.""

column2: he's talked down software like Ableton
column3: which offers pre-programmed instruments at affordable prices that Villalobos
column4: with his impossible ears
column5: can identify in ""two seconds."" Instead
column6: he uses modular synthesizers
column7: building each electronic element from raw wave forms. Bar soap? No. He makes his own. (Maybe now is the time to mention that the vinyl edition-- i.e.
column8: the one for the hardcores-- has three extra tracks
column9: all of comparable quality to anything else on the CD version. Villalobos
column10: of course
column11: encourages attentive listening; most of the vinyl only has one track on each side
column12: which is a very different experience from listening to it as an almost continuous block of sound.)

column2: he's a snob. He's monkish in his austerity. There's also nobody making the kind of music he's making right now. Like last year's collaboration with Max Loderbauer re-imagining tracks from the catalog of German jazz label ECM
column3: Dependent breaks down genre and expectations
column4: but does it with a polite kind of confidence. It recalibrates the ear. Maybe it's appropriate to assess it like a drug: Side effects may include a heightening of sensitivity to the sound of the world around you. Call his tracks ""environments""-- my guess is
column5: he would. In them
column6: even melody-- one of the most basic components of music-- can sound totally foreign. It's true that destruction can be an act of creation
column7: but the same goes the other way around: In building
column8: Villalobos
column9: with his big ideas and cheerful disposition
column10:
tears down.

""I was totally out of my element
column2: but you have to do these things in life to change and grow
column3: to learn about yourself and to learn about other people as well... I don't know if I can even work with these [Cuban musicians] because they're on a totally different level musically
column4: and I feel so inferior
column5: but then you play them something of yours
column6: and it's not that they feel the same exactly
column7: but they don't know how you created what you created. So you're both in an unknown
column8: so to speak.""—Mala
column9: to FACT
column10: on the origin of his debut LP.

column2: the dubstep pioneer sets himself to an ambitious task.  Challenged by musical sage Gilles Peterson to mix soundsystem culture with the traditional melodies and instruments of Cuban music
column3: Mala traveled to Havana to retrieve those sounds from their source
column4: on a kind of musico-anthropological expedition. And though the album doesn't work in many places
column5: it's a laudable attempt to mix together two styles which are
column6: at first appearance
column7: utterly alien to one another.

column1: If anyone has earned the right to try his hand at bringing such disparate worlds together
column2: it's Mala. The man is to dubstep what Primo is to boom-bap: a living legend with as much influence as any single artist in defining a beloved sound. The difference between the two producers
column3: and the reason that LP-devotees haven't heard of Mala
column4: is that dubstep
column5: as a dance genre
column6: is powered by the single. Mala's never even released a full length record before-- only singles and dubplates.

column1: That this is Mala's first proper album is a key to the record's problems-- he's mentioned in past interviews that he's uncomfortable working within the confines of the long player. He's not used to making separate tracks cohere to each other
column2: and the discordance between songs on the album makes for transitions that are less seamless than they ought to be.
take the first two songs released from the album about a month and a half ago.  The B-side
column3: ""Calle F""
column4: is a wonderful makeshift jam session
column5: bringing together driving bass with keys and snappy Cuban snares. It's highly atmospheric with huge amounts of space to complete the vibe. On the other hand
column6: the A-side
column7: ""Cuba Electronic""
column8: is dark and dense
column9: with a grating automated sampled bark that adds to a general urban dissonance.

column1: Fans of exotic musical collages like Madlib's Speto de Rua-- Dirty Brasilian Crates Volume One or Frankie P's Hazy Nights in the Heights will enjoy the former. Fans of Kode 9 and Skream will enjoy the latter. It would take a hell of a broad taste range to enjoy both
column2: and even a listener with that eclectic a sensibility would have a hard time listening to ""Cuba Electronic"" and ""Calle F"" back to back. Though both are examples of extraordinary musicianship
column3: they just don't work together.

column1: Mala had only one request of his coworkers. He asked Cuban jazz pianist Roberto Fonseca
column2: his talented band
column3: and other Cuban collaborators to play their music at his favorite tempo
column4: the traditional 140 BPM. The producer then took those sounds home (apparently leaving the country with ""a hard drive's worth of music"") and toyed around with the samples for months on end
column5: eventually bringing in his trusted friend Simbad to help validate his work.  But unfortunately
column6: in the process of sculpting tracks
column7: Mala couldn't seem to decide which part of the album's title to honor. Most of the tracks here are forced to pick sides between ""Mala"" and ""in Cuba.""

column1: ""The Tourist"" is a slightly distorted version of a son montuno
column2: a subgenre of Cuban folk much admired for the way it swirls together the cooperative strings of bass guitar and piano. And even though we know that Mala is behind the boards
column3: he never seems willing to enter the fray.  The opposite is true on ""The Tunnel"" where the upbeat Havana drums at the bottom of the mix are completely overwhelmed by blaring synth
column4: rendering their presence entirely moot.

column2: there are a few tracks on which Mala gets the mix exactly right. ""Change"" is one of these
column3: a heady brew of spacious keyboards
column4: dubstep thump
column5: and beautiful Cuban brass.  ""Changuito""
column6: which features and is named after the OG Cuban percussionist finds the two drum masters riffing off one another in a thrilling exhibition
column7: two hyperbolic talents at play. And ""Ghost""
column8: perhaps best of all
column9: maintains the purity of Cuban handclaps and vocal exhortations while slowly blending in the ominous clouds of that weaponized DMZ sound.

column1: But these rare cohesive exceptions highlight the larger problem with the majority of the album. That Mala frequently eclipses his collaborators here is no surprise-- after all
column2: this is a Mala album. That they eclipse him the other half of the time is a good thing
column3: too-- a sign that he's humble enough to let others take the lead. But when two admirable entities participate in a collaborative project
column4: you expect to see two pairs of handprints pressed firmly into the concrete of the finished work. And too often here
column5: one pair is missing
column6: hovering just out of sight and leaving behind only the trace imprint of a couple of fingertips
column7:
a contribution so slight that it's barely even there.

If you were a Dinosaur Jr. fan the first time around
column2: it still seems amazing

column6: and he punctuated songs with jokes about J Mascis. Pointed tunes like ""The Freed Pig"" were followed by pre-recorded taunts played on a portable tape deck

It's unclear where everyone is in the reconciliation process at this point-- Mascis isn't all that effusive outside his guitar solos-- but part of what's made Dinosaur Jr. a great band is the ongoing tension between the group's leaders. (For his part
column9: the eternally mellow drummer Murph doesn't seem to be bugged by the bickering.) At this point

column2: bands getting back together to relive the glory days is nothing special. But it takes a certain kind of group to reunite and create vital music. In most cases

column4: J
column5: Lou
column6: and Murph are straddling the line between the two: On Beyond and Farm

column8: they sounded very much like they did in the pre-Green Mind SST years. I Bet on Sky's title offers a hint that they've gone in a slightly different direction for  album three (it's worth noting they've now matched their output of the first 80s run). The shift's easy to explain: I Bet on Sky feels like the material that emerged after Barlow was fired: 1991's underrated Green Mind
column9: 1993's alt-rock crossover Where You Been

column11: 1994's Without a Sound.

column2: more spacious feel to those albums; if you go back to the 1985 self-titled debut

When the Jon Spencer Blues Explosion returned to the stage two years ago after a six-year layoff
column2: their mission was philosophically simple
column3: if physically demanding: They just had to live up to their reputation as the perpetually sweat-soaked band that showed the 90s American indie underground how to get down. And as that 2010 reunion tour-- which coincided with extensive reissues of the band's 90s-era catalog-- continued to rack up positive notices well into 2011
column4: there was little doubt that
column5: even well into their 40s
column6: frontman Jon Spencer
column7: guitarist Judah Bauer
column8: and drummer Russell Simins still possessed the stamina of their twentysomething selves.

column2: what the Blues Explosion could bring to the table as a rebooted recording act was far less certain. From their 1991 debut through to 1998's Acme
column3: the band had undergone a dramatic evolution from no-waved scuzz-punks to studio-savvy funkensteins
column4: but one that had seemingly run its course as they entered the new millennium: 2002's Plastic Fang saw the band awkwardly try to temper its sound into '70s-Stones suaveness (tellingly
column5: it's the lone Matador JSBX release to not receive the reissue treatment)
column6: while 2004's Damage reverted back to the Acme game-plan of enlisting a supporting cast of hip-hop heavyweights (DJ Shadow
column7: Dan the Automator
column8: Chuck D)
column9: but in a manner that ultimately normalized the band's sound rather than redefine it. So a new Blues Explosion album in 2012 presents no obvious game plan. Do they make a sleek
column10: radio-friendly blooze-rock album in attempt to muscle in on some of them Black Keys bucks? Do they try to score cred points with the Ty Segall set by revisiting their early-90s avant-noise roots? Or
column11: given the Blues Explosion's track record of reconstructing black musics ranging from Mississippi Delta blues to Shaft-esque funk to NYC rap
column12: do they try to put their own absurdist spin on contemporary R&B?

column2: the answer is: none of the above. Which is the best possible outcome
column3: really: The Blues Explosion barrel through the album's 12 tracks as if they have no legacy to uphold
column4: no expectations to live up to
column5: and nothing to lose. Stripped of the cut-and-paste studio trickery and celebrity cameos that defined the band's records from the mid-90s onward
column6: the self-produced Meat and Bone boasts no ambition beyond capturing the Blues Explosion in straight-up
column7: no-bullshit rock'n'soul mode. It essentially provides them with a chance to rewrite their post-Acme history
column8: and posit the question: what if the botched back-to-basics mission of Plastic Fang was salvaged by the maniacal gusto of Extra Width?

column2: it's that Spencer sounds genuinely humbled. In the early 90s
column3: the Blues Explosion were distinguished not only by their fondness for the sort of blues-based tradition from which so much punk and indie rock tried distance itself
column4: but also by Spencer's penchant for hip-hop-inspired self-aggrandizement; ""Blues Explosion"" was not only his band's name
column5: but his most utilized lyric
column6: as if he were practising a form of inter-song product placement. But with Meat and Bone
column7: pretty much the only ""Blues Explosion"" you get is printed on the album cover
column8: and Spencer's banter here-- ""Are you ready for your new career? Need a J-O-B
column9: ""I feel like a god/ But I still got a problem paying the rent""-- leans toward the self-deprecating musings of someone who's aware he's no longer the king of the scene.

column1: Amid a 90s indie rock environment that frowned upon rock-star posturing
column2: Spencer's shameless shout-outs to himself came off as playfully arrogant
column3: if not outright provocative. But Spencer understands it's the sort of rhetoric that holds less power today
column4: when self-promotion isn't so much a cheekily effective way to assert a persona as a practical necessity for any aspiring indie act. So on Meat and Bone
column5: the focus is less on theatrical myth-making than reasserting the band's real-deal bona fides: three men in a room making one big racket. While ""Bag of Bones"" and the Orange-tinted ""Get Your Pants Off"" suggest the band haven't unlearned all of their funk finesse
column6: Meat and Bone gradually forsakes its congenial groove for pure smash-and-grab insolence
column7: hitting a feverish peak with the New York Dolls-damaged ""Danger"" and the contorted glam boogie of ""Black Thoughts""
column8: on which Spencer seemingly sums up his time out of the spotlight by declaring
column9: ""Without a doubt
column10: this is the worst vacation I have ever been on!"" But what makes Meat and Bone a success-- despite simmering down into a mid-tempo murk during its home stretch-- is that the Blues Explosion never assume their comeback is assured. They're reapplying for the job of America's most raucous
column11: hardest-working rock'n'roll band
column12:
and will let the sweat speak for itself.

The state of British black metal has always been a bit of a sore spot for folks across the pond. After Newcastle-upon-Tyne's most famous export
column2: Venom
column3: christened the genre and helped to inspire a horde of Scandinavian innovators
column4: England's contributions to the black arts were few and far between. In the mid-1990s
column5: Cradle of Filth's first few albums were a rare spark that illuminated the fog for a few years
column6: but Dani Filth and company dimmed into sub-mediocrity. The blackened grind duo Anaal Nathrakh and experimental armor-clad group the Meads of Asphodel have been continuing bright spots and the progressive crew Akercocke were solid enough
column7: but only in more recent years has metal's spiritual homeland given rise to a new crop of interesting
column8: engaging
column9: and innovative bands that have taken black metal by the horns and twisted until it suited them.

column3: Wodensthrone
column4: Fen

column11: Axnaar
column12: Vanyar

column19: looking even further back

column23: and their third full-length sees them back in fighting shape.

column3: blasting straight into a flurry of fairly straightforward black metal that slips into a clean
column4: glistening melody halfway through. The gentle
column5: yearning folk of interlude ""Æfterield-Fréon"" is heartbreaking in its sparse
column6: simple beauty
column7: and leads into the scathing
column8: up-tempo ""A Memorial"". Both ""The Swart Raven"" and ""The Glorious Plain"" juxtapose bleak
column9: biting tremolo with sections of a rousing
column10: chanted chorus stretched across an acoustic skeleton
column11: one of Winterfylleth's favorite (and most pompous) devices. It works here
column12: though
column13: and its various appearances over the course of the record are more charming than eyeroll-inducing. Dark romanticism permeates the album's lyrics and atmosphere
column14: and the ever-present blastbeats rumbling in the depths provide a solid anchor for the more fanciful moments.

column4: ""The Threnody of Triumph"" sounds less like a lament than a battle cry. The buildup and payoff from 3:20-3:49 alone makes this album worth checking out

In a year of adjective-rock album titles
column2: Mirage Rock is as telling of a descriptor as Celebration Rock. The difference is that Japandroids' intentions matched their achievements-- Celebration Rock was a winning testament to good times and good rock music at its most life-affirming. Mirage Rock
column3: on the other hand
column4: evokes an emptiness that couldn't have been intentional. Like an actual mirage
column5: there is no there there on Mirage Rock. All the elements for a typical Band of Horses album appear in their right places-- Ben Bridwell's honeyed whine
column6: the straightforward thrust of the guitars
column7: the earnest hippie-dippiness of the lyrics-- and yet the music dissipates instantly upon impact. Mirage Rock is so lightweight and inconsequential that it really does seem more like an illusion than a record; it's wispy and indiscernible
column8: as if the people who made it had no vision for what it should be.

column1: Band of Horses themselves have become something of an apparition-- what they appear to be aren't what they really are. With 2007's Cease to Begin
column2: Bridwell unveiled a version of Band of Horses that was not the Band of Horses of the group's beloved 2006 debut
column3: Everything All the Time. The original members-- including Mat Brooke
column4: who had been a bandmate of Bridwell's since their days together in the Seattle indie rock band Carissa's Wierd-- had quietly departed. By 2010's Infinite Arms
column5: which found the band signing to Columbia
column6: Bridwell had shed another member and added two more. Frontmen retaining a group identities despite losing their backing musicians is nothing new
column7: of course
column8: and Bridwell made sure to publicly declare Infinite Arms a very different beast from the first two BoH records. But if you cared about this group at all
column9: it was difficult to hear that album and not try to pick out the things that made Band of Horses what it used to be
column10: even if most of those things had been systematically removed by Bridwell and replaced by a flatter
column11: shinier
column12: more overtly southern rock sound.

column1: If Infinite Arms marked a significant turn away from the starry-eyed
column2: backwoods indie rock of the band's early sound
column3: Mirage Rock moves boldly forward into the realm of radio-conscious pop that its predecessor only toyed with-- although ""bold"" may be too strong a word for a record this mellow and inoffensive. The rush of emotions Band of Horses channeled on its first two albums has slowed to an intermittent trickle
column4: collecting into a very shallow and sad-looking puddle of a record containing nothing and reflecting nothing.

column1: Band of Horses was never the hardest riffing band in the world
column2: but it's disheartening to see just how far they've moved away from actual rock music here. Much of the album falls into the mold of ""Slow Cruel Hands of Time""
column3: a hazy folk-pop tune that aspires to the soft-focus comfort of 1970s AM radio staples like Dan Fogelberg and John Denver. And Bridwell has neither the lyrical insight nor the vocal gravitas to go any deeper than its superficial veneer allows.

column2: even on Band of Horses' good records. But he used to make up for it by pushing his music out as wide as it would go
column3: until it wrapped you up like the warmest of bear hugs. Mirage Rock
column4: in comparison

column6: hinting at an emotional catharsis that never arrives. ""How to Live"" moves along on a snappy start-stop drum beat
column7: but only reaches a peak courtesy of a stinging guitar solo cribbed from Neil Young.

column2: relatable sentiments into neat and clean three-minute packages-- typified by the band's irresistibly heart-tugging breakout song ""The Funeral""-- is obvious and not without merit. But over and over again on Mirage Rock
column3: this talent is used to serve up Americana-flavored junk food devoid of substance. The back-porch shuffler ""Long Vows"" and the annoyingly repetitive ""Shut-In Tourist"" are essentially placeholders for better classic-rock songs by Bread and Crosby
column4: Stills & Nash
column5: lazily flashing soft-rock signifiers without adding any depth of their own.

column2: he sings
column3: like a callow bro confusing Bane for Noam Chomsky. The line elicits a moment of embarrassment so shudderingly profound

column5: Mirage Rock seems to have been conceived

to say the least. Perhaps it's best to just squint your eyes and hope it disappears altogether.

Gaslamp Killer has emerged as a producer who developed his charismatic notoriety by pushing his corner of bass music into a something resembling a close cousin of acid rock. His highest-profile production gig
column4: Gonjasufi's 2010 album A Sufi and a Killer
column5: was psychotropic hip-hop at its most elemental
column6: stuff so gristly and eye-peeling-- and occasionally beautiful-- that it reset the parameters for what you could nod your head to (assuming you could still remember where it was located). Pick up that same year's Death Gate EP or jump back a year to his 2009 EP
column7: My Troubled Mind
column8: and you can hear that sound emerge from a mindstate reared on 1980s VHS horror
column9: hippy-biker exploitation soundtracks and car-trunk g-funk
column10: stuff that expanded on the Left Coast underground influence of '96-era Shadow and Automator into a red-lit grindhouse. And it becomes even clearer soaking on a mix like 2009's Hell and the Lake of Fire are Waiting for You!
column11: one of the best documents of his persistent efforts as a DJ to turn clubland crate-digger culture into an altered-state travelogue worthy of his Low End Theory bonafides. Flipping Dungen
column12: Can
column13: and space-age 70s European production library music in the same set as Smif N Wessun and Organized Konfusion is exactly the kind of approach that makes running in the same crowed as Flying Lotus and Teebs sound like a natural destination in context.

column1: Breakthrough is a record that fits Gaslamp Killer well as a rundown of everything he's been able to imprint on his career so far. It's a run of occasionally disorienting
column2: sometimes frantic
column3: usually unnerving trips into distinct corners of psychedelic and experimental influence that spark briefly to reveal vivid life and fade out just as quickly. And it succeeds
column4: driven as it is by up-front
column5: iron-fisted live drumming that's mixed up into the red. He builds around that neck-snap percussion in ways that dredge up an air of constant tension
column6: ebbing and flowing through so many different forms so quickly that it creates this air of unknowable dread; once it seems like there might be a consistent method to it
column7: it switches focus to some other angle. Pick a style
column8: and he'll coax out the most nerve-twisting elements of its abrasive side-- synthesized dirges that snap a wire and start sparking off into something noisier (""Meat Guilt""); Morricone panic attacks that sound purpose-built to soundtrack a splattery low-budget drive-in movie death (""Critic""); organ-driven garage funk given a stoner-metal lurch (""Dead Vets"").

column1: But calling Breakthrough the most direct line into Gaslamp Killer's singularly unhinged vision would be a bit misleading: As befitting an artist who's as important for who he's hung out with and given opportunities to as he is for what he's done on his own
column2: this is a record that leads him to filter his ideas through a number of like-minded collaborators. Sometimes it's just a matter of finding the right piece to plug in: Miguel Atwood-Ferguson's keening strings pierce through the wall of synth-hesher fuzz on ""Flange Face""
column3: Gonjasufi is his usual otherworldly presence on the spiritual admonishment of ""Veins"" and the outreach of ""Apparitions""
column4: Daedelus incorporates touches of 8-bit vertigo into ""Impulse""
column5: and Shigeto helps steer the percussive rattle of ""Keep it Simple Stupid"" through an analog squall that makes the title's advice sound a bit beside the point. And sometimes it's the collaborative aspect that actually drives the song itself-- Gaslamp Killer's heritage-driven enthusiasm for Turkish music
column6: previously heard in tracks like My Troubled Mind cut ""Turk Mex""
column7: is fleshed out with live instrumentation supplied by Amir Yaghmai on ""Nissim"".

column2: all right
column3: but how far deep has he worked himself in there? Because Breakthrough-- which it is and isn't-- feels like the kind of record his adventurous precedent has made into a familiar signature. It's the album that gets at his recent creative mode most definitively
column4: the one people might figure he had in him rather than the one that changed anybody's minds about him. Which is good news
column5:
really-- expecting a dose of high-quality doom-struck instrumental hip-hop and getting it is the kind of thing only jaded fad-hoppers get disappointed over. The idea that it might draw more fans to his stylistic strengths means the potential for a subsequent breakthrough of Cosmogramma advancement can wait a bit. This one offers plenty to wrap your head around in the meantime.
