column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18117/homepage_large.a226d6a8.jpg|Mourning in America and Dreaming in Color|528.0|Brother Ali|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rhymesayers/Warner']|2012-09-19 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:07:12.365327|"

When it comes to giving a fuck
column2: Brother Ali just doesn't give a fuck. He will run up in foreclosed houses in North Minneapolis with a crew of neighborhood poverty-fighting activists and end up in the back of a squad car for it. He'll antagonize his tour sponsors when they get cold feet about his lyrics
column3: like in 2007 when Verizon cut off their endorsement in the wake of ""Uncle Sam Goddamn"". And when given the opportunity to hide behind somebody else's ""post-racial"" melting-pot narrative that portrays him as some kind of cultural outsider (""the blind albino Muslim rapper!"")
column4: he publicly owns up to his place of white privilege
column5: keeping full recognition of the advantages he was given even as he holds pride in adhering to the tenets of what's still treated in America as a minority faith. He has all the work ethic and self-respect of someone who doesn't worry about what other people think
column6: and all the community awareness and sense of justice of someone who can't picture anything more important than what other people think.

column1: As much as he's solidified his place in the indie rap game
column2: Ali always seems like he's in the process of working out new things-- how to best balance out his roles as an artist and an activist
column3: how to reflect on his past and learn from his mistakes and conflicts
column4: and how to translate each new phase of his life and his experiences into work that maintains the precarious balance between being imposing and being humble. Mourning in America and Dreaming in Color is where the political agitation of The Undisputed Truth and the social humanism of Us intersect
column5: and there's no vague platitudes or defeatist cynicism here. Ali is a man with a purpose and zero interest in holding back
column6: someone so attuned to what it takes to move a crowd with his voice that he trusts in its power to let some complication and nuance support all the confrontational honesty.

column2: because when Mourning in America gets political
column3: at least in the early goings
column4: there's not much in it to make well-meaning liberals feel better about themselves. The America that frustrates Ali is one that still has something to pull for
column5: as he puts it in the Cornel West-featuring leadoff track ""Letter to My Countrymen"". With the idea that it's hard to want to better a country you're too defeated to see the good in
column6: he sees hope in the potential of its citizenry from the ground up-- ""It's home
column7: so we better make the best of it/ I wanna make this country what it says it is"". That it isn't what it says it is gets broken down severely in ""Mourning in America""
column8: taking off from the familiar rhetorical device of contrasting first-world militarization and guerilla insurgency-- ""terrorism is the war of the poor"" and ""warfare's the terrorism of the rich""-- to also get down to the essence of how that mindset doesn't even need another country's involvement
column9: and how it eats America at the core with shoot-first police and for-profit prisons. And just as he stands looking at American society as someone who's in a position to benefit from its injustice but doesn't want to
column10: he does the same with pop music for ""Won More Hit""
column11: breaking down the music industry's entrenched exploitation of black artists and tearing at it from the inside. These are the words of someone who wants himself and his country to be exceptional and powerful and successful without somebody else needing to suffer to make that happen-- any other victory would be pyrrhic.

column2: there's that something in Ali's voice that makes being preached to feel rousing instead of tedious. He builds verses that
column3: while rich with wordplay
column4: never let cleverness get in the way of clarity. Not that he doesn't get clever-- the bait-and-switch jokes of ""Need a Knot"" are a bit corny but sly nonetheless
column5: even when the clean-cut punchlines to the narratives about how he used to ""move white"" or ""chop green"" play their hands. And there's always the notion he practices-- that making every word and sentiment crystal clear not only gets the message across but the raspy yet booming impact of his flow too. So when he uses that voice and that lyrical bluntness to lay his personal life bare
column6: it puts a resounding weight behind it
column7: one that feels honest to a fault. Detailing how he had to cope with a grueling
column8: crew-fracturing tour itinerary upended by his father's suicide and the death of close friend/fellow Minneapolis rap mainstay Michael ""Eyedea"" Larsen in ""Stop the Press"" turns what could have been straightforward autobio into a clash between vulnerability and willpower. And ""All You Need""
column9: where he has to address his neglectful ex-wife and tell his son why his mother isn't around anymore
column10: does a grown-man job of placing the blame where it stands but makes sure to keep empathy in the picture: ""I know you wonder why your mother does the things that she do/ Well
column11: it's not 'cause she doesn't love you/ It's because she grew up in something they call 'foster care'...""

column1: Mourning in America and Dreaming in Color is more of a refinement than a deviation for Brother Ali
column2: even though there's one prominent change that could set off questions-- the departure of longtime producer ANT
column3: who was unavailable while on tour with Atmosphere. Taking his place for full production duties is Seattle's Jake One
column4: who maintains the Rhymesayers family connection and should have all the cred he needs solely on the back of White Van Music collaboration ""The Truth"". That precedent's met well on this slate of beats-- not too distant from the vibrant soul of Us
column5: but a bit more upfront and varied
column6: versatile conceptually (the pseudo-trap of ""Need a Knot"") and characteristically (the seething heavy funk of obligatory step-to-this-mic-and-get-fucked-up cut ""Say Amen""). And Ali adjusts his flow and cadence accordingly-- he flips more variations on his delivery than any of his previous releases
column7: and any illusions that he's one-dimensional in any respect are finally and fully eliminated on this album. That doesn't just go for his voice or his lyrics or his subject matter; it feels true to the man himself. If that means working out how much of his politics are personal and vice-versa
column8:
so be it. He contains multitudes.

"|16941.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16941-brother-ali-mourning-in-america-and-dreaming-in-color/|7.9|Nate Patrin

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18222/homepage_large.55f26532.jpg|Look to the Sky|2082.0|James Iha|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['The End']|2012-09-19 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:07:13.011156|"

It's been over a decade since both Billy Corgan and James Iha could call themselves members of the Smashing Pumpkins
column2: and now they've finally got something else in common: It's 2012 and they're both sorta acting like it's still 1998. Yet this tenuous link becomes an exception that proves the rule. While Corgan is still airing out grudges and resentments against any and all bands that ticked him off and fans who had the gall to stop buying his records after Adore
column3: Iha is calmly going about the business of releasing what sounds like a logical follow-up to Let It Come Down
column4: his solo record which celebrated its 14th birthday this year. This clearly has the potential to work out better for Iha. Bands who sound and sell like Smashing Pumpkins don't exist anymore
column5: and the leveling of the playing field has allowed artists to become stars even while making the sort of modest music Iha favored on Let It Come Down: peaceful
column6: easy California folk-rock
column7: dewy AM-radio pop. From the sounds of Look to the Sky
column8: Iha does want to be a star. Unfortunately it's on 1998's terms
column9: and he's prepared with bafflingly outdated alt-rock songs that could comfortably sidle between choice cuts from Marcy Playground and Semisonic and get their asses handed to them.

column1: It didn't have to end up like this. Iha's built up a lot of goodwill over the years simply by not being Billy Corgan
column2: and if you're amenable to the sort of  KROQ-friendly alt he abetted in A Perfect Circle and attempted as part of Tinted Windows
column3: there are moments that can press your Buzz Bin joy buzzer. Check the whooshing raygun effects from ""Speed of Love""
column4: the meek and unexpected female harmonies on ""Make Believe""
column5: and you'll be able to overlook his rhyming
column6: ""You rush in with stars in your hair/ You cast your spell and float through the air
column7: in the first damn line. Plus
column8: you hear those chiming
column9: flanged arpeggios on ""To Who Knows Where"" and it starts triggering memories of songs like ""Believe"" and ""The Boy""
column10: very strong Iha B-sides that admittedly wouldn't have fit anywhere on Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness like the comparatively limp ""Farewell & Goodnight"" or ""Take Me Down"" did. Besides
column11: there is precedent for this kind of thing being done quite well and quite recently. After all
column12: wasn't the Pains of Being Pure at Heart's Flood-produced Belong a document of alternate history where Iha took the controls of the Pumpkins ca. Mellon Collie for about 40 minutes? It's almost frightening how close some of Look to the Sky resembles Belong
column13: though Iha mostly favors the mid-tempo
column14: big-chorus stuff (i.e.
column15: ""The Body""
column16: ""Even in Dreams"") and the album's one very unfortunate genre experiment (""Appetite"") is the sort of baritone burlesque piano maundering Scott Weiland attempted at his most far-gone on <a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=verbFuGymN8"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">""Lady
column17: Your Roof Brings Me Down"". Weiland's was much better.

column1: You can engage in this sort of cautiously optimistic evaluation process for about 10 minutes
column2: after which the music of Look to the Sky just does not matter. I'd feel more comfortable telling you Iha has nothing to say here. The problem is that he does
column3: and it's mostly just sad to see the cruel strictures of rhyme scheme cause someone to sing things he would almost certainly never think or speak. It might sound strange to bring up Iha's lyrics as unacceptable considering that
column4: with all due respect
column5: the bar's not really all that high in this field. Some might just go ahead and say that ""I'm traveling at the speed of love/ And sooner and later I'll be crashing"" is not a lyric that should emerge from the mouth of a grown-ass man. I'll give Iha the benefit of the doubt and say ""twee"" doesn't really have an age limit
column6: though the frequency of song titles like ""Summer Days""
column7: ""New Years Day""
column8: ""Make Believe""
column9: and oh yes
column10: ""Speed of Love"" tests patience merely by appearing on one's iPod.

column1: My bigger issue is that those aren't the kind of lyrics that should be coming from a guy who clearly knows how to put a song together and might've been sitting on these ones for the better part of a decade and a half. When Pains' Kip Berman sings an iffy lyric like ""Tell me again what the body's for/ 'Cause I can't feel it any more"" on ""The Body""
column2: the sentiment and emotional content is understandable even if you might want to phrase it differently. I can't even really give Iha's lyrics the dignity of cliché because clichés are truth for the most part. Most of this stuff has a strange aggression in its refusal to even bother making any sense. Here's the intro triplet on ""Waves"": ""Waves wash over me/ Drag me out to sea/ A tide pours slow-ow-ly
column3: but wait... how are the waves washing over him if he's not already out to sea? Iha has no time for your follow-up questions
column4: pressing in a maudlin deeper register: ""Tonight I feel so alone/ Tonight I've wandered far from home."" Got that? And
column5: for God's sake
column6: does he really rhyme the title of ""Till Next Tuesday"" with ""close the door till it's news-day?"" Even with that bashful voice of his
column7: the words become impossible to ignore and these aren't songs so much as a kind of mental tennis game where Iha serves and you put yourself in position to volley with a guess at the most obvious and often correct rhyme. ""Gemini"" becomes a highlight by default as it's about the only song here that doesn't adhere to a strict AA/BB pattern.

column2: but it's the context of Look to the Sky that makes it pitiable. Maybe slap some preset beats on it and trade out some of the guitars for synths of Gushers-like sickly sweetness
column3: attribute it to a post-Owl City new jack rather than a well-known guitarist from a 90s alt-rock titan
column4: and you might have something that all of a sudden shows up in Billboard's Top 20 without your having any idea where the fuck they came from. But in the aforementioned leveled playing field
column5: Iha gets exposed-- Look to the Sky expresses so little that could be considered real or truthful that it couldn't have been created out of some sort of emotional necessity and is aiming for radio formats that no longer exist. Or
column6: to paraphrase the most withering putdown of 1998
column7:
99% of its fans don't exist.

Since they started in the early 2000s
column2: Sic Alps' music has made its way into the world via a host of formats (7""
column3: cassette
column4: LP) and labels (Siltbreeze
column5: Slumberland
column6: and Woodsist)
column7: but however it arrived
column8: you could always count on one thing: It would be damaged. Songwriter Mike Donovan and drummer Matt Hartman sought an improbable union of pop sweetness and sonic hate
column9: blasting Kinks riffs through Pussy Galore's shredded speaker cabinets.

column1: But if you're the type who comes to Sic Alps looking to get your hair blown back
column2: the opening notes of the group's self-titled fourth album (fifth
column3: if you count the compilation A Long Way Round to a Shortcut) will be a bit discombobulating. The record begins not with the death rattle of a battered thrift-store amplifier
column4: but the harmonious tones of a hired string section. It's a soft but sinister set of songs-- the Bay Area's answer to the Velvet Underground's self-titled record. Where Sic Alps were once wasted and wobbly
column5: they are now stoned and serene.

column1: However messy the old Sic Alps sounded
column2: they worked hard on it. Donovan would track his vocals and guitar alone in a single take
column3: after which Hartman would step in to help graft on scuzz and grunge one 8-track layer at a time until things sounded right (or wrong in the right way). Napa Asylum
column4: the group's third LP
column5: was a culmination of this approach-- a grand Zen Arcade-style throw-it-all-in-the-pile double album that pinballed between zonked-babbling
column6: free-form noise collages
column7: and a few worthy garage-rock nuggets. In terms of sheer sprawling weirdness
column8: it would have been hard to top.

column2: though. Shortly after that record's release
column3: the band booked some time with San Francisco studio mainstay Eric Bauer to record some follow-up material. But in the spring of 2011
column4: Hartman abruptly parted ways with the band. Those songs-- versions of which saw release throughout the following year on a series of 7"" singles-- had a little bit of extra breathing room
column5: but kept the fuzz cranked. By the time Sic Alps went to record another full length
column6: they had the grit out of their system.

column2: also recorded with Bauer
column3: isn't the band's first encounter with a professional studio
column4: but it's certainly the most professional-sounding set of songs that they've ever assembled in one. For the first time ever
column5: it sounds like the rhythm section was recorded in the same room at the same time. Where Donovan once came off like the Mission's most sinister hippy
column6: on Sic Alps he's affected a more amiable persona: the Malkmus-style gentleman slacker. After wafting in on a cloud of drone and hiss
column7: ""Polka Vat"" congeals into a relaxed-fit groove worthy of Wowee Zowee­-era Pavement. ""Moviehead"" perfectly pairs a twanging Creedence-style riff with lyrics that drop references to ""shred-dogs"" and bengaline silk. There's still a little bit of scuzz
column8: but it's been pushed to the background
column9: leaving Donovan alone in center frame. But as a lyricist
column10: he's at his best on Sic Alps
column11: sinking bizzaro couplets left and right. On ""Rock Races""
column12: he sounds
column13: for the first time ever
column14: optimistic. ""Let's knock every wall down for love
column15: he sings. And when Donovan's words trail off into lazy la-la-las
column16: the string section picks up the slack. Sic Alps rarely reach for a grand gesture
column17: but here they skirt into sublimely cinematic territory.

column1: The pro studio production hasn't reduced the essential strangeness of Sic Alps' music
column2: though. Rather
column3: the transition from lo-fi auteur to visionary singer-songwriter is Drag City's standby narrative-- the path that produced some of the label's most resonant artists
column4:
from Will Oldham to Bill Callahan to David Berman. Scrubbing up doesn't always mean selling out.

Cruel Summer is not Kanye West's record; listening to it
column3: I found a certain peace in reminding myself of this. Cruel Summer is a crew album
column4: a chance for all of the rappers he's signed to his G.O.O.D. imprint during the past few years to momentarily feel like they own the place. They range from former greats like Pusha-T to half-decent punchline rappers like Big Sean to entourage bottom-feeders like CyHi the Prince
column5: and spending a long time in their presence can feel like being trapped in a reality-TV house. Kanye drops by occasionally
column6: but he mostly feels a million miles away. Kanye's career has been built on maniacal quality control
column7: but Cruel Summer feels uncharacteristically disposable.

column1: Even the title is botched. The album arrives on September 18
column2: with school in session and the season's cruelest days far behind us. This day late/dollar short feeling persists throughout. The production is often cluttered with unnecessary effects
column3: like the vocal ""whoa-oh-oh"" synth pads West threw on his remix of Chief Keef's ""I Don't Like"" when he couldn't figure out how to improve it. Songs take ill-advised turns. After verses from Raekwon
column4: Common
column5: Pusha T
column6: 2 Chainz
column7: and CyHi the Prince are hurled at you like a handful of action figures on ""The Morning""
column8: the song inexplicably changes key so that Nigerian singer D'Banj can warble in Auto-Tune. ""Sin City"" starts out with a generic dubstep low-end before transitioning into a mortifying slam-poetry performance by Malik Yusef. And then when that's over
column9: who should come along next but... CyHi the Prince. Again.

column1: If Kanye had resisted the temptation to stuff Cruel Summer with his LucasArts production magic
column2: it might have worked as a pure bid for rap radio's dead center. With ""Niggas in Paris""
column3: West got closer to that center than he'd been in a while; My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy
column4: for all its accolades
column5: struggled to find its foothold on the pop charts. There are a handful of hits here
column6: and they range from the pretty good to the fantastic. You've probably heard them all by now
column7: and they will outlive this comp; they are are the reason the record deserves to exist.

column2: the producer who brought Kanye the ""Paris"" beat; he shows up on with ""Cold"" (formerly known as ""Theraflu"")
column3: a sleekly coursing West solo track in which he hashes out the increasingly silly details of his life -- his jealousy towards Kim Kardashian's 72-day husband Kris Humphries; his adventures go-karting with Polish models -- with his trademark aggrieved sense of urgency. Hit-Boy also offers up ""Clique""
column4: a transfixing
column5: Timbaland-like collection of hiccups and synth strobes. ""Clique"" is haughty
column6: spotless
column7: and coldly perfect; it sounds like bottle service. West takes the opportunity to sneer at former CIA director George Tenet's car.

column2: there are three tracks from Hudson Mohawke
column3: the rising Glasgow producer whose compellingly fractured beats have caught the ear of hip-hop figures like Just Blaze. His contributions -- ""To the World""
column4: ""The One""
column5: and ""Bliss""
column6: which makes use of 2009's ""Ice Viper""-- don't sound like anything off of his riotous Satin Panthers EP
column7: but they are welcome signs that Mohawke is moving into high-profile hip-hop territory. ""To the World""
column8: a track featuring R. Kelly that's built off a slightly stiff drumline beat and swarms of string plucks
column9: benefits from an animated turn from Kanye
column10: who mangles Francis Ford Coppola's name hilariously and taunts Mitt Romney in a nagging singsong for failing to disclose his taxes.

column1: But once the early run of singles are out of the way
column2: things start to go south. By the time you get to Kid CuDi's dribbly alt-rock solo turn ""Creepers"" (actual lyric: ""If I had one wish
column3: it'd be to have more wishes/ Duh... Fuck trying to make it rhyme"") it seems like even the artists involved have left the room. Pusha-T huffs and snorts a lot
column4: but drops lines like ""wherever we go
column5: we do it pronto."" You'd never guess from his performance here that he was once a member of Clipse. Big Sean
column6: who's shown flickering signs of wanting to actually rap lately
column7: sits back and offers terrible puns on the word ""ass."" R&B singer Teyana Taylor comes nowhere near her work on Twisted Fantasy.

column2: which has become as much of an art for Kanye as his music over the years
column3: that is most blatantly missing here. The only people who seem to recognize what's at stake are the old-timers. Ma$e
column4: of all people
column5: shows up out of nowhere on ""Higher"" to lick shots at his former Bad Boy rival Loon: No one cares
column6: but he still sounds slick. And then there's Ghostface
column7: who roars to life at the end of ""New God Flow""
column8: a track based off his own ""Mighty Healthy"" from 2000's classic Supreme Clientele. Ghost's appearance is an obvious prestige-casting move
column9: but still a perfect one
column10: and he makes the most of it
column11: reliving his Pretty Toney days one more time. A handful of guests aside
column12: though
column13: none of G.O.O.D. Music's personalities do much to justify their newfound prominence. If Cruel Summer is meant to be an argument for the label's other talent
column14:
it makes a weak case.

In the world of Woods
column2: minor refinements mean a lot. Bend Beyond is the Brooklyn band's seventh album in seven years
column3: and in broad terms it isn't all that different from Woods' other records. The group's reference points remain the same: 1960s sunshine pop
column4: the Grateful Dead's improvisational explorations
column5: and 90s lo-fi. The most immediately distinctive attribute of Woods' music-- and its most decisive point of demarcation-- is singer Jeremy Earl's childlike falsetto; if you can't appreciate Earl's voice
column6: Woods' rapidly growing discography (which is also rounded out by various EPs and singles) will be a non-starter. Otherwise
column7: that body of work is among the most consistently enjoyable from any young indie rock band in the past several years
column8: and Bend Beyond is Woods' most approachable gateway yet.

column1: As for the minor refinements made on Bend Beyond
column2: they aren't all that minor at all
column3: actually-- the songwriting is more disciplined
column4: and the production offers more clarity and variety than ever before. While 2011's Sun and Shade exhibited Woods' jammy side amid the usual folk-pop gems
column5: Bend Beyond is all pop
column6: all the time
column7: with only one song running past the four-minute mark
column8: and only by 25 seconds. That song happens to be the foreboding title track
column9: already one of the all-time great Woods tracks and an in-concert highlight that runs two or three times longer live than on record. But even in truncated form
column10: ""Bend Beyond"" is a thrilling example of Woods' ability (in spite of living thousands of miles away on the opposite coast) to conjure the spirits of L.A. folk rock and the dark vibes emanating from the scene's seamy underbelly. If ""Bend Beyond"" is the album's best song
column11: ""Is It Honest?"" sounds like the record's surest hit
column12: opening with a shimmering electric-guitar riff that might be the single catchiest moment on any Woods album. (Though it's rivaled by the harmonica blowing like a train whistle through ""Cali in a Cup"".) But darkness lingers in ""Is It Honest?""
column13: too-- ""It's so fucking hard to see
column14: Earl spits in the chorus
column15: an uncommonly aggressive moment in this group's otherwise peaceful
column16: pastoral universe.

column1: Whatever battles are being waged in the lyrics against demons real and imagined don't carry over to the music
column2: which is effervescent and sweetly touching and unmistakably presented with well-earned confidence and new-found polish. On past records
column3: Woods might have obscured the delicate campfire ballad ""It Ain't Easy"" in layers of tape hiss. (Tape manipulator G. Lucas Crane is mostly absent throughout Bend Beyond.) But here it shines in crystal-clear fidelity
column4: and the stunning melody earns such treatment
column5: carried on sparkling acoustic guitar and Earl's tender
column6: heart-tugging vocal.

column1: In an interview with Pitchfork earlier this year
column2: Earl said the idea on Bend Beyond was to spend a little more time on the songs than usual
column3: as opposed to the extemporaneous approach of past releases: ""That was always our style: embrace the spontaneous energy of recording a song the minute after it's written
column4: do the overdubs really fast
column5: mix while recording. For this album
column6: we decided to re-record stuff more."" You can hear that extra care in the fantastically menacing organ riff on ""Find Them Empty"" and the chiming guitar riff that lifts the chorus of the charming ""Impossible Sky"". For the first time
column7: Woods have given their own songs their full due on record.

column1: Fans of Woods' ""spontaneous energy"" might lament the relative straight-forwardness of Bend Beyond (even if the band's recent self-titled split release with Amps For Christ suggests they haven't entirely left that approach behind). But Woods' greatest strength has always been songwriting
column2: and sharpening the focus and cleaning up the production has only enhanced the band's welcoming melodies. Besides
column3: it's about time this chronically undervalued group broadened its audience a bit. After Bend Beyond
column4:
there are plenty of other great Woods records that await neophytes.

Nothing reminds you that you've been taking the Sea and Cake for granted quicker than listening to a new Sea and Cake album. When they play together
column3: John McEntire
column4: Sam Prekop
column5: Archer Prewitt
column6: and Eric Claridge occupy an indie rock niche all their own
column7: and their utter consistency at turning out well-wrought
column8: prettily cerebral records might help explain why they've never met a hype cycle that paid them any mind in spite of the quality of their music. Trends come and go
column9: but the Sea and Cake are more or less constant
column10: and have been for almost 20 years. Even when what they do comes into vogue
column11: as it has a few times
column12: they seem to be left out of the think pieces because they're not new.

column2: their music sits in an open-air bar on a beach in St. Kitts
column3: but sonically
column4: it sits on a beach between Lake Shore Drive and Lake Michigan
column5: with an occasional chill in the breeze blowing off the water. Sam Prekop's voice is a breathy wisp that champions tone over diction
column6: and as such it fits in with the self-effacing playing of his bandmates. Listening to the gorgeously captured sounds on Runner
column7: the band's 10th LP (counting last year's relatively concise The Moonlight Butterfly)
column8: it's clear that these are highly accomplished musicians
column9: but there's not a single moment where all that prodigious technique isn't kept on a tight leash. Prewitt might unleash a ragged and fiery lead on ""Skyscrapers"" after the first verse
column10: but McEntire's neat and orderly production keeps it from raising the temperature of the song too much.

column2: that kind of imposed restraint might be suffocating-- oddly
column3: it helps this group's music breathe. ""Harps"" is practically all breath
column4: a song so light it feels as if the slightest gust could snatch it away-- Prewitt's e-bowed guitar part gives it a sort of Berlin-period Bowie vibe
column5: and McEntire's crisp drums are its only ballast. It's easy to just let the album play and fill the room while you do something else
column6: but a close listen reveals a lot of thought and care in the way these songs are constructed. One of the most startling left turns on the album comes when ""The Invitations"" transitions unexpectedly from a normal
column7: breathy Sea and Cake song into a sort of beachy
column8: droney disco track halfway through.

column1: Runner shakes out as one of this band's most subtly varied albums
column2: and it can be an immersive listening experience if you give yourself over to it. Outside of ""Harps"" and the energetic opener
column3: ""On and On""
column4: the songs work more on a textural and sensory level than as melodically memorable set pieces
column5: but this does nothing to diminish their beauty or the craft evident in their construction
column6: nor the fact that this is the kind of music that can wrap you up easily in something as simple as a compelling chord sequence
column7: as it does on the title track. The Sea and Cake may never be the thing that everyone is talking about
column8: but here
column9: they're as reliable as ever
column10:
and that has its own kind of value.

Back when major label hip-hop CDs were released with greater frequency
column2: the most common criticisms were their length and inconsistency. With Illmatic as a guiding light
column3: and 2xCDs generally regarded as little more than a stunt to double soundscan counts or overreach artistically
column4: critics lamented the lack of editing and conceptual cohesion of many of the most interesting albums of hip-hop's commercial golden age. Gunplay's latest mixtape
column5: 601 & Snort-- presumably retitled from 106 & Snort due to potential legal similarities to the BET television program-- is proof that this isn't always an ideal. There's nothing on 601 & Snort to complain about
column6: but it feels like a shadow of a great record
column7: a stopgap whose place in history will largely be determined by what happens next in Gunplay's career.

column2: unquestionably
column3: one of the most vibrant and entertaining personalities in hip-hop
column4: a throwback to a time when skilled
column5: animated rappers like Busta Rhymes and Redman ruled the airwaves; it's difficult to understand why isn't already in deodorant commercials or stoner movies. (Luckily
column6: he is in hilarious promotional videos that give an idea of the his star power.) But while some were aware of the rapper's considerable strengths prior
column7: it was Gunplay's guest spot on Kendrick Lamar's ""Cartoon & Cereal"" that seemed to push him into the national media spotlight. Where he had previously been a hero to roughneck rap connoisseurs
column8: thanks to his explosive turns on ""Mask On"" and ""Rollin""
column9: his move to the attention of bloggers and label heads (he was signed to Def Jam earlier this year) has been marked by a stylistic shift. Where last year he ripped across contemporary-sounding Luger tracks
column10: this year he's moved on to freestyling over older 90s production: RZA beats
column11: Pimp C beats
column12: the ""Deep Cover"" instrumental. Luckily
column13: Gunplay always sounds engaging
column14: even when he doesn't sound particularly focused.

column1: When he snaps into a well-written verse
column2: it goes from being a fun tape to transcendent. 601 & Snort feels slight because it contains only one true moment like this: ""Bible on the Dash""
column3: a freestyle over a Morris Brothers-produced Shy Glizzy song called ""Southside"". The track finds Gunplay locked in: ""I asked the pastor
column4: 'what's the fastest way to heaven for a bastard with a tarnished past
column5: give me an honest answer?/ With all this Hannah Montana without the Arm & Hammer am I gonna get the slammer or the casket?'""

column1: But the bulk of the tape is less a collection of songs than well-curated beat tape of one-off freestyles
column2: a generic Rick Ross collaboration
column3: and an artist hinting at what more he could accomplish given the right situation and motivation. Maybe Gunplay is one of the few rappers who understands that just spewing out releases
column4: his best tracks mixed amongst sub-par collaborations and half-hearted efforts
column5: isn't an ideal marketing strategy for all artists
column6: and we'll get a diverse
column7: 21-track monster of a Def Jam LP by year-end. In that case
column8: 601 & Snort feels like a pretty decent warm-up
column9: a stopgap measure to keep us entertained and anticipating. On the other hand
column10: the considerable delays
column11: non-releases (what happened to Bogota?)
column12:
and light catalog of full-on 2012 songs worth celebrating aren't positive signs. These records will only maintain buzz for a limited time. A solid project looks pretty vital right now.

Finnish death-laced doom metal band Hooded Menace's style-- that is
column2: horror-- might be more important than their sound. They aim to bridge 1990s death metal menace and the arch and stomp of early doom dudes
column3: but that's almost the sidecar; their name is lifted from Amando de Ossorio's classic 70s Blind Dead series
column4: their cover art depicts cross-shaped tombstones
column5: maligned skulls and ghouls on the hunt for souls
column6: and their music features film samples about vampires and vivified corpses. ""There's no Hooded Menace without horror. It wouldn't be the same
column7: multi-instrumentalist and bandleader Lasse Pyykkö said in a 2010 interview
column8: articulating the obvious. ""We all dig horror films from the past and find it a vast source of inspiration.""

column1: On two previous full-lengths and a bevy of splits
column2: such inspiration has served as kindling for Hooded Menace's music
column3: giving their lurch a primal and welcome urgency. But on this year's Effigies of Evil
column4: Pyykkö and Pekka Koskelo's debut for Relapse Records
column5: such aesthetic influence overrides the music itself; that is
column6: these eight tracks often seem more like attempts to convey the pair's gruesome obsessions than to make a memorable metal record. Pyykkö has long talked about how the sinister atmospheres and wretched images and sounds of horror films fit Hooded Menace
column7: but Effigies of Evil often feels like an attempt to fit the band to those qualities
column8: to force these winding doom riffs into unnecessarily unbecoming directions. The result is often more mawkish than scary. ""Summoned Into Euphoric Madness""
column9: for instance
column10: offers the creation myth of a wolfman
column11: or
column12: as Pyykkö roars by way of unmemorable refrain
column13: the ""legend of the lycanthrope."" But his tendency to growl the lyrics and distend the syllables-- you know
column14: like a legitimate wolf-- seems mostly inane
column15: a distraction from the song's otherwise brilliant cascade of riffs and powerful march toward the end. The same holds for ""Curses Scribed in Gore""
column16: a rhythm-and-pitch-bending marathon that rumbles heavily enough for three minutes before settling into an instrumental bridge ostensibly meant to sound creepy. It lands much closer to goofy. And again
column17: so it goes with the corpse-prodding ""Crumbling Insanity""
column18: in which Pyykkö goes for full zombie vocals above a funerary guitar line-- that's after a sample about the rising dead
column19: mind you. If this all sounds more scary than silly
column20: please beware of totally terrifying things like hobgoblins and bugaboos.

column1: Considering that it's creation was so fueled by film
column2: Effigies of Evil feels strangely more episodic than cinematic. Hooded Menace are the kind of act that demands a concept album
column3: with transposable threads spread throughout the record
column4: tying the horror show together for an inescapable hour. They've teamed here again with the lyrical partnership of Tanya Sim and Kevin Campbell (Pyykkö has long been clear about his distaste for writing lyrics); taken by themselves
column5: their stanzas of creatures seeking ""unholy rebirth"" or overlords out for ""torture and mutilation"" are where the horror show actually finds its payload. But Pyykkö's decision to eviscerate the lyrics with the lowest bellow he can manage means they largely only work in the liner notes. The words get little support from the music
column6: either
column7: hidebound as Hooded Menace are to song-length bursts of brutality that flicker and soon disappear. This record feels as much defined by its exits as its overwhelming sense of anything.

column1: In another 2010 interview for That's How Kids Die
column2: Pyykkö was asked whether
column3: given his obsessions and inspirations
column4: he'd ever considered making scores for horror movies. Pyykkö claimed incompetence
column5: saying that
column6: despite being the person who writes Hooded Menace's music and plays everything but drums on each record
column7: he's also a lousy keyboard player. ""It's a pity that I suck at keys
column8: he said. ""Horror keyboards would rule and if you really could play piano it damn surely would help."" Effigies of Evil feels very much like Hooded Menace's attempt to subvert the question
column9: to create their own horror shorts within their music rather than using their music to score them. Occasionally
column10: a few riffs sit memorably
column11: and a few shifts in structure are notably unorthodox
column12: even for these Candlemass adherents. But overall
column13: the reach required for that grasp is still beyond their means and methods
column14: turning all their attempts at being dire into a looming cloud of indifference. This time around
column15:
perhaps Hoodied Menace would be more apt.

""This is a foreground."" That was the last lyric left hovering in the mist of Grizzly Bear's breakout 2009 album
column3: Veckatimest
column4: and it's a pretty good image to describe what it's like to listen to one of their records. The key word there is ""a
column5: signifying one of many. Whether it's the ethereal
column6: friendly-ghost vibes of Yellow House or Veckatimest's pristine chamber pop
column7: Grizzly Bear create music in deep focus; what's going on in the margins of their songs is just as important and expressive as the center. Taking cues from artists like Talk Talk and Van Dyke Parks
column8: the Brooklyn four-piece make pop music with an ear for the ambient
column9: asking us to notice the importance in detail
column10: the beauty of texture
column11: and the foregrounds that exist all across our spectrum of perception.

column1: While there's no question that Grizzly Bear's last two records have sounded gorgeous
column2: critics of the band have wondered if that's enough. Shields
column3: the band's fourth and most compositionally adventurous record
column4: should put those concerns to bed. Though full of baroque
column5: detail-rich production and latticework melodies
column6: Shields also offers an emotionally resonant core. The album is an excavation of loneliness
column7: melancholy
column8: and self-reliance. It's also a demanding record
column9: without an instantly gratifying single like ""Knife"" or ""Two Weeks"" to hook restless ears. But the rewards that come from immersing yourself in it are odd and profound. Shields feels like a summation of Grizzly Bear's strengths
column10: drawing a line from the muddy
column11: minor key sonic palette of Ed Droste's home-recorded Horn of Plenty and stringing it to the heels of boundless ambition.

column2: ""Sleeping Ute""
column3: is the lone track retained from an aborted early session in Marfa
column4: Tex.
column5: and it feels like a continuation down the path Daniel Rossen ambled on his 2012 solo EP
column6: Silent Hour/Golden Mile
column7: which sought solace from a busy life in the elements. ""If I could be still as that gray hill
column8: Rossen pines
column9: before giving into an admission of humanness: ""But I can't help myself."" Chris Bear's drum rolls emulate thunder while chords crest with the rhythm of waves. ""Sleeping Ute"" moves so evocatively and theatrically like water that it sounds like a big-budget radio play of The Tempest. But as grandiose as it often gets
column10: ""Ute""
column11: like Shields itself
column12: always retains a certain intimacy. These are dark and anxious waters
column13: the choppy and tumultuous movement of the sea inside.

column1: Grizzly Bear have acquired a reputation for politeness; maybe it was the bow ties
column2: maybe it was the passive-aggressive inflection of their most famous lyrics (""Would you always? Maybe sometimes? Make it easy?"")
column3: maybe it was just that Michael McDonald collaboration. But Shields serves as a visceral reminder of how unsettled and uncanny Grizzly Bear's music often feels. (Remember that superbly creepy video for ""Two Weeks
column4: full of smiles pulled tight enough to induce nightmares?) The pair of lead-off singles
column5: ""Sleeping Ute"" and ""Yet Again""
column6: each find a way of transcending the tension of ""putting on appearances
column7: one of Grizzly Bear's favorite themes. The lyrics of the Droste-led ""Yet Again"" detail repression and repose (""Take it all in stride/ Speak
column8: don't confide"")
column9: which makes the payoff-- a final minute of instrumental fury lead by the torrent of Chris Bear's percussion and the squiggling lightning strikes of Rossen's guitar-- that much more cathartic. Dynamic shifts like this give the record an air of uncertainty that contrasts with the sheer beauty of the arrangements.

column1: Grizzly Bear is a democracy. They stand in a horizontal row on stage
column2: and you get this sense of intra-band egalitarianism from their records
column3: too. By now
column4: each of the four members has cultivated his own unique and expressive vocabulary
column5: and each feels integral to the sound of Shields. Chris Bear's drumming is lyrical and swift
column6: moving from delicately timed details to big
column7: booming ruckuses (check out the way his percussive rumbles in the background of the verses of ""Yet Again"" foreshadow its avalanche of a conclusion)
column8: while Chris Taylor's penchant for haunting effects and gently buoyant grooves adds an otherworldly weightlessness to these soundscapes. Droste's voice resounds with ache and longing
column9: and there's a newfound and welcome gravel to his vocals that add a raw
column10: unvarnished quality to songs like ""The Hunt"" and ""Speaking in Rounds"".

column1: But Shields showcases Rossen's growth most of all. The songs that sounded distinctly his on Yellow House-- ""Little Brother"" and ""On a Neck
column2: On a Spit"" in particular-- were grounded in a familiar folk sound. But from the rollicking strums that propel ""Speaking in Rounds"" to the creaking
column3: rusted textures he teases out of ""The Hunt""
column4: Rossen's playing on Shields is a seamless blend of folksy textures
column5: jazzy fluidity
column6: and proggy imagination that feels downright inimitable. Joni Mitchell has called her own idiosyncratic tunings as ""chords of inquiry
column7: and this feels like an apt term for the tones and inflections that Rossen conjures too. They're stirring precisely because they're unresolved: the progression that ends ""Speaking in Rounds""' chorus
column8: for example
column9: chirps like a series of unanswered questions
column10: each one a little more urgent and insoluble than the last.

column1: And that's a great part of Shields' emotional pull: The album reverberates with a sense of irresolution. This was present before with Grizzly Bear-- Yellow House's ""Colorado"" concludes with a fireworks display of unanswered pleas: ""What now? What now? What now?""-- but never to such a degree. And it's that tension that makes returning to Shields so rewarding. The final one-two punch is a stunner
column2: where the poignant grace of ""Half-Gate"" gives way to the magnificently epic ""Sun in Your Eyes"". If ""Sleeping Ute"" was the start of a sojourn from society
column3: ""Sun"" ends not with a return but a transcendent kiss-off: ""So long
column4: I'm never coming back.""

column1: This closing pair of songs speaks to the album's complexity. Despite the formalism and easy-to-love production
column2: Shields' best moments inflict a sense of unease that wriggles under the skin and lingers after the final crescendo. But this collection of unvarnished shipwreck-spirituals is after something more challenging than a feel-good ending. With Shields
column3: Grizzly Bear make certain demands--hold still
column4:
listen closely-- that seem downright radical in a busy and impatient world.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18217/homepage_large.f4666879.jpg|Kill My Blues|29596.0|Corin Tucker Band|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Kill Rock Stars']|2012-09-17 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:07:19.139031|"

At what age does your feminist anger stop being qualified as ""riot grrrl rage""? Kill My Blues
column2: the Corin Tucker Band's sophomore album
column3: is being heralded as the former Sleater-Kinney bandleader's default to her '91 Olympia factory settings. This is a fantastic prospect surely stoking our 1990s nostalgia and wiping the weird taste of her previous album off our palates
column4: but it doesn't quite hold.

column2: 39-year-old woman
column3: and on Kill My Blues she tackles topics that weren't on her riot girl radar at 20: mortality
column4: the joy of conception
column5: how she could use a vacation. She is singing from the perspective of her life as the mother of two kids who's maybe a little wistful for days when her life was a little more carefree and Joey Ramone was still above ground. Her rage is no more than that of any American who's paying attention in 2012.

column1: It's only natural that we'd want Tucker to stay put in her Revolution Girl Style
column2: Now! pose. Who wants our rock stars to get old? To change? Rock'n'roll is the province of the young. Therein lies the discomfort of our icons' maturing and making records that reflect their evolving ken. Fandom would be so much tidier if they could keep neatly fitting the nostalgic niche we hold for them in our hearts. (""My old life is dead
column3: sings Tucker
column4: joyful on ""Blood Bones and Sand""
column5: her song about the maternal tether.) Tucker is at the fore of the generation of post-grunge boom indie rockers
column6: punks who were close enough to glean the sad lessons of heroin and major label deals from a safe distance
column7: and subsequently they are still alive and fortified by the same communities that fostered them making music in the first place; it might be a while before we see any of these folks ""age out"" of the DIY scene.

column1: And so there we are with Kill My Blues
column2: on the heels of Tucker's solo debut
column3: <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14700-1000-years/"" target=""_blank""><i>1
column4: 000 Years
column5: a record the sounded better on paper than in real life (it turned out Tucker's Joni-phase produced her Hejira rather than her Blue). On tour
column6: Tucker saw how drumless balladry wasn't energizing her fans that live and love for her scream and guitar sheroics-- and so begat this return to form.

column1: The good news is the Corin Tucker of Kill My Blues is not the Corin of Heavens to Betsy
column2: nor is she the same woman we knew from that year when Dig Me Out forever blared from the stereo. The range of her voice is more expansive
column3: and there is an absolute control here that she's never had before; when she goes full-throttle
column4: the effect is stunning. Perhaps she's outgrown some Olympia-born punk shame about being a full-fledged rock singer; no longer aiming for raw and ragged and instead giving us the full Benetar. It's Tucker's voice that gives Kill My Blues its thrills.

column2: Tucker sings of coming to after years busy with raising her young family
column3: amid the GOP's War on Women
column4: confronting the same battles for women's lives and bodies that riled her two decades ago. She points the rhetorical finger at herself
column5: asking
column6: ""Did I fall asleep/ On the backs of the women that come before me?"" Musically
column7: it's the closest thing to a Sleater-Kinney moment on the record
column8: spirited and gnashing. Tucker's band are formidable old hands all-- onetime Unwound drummer Sara Lund
column9: one of the underground's great distinctive players and <span class=""s1"">Seth Lorinczi of Circus Lupus (if you are old) and Golden Bears (if you aren't) and Mike Clark
column10: the spare guy in the Jicks-- they give the pensive album some thrust. The strange part is that Tucker still plays as if Carrie Brownstein and Janet Weiss were at her side; there is a space around her that feels like it needs to be filled
column11: her antic rhythm and tempo don't always settle with Lund's in-the-pocket playing.

column2: but is uneven
column3: dragging toward the end. The high points are the ""Teen Spirit""-bite and twinkling keys of ""Constance""
column4: and Tucker's blistering tribute to Natalie Cox
column5: ""I Don't Wanna Go"". The album's best moment-- the bridge and solo flourish on ""Joey""-- happens two minutes into a song that otherwise goes nowhere. The cutesy ""Summer Jams"" feels long at four minutes and Tucker employs a string of clichés that are below her faculties. The album is self-produced and at times it seems they could have benefitted from some outside ears to help tighten things up. Tucker is unquestionably at the height of her power as a vocalist
column6:
but there are times where even that can't buoy Kill My Blues.

"|17043.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17043-kill-my-blues/|6.5|Jessica Hopper

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18215/homepage_large.a1efc341.jpg|The Inner Treaty|28951.0|Sun Araw|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Drag City / Sun Ark']|2012-09-17 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:07:19.789750|"

One of this year's nicest surprises was an album called Icon Give Thank
column2: which put roots-reggae vocal group the Congos together with experimental musicians M. Geddes Gengras and Cameron Stallones
column3: aka Sun Araw. The Congos are responsible for one of the most venerated albums in reggae history (1977's Heart of the Congos); Stallones is a guy from Long Beach who records gooey half-songs and peppers his interviews with reflections like ""life's a trip
column4: but it's heavy
column5: too
column6: and ""you have to just learn to continually create the situation inside yourself.""

column1: The pairing-- part of RVNG Intl.'s FRKWYS series-- seemed wacky but ultimately highlighted more similarities than differences. Sun Araw tracks usually consist of a few basic things: slow
column2: bubbling drum machine patterns
column3: strobing synthesizers
column4: and guitars processed to sound like the trickle and buzz of a jungle at night
column5: or a Rube Goldberg machine burping up its springs. Occasionally
column6: Stallones is inspired to sing
column7: and when he is
column8: he tends to keep it simple. (Most of his lyrics sound like variations on ""alright!
column9: ""yeah!
column10: or ""alright
column11: yeah!"")

column1: The connection to reggae isn't in the tracks' composition
column2: but in their texture and vibe. Like a lot of prime 70s Jamaican music
column3: Sun Araw albums function like a sonic sweat lodge: hot
column4: trippy
column5: and claustrophobic
column6: but joyful at their core
column7: a collection of a thousand sounds bumping into each other in a humid room.

column2: On Patrol and Ancient Romans
column3: could be as dense as Pink Floyd and 70s Miles Davis-- two good musical approximations of pitch blackness. His newest album
column4: The Inner Treaty
column5: focuses on a lighter
column6: more scattered side of his sound
column7: a sound rooted in gospel and the positive
column8: mystical explorations of jazz artists like Pharoah Sanders and Alice Coltrane.

column2: this is still Sun Araw
column3: and the end result still basically sounds like a neon compost heap. The difference between The Inner Treaty and On Patrol or Ancient Romans is scale: This time around
column4: the heap seems a lot smaller. The mix isn't as cloudy either. Instead of letting everything melt together-- ""melt"" being the most important verb in the Sun Araw dictionary-- Stallones keeps all the sounds pretty well delineated. The sounds themselves are more cartoonish
column5: too: the squiggles squigglier and the farts farther. The result is an album both more contained and more chaotic-- the sound of something icky growing in a petri dish.

column1: One interesting thing about Stallones' music in a broader sense is how much more it relies on black and nonwestern sounds than on white
column2: European ones. Stallones isn't the only young white artist who could be named here
column3: of course-- the slow rebranding of R&B as something hip and artistically credible is part of the conversation
column4: too. Fifteen years ago
column5: ""experimental"" and ""noise"" music was descended primarily from classical composition
column6: synth labs
column7: or largely male populations figuring out how to make weird
column8: harsh-ass sounds on shoestring budgets. Now reggae and dub are familiar touchstones for twentysomething bands on cassette labels
column9: and you get art-world-approved musicians like Oneohtrix Point Never naming DJ Screw as an influence-- evidence that the terms on which music being made by groups like Stallones' are changing.

column1: Stallones' particular gift is creating a space where things are always either barely coming together or almost falling apart-- a space where music can sound like it's coming to life on record. My understanding
column2: though
column3: is that most of what Stallones does is improvisational
column4: and my guess is that committing any of what he does to record is just playing the game of how music is traditionally released into the world-- as physical product. In that respect
column5: The Inner Treaty-- like all Stallones' albums-- is less a jewel box of finely honed compositions and more a rough sketch of how Stallones is currently thinking about how music might be put together. On Patrol and Ancient Romans were foggy and inward-spiraling albums; The Inner Treaty is clear
column6: toylike
column7: and sometimes even funny.

column1: His closest relation in recent history is Excepter
column2: a Brooklyn band whose single greatest talent as musicians was being able to sound like they'd unlearned how to play music entirely. And like Excepter
column3: Stallones seems more concerned with producing a lot of material than perfecting any of it. That's no slight. Part of what's exciting about an artist like Stallones is that you know he's already on to the next thing. Icon Give Thank
column4: the Congos collaboration
column5: came out in April. Two imaginative
column6: weird
column7:
genre-pushing records in one year-- not bad.

"|17041.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17041-the-inner-treaty/|7.0|Mike Powell

column2: the latest Drag City album by Ben Chasny's prolific Six Organs of Admittance
column3: opens with ""Waswasa"" and a full-bodied electric riff that's about as delicate as kickstarting a vintage Harley. From that first moment on
column4: the album makes plain that Chasny has made another of his trademark directional shifts

column5: straight-ahead
column6: no-nonsense break that reveals his ear for beats at their most unadorned and immediate-- though the way he chops the beat up every few bars and incorporates a floaty little psychedelic-soul guitar riff here and there hints at more familiar things to come. Other cuts like ""Vee in Detroit""
column7: ""Freddi's Popcorn""
column8: and ""Dreams of a Piece"" are little more than the sum of their drums

but anyone who listened to it then would be justifiably amped to hear what this Shadow kid would come up with next.

column2: and more able to hear it all as one flowing body of work. Take the ironically titled ""I Can't Concentrate""
column3: an 11-minute piece that hammers at its cycling figures with dizzying focus. Before it's even half over
column4: I forget about tracking each note and instead let the piece pour into my ears
column5: as if it were a kind of inverse magic eye painting. (It helps that ""I Can't Concentrate"" ends with a palate-cleaning bit of wailing free jazz). That track comes from Arms
column6: perhaps the strongest record here
column7: but there are many other spots on Score where hard-turning loops can mash your brain into blissed mush.

column1: If that sounds more excruciating than fun
column2: be advised that the extra material sprinkled throughout Score adds texture and diversity
column3: helping the band sound three-dimensional. Energetic remixes-- particularly two by Excepter's Nathan Corbin-- do part of that job. But the richest bonus comes from concert recordings. Zs have always been a phenomenal live band
column4: often sitting in a circle and leaning into the music until their breath and sweat coats the room (Mincek himself thought of Zs as ""one big muscle."") Some of the recorded evidence here-- particularly a tense version of the bubbling ""Bump""-- captures that experience with impressive accuracy.

column1: That real-life accuracy is something I've found occasionally lacking in Zs studio albums. I thought that was corrected by 2010's excellent New Slaves
column2: but now I wonder if I wasn't wrong about these early records too
column3: which feel infused with much more blood and guts than I remember. And the imagination in the compositions and precision in their execution gives Score a cumulative effect. That's not to say that any of these records-- except perhaps Arms-- is a masterpiece on its own. But when you take them all in together
column4:
Zs sure do sound like masters of their craft.

Editor's Note: The lead of this review has been changed
column3: as the original text contained a passage similar to one found in the Willamette Week interview linked in the piece. The author of this review
column4: who read the interview in question
column5: indicates that the similarity was not intentional. Pitchfork regrets the error.

column1: What's worse: the encroaching feeling that something's going terribly wrong
column2: or the fallout from the inevitable? On 2010's Mines
column3: not much was going right for Menomena's Danny Seim
column4: Brent Knopf
column5: and Justin Harris. The band was hardly talking
column6: their inability to communicate in a civilized fashion meaning that the record took over three years to complete. Something had to give
column7: and Knopf left the band. Seim and Harris figured out their communication issues
column8: laying bare to one another their proposed subject matter for Menomena's first record as a duo: Seim's realization that he had spent more time alive without his mother than with her-- she died in 1994-- and the fact that Justin's mother had essentially raised him alone
column9: his father a frequently flighty and difficult Vietnam veteran. It's not exactly the kind of thing that calls for balloons and party streamers
column10: yet Moms largely eschews the weighty devastation of Mines for an unusually dramatic tone; the most notable example of which are Justin's saxophone parts
column11: now more like fanfares than harbingers of doom. It's feasible that the record's bold sound might have been conceived to compensate for Knopf's absence-- and not in a bad way-- though it's hard to see how the vagaries of the songwriting that Knopf demonstrated on his most recent album as Ramona Falls would fit into Moms' emotionally raw feel. These aren't so-called naked songs in the singer-songwriterly sense; Moms often feels like turning up to a family function in the buff
column12: and letting everyone have it.

column1: If Mines was about possession-- note the cute baby grab of the title-- then Moms concerns itself with what we're given by others; ancestry
column2: in a word. But the push and shove here is how these familial endowments inspire gratitude and resentment. ""Hail Mary
column3: is this golden ticket all that you've left me? For the therapists to pawn off and retire on the proceeds?"" goes ""Baton""
column4: one of Seim's songs that deals less with regret than the anxiety over memories slipping away-- like ""I wish I could remember if my last words were sincere."" (The ominous and distant ""Tantalus""
column5: the name of a street near where Seim grew up in Hawaii
column6: seems to be about revisiting childhood as a tourist.) It freewheels through different intensities-- a light organ and skewy drum solo in the verses
column7: gradually intensifying to a chorus that's blustering and huge
column8: but made up of the erratic samples that characterized their earlier work
column9: which is definitely a tendency now more particular to Seim than Harris.

column1: True to the interview that originally revealed the band's fractious relationship
column2: Harris is considerably more direct lyrically. (As an aside
column3: it's quite eerie how much both men sound like Damon Albarn vocally.) ""Baton"" is followed by ""Heavy Is as Heavy Does""
column4: which opens with a bitter conversation between the piano's high
column5: pleading notes and unwavering lower end
column6: Justin cutting straight to the chase: ""Heavy are the branches hanging from my fucked up family tree."" Come the end
column7: bouts of saxophone inflate and burst
column8: combining with squealing guitar for an effect akin to driving around hairpinned back roads in the dead of night
column9: the rain pounding like bullets.

column1: Moms is without doubt the most aggressive record Menomena have ever made. ""Giftshoppe"" gamely bowls along with the sweet
column2: rhythmic chant peculiar to so many Menomena songs before wreaking a course of total disorientation; piercing piano reeling around huge drum fills (it's one of Seim's) and blurry synthesizer hazes that slosh rapidly between the speakers. Masculinity comes in for a kicking too-- ""You perverted
column3: aging fuck/ What age did your mind get stuck?"" Seim sings nonchalantly
column4: possibly to a mirror. ""Pique"" has less jagged
column5: more luscious production (though bears quite the guitar solo towards the end)
column6: but sees Harris once again compete for the record's most affecting lyrics: castigating his dad for his haphazard upbringing
column7: making him ""a failure
column8: cursed with male genitalia/ A parasitic fuck with no clue as to what men do
column9: and impossible to love."" The note with which he holds that last line feels like the climax of some (admittedly unusual) rock opera with a very non-rock opera subject; testosterone
column10: you got a lot to answer to.

column1: It's not tough to guess which ""tiny muscle"" Seim is pleading to work at the beginning of ""Capsule""
column2: where he's ""like a nervous random stranger at a glory hole."" The song kicks off with a growling guitar lurch
column3: veering into a verse characterized by the kind of bassline that's as cool as a stoner that keeps their wit about them even at points of maximum intoxication. Perhaps it's endemic of his being a ""perverted
column4: aging fuck"" that talk of glory holes gives rise to recollections of his mother
column5: though his realization that ""we never talked on a cellular telephone"" is a mark of his age and era. Things get darker on Harris' ""Don't Mess With Latexas""
column6: a conflicted ode to the seduction of someone half one's age (and IQ) which heralds its subject with elastic guitar splurts that sound like the products of windmilling arms
column7: choral ""huh huh huh""s adding to the theatricality. The only rumination on the subject not wrought by self-flagellation is the jaunty ""Plumage""
column8: which opens Moms in a similar way to how ""Queen Black Acid"" opened Mines-- as someone slips away
column9: though this time Harris is pleading rather than admitting defeat: ""I don't want to be just anybody to you/ I want to be your one and only mate for life/ Instead I'm just like everybody else who's tried.""

column1: The thing with songs about relationships is that the lyrical denouement needn't be the end. The arcs of these stories are varied
column2: but cyclical; plenty more fish in the sea
column3: and all that. The familial
column4: ancestral
column5: genetic subject matter of Moms
column6: however
column7: only has one resolution
column8: the certainty of which Seim entertains towards the end of ""One Horse""
column9: a 10-minute epic where stark cello snips stand on ceremony as the rest of the song crumbles like a cliff face: ""I know the ending/ Yet I'm faking suspense/ We're fertilizer for the trees/ From dust to dust
column10: roots will pass through us."" Although Moms is the result of its two creators' putting themselves through the wringer
column11: it never feels overshadowed by dread. Whether the downward spiral or the fallout
column12:
Menomena are pros at putting on a game face.

There's a scene in the film Searching for Sugar Man in which a reporter asks Rodriguez
column2: a songwriter claimed as the ""lost Bob Dylan
column3: whether he resents missing out on royalties as a ""bigger than Elvis"" superstar in South Africa while his American debut was overshadowed by generation-defining records like After the Gold Rush and Bridge Over Troubled Water. Sunglasses firmly in place above his signature unflappable grin
column4: Rodriguez says
column5: ""It's the music industry. There are no guarantees."" He's right
column6: and eventually he gets his reparations with stretch limos
column7: white carpets
column8: and yearly sold-out shows in Cape Town. But his Zen attitude is still frustrating. Doesn't he hate Bob Dylan just a little?

column1: We get more of an answer from singer-songwriter Chris Porterfield
column2: whose overshadowing Voice of a Generation is Justin Vernon. In an interview with Rolling Stone's Steven Hyden
column3: Porterfield said he was proud of his former bandmate in Wisconsin folk collective DeYarmond Edison; but he let his Minnesota niceness lapse long enough to feel ""gross jealousy"" toward Bon Iver. As Hyden noted
column4: the feeling is only human: Both sprang at least somewhat formed from the same fertile Midwest territory and traffic in meditative
column5: solo acoustic folk
column6: but Vernon's meteoric rise to fame has since eclipsed Porterfield's empty open-mic nights and stints opening for better-known bands-- including Bon Iver-- under his former pseudonym
column7: Conrad Plymouth.

column2: Porterfield continues to be dogged by headlines like ""Chris Porterfield is Field Report (and used to be Justin Vernon's bandmate)."" Other than his one-time confession to Hyden
column3: Porterfield has publicly shown no signs of resentment toward Vernon. In fact
column4: he embraces the relationship
column5: recording Field Report at Vernon's April Base studios and even drawing inspiration from him
column6: saying in the same interview that he admires Vernon's continuing loyalty to the Midwest. ""He made me think that someone not living in a major city
column7: who writes stuff that he believes in about stuff he went through
column8: that people want to hear that.""

column1: Lyrics like ""This bitterness was killing me all along/ I am not waiting anymore
column2: the loosely analogized ""I spent eight long years working on my screenplay"" (""I Am Not Waiting Anymore"")
column3: and ""I just want to speak the truth/ I have not been able to"" (""Captain Video"") belie those warm and fuzzy feelings. It's not like Porterfield tried to conceal the somewhat autobiographical origins of his lyrics any more than he's hidden his last name behind an anagram
column4: but he wrote some conspicuously analogous situations that reveal a rawer nerve than he's disclosed in interviews. Was Porterfield seething during the long years he spent working in an admissions office while his friends were getting nominated for Grammys and bringing back dad rock? Probably
column5: but that's just the music industry.

column1: One of the differences between Porterfield and Vernon is that the latter has a story and the voice to tell it
column2: even if you can't understand what he's saying half the time. Field Report
column3: while eloquently assembled from bits and pieces of Porterfield's former projects and influences
column4: doesn't bring anything like that to the contemporary Eau Claire folk tradition. Opener ""Fergus Falls""
column5: for example
column6: was actually a Conrad Plymouth track. This time around
column7: Porterfield shows restraint
column8: replacing the piano with banjos and sinking the drums lower in the mix. It burns slowly and efficiently
column9: from the hollow opening twangs to the rousing
column10: closing canon. He could have drawn from Smog's A River Ain't Too Much to Love
column11: which Porterfield admires for its ""clean but small"" guitars and ""detailed but universally nostalgic lyrics.""

column1: Bill Callahan is all over this record
column2: from the endlessly repetitive chords to the naturalistic ""vistas of buckthorn and tamarack"" in ""In the Year of the Get You Alone"" to Porterfield's deadpan talk-sing. Field Report has got the detailed and nostalgic part of Callahan's lyrics down pat
column3: namedropping over 100 proper nouns into the 15 songs that were whittled down to the album's 11: Doris Day
column4: Glen Shirley
column5: Dom DeLuise
column6: JonBenét Ramsey
column7: the U.S.-Dakota War of 1862. But unlike Smog and ""Fergus Falls""
column8: they're excessive. Callahan can say something like ""special underwear"" and people will listen
column9: but Porterfield sounds like he doesn't actually know what he's talking about. There are times when it works
column10: like the juxtaposition of Dahmer and Liberace on ""Incommunicado""
column11: which alludes to Porterfield's current home of Milwaukee while playing to his strengths in multi-part harmonies.

column2: Field Report sounds a lot like his old band. When listening to an album like Silent Signs
column3: you can hear the vestiges of Megafaun's telltale banjo twangs and early Bon Iver's lightly brushed drums
column4: but you can also hear how both bands have naturally evolved into autonomous
column5: quite distinct entities; so distinct that Porterfield felt out of place on a recent tour with Megafaun
column6: his former musical collaborators. When Field Report deviates from DeYarmond Edison's retrospectively entry-level folk
column7: however
column8: it's jarring. Bon Iver's unabashedly luscious synthpads float like dry ice across the bottom of ""Taking Alcatraz"" and ""Evergreen""
column9: filling the spaces between unadorned guitar strums better left unsaid.

column1: And there's Field Report's conundrum: He doesn't quite do enough to differentiate himself
column2: but when he does
column3:
it sounds forced and unnatural. That might be due to the music industry or timing-- it's as if Mike Heidorn decided to have a solo career after Summerteeth-- but it's more likely due to Porterfield's still-developing talents as a solo artist.

column1: Following his album Iradelphic from earlier this year
column2: Clark has already moved on
column3: his natural inclination for restlessness leading him to rework three tracks from that LP and adding them to another three new recordings for this EP. Read up on Clark's recent studio output and live performances
column4: and the word ""psychedelic"" will crop up
column5: although it's difficult to match up this music with the true definition of the word. These tracks don't represent some kind of mind-altering tussle with the doors of perception. But
column6: to be fair to Clark
column7: nor does most music described that way. Instead
column8: much of Fantasm Planes rests in quietly reflective passages of sound
column9: edging close to the rustic-electronic idyll that a number of British musicians in this realm find consistently alluring.

column1: This is a bump back down to earth instead of a total removal from it
column2: a shying away from the cartoony blitz-out of prior Clark releases like the synapse-shattering originality of his 2008 album Turning Dragon. Many artists who appear to make it their mission to hurtle relentlessly into the future find that the past has a way of coming up in an outside lane to overtake them. If that was the case for Clark on Iradelphic
column3: which was backed into a corner with no particularly interesting place to go
column4: on Fantasm Planes it feels like he's lapping himself several times over. For someone once so resolute on finding new lines to trace out for himself
column5: it's remarkably easy to figure out how Clark got to where he wanted to go here. Even the title of ""Henderson Swooping""
column6: an almost unrecognizable retool of the folksy ""Henderson Wrench"" from Iradelphic
column7: owes a considerable debt to the oft-whimsical ways of Boards of Canada.

column1: Despite the creeping feeling of genre exercises playing out
column2: there are moments to seek solace in on Fantasm Planes. The title track works in a jazzy lightness reminiscent of the type of electro-fusion crossovers former Warp signees Red Snapper were attempting in the 1990s
column3: all set to beats so bouncy it feels like you can reach out and stretch them. On ""Fantasm Planes"" there's a sense of narrative
column4: a feeling of a story being set in motion and playing out
column5: full of bends in the road that take time and thought to navigate and digest. That's when Clark excels across all his work
column6: making it even more disappointing when the Aphex-by-numbers ambience of ""Dove in Flames"" brings this EP to a limp close. ""Brigitte"" verges on that territory
column7: too
column8: but gathers some clout of its own as Clark does some Blanck Mass-style empire building
column9: only to tear it all down in flames at the end.

column1: ""Brigitte"" is a useful musical metaphor for Clark's endless urge to enter a cycle of construct
column2: destroy
column3: renew. Just when it feels like he's onto something
column4: he discards it
column5: perhaps with more haste than he should. Clark may complain
column6: with some justification
column7: that he'd be accused of repeating himself if he settled into a recognizable style and worked up multiple variants on it. But Fantasm Planes is a series of loose ends that lack the sense of purpose and playfulness that made his prior work such a persuasive listen. Even the one vocal contribution
column8: from Martina Topley-Bird on the reworking of ""Secret"" (titled ""Secret Slow Show"")
column9: is an uninspired choice. It's a needless hark back to an older era
column10: clumsily falling into 90s trip-hop pastiche when the beat kicks in during its final third
column11: with Topley-Bird wheeled in just as she was back then to provide suitably ""spacey"" vocals. Clark can
column12: and hopefully will
column13: do better. But for now he feels like a genuine talent unable to find a foothold.

column3: Turbo Fruits offer ripping guitars and barroom aggression in service of throwback rock'n'roll. As the former Be Your Own Pet members told Rolling Stone
column4: the album was recorded under the influence of Lil Wayne
column5: 1970s soul
column6: and Enya. Let that potpourri of sounds and influences simmer
column7: because there's another thing you should know about Butter: Lyrically
column8: it's an album of post-Garth Brooks country radio songs. There's no twang
column9: over-glossy sentimentality
column10: or patriotism-on-steroids flag waving. But while nothing here can be pegged as country sonically
column11: their lyrics follow the same direct and literal ""I'm telling a story and here's what happened beat-for-beat"" frame of country radio at its most cliche. Which is not to knock an entire songwriting style-- there are obviously great songs that fit within that structure. These
column12: however

column1: Here are the opening lines of ""Don't Like to Fight"": ""Drinkin' Jack
column2: getting lit/ Group of girls comin' up to us/ We could tell they was into it/ Saw a dude givin' dirty looks/ With his friend
column3: talking shit/ Then a man came up to me and said/ 'Boy
column4: you talkin' to the wrong chick.'"" If that verse were an exception

column7: ugh

column9: drinking
column10: weed
column11: cigarettes
column12: and other carefree-but-edgy material. Their subject matter draws an easy comparison to another recent Nashville song
column13: JEFF the Brotherhood's ""Sixpack""
column14: but in this case

column16: or worse

column1: What partially saves Turbo Fruits from their own lyrics is their knack for muscular riffs. Get past the words
column2: and ""Don't Like to Fight"" is a rock'n'roll song worthy of Motörhead. It's got distorted guitars
column3: muscle
column4: and
column5: yes
column6: ""the fight riff."" Same deal with ""Where the Stars Don't Shine""
column7: which was a ripping one-take live recording. They even manage to stick the landing on the instrumentation of their lighter fare

column12: slick-sounding album the band's put out

column14: ""Man
column15: we're ready to start being able to pay our bills. Our hope is that this record takes us to the beginning of that goal."" Also worth noting: The band's polished new sound is housed on Kings of Leon's label.

column2: Turbo Fruits have offered a carefully honed caricature of themselves. They tell stories about bar fights
column3: about gambling
column4: about hitting the road
column5: about drinking and smoking pot. And as if that picture still wasn't clear

column8: ""Yeah

column10: guys."" Because they're drunk! That's just how rebellious they are! They drink in the studio! But as Stein noted
column11: all the ""don't give a fuck"" posturing wasn't reflected in the band's process: ""I've never been more prepared for recording a record in my life. We had a no-mess

they never find a sound that's fully captivating or convincing.
