At this past July's Pitchfork Music Festival
column2: the scheduling gods played a cruel joke on fans of fuzzed-out San Francisco garage-rock by placing scene vets Thee Oh Sees and their prodigal-son pal Ty Segall on competing stages with overlapping set times. The irony was not lost on Thee Oh Sees' frontman John Dwyer
column3: who
column4: despite getting their show off to a righteously arse-kicking start
column5: jokingly begged to the crowd after three songs ""don't leave!"" as Segall's set time approached. This simple
column6: self-deprecating plea effectively delineated the difference between these two like-minded
column7: furiously prolific acts.

column2: after all
column3: is in the midst of a banner year that's seen him release two albums-- including his best to date
column4: Slaughterhouse-- with a third on the way
column5: and he's still young enough that his whimsical
column6: impulsive approach to recording forms a media-friendly narrative of the punk wunderkind realizing his true potential. On the other hand
column7: Thee Oh Sees are the latest
column8: albeit the most durable
column9: in a long
column10: 15-year lineage of Dwyer-helmed projects
column11: and one whose consistency-- in terms of both quantity and quality-- makes for a somewhat less sexy story. Dude releases a shit-ton of records because
column12: after all these years in the game
column13: he's still restless and resourceful.

column2: Putrifiers II is Thee Oh Sees' first album of 2012
column3: which is a weird statement to be typing considering that we're well into September. (Though given the band's ceaseless output
column4: it's not too far-fetched to imagine that a Putrifiers I was recorded and scrapped somewhere along the way.) Thee Oh Sees' records have more or less charted the band's evolution from Dwyer's solitary psych-pop project to brute-force hypno-punkers. Now
column5: with their reputation as one of America's most redoubtable live acts wholly assured
column6: Thee Oh Sees use Putrifiers II to explore the possibilities of the studio and more lustrous modes of psychedelia. It's not exactly uncharted territory for Dwyer and company
column7: but where Thee Oh Sees are prone to segregating their more refined pop sensibilities from their gonzo-rock rave-ups (as their two 2011 releases
column8: Castlemania and Carrion Crawler/The Dream
column9: respectively illustrate)
column10: Putrifiers II reconciles these two modes
column11: providing a more complete
column12: elaborate picture of this band's many capabilities and strengths.

column1: Which is to say: If the sheer enormity of Thee Oh Sees' dense discography has proven too forbidding for you to delve into
column2: Putrifiers II is a convenient summary/gateway
column3: opening with a killer shot of the band's patented echo-drenched fuzz-punk delirium (""Wax Face"") and closing with a baroque
column4: string-swept lullaby (""Wicked Park"")
column5: while traversing all points in between. But even as Putrifiers II turns more melodic and mellow
column6: broadening the band's sonic scope with strings and woodwinds
column7: it retains the nervy irreverence: With its shrieking cello line and opium-den ambience
column8: ""So Nice"" unabashedly kneels before the shiny leather boots of the Velvet Underground's ""Venus in Furs"" and
column9: as such
column10: becomes a knowing allegory for the master/slave dynamic that plays out in the original.

column1: If the drawn-out title-track dirge and the moonlight-strolling ""Will We Be Scared?"" (the sort of warped
column2: revisionist 50s-style ballad Bradford Cox has made his stock-in-trade) threaten to curb the mid-album momentum
column3: they prove to be effective calm-before-the-storm set-ups to the mighty ""Lupine Dominus""
column4: which manages to condense everything that is great about Thee Oh Sees into three thrilling minutes: Dwyer and Brigid Dawson's eerily androgynous harmonies cooing a disarmingly childlike melody
column5: and a car-crash tangle of guitar/organ noise
column6: all hitched to a steely Krautrock pulse. It feels like the sort of song that
column7: after so many years of exploratory recordings
column8: could very well define the true sound of Thee Oh Sees. Or it's the sort of peak moment that could give Dwyer reason to tear it all down and radically redefine his band once again. At the very least
column9:
we know it likely won't be long before we find out.

column3: Bonnie ""Prince"" Billy played an unannounced

column1: Olsen's voice is possessed of an intensely dramatic range; one minute she's barely singing-- more a downcast

column3: she's a tragic heroine of the Weimar cabaret

column6: lost singer Connie Converse
column7: Jason Molina's old-timey drama
column8: Bill Callahan's terrific and unsettling ability to shift between dourness and comfort

column6: one of the album's only slightly weaker tracks; rawer
column7: even
column8: than anything on Strange Cacti. ""I thought this time last year

column12: as if recalling a more casual expectation-- improving at French

column1: For anyone starting to worry for Olsen's emotional health

column3: inviting firelight away from Half Way Home's darker corners. The certainty of her feelings in the opening song
column4: the waltzing ""Acrobat""-- ""I love the way your body's made/ I love the way your voice is sex""-- revives Olsen
column5: who had assumed herself to be dead

column17: oh!/ You know

column1: What makes Half Way Home magnificent is its openness to what could be
column2: to potential. Yes
column3: we're all going to die in the end
column4: and you can get there by casting off all belief and going it alone
column5: or gathering moss and weighing heavier

column8: the transference of intention to what's really conveyed; the tug of war between wanting to be something to someone and offering them yourself in return
column9:
while keeping something for self-protection. It's a very open record about what goes on behind a staunch emotional guard; what Will Oldham said about that ""mixture of apprehension and satisfaction at the same time"" rings completely true. That battle and potential is best summed up in a line from the closing song: ""It's known that the tiniest seed is both simple and wild.""

column1: When the Raveonettes burst out of Copenhagen 10 years ago
column2: they recorded each of their albums under a strict creative constraint
column3: which seemed a bit arbitrary at the time. Every song on their 2002 debut EP
column4: Whip It On
column5: was written in B-flat minor; B-flat major defined their first full-length
column6: Chain Gang of Love
column7: a year later. For catalog highlight Lust Lust Lust in 2008
column8: Sune Rose Wagner trashed all the crash cymbals and played all the instruments himself. ""I always put a little bit of restrictions on myself
column9: and I only do it for my creativity
column10: Wagner told Pitchfork that same year. ""And I do it sometimes because I want the music to stand out a little bit more than many other bands do.""

column1: Those restrictions distinguished their first batch of albums
column2: and even the subtle loosening up on 2005's Pretty in Black
column3: their most polished and
column4: some might say
column5: overcooked record
column6: gave it a specific sonic identity. Moreover
column7: it implied a sense of growth and development
column8: painting Wagner as something of a gleefully mad scientist; despite being dismissed as gimmicky
column9: the Raveonettes prospered in the wake of the millennial garage rock movement
column10: even as groups like the Vines withered and fell away. In retrospect
column11: those restraints seem impressively savvy
column12: as they always kept new ideas and new moods in reserve.

column1: Perhaps because those simple guidelines so defined those early releases
column2: the piano appears to play a much more prominent role on Observator
column3: their latest album
column4: than it actually does. It's the main instrument on the second track and early single ""Observations""
column5: which marks the first time the Raveonettes have showcased the instrument in their music. It suggests a musical theme for the record
column6: as though Wagner had challenged himself to write every song on keyboard instead of guitar. Especially following the skeletal
column7: spryly despairing opener ""Young and Cold""
column8: the piano's heavy sustain becomes a kind of drone in itself
column9: slyly tweaking our expectations for shoegaze drift. Those pounded chords square off against the sharp notes of Wagner's rockabilly guitar to give the song its perverse
column10: nocturnal vibe
column11: which suggests the Raveonettes possess the power to transform even the sunniest afternoon into post-hangover 3 a.m. In a year when one of the biggest pop hits evokes the vodka-commercial glamor of a night spent club hopping with attractive friends
column12: ""Observations"" picks up the party a few hours later
column13: when all your friends have abandoned you and you're not sure how you're going to get home.

column1: A full album in this vein sounds promising
column2: but unfortunately
column3: Observator has no interest in teasing out that mood or even using that instrument again. The piano is quickly discarded and with it any sense of the album as a distinct entity in the Raveonettes' later catalog. They can still set a specific mood with just a few notes
column4: and Wagner and Sharin Foo deliver some of their spryest hooks on ""She Owns the Streets"" and ""The Enemy""
column5: but these songs sound suspiciously light
column6: lacking the urgency or stakes of their best material. Especially on the second side
column7: Wagner indulges a particular strategy of repeating lines until they resemble hooks without actually hooking you. Especially sequenced back to back
column8: ""Downtown"" and ""You Hit Me (I'm Down)"" quickly become grating

column5: dredging grungy 1950s juvie rock and 60s girl groups through 70s punk and 90s shoegaze. A decade into their career

column3: and chances are you'll find Music Tapes frontman Julian Koster's name somewhere in the liner notes. For going on 20 years
column4: Koster's been instrumental in shaping the sound of Elephant 6's sprawling psychedelia
column5: lending his singing saw (and his considerable compositional expertise) to Neutral Milk Hotel and the Olivia Tremor Control
column6: to his own Chocolate USA and the Music Tapes. Though the weird whinny of Koster's favored axe and his symphony-on-a-shoestring arrangements are nearly as essential to the E6 sound as their thousand-part harmonies

column1: Running an impressive gamut between stark confessionals and sepia-toned Stephen Foster fantasia

column5: an instrumental piece that sounds like the way a yellowed photo of Coney Island looks. This time-travel effect is slightly unsettling
column6: like a letter to your grandmother-- or
column7: perhaps
column8: the postcard that inspired your favorite record cover-- falling out of an old book. Mary's Voice is interspersed with church bells
column9: ambient whatsits
column10: otherworldly saw interludes
column11: even a brief intermission. Koster's knack for putting sounds together certainly hasn't gone uncommented upon over the years
column12: but here
column13: he's not simply stringing together a few dozen parts. In Mary's Voice's
column14: he and Cucchiaro have created a eerily beautiful little world unto itself.

column4: deeply felt ""Takeshi"" as a spiritual cousin of sorts to Aeroplane's astonishing finale

column2: California-based producer John Tejada has straddled the line between carefully crafted
column3: home-listening electronic music and sleek
column4: minimal house for the bulk of his career
column5: making him one of those rare touring DJs whose work has an undercurrent of domesticity to it. That might not be the most fashionable look (Tejada is

column2: Tejada has forged a reputation as a master craftsman

column4: elegant house. On previous records
column5: such as last year's Parabolas

column8: but on The Predicting Machine

column1: Anyone who spent the early 2000s combing Warp and so many Warp-inspired cottage industry label back catalogs will find lots of familiar sounds here. The sprightly twin bill of ""Glaringly Happy"" and closer ""When All Around Is Madness"" chime with the naive effervescence of the Morr Music era; the undulating ""Radio Channel"" churns on a frosty
column2: ambient loop that wouldn't have sounded out of place on a Biosphere record; and the gently percolating synths from ""Winter Skies"" evoke Plaid at their warmest.

column1: Were The Predicting Machine just a demonstration of Tejada's fluency in those specific dialects of IDM and ambient
column2: it wouldn't be nearly as interesting
column3: but the slightly more retro-leaning aspect of the record is offset nicely by some lustrous
column4: future-facing house. ""An Ounce of Perception"" introduces a limber and vaguely schaffel-inspired rhythm before descending into a gleaming melodic hook; ""Horizon to Horizon"" boasts a wet
column5: elasticated rhythm
column6: and the knowingly titled ""A Familiar Mood"" returns Tejada to the percolating tech house that most people associate him with best. Add it all up
column7:
and you get one of Tejada's most varied records to date.

column3: the first song we heard from David Byrne and St. Vincent's collaborative project was titled ""Who"".  With its firm acoustic strumming

column14: and the on-paper perfection of the pairing.

column1: You could argue that David Byrne and Annie Clark collaborating on an album in 2012 is better framed by the question immediately asked of any such high-profile pairing: ""Why?"" On the surface
column2: the two have quite a few commonalities. Both Byrne and Clark are equally fascinated by the theatricality of everyday life: the scripts and performances that drive our days and raise the stakes of our mundane interactions to the level of high drama or (for this duo) dark comedy. Both performers are known for their thousand-yard stares (compare the covers of Byrne's Feelings with St. Vincent's Actor) that suggest a quiet intensity merged with a playful approach to self-presentation.

much of the power of Clark's and Byrne's music relies on the tension between being trapped and letting go. The primary narrative arc of Talking Heads' legendary live concert Stop Making Sense sees the reluctantly public shut-in character of the jittery ""Psycho Killer"" gradually learn to embrace his eccentricities
column3: leading to the effusive gospel of closer ""Take Me to the River"". In her five-plus years as St. Vincent
column4: Annie Clark has set and broken pre-determined molds from every conceivable direction-- at her best
column5: she can go from ""Psycho Killer"" to ""River"" in a single song. It makes sense
column6: then
column7: that much of Love This Giant is taken with the idea of human transformation
column8: as evidenced by the album's prosthetically-enhanced cover art. On ""The One Who Broke Your Heart""
column9: we hear of ""the beautiful people"" who ""did some work on your face."" Clark sings of the hopeful revelations of a gradual thawing process on ""Ice Age"". On ""I Am an Ape""
column10: Byrne playfully reverse-engineers evolution.

column2: collaborations aren't always as simple as pairing two smart artists cut from the same cloth. Because they're so taken with the idiosyncrasies of others' behaviors and interactions
column3: Byrne and Clark constantly run the risk of their music tipping over into obsessiveness
column4: of living up to the lifeless caricatures they're ostensibly picking apart. Especially considering the expectations attending a project created by two kindred spirits with ideas and talent to spare
column5: Love This Giant is a disappointment. With precious few exceptions
column6: neither Clark nor Byrne seems willing to push the other into new musical territory that might contain revelations about either. The songs merely stand apart from life and dryly comment on its strangeness
column7: while the arrangements-- most prominently featuring the work of several conservatory-level brass players-- are suffused with the sterility that always threatens long-distance collaborations.

column1: ""Dinner for Two"" is representative in this regard. The narrator spends the song contemplating the sad fact that he's never able to enjoy a quiet
column2: intimate time with his lover
column3: because both are too busy with such nuisances as dinner parties with possibly famous authors milling about. The song's arid brass arrangement and bland percussion do it no favors (elsewhere on the album
column4: John Congleton handles drum programming duties
column5: and seems intent on dragging the music kicking and screaming into 2001). Later
column6: there's ""I Should Watch TV""
column7: which whooshes Byrne right past the clever engagement with popular culture that made a song like ""Found a Job"" such a quirky joy
column8: and plops him straight into a self-important deconstruction of his own silly impulses. He's admitting that he really should watch more TV
column9: because it would offer him insight into the minds of the nameless bodies he sees moving around himself everyday. But he resists
column10: and instead sets off quoting Whitman's ""Song of Myself"" as if to convince himself of his own uniqueness.

column2: it's hard to imagine too many people discovering her through this collaboration
column3: but either way
column4: she's responsible for Giant's best moments. In her own way
column5: she's downright soulful on the refrains of ""Weekend in the Dust""
column6: a style that serves as a compelling counterpoint to the icy
column7: aristocratic lilt she inhabits on the verses. Though ""Ice Age"" may not count among the highlights of Actor or Strange Mercy
column8: it shows Clark's skill at shifting gears mid-song without disturbing the cargo
column9: and at employing elements strategically-- here
column10: Giant's omnipresent (and stiflingly monochromatic) brass is mostly reduced to subtle color and minimalist chorus additions
column11: until blooming during the song's well-earned coda. It's not exactly high praise
column12: I know: Here are the two best songs on a strange flop of a high-profile collaboration. In retrospect
column13: it seems Giant will function less as a career highpoint for either artist
column14: and more as a historical marker of the career trajectories of each participant. Byrne plays the wandering dilettante
column15: content to transform his old ideas anew
column16: while Clark upstages her mentor
column17:
convinced she still has a lot more to prove.

Sean Ragon doesn't like to make things easy for himself. The former Love as Laughter bassist
column3: now a Brooklyn record store owner
column4: operates within a subgenre-- post-punk folk-- that
column5: if not treated carefully
column6: can conjure thoughts of open-mic aspirants murdering Pogues songs at campus pubs or
column7: worse
column8: get you labeled a fascist. And even if you disregard its Fatherland intimations

column10: with the expectation that there's a congregation of impressionable souls out there waiting to heed his call.

column1: That scenario seemed rather unlikely when Ragon first debuted Cult of Youth in 2007 as a solo project that emphasized the contrast between the gnashed-teeth aggression of his vocals and the stripped-down acoustic strums underpinning them. In the wrong hands
column2: folk-punk can feel like the musical equivalent of bringing a knife to a gunfight. But Ragon has avoided this pitfall by recruiting a proper backing band-- including drummer Glenn Maryansky and Zola Jesus' go-to violinist Christiana Key-- and putting their individual skills to excellent use
column3: transforming Cult of Youth from one man's caustic catharsis into something increasingly inviting and alluring
column4: while still retaining the fire and ire that initially fuelled the enterprise.

column1: You can hear that transformation happen in real time on Love Will Prevail's ""Garden of Delights"". It intensifies over the course of eight verses-- each more grueling and despairingly world-weary than the one before-- before yielding to its first and only chorus
column2: a defiant
column3: optimistic affirmation of the new album's title. This a shift that exemplifies Love Will Prevail's open-hearted
column4: wide-screened splendor: While it's safe to assume that Ragon will be buried with his acoustic guitar
column5: the band's sound is greatly amplified by foregrounding Key's furious fiddle-playing
column6: Maryansky's rollicking rhythms
column7: subtle electric-guitar textures
column8: and majestic swirls of brass-- reminiscent of Robert Wyatt's 1974 masterpiece
column9: Rock Bottom-- that lend Love Will Prevail a spacious
column10: otherworldly feel
column11: without ever acquiring the NPR-tasteful sheen of so many other indie folkestras. And if Ragon's bottom-of-the-well bellow will remain a barrier to entry for some
column12: it's put to far more benevolent use here: the band's expanded palette is matched by a greater penchant for brisk
column13: accessible hooks-- from the anthemic ascent of opener ""Man and Man's Ruin"" to the scrappy charm of closer ""It Took a Lifetime""-- and Brix Smith-like interplay with guest vocalist Beverly Hames that forge a greater aesthetic distance between Cult of Youth and their post-industrial progenitors. (That said
column14: ""Path of Total Freedom"" confirms Ragon is still a sucker for Celtic-punk jiggery; fortunately
column15: this regression only lasts for 70 seconds.)

column2: Ragon's lyrics are highly evocative if not outright provocative; those looking for a more sinister intent to Cult of Youth's M.O. may find what they're looking for in a surface reading of mid-album double shot ""A New Way"" and ""New Old Ways""
column3: whose titles bring to mind another band that had a lot to answer for. But the mood is ultimately one of liberation and celebration: the former is an arms-swaying shanty that only grows more exuberant as it gets swallowed up by an encroaching wave of distortion; the latter rides its hypno-chant chorus into a heady dub-jazz outro that you wish they'd play out forever. (And
column4: if anything
column5: proclamations such as ""There's a war abroad that cannot be won/ There's a war at home that has just begun"" and the call for ""forward thinking in a backwards time"" make most sense as critiques of post-Dubya Republicanism.) Even theatrically bloodthirsty moments like the busker-Bad-Seeds rager ""To Lay With the Wolves"" reinforce the idea that this album's title is not ironic: After a stormy three-minute build
column6: the song simmers down with Ragon proudly admitting
column7: ""I fell in love/ In love with the world/ Because that's when it hit me/ That all was right/ Yes
column8: that's when it hit me/ That the future was bright."" It's hard to decode whether Ragon's talking about the future of America or just that of his own band; at the very least
column9:
Love Will Prevail gives you ample reason to believe in the latter.

In the evolution of the Late Night Tales mix series from showcasing acts like Zero 7 and Groove Armada into a more self-aware series of homages to yacht rock and MOR 1980s pop over the past decade
column3: it's comfortably occupied that place where music taste seems performative yet sincere
column4: aware of its potentially embarrassing tendencies but not entirely inclined to care. Its expanded stylistic scope makes a statement in itself: If you want to fight against the idea that downtempo slow jams are soporific garbage
column5: it's a savvy move to string together examples from every corner imaginable-- radio-ready R&B
column6: fusion jazz
column7: IDM
column8: indie pop
column9: MOR
column10: folk
column11: ambient
column12: new age-- and pull off at least a moderately unpredictable dynamic by trading genre for mood. Split the difference between all these styles
column13: and in the best case scenario
column14: the compilation curators come up with their own new thing entirely.

column2: meanwhile
column3: mostly involves a lot of weird juxtaposition for its own sake. And while Metronomy's entry into the Late Night Tales series isn't necessarily the worst case of anything
column4: it is one of those mixes where half the entertainment value seems reliant on poking at clashing sensibilities. Joe Mount and co. have spent their three-album career toying with styles and then jumping off to the next thing
column5: and the tracklist on this collection clearly comes from the library of someone who knows the value of being adventurous without losing sight of what makes for decent pop. Building a bridge from Tweet to Chick Corea or Autechre to the Alan Parsons Project is one of those egalitarian-in-theory notions that comes from the noble idea of trying to make the avant and the accessible at least shake hands for a bit
column6: and when it's pulled off well
column7: notions of so-called clashing sensibilities feel mercifully irrelevant.

column1: It's a brilliant choice to lead things off with OutKast's underrated The Love Below deep cut ""Prototype""
column2: the swoony psychedelic soul that emerged when André 3000 tried taking his own slice from D'Angelo's Voodoo. And the transition into Tweet's ""Drunk""
column3: an overlooked piece of headswimming
column4: loneliness-wrecked heartbreak from Southern Hummingbird
column5: makes this the beginning of what
column6: in another context
column7: could have been an amazing dedication to the more introspective and intensely slow-burning moments of early-00s R&B. But then the scene starts to shift-- subtly at first
column8: from there into soul-jazz and fusion (Sa-Ra Creative Partners' ""Cosmic Ball""; Chick Corea's ""El Bozo
column9: Part 1"")
column10: then into a pile-up of indie rap (Dr. Octagon)
column11: 80s electro-soul (World Class Wreckin' Cru)
column12: 70s soft rock (the Alessi Brothers)
column13: IDM (Autechre)-- and soon enough
column14: the pieces stop actually fitting together.

column1: The problem is that it's not enough to just get things to sound good together-- they have to feel good together
column2: too. And as a tone-setting exploration of anything deeper than a record collection
column3: this mix doesn't really make that much sense. The transitions can be jarring on a pure sonic level; the segue from ""Drunk"" to Sa-Ra's ""Cosmic Ball"" tries to bridge minimalist R&B with  space-jazz
column4: and the way their respective drum sounds try to shove each other aside has the same feeling of an elevator suddenly jostling between floors. Other juxtapositions are so jarring that it almost seems like they're trying to spin some snarky punchlines. If you somehow find a way to sink your way in to the jokey neo-electro of Geneva Jacuzzi's ""Love Caboose"" and get on its arch-to-a-fault wavelength
column5: getting shoved from there to Two Lone Swordsmen's hopped-up Kraut-punk workout ""You Are..."" is a rude way to knock you out of the loop. I wasn't kidding about the Alessi Brothers-Autechre transition
column6: either; the segue from the twee AM pop of ""Seabird"" into the seasick glitch of ""Fold 4
column7: Wrap 5"" might have good intentions
column8: but it still sounds like the kind of pairing that cancels out both songs' traits entirely. And as wide as the scope of downtempo tracks can be
column9: it fails to set any cohesive mood; it goes from romantic to lonely to cosmic to quirky to unnerving all in its first five selections and never manages to recoup any sense of consistent purpose.

column1: Metronomy's Late Night Tales entry might work a bit better as a showcase of influence
column2: but not much better. Any collection that includes something from early-70s synthesizer super-workshop Tonto's Expanding Head Band (""Cybernaut"") and the talkbox-goes-country innovation of steel guitarist Pete Drake (""Forever"") at least has novelty on its side. But whatever influence that stuff might have on Metronomy themselves isn't all that present in a new track of theirs that's included here
column3: ""Hypnose""
column4:
a slow trudge of vaguely Bernard Fevre-esque codeine disco that sounds about as innovative and personality-rich as your typical circa-1979 production library music LP. Songs like that shouldn't feel like less than the sum of their parts. Neither should mixes.

True bootlegs are endangered species. In the past
column2: they've circulated through networks of diehard fans and avid tape traders

column4: an odd cover in the setlist

column7: the traditional equation of rarity with value is beginning to break apart. By titling his first live album Bootlegs

column1: Bootlegs doesn't actually sound truly raw
column2: but it does sound raw-ish. In the case of this particular artist
column3: that's more than enough to lend these songs new life and new urgency compared to their studio iterations. Throughout his 20s-- this release marks his 30th birthday-- Lerche has shown a tendency toward crippling professionalism; his albums sound too slick
column4: too clever by half

The xx's self-titled debut was the kind of record that filled a void most of us didn't know existed. Several currents of music flowed into the work of this London band to create something that felt strangely new. Singers Romy Madley Croft and Oliver Sim treated the pop song like a whispered secret
column3: an achingly intimate exchange best understood in the general vicinity of a bed. And the xx foregrounded the hushed voices by process of subtraction
column4: creating music with a daring sense of space. Under the production direction of third member Jamie Smith (now known as Jamie xx)
column5: the xx created a sound world where the simplest chord change was freighted with emotion. xx's minimal production reacquainted listeners with the expressive possibility of the guitar. Croft's gently picked lines
column6: ultra clean with a tasteful mist of reverb
column7: were quietly devastating in their own way
column8: connecting the music with indie rock proper. The final piece of the puzzle was Jamie xx's careful beat programming
column9: which was aware of up-to-the-moment trends in UK bass music but never pandered to them. These parts came together in a debut that sounded great at the time and has become a landmark. Channeling the spirit if not the precise sound of the softer and more cerebral end of R&B (Sade Adu is the spirit mother
column10: Aaliyah the holy ghost) and mixing it with a pinch of DIY guitar music and a smart underpinning of rhythm
column11: the xx created music rich with possibility. And while they didn't change the way music was made
column12: they did have an effect on how it was heard. Without them
column13: we'd be coming at music by artists like the Weeknd and Jessie Ware with different ears.

column1: But you knew what was coming with album number two: Where do you go next? Do you light out for new territory or refine what's already there? The xx have chosen the latter tack
column2: if you consider further stripping of their already-naked sound a refinement. Coexist takes the most distinctive things about the xx-- ""shh"" vocals
column3: guitar patterns that feel like faint line drawings
column4: lyrics that detail the most essential aspects of yearning-- and eliminates virtually everything else. It didn't seem possible that the arrangements on the debut could stand to have even more taken from them
column5: but that's what's happened here. In that regard
column6: the album feels in its own way brave. They're doubling down on what makes them stand out
column7: which brings with it the real possibility of self-parody. Fortunately
column8: the xx aren't at that point yet. So the most appealing thing about this record is that this band
column9: having created a brilliant and moving sound
column10: returns to it again for another 38 minutes. ""Angels"" drips with austere beauty
column11: ""Tides"" begins a duet so stark it's breathtaking
column12: the evocative piano in ""Swept Away"" is a nice wrinkle. This is still gorgeous stuff
column13: and it's hard not to enjoy it while it's on. But while the edifice of their aesthetic still stands
column14: in a few places it's getting a little rickety.

column1: If generally successful on its own terms
column2: Coexist also serves to remind us why exactly the debut was so brilliant. For one
column3: xx had a very subtle and effective sense of dynamics. I'm thinking in particular of songs such as ""Islands""
column4: with its halting beat that mapped the push-pull production of Timbaland onto an indie pop context. There are no such moments on Coexist
column5: an album that moves from one song to the next like a slow-rolling fog. You can't help but wish Jamie xx had experimented a bit more and borrowed ideas hatched from his creative run of production work since the debut. With his remixes
column6: DJ sets
column7: mixes
column8: and a brilliant single
column9: he's proven to be one of the more adventurous and open-minded young producers going
column10: hungry to incorporate all kinds of sounds and approaches into his music. The only real evidence of those explorations here is the steel drum that pops up on ""Reunion""
column11: which brings to mind his use of the instrument in his single ""Far Nearer"" and gives Coexist a rare crack of light. There's no reason why the xx have to try something new sonically. But bands with a unique signature generally stick around by growing as songwriters and staying open to the possibilities of production. Coexist shows no such growth. With the music so focused and constrained
column12: the album becomes slightly claustrophobic; where the first made you think about the different sounds that came from outside
column13: this feels closed off.

column2: the xx have done away with specificity and chosen to focus on the travails of relationships using the broadest possible language. If I were to say
column3: ""You know the song that mentions a look in a lover's eyes?"" you'd say
column4: ""Which one?"" because some variation of the phrase pops up repeatedly. I see it in your eyes... the feeling in my heart... something has changed...the feeling goes on... never again... A handful of images and thoughts are shuffled like a deck of cards and doled out
column5: seemingly at random. And while Croft or Sim don't need to get near Frank Ocean's level of sophistication for their music to work
column6: with music so minimal
column7: I find myself yearning for a line as pedestrian and relatable as ""We watch things on VCRs."" Too often
column8: these words feel like placeholders.

column2: I find myself enjoying Coexist and returning to it. It's hard not to be disappointed given what came before
column3: but the xx are still a special band
column4: and time could possibly be kinder to their second LP as its place within a longer career comes into focus. For now
column5: they've earned the right to make this record. Every band that creates a new world deserves a chance to return to it

column8:
is generally a harder sell.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18345/homepage_large.56abc955.jpg|Dedication 4|2616.0|Lil Wayne|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Young Money Entertainment']|2012-09-10 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:07:37.957061|"

The Dedication mixtapes have reliably served as a barometer of Lil Wayne's creative fire: On 2
column2: he was a determined kid busily fulfilling his own ""best rapper alive"" prophecy. On 3
column3: he was skidding dangerously post-Carter III
column4: whacked out on codeine and sounding frayed. Dedication 4
column5: for its part
column6: is the clearest transmission yet of a message he's been sending for a while: He'd rather not to be rapping anymore. From a beat selection so obvious that the word ""selection"" feels generous to Wayne's recycled punch lines to his unimaginative rhyme patterns
column7: the mixtape is joyless clock-punching work from a rapper who has given some indications he doesn't even like his own music as much anymore. But a career's a career
column8: and when you've gotten this famous
column9: you don't just stop
column10: even if maybe you'd prefer to. This is the spirit Dedication 4 comes to us in: Somehow
column11: I don't think this is what 2005 Wayne meant when he promised us he'd only retire when he died.

column1: Not many rappers bother with this format anymore
column2: in which a rapper flexes skill over a tape full of borrowed beats to point out how much better they are than the rappers that paid for them. Nonetheless
column3: this is the sort of mixtape that elevated Wayne from ""famous rapper"" to ""legendary rapper."" His freestyles over beats like ""Show Me What You Got"" and ""Shoulder Lean"" have become classics on their own. By contrast
column4: Dedication 4 is a game of rap karaoke. The beats he raps over-- ""Same Damn Tune""
column5: ""Burn""
column6: ""Mercy""
column7: ""Don't Like""
column8: ""Amen""-- are so ubiquitous that every rapper in the world looking for a quick SEO boost has spit some bars over them. Worse
column9: Wayne falls immediately into the song's preexisting rhyme pattern
column10: offering nothing to distract you from its source material: For a rapper so famous for stealing-- and murdering-- beats
column11: the worst I can say about Dedication 4 is that there isn't one moment where I wouldn't rather be listening to the often mediocre originals.

column1: There are a dozen or so good punch lines scattered on D4
column2: enough to make it fun enough for one listen: a good ""Jack Black/Jack White"" joke on ""Magic""
column3: a ""straitjacket/straight jack it"" pun on ""Burn"". On ""Cashed Out""
column4: he neatly unites his well-documented Gremlins fixation to his sex fixation with the line
column5: ""That pussy so wet
column6: it turned into a Gremlin."" Wayne doesn't sound depressed or detached here; he's still having fun
column7: collapsing into giggles after dropping the Larry-the-Cable-Guy-worthy ""I would talk about my dick/ But that shit would be a long story."" He just sounds uninspired
column8: and in need of a new style.

column1: There are two surprising moments on Dedication 4: One is Nicki Minaj's hilarious faux-Romney endorsement on ""Mercy"" (if Minaj were actually to offer a Romney endorsement
column2: I don't think the straight-faced line
column3: ""I'm a Republican
column4: voting for Mitt Romney
column5: on a Lil Wayne mixtape would be her method). The other is when G Dep's ""Special Delivery""
column6: of all things
column7: shows up late on the mixtape. ""I don't even like this beat
column8: Wayne mumbles playfully
column9: before slipping in one of the tape's liveliest verses
column10: dancing in and out of double time. It's one of the only verses that doesn't feel like a minimally tweaked update on something he said in 2007. Wayne has admitted lately that he's bored with rapping
column11: reasonably pointing out
column12:
""I've been doing it since I was eight and I'm about to be 30 in September... I think fans deserve a little-to-no Wayne. I've been everywhere."" He's right. Let's hope Dedication 4 is the last we hear from Wayne for a while: We can wait until he has something to say before he approaches a mic again.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18161/homepage_large.40d0389e.jpg|For My Parents|2816.0|Mono|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Temporary Residence']|2012-09-10 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:07:38.552246|"

Mono are a post-rock band with a well-tested formula that they have been working for years: lay out a weepy string theme
column2: fatten it up slowly over nine or 10 minutes
column3: and then nail it to the wall with guitars. On  their latest album
column4: For My Parents
column5: there isn't much juice remaining in it: You can anticipate every single dynamic shift in its five compositions
column6: which is not typically an asset for instrumental music meant to take you on an emotional journey. There isn't much of a journey to be taken on For My Parents; the music doesn't develop
column7: darken
column8: or tell a story so much as it expands and deflates like a balloon. Trying to engage actively with it
column9: to search its contours with your mind
column10: is like poking a soap bubble.

column1: As they did on their live album Holy Ground
column2: they enlist the Wordless Music Orchestra to back them
column3: and the added heft of their strings makes the bombast even harder to take seriously: This is music destined for helicopter-panning shots of majestic rainforest canopies
column4: close-ups of dewy-eyed Olympic athletes
column5: and little else. They also stepped out from Steve Albini's production to enlist producer Henry Hirsch
column6: who gathered the band and the orchestra in his cavernous cathedral space
column7: Waterfront Studios
column8: where every kettle-drum thump and overdriven guitar could resound into the heavens. The album sounds beautiful
column9: in the way that Peter Jackson's visions of heaven in his critically reviled adaptation of The Lovely Bones looked beautiful: picture-book simple but vivid and clear.

column1: The Wordless Music strings play their melodies with a nice arm-twisting dab of schmaltz
column2: which is necessary when you are navigating the Mr. Holland's Opus-caliber key modulations in the finale of ""Legend"". They manage to make a simple rising major scale on ""Legend"" feel like dawning rays of morning sunshine. It's an uphill struggle
column3: though
column4: to claim real pathos from such transparently cheesy material: The guitar melody for ""Nostalgia"" directly plagiarizes some Suzuki Violin School tune-scrap my memory is still struggling to place from my childhood years in group classes. The melody to ""Unseen Harbor"" has a similar children's-exercise obviousness to its progression. It's hard to turn a nursery rhyme into Tchaikovsky.

column1: Mono's music is better used than listened to actively. As a vigorously marked road map to emotional catharsis
column2: I can imagine it being helpful: If I were
column3: say
column4: doing a particularly tough yoga class
column5: I'm sure that cueing up ""Dream Odyssey"" at the right moment would help me sink more deeply
column6: more meaningfully
column7: into my Warrior Two. Other music functions this way
column8: creating a space for you to have your own thoughts more than it bothers to have its own. But you can't exactly sink into a soothing bubble bath while Mono plays
column9: either
column10: as every piece works its way into a thundering
column11: Trans-Siberian Orchestra climax that would have me scrambling out of the tub for the volume button.

column1: The garish maximalism would be fine if the pieces did more to distinguish themselves from each other. Or if they were truly exciting. But For My Parents suffers
column2: somehow
column3: from both tastefulness and tastelessness: Too mushy and indistinguishable to wallop you in the gut and too cheesy to be taken seriously
column4: the album feels
column5: at its worst
column6: like a series of power ballads with the choruses ripped out. If they really want to make the post-rock equivalent of a Michael Bay film-- try a dirtier distortion pedal
column7: for instance
column8: or bring in the brass or better yet
column9:
a big heavy gong-- I'm there. But that kind of awesome would likely entail risking more genuine awfulness than Mono probably have in them.

"|16985.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16985-for-my-parents/|5.4|Jayson Greene

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18253/homepage_large.f1688b8d.jpg|The Carpenter|5496.0|The Avett Brothers|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['American']|2012-09-10 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:07:38.692892|"

It has been said that The Carpenter is the Avett Brothers' album about death. Death is there in the first song
column2: there in the last
column3: and wheedling all in between. The brothers
column4: actual and nominal
column5: aren't the raggedy kids they were when they started out a decade ago; they've married
column6: started families
column7: settled down. The band's last record
column8: 2009's I and Love and You
column9: offered a tamer version of Seth and Scott Avett's splintered yawps and shredded banjo strings
column10: and their live show has tempered as their catalog has filled out and fanbase expanded from regional devotees to national masses. It's tempting to peg the Avetts' story as one of a little-band-that-could selling out and smoothing over when a major label and bigger stages come calling
column11: but I'm not sure it's that simple; for an act in it for the long haul
column12: a certain rounding of the edges seems not only inevitable
column13: but natural-- healthy
column14: even. Growing up is hard to do
column15: but outright refusing can be trickier.

column2: as the Avetts know
column3: it all shakes out the same in the end. This record
column4: the band's second for Rick Rubin's American Recordings
column5: is hardly the first time their eyes have focused on that far
column6: dark horizon. Among all the rough-and-tumble soul-searching and skirt-chasing of their five previous releases there's been a steady procession of nods toward the dying of the light: ""The Lowering""
column7: from 2006's Four Thieves Gone
column8: remains the most gutting; Emotionalism's ""Die Die Die""-- which renders death a taunting
column9: stomp-along chorus-- still the most fun.

column1: But The Carpenter offers something different. In its most lucid moments
column2: at least
column3: it grapples with something perhaps more unfathomable than dying-- not being old
column4: but growing old. ""Things change and get strange with the movement of time/ It's happening right now to you
column5: Scott drawls on ""Down with the Shine""
column6: the rhapsodic choruses smudged with bleary
column7: boozy horns. There's a vast swath between shaking a fist at death and finally meeting its hand; meanwhile
column8: calendar pages turn
column9: diesel engines pull us along
column10: babies are born. ""A Father's First Spring"" could fall into the treacle-trap its title suggests but avoids it thanks to one of the band's finest songwriting efforts in some time. ""I have been homesick to you since we met
column11: Scott sings of and to his own little girl
column12: countering the sweetness with the sudden abject terror of new fatherhood: ""The realest thing I ever felt/ Was the blood on the floor and the love in your yell/ I was a child before the day that I met Eleanor."" Under the verses
column13: guitar lines tease and knit into one another; on the chorus
column14: Benmont Tench's organ wells and whirrs like an overfull heart.

column1: Too many of the other songs feel starved of that love
column2: though. The title track
column3: which opens the album
column4: suffers from major tonal whiplash
column5: the chillingly oblique line
column6: ""when the black dress drags upon the ground
column7: I'll be ready to surrender
column8: bafflingly abutted with the rancid cliche of ""we're all in this together."" The maudlin ""Winter in my Heart"" is colorless despite the verses' insistence upon listing color after color
column9: the mopey strums and mews of ""I don't know what the reasons are"" so effectively calling to mind that antidepressant ad with the morose bouncing ball that Zoloft should cut the band a check. ""I Never Knew You"" tries to slip into a loose-armed barroom vibe but veers into weird sock-hop territory before it gets the chance
column10: plagued all the while by an needling
column11: petty bitterness that would've been out of place even on the band's freshman efforts.

column1: The most notable travesty here-- and I do believe it is a travesty-- is ""Paul Newman vs. the Demons""
column2: which Scott Avett this summer told Rolling Stone was meant to harken back to the Avett Brothers' earlier incarnation as ""a loud band"" with an affection for Soundgarden
column3: but which only proves they were wise to avert course in the first place. Heaped upon the gunky
column4: puffed-up electric guitars and drum thrashings and hernia-busting vocals are lyrics referencing the movie star's eponymous line of organic
column5: all-proceeds-to-charity wine. ""Oh
column6: to be like him and walk a path / To lend a hand
column7: do something worth a damn
column8: the brothers sing. In all honesty
column9: if these guys want to slap their name on some preservative-free snacks-- Avett-O's
column10: maybe?-- I'll leave Publix with a box or two. But I'd rather reenact the egg-eating scene from Cool Hand Luke with a jar of Sockarooni sauce for dipping than listen to this song ever again.

column2: the Avetts' best release might be 2008's The Second Gleam
column3: a spry
column4: six-song EP; The Carpenter
column5: winnowed down to its best efforts
column6: would seem of a piece. This may be the real tragedy of the band's signing to Rubin's American imprint
column7: which was recently shuffled from Sony to Universal Republic: the need to justify the major-label investment with full LPs rather than the inbetweeny projects allowed for by Ramseur Records
column8: the band's longtime independent home. Rubin may be a wizard in the studio
column9: but his involvement has fostered a truly remarkable level of bloat in this once bare-boned
column10: focused band. But who knows? Maybe this is all exactly what they want. And if it is
column11: who can blame them for getting it? Life is too short
column12: and too long
column13:
for anything else.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18167/homepage_large.0e12c24a.jpg|Come of Age|29550.0|The Vaccines|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sony']|2012-09-10 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:07:39.284016|"

The Vaccines are not joking. Just joking; they are joking. That seemed to be the takeaway of their debut
column2: What Did You Expect From the Vaccines?
column3: the title of which wisely tried to curry favor with the listener by shifting the focus from the unyieldingly competent lad-rock within to what the Vaccines wanted to be seen as their utter lack of complicity in being swept up by perfunctory hype. Maybe they had a point: Even if they were heralded by NME as the ""Return of the Great British Guitar Band
column4: their relationship with the press seemed like less a torrid love affair than a blind date based on type (""you two will so get along"").

column2: it's not surprising that Come of Age is pulling all the same tricks both musically and philosophically. On leadoff track ""No Hope""
column3: Justin Young sings
column4: ""I don't really care about anybody else/ When I haven't got my own life figured out
column5: and it's clear that the title points to a reprise of the debut's self-reflexive copouts. On <i>Come of Age
column6: the Vaccines prove they've done nothing of the sort. What they have done is create a quasi-concept album about a rock band treating its job with the checked-out disinterest of an office drone
column7: doing the bare minimum to get by
column8: learning nothing
column9: and being scared to death by the obligations that come with appearing to give a shit.

column2: the music on Come of Age is wholly uncomplicated yet capable of winning listeners over by deftly straddling a very fine semantic distinction. Can you tell the difference between the figurative ""you've heard this before"" and the literal ""you haven't heard this before"" and want music to embody both? There's absolutely nothing the Vaccines do that hasn't been approved
column3: market-tested
column4: and confirmed over the past 30 years of British rock that warily views any encroachment of electronic music
column5: hip-hop-- basically anything not evolving from the Jam-- as a threat. The faster numbers barge in with a ""Brianstorm""-like whirl of drum rolls and tremolo picking
column6: then immediately taper off. The slower ones pick and choose from any number of song structures you vaguely remember from whatever Drums or Strokes album you listened to last. Not a single band member seems capable of doing anything without the other three's approval: Vocal melodies move completely in lockstep with well-worn progressions
column7: and occasionally just mimic the bass root notes. There's an occasional spray of surf rock
column8: but otherwise Come of Age is utterly subservient to Young's lyrics.

column1: The established templates make Come of Age catchy at the very least
column2: even if Young treats his gift for sticky choruses like ""No Hope"" and ""Aftershave Ocean"" like something that would make him feel guilty if he decided to sell insurance for a living. It's fine that this is music driven by personality rather than innovation
column3: but Young lacks the charm to be likeable or even the swagger to be unlikeable either. As a result
column4: Come of Age becomes an inverse Portnoy's Complaint where the narrator morbidly fixates on the utter meaninglessness of every single one of his thoughts. Let him tell it: ""I could bore you with the truth about an uneventful youth/ Or you could get that rap from someone else."" ""So let's go to bed before you say something real/ Let's go to bed before you say how you feel."" ""I'm no teenage icon/ I'm no Frankie Avalon/ I'm nobody's hero."" ""You can't hold a gun to my head/ Because baby I would just refuse."" Even spread across the entity of Come of Age
column5: it would be a disconcerting admission of serious writer's block or more likely crippling laziness. Those lines are all within the first four songs.

column2: as evidenced by ""Bad Mood""'s surely self-aware taunt
column3: ""You look disappointed in me/ I'm not as thoughtful as you thought I'd be."" More revealing is ""Weirdo"". Stylistically
column4: it's the most outré inclusion on Come of Age
column5: if only because its juddering bassline recalls Pixies and they're American. But the Vaccines pretty much reject any of Frank Black's lyrical lessons as Young pleads
column6: ""I'm not a weirdo
column7: to win a girl's heart. You look further down the tracklist and
column8: surely
column9: a song entitled ""I Wish I Was a Girl"" is willing to cop to something? Sorta-- Young moans
column10: ""Life is easy when you're easy on the eye
column11: and you might even overlook the deflating misogyny of that statement and find relief in the fact that he finally says what's been implied the whole time: He envies people who are expected not to have anything to say.

column1: Which quite obviously renders the regular-guy shtick the Vaccines play on Come of Age as total bullshit
column2: especially since you can purchase a deluxe version with bonus tracks and an entire extra disc of live cuts. It's as oily and slick-talking as any political figure trying to ascend to a position of tremendous power while convincing the populace they're ""one of us
column3: an easier path to take than simultaneously exhibiting leadership and empathy. But not even the soft bigotry of low expectations can suffice here since Come of Age hardly feels escapist. In fact
column4: it's even more of a dystopian nightmare than Kid A or an El-P record: The Vaccines draw us into a universe that revolves entirely around Young
column5: and if he's got nothing to say
column6: his only possible conclusion is that nobody does.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18156/homepage_large.fd5d079f.jpg|I Know What Love Isn't|2590.0|Jens Lekman|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Secretly Canadian']|2012-09-07 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:07:39.770521|"

Two years ago
column2: Swedish pop troubadour Jens Lekman released the first song that would appear on his next LP
column3: and it was a characteristically verbose
column4: witty
column5: and string-kissed number called ""The End of the World Is Bigger Than Love"". That title was disconcerting: Jens Lekman's music is the kind you look to when you need confirmation that love is the end of the world. Over the past decade
column6: few songwriters have dedicated themselves to dramatizing the rise and fall of the heart as brilliantly as Lekman. Whether he's falling in love at the post office or making out during a boring Sunday sermon
column7: his well-detailed
column8: gracefully arranged songs inflate everyday moments and view the most banal aspects of modern life through rosy lenses
column9: as though somebody's constantly spiking his drinks with love potion. So the message of this new song was a stark departure. Coming from the guy who once wrote a song about using his one prison phone call to dedicate a love song to a girl on the radio
column10: a chorus like ""A broken heart is not the end of the world"" brings with it Santa's-not-real-either levels of illusion-shattering.

column1: But even for the most hopelessly romantic Lekman fans
column2: two years should have been long enough for the track to reveal itself as a grade-A grower. There are a few characteristic laugh-lines (""It's bigger than the Flatbush Avenue Target! And their pharmacy department!"")
column3: but mostly ""End of the World"" glides through a wide variety of tones
column4: scenes
column5: and feelings
column6: as Lekman's breezy delivery distracts from how difficult it is to write a song that's so emotionally precise yet complex. The second verse finds him in Washington
column7: D.C.
column8: on the night of the 2008 presidential election
column9: trying to reconcile his private heartbreak with the public elation exploding around him-- and the strange happiness he feels in that moment
column10: too. This isn't ""Black Cab""
column11: his magnificently gloomy 2003 ode to being bummed when everyone around you is happy. It's a song about the infinite shades of gray that exist between joy and sadness. These are not always easy things to capture in pop songs
column12: but they're the hues he's chasing throughout I Know What Love Isn't. During a six-minute song about the painfully prolonged end of a relationship (""The World Moves On"") someone snips
column13: ""I wish you just would have cheated on me instead."" For one thing
column14: that would have been an easier song to write.

column1: All of this means that I Know What Love Isn't is
column2: by some stretch
column3: the hardest Jens Lekman record to love-- or at least feel instantly infatuated with. His earlier songs specialized in big
column4: bombastic choruses and memorable hooks-- the kind of writ-large tricks that leave you swooning on first listen. But he's after something different here. A word that Lekman's repeatedly used when describing the record is ""aerodynamic
column5: and in a recent interview he said
column6: ""You know how in the early 90s
column7: a lot of the songs were very focused on the verses being very quiet
column8: and the choruses being super loud
column9: like Nirvana? I was looking for the opposite of that
column10: where you hardly notice where the chorus starts; it's just like an airplane taking off from a runway
column11: smooth
column12: and all of a sudden you're in the air.""

column1: Though he sometimes takes this ""smoothness"" to an extreme (the Spanish guitar solo and saxophone riff make ""Erica America"" one of the more divisive songs in his oeuvre)
column2: it's most gainfully employed in the service of some of Lekman's classic lyrical sleights of hand. He's always gotten a kick out of wordplay (""And when she talked about the fall/ I thought she talked about Mark E. Smith"" remains one of his greatest deadpans)
column3: but on the standout ""Become Someone Else's""
column4: it's used with remarkable deftness-- not a punchline so much as a gutpunch. Over a moseying
column5: Bacharach-y piano riff
column6: the title phrase transforms from an idyllic profession (""Life's too good to become someone else's"") to an image of loneliness ('That lonesome feeling and what it tells us/ Sleeping on my arm 'til it becomes someone else's""). It's funny
column7: until it's not-- at which point you realize that it ranks up there with his best songs.

column2: Lekman's gone so far as to say that he hates ""albums."" His terrific 2005 record Oh You're So Silent Jens was actually a singles collection
column3: and when it came time to assemble the tracklist for his arguable career highlight Night Falls Over Kortedala
column4: he let his friends choose what should make the cut. The hodgepodge approach suited him well
column5: and those records had a feel that was both panoramic and casual: A song about his girlfriend was followed by a song about his barber
column6: each as expertly sketched. I Know What Love Isn't is
column7: he admits
column8: singularly focused on heartbreak
column9: and because its 10 songs are variations on a single theme
column10: he's said it feels like the first proper album he's made. But he's the first one to point out the casualties of thematic maturity: ""[On Night Falls Over Kortedala]
column11: I created a big rainbow of different colors on my little palette
column12: he explains. ""But
column13: for this album
column14: I only chose a few of those colors
column15: so it's a little bit more held back."" Ultimately
column16: some of those missing colors leave a void.

column1: But even when he focuses his unflagging talents within fixed bounds
column2: Lekman's still one of the most distinct and observant writers in indie rock today. The understated closer
column3: ""Every Little Hair Knows Your Name""
column4: is a gem
column5: as wrenching as it is lyrically agile. The title and first verse make it sound like a love song
column6: until the phrase ""when we broke up"" drops like an anvil. ""Every chord I struck was a miserable chord
column7: he croons
column8: and then plucks a few examples
column9: note by mournful note. ""It all sounds the same
column10: every chord knows your name."" It's heartbreak at its most sumptuously sad
column11:
as though he's taking back everything he said before. It actually sounds like the end of the world.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18198/homepage_large.f0429926.jpg|Heat Lightning Rumbles in the Distance|2015.0|Patterson Hood|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['ATO']|2012-09-07 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:07:40.273273|"

Even when he's exhausted
column2: Patterson Hood can't relax. Between tours and album cycles for the last two Drive-By Truckers records
column3: 2010's The Big To-Do and 2011's Go-Go Boots
column4: Hood decided to spend his down time writing a novel. Conceived while he was on the road for To-Do
column5: the book was supposed to be a semi-autobiographical novel about a deeply troubled period in his life back in the early 90s. ""I was 27
column6: my band broke up
column7: I got divorced and left my hometown to live in Memphis
column8: Hood writes in the promotional materials for Heat Lightning Rumbles in the Distance. ""My car got stolen
column9: our band's truck got stripped and I fell in love. I fell out with my family (who I was very
column10: very close to) and had my heart broken. I seriously pondered killing myself several times but instead wrote literally over 500 songs in a three-year period.""

column2: it shouldn't come as a surprise that his plans for a book eventually turned into an album. But the songs on Heat Lightning aren't otherwise typical for Hood
column3: as they're drawn more directly from his own life than the character studies and southern noir tales of petty crime and drunken malfeasance that he's known for. Heat Lightning is also more hopeful than much of his work
column4: including his previous solo record
column5: 2009's Murdering Oscar (And Other Love Songs). The songs might be inspired by the bleakest part of Hood's personal history
column6: but he's looking at it from a safe distance
column7: with the perspective of a family man with a much improved station in life.

column1: The album's titular metaphor is reminiscent of ""Tornadoes"" from 2004's The Dirty South
column2: one of Hood's most unsettling and evocative songs about a twister literally tearing families apart. But the sense of foreboding that exists in the title track is an echo from a far-off past; it exists in a different reality from where the song's protagonist currently stands with his wife and their ""babies at our feet"" as ""the warm summer wind blows"" like a salve. And so it goes for many of the low-key rumblers on Heat Lightning: Hood's songs survey lives (or perhaps just ""life"") marked by alcoholism
column3: loneliness
column4: loss of loved ones
column5: and lessons learned the hard way. But any sadness or desperation on this record is filtered through the reassuring knowledge that these hard times eventually passed.

column2: then
column3: is a life-affirming album disguised as a depressing song cycle
column4: with the gut-level power of Hood's best work cut back significantly. It is very much a ""home"" record by a man who typically makes ""road"" records
column5: with the noticeable lack of urgency that suggests. Even though Hood recruits several of his cohorts in Drive-By Truckers as backing musicians
column6: and adds ringers like Kelly Hogan and Centro-matic's Will Johnson
column7: there's no mistaking Heat Lightning for anything other than a solo album
column8: and a relatively low-stakes one at that. Hood has assembled a loose narrative connecting the songs
column9: but many of them still sound like unfinished demos

Naming your group Teengirl Fantasy suggests a self-conscious interest in someone else's idea of joyful abandon. Or at least
column3: it does if the group in question is a pair of male twentysomethings. Since they formed
column4: Oberlin buddies Nick Weiss and Logan Takahashi have treated hedonistic
column5: crowd-moving dance music this way: as something colorful
column6: captivating

column8: but so far

column10: Tracer

column12: and Weiss and Takahashi haven't quite closed it yet.

column2: their defining statement remains Weiss' slowing down of Mariah Carey's ""Touch My Body"" past the point of recognizability
column3: a calling-card moment that heightened expectations for their debut
column4: 7AM. That record never quite fought its way out of the middle-- the middle of the road
column5: the middle of the dynamic range
column6: the aesthetic midpoint between the drama of the records they loved and the remove they approached them from. The best song
column7: ""Cheaters""
column8: once again hitched its star to a super-heated vocal performance
column9: the churchy Philly-soul grit of Love Committee's ""Cheaters Never Win"". On Tracer
column10: they take another step away from the music of the past
column11: bringing in a handful of guest vocalists
column12: including Panda Bear
column13: Kelela
column14: and Laurel Halo
column15: with mixed results.

column1: Laurel Halo's voice is awfully close to a synth tone already
column2: and it floats weightlessly around the synth programming on ""Mist of Time"". Panda Bear's voice fraternizes uncomfortably with the pistoning rubbery drum and mechanical Detroit-house atmosphere on ""Pyjama"". ""EFX""
column3: featuring Kelela
column4: doesnt work at all. The vocals are simply thin
column5: and the song's disparate parts-- the meandering chorus melody
column6: the tinny sixteenth-note hi-hats
column7: the uncertain
column8: shuddering rhythm of the synths
column9: the syncopated finger pops-- just don't cohere. It isn't a shrewd recasting of a standard R&B song; it's simply an ineptly made example of one.

column2: however
column3: Weiss and Takahashi lay out their visions in purely instrumental terms
column4: and the production is sumptuous and beautifully tactile. This is what Teengirl Fantasy do best: They craft immaculate headphones music
column5: full of enveloping small details. The panning synth on ""Orbit"" hits like sunlight on a river
column6: while the watery blub of the drums and the little whispers that strafe across the mix all suggest an environment alive with tiny sounds of life. ""Vector Spray"" is built on a beat that sounds like feet splashing in shallow water and then wraps perspective-bending synth prisms around it. ""Eternal"" surrounds a breath-caught heartbeat pulse with a firefly storm of soft lights.

column2: Teengirl build a world that feels very much their own
column3: a place where industrial soot and grime mixes with blinding rainbow light.  The music is both layered and weightless
column4: misty and bright. If Tracer has significant replay value
column5: it's for the parsing of the details of its light-filled surface
column6: for the sounds themselves. During these moments
column7:
the music that inspired Weiss and Takahashi to start making music in the first place feels pleasantly remote.

The South London trio LV's follow-up to last year's accomplished Routes
column3: and their first full-length on Hyperdub

column6: two invigoratingly elastic dance music worlds that draw on a rich and overlapping heritage. Vocally it features turns from three distinctive South African acts
column7: Johannesburg's rapper/producer Spoek Mathambo and Okmalumkoolkat of music/performance art crew Dirty Paraffin along with Cape Town kwaito duo Ruffest. Each taps into
column8: bounces off of
column9: and elevates different elements in LV's music. And lyrically it's laced with a potent mix of languages: Zulu
column10: Xhosa
column11: English

column13: one that breeds a deeper infatuation with every lean closer.

column2: which means ""work"" in Zulu
column3: began with a trip that Gerv Gordon took to South Africa at the end of 2009 to visit family (he was born in Cape Town but moved to London as a child). There
column4: invigorated by the music scenes he encountered
column5: he was introduced to Okmalumkoolkat through Spoek Mathambo
column6: which resulted in 2010's tightly wound firecracker ""Boomslang""
column7: setting the precedent for subsequent collaborations with Spoek and Ruffest.

column1: Hailing from the township of Nyanga close to Cape Town
column2: Kwaito duo Ruffest rap in a mix of Xhosa and English. Mirroring the duo's bullet-like
column3: on-the-beat
column4: almost grime delivery
column5: LV's production for Ruffest's features is taut and punchy. While ""Nothing Like Us"" and ""ThaTha Lo"" have that chin-jutting dancefloor bounce
column6: ""Hustla"" strikes a chord with the global club underground's current spooky/sexy strain. Gorgeous album closer ""Uthando Lwaka""
column7: which means something between your love and love salvation in Xhosa

column2: who this year released his second experimental hip-hop album
column3: Father Creeper
column4: on Sub Pop
column5: LV had license to get abstract
column6: resulting in the two most quietly reflective moments on the record. ""Limb"" and ""Work"" both fizz with funk's low-slung sensual energy
column7: albeit at a fraction of the pace
column8: with the latter's skittering finger clicks providing perfect kindling to Spoek's skeletal lyrics. While his presence is minimal
column9: Spoek's features act as crucial pivot points and breathing spaces on Sebenza's otherwise non-stop ride.

column1: It's Okmalumkoolkat who's the undisputed star of the show
column2: however
column3: and not only because he features on eight of the album's 14 tracks. He has something of a Keith Haring pep to his post-it note flow
column4: spitting sharply and wittily on the universal intricacies of digital life. ""Dude
column5: we need many more hits/ Yeah
column6: I know
column7: he playfully back-chats himself on ""Animal Prints"". Perhaps because they've worked together before

column9: providing the acrobatic MC with plenty of audio hinges to spring off and distilling his frenetic energy with skillful framing.

column2: an ode to putting your back into it
column3: his rolling ""r""s ricochet off LV's synths
column4: working their tension into something urgent and infectious. Then on ""International Pantsula""
column5: he channels Joyce Sims' late-80s hit ""Come Into My Life"" on the hook
column6: vocoder warping the line to ""you gotta check out my blog
column7: I got so much shit to show you
column8: as if to underline that the spirit of our times is more often about likes not love. It's not all jokes though: again on ""Sebenza"" he slips in
column9: ""Since a way back they've been trying to silence us.../ Rubber bullets."" Those final two words wobble menacingly atop a precipice of bass
column10: a disillusioned allusion to the South African police service's infamous and inflammatory employment of them at many social protests of the past few years.

column1: An understanding that runs deeper than accessible language is the challenge and reward that Sebenza offers. Do we need to know what an artist is saying to hear what they're saying? Do we need a translation to respond to the energy? In the 21st century these questions should be as rhetorical as they feel. ""I'm a Zulu confuser/ Zulu computer/ Zulu wha' wha' what?"" teases Okmalumkoolkat on the ultra ear-wormy ""Zula Compurar"". Then on the divinely disheveled ""Spitting Cobra"" he pleads
column2: ""My slang is my language/ Please understand it/ Please understand it.""
LV meet Okmalumkoolkat
column3: Ruffest
column4: and Spoek Mathambo on common ground somewhere between South London and South Africa. What they've so deftly achieved is providing the space for each MC to carve out their own story: They neither swamp nor leave them adrift. The tracks feel like true collaborations rather than features. The energy exchange feels mutual. Sebenza feels like the future
column5:
now.

Mark Fell is like a calculus teacher. As one half of the experimental duo SND and more so under his own name
column2: he conducts unapologetic beat experiments. And like a math instructor

column5: in inputs and outputs. Fell's been more prolific under his own name than as a member of SND; Sentielle Objectif Actualité is a revision of three 12""s he released this year as Sensate Focus
column6: one of which was already a re-working of a house thumper he recorded with Terre Thaemlitz. Ahem: ""In calculus...the derivative is a measure of how a function changes as its input changes.""

column3: 3.33333333333333333-- correspond to an energy measurement for the latent heat fusion of water
column4: though I've no idea exactly what that means
column5: or if this is a coincidence) are the most straightforward

column7: when house was mingling with techno
column8: and the result was acerbic
column9: concrete soul. The Editions Mego page for Sentielle offers ""Recommended contextual materials"" from this era (an obscure MK remix of Chez Damier and Choo Ables' ""Hard to Get""). I like to think Fell had to be talked out of labeling these selections ""homework."" That same Editions Mego page also offers a roadmap for heroic DJs. Show your work for full credit: ""Track 4
column10: 128 bpm with 60 units each lasting 117.19ms
column11: with inserted pauses of between 4 and 80 units.""

column1: You get the idea: Sentielle is heady stuff. Like previous albums UL8 and especially the fantastic Multistability

column4: highly emotive dance music. Fell's work is intense and reptilian
column5: non-confrontational in the same way that the Cold War was really just scientists thousands of miles apart hovering over buttons; a show of brutality would humanize the battle.

column1: Mathematical analogies and explanations help me understand why a composer as talented as Fell would make this music
column2: but they're not necessary to enjoy it. It's best not to focus on the calculations

column7: but they reflect light in a way their host matter can't. Fell's synths and snatches of melody sound imperfect set against his rhythms

column9: long-lost uncle to the slappy
column10: harsh surfaces turned out by younger artists like Jam City and Girl Unit.

column2: a reminder that psychedelic experiences can occur while totally sober if you deny yourself food
column3: or rest. Fell denies us much of what we expect from dance music: a sense of journey
column4: a traceable rhythm
column5: a defined purpose or utility. In doing so

column7: he approaches trance from the complete opposite direction. You can still burrow down
column8: nod out
column9: ask how many stars are in the sky; unlike most trance music
column10:
Sentielle will encourage you to count.

Like another revered Minnesotan songwriter
column2: Bob Mould is a don't-look-back kinda guy: The noise-pop trail he blazed with Hüsker Dü in the 1980s was roadblocked by a pair of dirgey
column3: despairing solo releases; his short-lived return to rock in the early 90s with Sugar was answered with a series of increasingly sophisticated-- and occasionally electronic-- solo albums informed by his pre-millennial immersion into New York's gay club scene and contented ease into middle age. Always self-aware but never self-obsessed

column5: and of his wavering desire to engage with the contemporary alt-rock for which he essentially wrote the playbook. But Mould has
column6: uncharacteristically

column1: Just as Sugar emerged in 1992 right as Hüsker Dü's legacy was becoming manifest in both the chart-conquering crunch of Nirvana and the underground-overturning squall of My Bloody Valentine
column2: Silver Age arrives as a totem of Mould's continued influence on today's mainstream rock (Foo Fighters
column3: Green Day) and indie-level (No Age
column4: Japandroids) artists alike. Recorded with the band he used to tour 2009's stately Life and Times-- bassist Jason Narducy and Superchunk/Mountain Goats drummer Jon Wurster-- Silver Age immediately establishes itself as a more roaring
column5: rambunctious affair. In fact
column6: the album is so true to fuzz-pop form that you might easily mistake it for an unearthed bonus disc of quality Sugar outtakes from those recent reissues; the opening anti-sellout screed ""Star Machine"" could even pass for a 90s-era comment on mallternative-rock chancers. The title track
column7: however
column8: firmly asserts the record as the work of a modern-day Mould when he declares
column9: ""I'm never too old to contain my rage
column10: before spitting on the ""stupid little kid [who] wanna hate my game."" Yet there's a vigor and vitality running through Silver Age that belies those cranky-old-man sentiments; while there is much to admire about Mould's penchant for taking risks and shifting creative course
column11: no fan would complain if he simply delivered euphoric power-pop knockouts like ""The Descent""
column12: ""Briefest Moment""
column13: and ""Keep Believing"" in perpetuity.

column1: The Sugar reissues provide a convenient yardstick with which to measure the strength of the songs here
column2: though they also draw attention to the new album's monochromatic sound-- Silver Age would benefit from a destabilizing dose of loopy psychedelia à la ""Hoover Dam""
column3: or a more direct appeal to heart in the vein of ""If I Can't Change Your Mind"" to bring greater dimension to the album's workmanlike drive. But just as those classic Hüsker Dü records suggested an infinite depth of noise despite their pancaked production
column4: Mould still covers a lot of ground here while staying in the red. From the dreamy
column5: ""Man on the Moon""-style drone of ""Steam of Hercules"" to the foreboding urgency of ""Angels Rearrange""
column6: Mould just sounds so perfectly at home when howling in the face of a hurricane-- his voice is as natural a complement to a hazily overdriven power chord as Brian Wilson's is to a harpsichord. Silver Age is a suitably self-deprecating title from an artist whose considerable cachet hasn't always allowed him to cash in; Mould effectively owns up to his contrarian tendencies when
column7: in ""The Descent""
