column9: ""I didn't want to play the song/ That gave people so much hope."" But as a showcase of a seasoned master in his element
column10: Silver Age's bounty of direct
column11:
distorto-pop hits measures up to Mould's gold standard.

column7: from Timbaland's early aughts production to the agro-rap of Three 6 Mafia and Waka Flocka Flame.

column1: The 22-year old producer Ryan Hemsworth's new EP
column2: Last Words
column3: is another sterling release from the collective
column4: and while it's too scattered to be considered truly excellent

column1: Hemsworth has a history of making beats for such offbeat rap acts as Deniro Farrar and Main Attraktionz

column3: webby thud of Clams Casino

column5: colorful bits of sound engaging the listener like a light show for purp-heads in a narcotic stupor.

column2: though it's the least danceable of everything here

column4: Hemsworth sets up a droning masterpiece
column5: punctuated by schizoid drum machines and followed by an ominous minor keyboard loop which sounds a hell of a lot like ""Black and Yellow"".

column2: starts in the same drone sphere as ""Colour & Movement""
column3: but takes off quickly when Timbaland-like drum machines are added
column4: and drops sound out two-thirds of the way through to make way for the eerie harmonizing of a chorus of lady phantoms. It's haunting
column5: elegant
column6: and heavy
column7: a song to be played in a cathedral that was converted into a nightclub and still hasn't been fully exorcized.

column2: Hemsworth gets overly enthusiastic and flips a sample unnecessarily. Even if opener ""Charly Wingate"" is clearly a tribute to the now forever-incarcerated Max B
column3: the song's use of his ad-libs distracts from what would otherwise be a perfect dance track. But for the most part
column4: the allusions are seamless
column5: as on ""Slurring""
column6: where Waka's offhand comment on his less-than-sober state from ""15th and the 1st"" becomes the basis for a maximalist
column7: warped club track
column8: which builds expertly
column9: reaching a peak without ever becoming exhausting or frantic. This is perhaps Hemsworth's principal skill: managing tracks all the way through and avoiding tedium and redundancy.

column1: A set of uniformly solid beats like these also serves as a base upon which other producers can build. The strongest showing comes from Supreme Cuts
column2: whose heady version of ""Overthinking"" stuffs the original with a whole new set of sounds
column3: obscenely amplifying the highs to create the best club track on the album. But don't count out Baauer
column4: whose already rapidly ascending profile should be boosted even further by his work on ""Slurring""
column5: as he too converts something that was sitting on the rap-dance margins into a full-on rave track
column6: with massive drum cycles and the undeniable shudder of uncut adrenaline.

column2: purple sound that Hemsworth is working with here has graduated in the past year
column3: as laid-back producers like Shlohmo and more aggressive ones like Rustie compete for the same space. Hemsworth
column4: though not quite in the same category as those guys
column5: marries the two mindsets. In the process he produces an EP that that gives the impression of being greedily
column6: beautifully excessive
column7:
while in actuality remains more poised and controlled than something this fun has any right to be.

Despite a moniker that suggests kinship with the last decade of bands drawn to ideas of  carefree adolescence

column3: known best as the keyboardist for Here We Go Magic
column4: TEEN make cloudy
column5: lo-fi indie that wouldn't sound out of character being banged out in a suburban basement after homeroom. Lyrically
column6: however

column8: which is the rub. While you get the sense that Lieberson herself is more than willing to provide a window into her thought process
column9: the music suggests she isn't ready to make big decisions. Whereas a 14-year old snaps to decisions and sorts out the details later (if at all)

column11: getting lost in their own thoughts.

column1: You could say that In Limbo has a firm grip on vibe but a very loose sense of form. ""Better"" opens the album strongly
column2: driven by a sharp vocal
column3: pungent synth lines
column4: and Moe Tucker-inspired drum primitivism
column5: while Lieberson plainly but forcefully asserts
column6: ""I do it better than anybody else."" Her post-punk punch is tougher than the song
column7: but not by much. ""Better"" peaks around the three-minute mark-- the handclaps added to the chorus are a nice touch-- but then it continues on for two minutes more
column8: neither changing nor adding anything new

column2: this might have worked. Lieberson was an important cog in a strong machine there
column3: and the whole band was precisely equivalent to the sum of its parts. Particularly in a live setting
column4: they could stretch out and morph a simple rhythmic idea for what felt like an eternity
column5: with each player's parts as fascinating to focus on as the clockwork sound of the entire band. With TEEN
column6: this is not the case. The songs are dense and trebly
column7: swirling and mutating but rarely growing
column8: and too often staying way past their welcome. There are plenty of worthwhile ideas
column9: but a seasoned producer could strategically shave 20 minutes off the album while losing little.

column2: Lieberson's ideas get lost. In Limbo would definitely benefit from a few more songs with the animated romantic ache of ""Come Back""
column3: and minus album-closer ""Fire"" (my first thought upon hearing the song's opening seconds was of the band glumly receiving the ""millionth customer"" prize for appropriating Hal Blaine's ""Be My Baby"" drums). The second half of the record
column4: marked by the lingering dirges ""Unable"" and ""Roses and Wine""
column5: falls into a slumber. While ""Roses"" drags on for six-and-a-half minutes with nothing much to report

column7: narrating the mundane predictability of person-to-person interactions and the seeming impossibility of breaking free of this rut. Humming along at a numbing pace
column8: the song does no justice to such an interesting perception

column10: and should make better albums than In Limbo
column11: once the band gains the strength of Lieberson's convictions. With material like this
column12:
it's best to strive toward investigating and captivating rather than simply brooding.

Seventeen years after Chan Marshall's debut as Cat Power and six years after her most recent album of original material
column2: comes Sun
column3: her ninth album. But let's drop the math right there. Because Sun is a record with its own peculiar temporal logic
column4: one that's circular rather than linear. Take that picture on the cover
column5: for example. It's Marshall 20 years ago
column6: but toward the end of Sun's almost six-year gestation period
column7: she chopped off her hair and looks
column8: once again
column9: like the image in the photo. At the risk of engaging in cheap analysis
column10: this fact feels not entirely trivial. ""When we were teenagers
column11: we wanted to be the sky
column12: she sang on her enduringly haunting 1998 record Moon Pix
column13: her voice warbling at that moment as if she were delivering an elegy
column14: like it's a shame we all at some point give up on those lofty and poetically illogical dreams. But Sun is a testament to what happens when that sensibility and logic somehow survive a turbulent adulthood: This
column15: these weather-beaten and irrepressibly hopeful songs all seem to say
column16: is what it sounds like when you still want to be the sky at 40.

column2: Sun is a declaration of independence. There are
column3: of course
column4: the biographical facts
column5: the things the record's defiant tone feels like a direct break with-- stage fright
column6: substance abuse
column7: break-ups
column8: creative demons (it's been reported that Marshall scrapped some early demos because a friend told her they sounded too much like her older stuff). It is also the first Cat Power record to feature prominent synthesizers and (occasionally) Auto-Tune
column9: though that doesn't exactly mean it sounds like anything on the radio right now. But you'd get these ideas about autonomy and independence just from perusing the lyric sheet
column10: too. ""I want to live my way of living
column11: she chants on the meditative ""Always on My Own"". The next song
column12: ""Real Life""
column13: is about the universality of grass-is-always-greener yearning (""I met a doctor/ He want to be a dancer/ I met a mother/ She want to be alone""). Spinning her years of tour-induced wanderlust into wisdom
column14: Marshall offers them all some sage advice: ""Sometimes you gotta do what you don't wanna do/ To get away with an unordinary life.""

column1: In the way it simultaneously embraces darkness and light and exists completely and defiantly outside of any larger musical trends (and clearly operates with no particular fear or hang-ups about kitsch-- check out that eagle sound effect on ""Cherokee"")
column2: the closest thing to Sun we've heard this year is probably Fiona Apple's The Idler Wheel. But whereas Apple focuses on the highly idiosyncratic clockwork of her own brain
column3: Marshall is more interested in the ways in which she is
column4: in some fundamental human way
column5: no different from anybody else. In some cases
column6: this means grappling with her own privileges (""Ruin""'s deceivingly upbeat chorus actually goes: ""Bitchin'/ Complainin'/ When some people ain't got shit to eat""). And in others
column7: it means those sorts of bald-faced cosmic statements about mortality that few other artists can pull off (see: a song called ""Human Being"" that goes
column8: ""You got a right to breathe/ You got a right/ You're a human being."") In her recent profile of Marshall
column9: Amanda Petrusich linked Cat Power's songwriting philosophy back to an earlier time when ownership was a much looser concept and all songs were considered public domain. She sees people like this
column10: too
column11: including herself. So in the moments when Sun feels kitschy
column12: it's because it's got a generousness of spirit that's fallen sharply out of fashion at some point
column13: that something about our experience is public and shared
column14: that we're all pretty alike just by virtue of being human.

column1: Sun's middle stretch from ""Always on My Own"" to ""Human Being"" suffers from being a little muddy and unmelodic
column2: but stick around for the finale. It starts with the late-night
column3: long-walk-home soundtrack ""Manhattan""-- gorgeous
column4: hypnotic
column5: and quietly
column6: unsentimentally lonely (""All the friends we used to know ain't coming back""). And then there's Sun's late-sequenced
column7: 11-minute centerpiece
column8: ""Nothin But Time"". Which brings us back to that ""public domain"" idea: With its parade-float pace and self-consciously anthemic lyrics (""You got nothing but time/ And it ain't got nothing on you... It's up to you/ To be a superhero"")
column9: it is
column10: yes
column11: a clear homage to Bowie's ""Heroes"". But it's ""Hey Jude""
column12: too: Marshall wrote it to cheer up her ex's teenage daughter
column13: and the longer it goes on
column14: the truer its optimistic truisms ring
column15: the stronger the urge to holler them along with the rest of of voices (""You wanna live!""). It's an odd but fitting peak. By the sixth minute
column16: when Iggy Pop's voice comes in god-sized and benevolent
column17: it's like some sort of peyote daydream where one of the faces on Mount Rushmore stoops to talk to you and has only the kindest things to say.

column2: maybe she's just talking to herself. ""Time
column3: nothing but time
column4: was another lyric she sang on Moon Pix
column5: except there she moaned it a little bit like it was a prison sentence. Here it's a mantra. Sun doesn't reach the heights (or more accurately
column6: wallow in the depths) of Moon Pix
column7: but more than anything else she's made
column8: it feels like a companion piece to that record
column9: a conversation with an older and wiser voice. But what she seems to have learned out there is that wisdom means knowing less than you once thought you did
column10: whether that means embracing some new instruments even if you have no idea how they work
column11: or seeing sense where others see paradox. Sun is a double-exposed photo. You know those afternoons when the sun's high but somehow the moon's just unexpectedly hanging out
column12:
too? That's the kind of sky Marshall got to be.

column2: whose three solo tracks go a long way toward invalidating the previous three paragraphs. Ferg's style is similar to Rocky's-- his flow is hyper-musical

column2: though

is the exception. The individual members of A$AP Mob have stepped out of the shadows and shown that they have a long way to go before establishing themselves as compelling figures on their own. Romance in contemporary popular music
column2: as it is in life
column3: is hard to come by. Songs of love and lust are commonplace
column4: but romance? It seems to be a luxury we can no longer afford
column5: which is a shame. Romance might only be artifice
column6: but sometimes it's a necessary artifice
column7: presenting an elusive vision that exists in our hearts and can only be made tangible in art. Even if Long Slow Dance
column8: the fourth full-length album by San Francisco psych-pop group the Fresh & Onlys
column9: were not loaded with excellent songs
column10: it would be worthy of affection because it is so unabashedly imbued with this lost sense of romanticism. The band's principal songwriter
column11: Tim Cohen
column12: is pictured on the back cover as a typical po-faced indie rock dude with the de rigueur bushy beard and scraggly
column13: mussed-up 'do. But on the record
column14: he's a tuxedoed Fred Astaire doing a soft-shoe with Ginger Rogers through a wondrous black-and-white world. Lush and love struck
column15: with a light-as-air melodicism that blesses the songs like sprinkles of pixie dust
column16: Long Slow Dance dares to revel in that magical moment between a first kiss and the walk back to the car
column17: and stretch it out to the length of a lifetime memory.

column1: The Fresh & Onlys pointed in this direction on 2010's great Play It Strange
column2: which was kicked off by the band's two best-ever songs
column3: ""Summer of Love"" and ""Waterfall"". With its Beach Boys harmonies
column4: gently rolling surf guitar
column5: and Cohen's dreamy
column6: reverb-heavy vocal
column7: ""Summer of Love"" suggested a mood of escape that the more propulsive ""Waterfall"" explicitly spelled out in the lyrics. Frequently classified as revivalists
column8: the Fresh & Onlys were actually evolving into sensualists
column9: and that process comes to a head on Long Slow Dance
column10: which deals mainly in expressions of love at its most immediate and pleasurable.

column1: Cohen is never more charming on Long Slow Dance than he is on the title track
column2: a jangly strummer that supplements the Fresh & Onlys' usual 1960s rock touchstones with nods to the Cure and the Church. ""You supply the innocent mind/ And I'll bring the guilty heart/ And borne together
column3: we'll make the perfect romance
column4: Cohen sings
column5: his flat baritone cracking just enough to indicate a thawing of his previously cool façade. It's not clear whether the person he's singing to truly exists
column6: nor does it matter; what's important is that Cohen's yearning is relatable even as the evocative music elevates it to poetic heights. Unlike many similar-minded groups that merely allude to prior examples of classic songwriting rather than carry on the tradition
column7: ""Long Slow Dance"" is a genuinely fantastic example of the form
column8: with Cohen following through a list of ""you're wonderful and I'm scum"" metaphors as the impossibly comely music conjures a quick tango underneath a starry sky.

column1: The rest of Long Slow Dance nearly matches that high level of swoony wonder. ""Dream Girls"" is a twangy lament in the vein of Chris Isaak
column2: and ""Presence of Mind"" sounds custom-made for movie montages
column3: with its giddy marimba flourishes and squiggly dream-sequence guitar riff from Wymond Miles. (It also carries the album's nut graph: ""Here lies a man with stars in his eyes/ What does he care if the future is bright?/ The future is bright
column4: after tonight."")

column1: Easily the slickest album the Fresh & Onlys have made yet
column2: Long Slow Dance subtly expands the band's sonic palette without overwhelming the band's appealing simplicity. The sweeping ""20 Days and 20 Nights"" takes a melancholic turn via a wistful piano solo
column3: while the moody folk-pop tune ""Executioner's Song"" culminates with a surprisingly expressive horn section. The sinister lo-fi side of the group's personality displayed on its 7""s and 2009's spooky Grey-Eyed Girls has been sublimated. For now
column4: Cohen is playing up the poppiest aspects of his band's sound
column5: occupying the space once owned by the Shins on <i>Oh
column6: Inverted World and Chutes Too Narrow. With Long Slow Dance
column7:
he's made a record for blissfully happy nights.

Here's a description of endearment from ""Police Brutality"": ""Baby fat still hung on your cheeks like a lil' JonBenét."" That same song dips into some fairly graphic imagery later on

it's definitely a far cry from Free Drugs;-).

column1: Nowhere in the Animal Collective discography has that sense of unease felt so pronounced as on Centipede Hz. The band's latest album is to Merriweather as Strawberry Jam was to Feels-- the anxious flipside to an ecstatic predecessor. But its execution is even more relentless. column2: they've never before hit with such blunt force. The rippling rhythms and aquatic ambience of Merriweather is displaced by industrial-strength ballast: Lead-off track ""Moonjock"" announces itself with a morse-code crunch that could practically pass for Sleigh Bells
column3: while stuttering lead single ""Today's Supernatural"" closes with the sort of drum-set-toppling flourish that arena-rock acts use to stretch out their last encore. These songs get Centipede Hz off to a deliriously disorienting start

column5: it becomes increasingly apparent that Centipede Hz's over-caffeinated energy comes at the expense of what
column6: for all their restless creativity
column7: has always been Animal Collective's greatest virtue-- their patience.

column1: From Sung Tongs' ""Kids on Holiday"" and Feels' ""Banshee Beat"" to Strawberry Jam's ""Fireworks"" and Merriweather's ""My Girls""
column2: Animal Collective's greatest moments have conveyed a shared sense of discovery. There's a sense of something special being slowly revealed
column3: of chaotic rhythms

Now Orb linchpin Alex Paterson and German techno mortician Thomas Fehlmann

In his 1997 book Invisible Republic: Bob Dylan's Basement Tapes
column2: Greil Marcus devised the term ""the old

column6: Weird America"" was his original title for book

column8: most often floating free of any source or attribution

column2: weird America"" implies not only a pre-rock or a pre-War regionalism

column8: and aspired to something like fame. Today ""the old
column9: weird America"" has become a self-conscious genre that overlaps with Americana
column10: indie rock
column11: and the darker corners of country music. Certain ideas have become attached to the phrase
column12: which means that it has become shorthand for a kind of commercial independence and creative authenticity that its first practitioners were never concerned with in the first place.

Let me get it out of the way and welcome everyone who clicked here with the sole hope of witnessing Pitchfork's biggest statistical mea culpa ever. Ten years is a long time for sour grapes to ferment

column7: praising it not so much for its musical value as its ability to combine with Adderall and Keystone Ice to form an outgoing college senior's Holy Trinity of nihilistic intoxication. It was and is a record that inspires extreme reactions. And a lot of us seemingly did I Get Wet a great disservice trying to intellectualize it from both sides. Now here we are 10 years later and nothing has changed about the record except our relationship to it. Even though critics of Andrew W.K. were often branded as the fun police and his fans considered fools or incurable ironists

column3: or idiot savant genius. But do you want to turn a record whose first song is called ""It's Time to Party"" into an academic work? Many
column4: including Andrew W.K. himself
column5: have tried to frame ""party"" as a metaphorical device or a Zen philosophy
column6: but come the fuck on: It does nothing new in any technical sense if you've been in a basketball arena at any point in your life. And still
column7: the only response to hearing the initial detonation of guitars
column8: kick drums
column9: and fake orchestra hits from ""It's Time to Party"" is
column10: ""What the fuck is this?"" Or to backflip into a kegstand
column11: after which the next 90 seconds should not be spent around any breakable or flammable home furnishings. ""Party Hard"" is the next song and upon first exposure
column12: the two may seem like the five greatest minutes of music you've ever heard.

column1: Whether you consider these songs to be brilliant
column2: brilliantly dumb
column3: or just dumb
column4: I Get Wet is necessarily simple. Though placed in the lineage of hair metal
column5: there's almost no technical flash
column6: no power ballads
column7: not even a single minor chord. The trickiest modulation happens on the chorus to ""Girls Own Love""
column8: which may or not just be a Hysteria deep cut played at twice the speed. The vocal harmonies of ""Party Hard"" are stacked so thick that the melody barely moves
column9: making it the easiest and best karaoke song ever. Even if ""Party Hard"" had lyrics about anything else
column10: it would still be a keg-rock legend based on its riffs alone-- they're the four best on I Get Wet
column11: which makes them the four best of that year. But unlike those from
column12: say
column13: White Blood Cells
column14: they just sound wrong banged out on one guitar. The impossible number of vocal and guitar overdubs on ""Take It Off"" pushes it beyond even shoegaze incomprehensibility. You simply can't divorce the sensational effect of I Get Wet from its emotional one
column15: and the music truly is the message: ""It's Time to Party"" immediately triggers I Get Wet's enduring effect
column16: the same pit-in-the-stomach feeling of boarding a roller coaster
column17: asking someone out
column18: or looking at your bank account after a particularly brutal weekend. It's thrilling
column19: it's nauseating
column20: there's no going back.

column1: But while I Get Wet is the perfect Andrew W.K. album
column2: it's in no way a perfect album. For one thing
column3: there are the songs that actually try to make some sort of coherent statement and could potentially take on some sort of post-9/11 relevance (""I Love NYC""
column4: ""Ready to Die""). But they thrash about as blissfully unaware as ""Party Hard"" because they make absolutely no sense. Many hear I Get Wet as a record of unintentional comedy
column5: but ""I Love NYC"" falls into the realm of intentional comedy because I don't even think it's about New York City. Or any city. ""She Is Beautiful"" and ""Girls Own Love"" are both hilariously bereft of any kind of eroticism
column6: women viewed as mere vessels for expressions of male lust and yet beyond all comprehension. They're songs Barbie and Ken might fuck to. Point being that
column7: for an album that supposedly steamrolls any talk of nuance
column8: it has some pretty mundane issues. And the second half is much weaker than the first. If you don't believe me
column9: ask anyone who's shown up to the I Get Wet 10-year anniversary shows 20 minutes late. (Dude loves to party but he's remarkably punctual.)

column1: Part of that is inevitable since any record that starts with ""It's Time to Party"" and ""Party Hard"" doesn't leave much room to build on an upward trajectory. But while ""Party Til You Puke"" is the culmination of I Get Wet's ""Party"" trilogy
column2: it's also the tipping point where the thought of past
column3: present
column4: or future partying becomes unbearably oppressive. The sheer velocity of its call and response vocals renders it a monolithic yell of ""CHUG
column5: and immediately afterwards
column6: ""Fun Night"" is that guy handing you a rally beer at the toilet when all you can say is ""not now
column7: bro."" ""Got to Do It"" is ""Girls Own Love"" seen through the eye of a tiger
column8: and though I've owned this record for nearly a decade
column9: to this day I still can't remember what the title track sounds like. To its credit
column10: ""Don't Stop Livin' in the Red"" is pretty much the only way this record could end
column11: and it's nice to see it get him some Target ad money even though it's almost impossible to imagine its
column12: um
column13: suggestive cover appearing in the superstore's sales racks. So I suppose there's irony somewhere in all this.

column2: it's worth exploring whether or not you're amongst Andrew's white-denimed minions. There's a batch of live tracks that are curiously and intentionally recorded in a way that Andrew W.K. once described to me as what he hears when he's on stage. I'd say the demos and alternate takes are far more intriguing since the idea of I Get Wet ever existing as demos is hilarious-- just imagine Andrew W.K. hunched over an acoustic guitar trying to finish ""We do what we like…"" with the right lyric.

column1: If you're 20 years old and haven't heard I Get Wet yet
column2: go ahead and enjoy it while you can. But I won't convince you that it matters in a larger sense even though the ostensible goal of any reissue
column3: particularly in the case where the original isn't out of print
column4: is to edify or reassess. That's unnecessary with I Get Wet. Not much Andrew W.K. did or could do after the record would redeem
column5: justify
column6: or vindicate your original opinion of it. About a year and a half after it failed to set the charts ablaze
column7: The Wolf happened
column8: and while it's a perfectly fine record
column9: its value is entirely manifested in its utility for expert-level trolling; surely on a message board somewhere
column10: someone is taking great satisfaction in his opinion that it's better than I Get Wet.

column1: Andrew W.K. did go on to make other records on a much smaller and cultishly followed scale
column2: which was likely meant to happen from day one. In spite of the utter lack of separation between Andrew Wilkes-Krier and his living
column3: breathing party persona
column4: neither appears to have aged a day in the past decade
column5: which perhaps confirms the record's totemic
column6: unyielding nature. Because really
column7: while my life has changed significantly since my first exposure to I Get Wet and I maybe spin this record once a year
column8: I still don't think there's ever been an album that does a better job
column9: while it's actually playing
column10:
of convincing me it's the only music I'll ever need for the rest of my life.

column8: these pieces seem undecided. ""Absorption""
column9: for instance

column19: and washes of noise; after he sings a verse
column20: they rupture the beat until it falls apart
column21: a trail of percussion and synthesizer whir following behind the fading pulse. The indulgence gives Stewart's pathos a rare patina of comfort and approachability. That is
column22: if one of Xiu Xiu's chief assets is his urgency
column23: Stewart works quite well in the absence of it

The artwork for Edinburgh-via-London band Django Django's eponymous debut perfectly sums up the record's basic contrast: the clash of the dustbowl against some futuristic
column3: swirling alien presence. Prairie guitars with heavy-thumbed top strings sidestep and shuffle around chirruping synthesizers
column4: sonar-shaky womps
column5: and krautrock plains in a fashion not dissimilar to Beck's more recent releases. However
column6: one of the joys of Django Django is that even though it's rendered in two basic colors-- natural and synthetic-- the scenarios it conjures are significantly more multifaceted.

column1: There's a boyish sense of adventure and emotion to this album. Following a mechanical introduction that sounds like the theme to a 1980s science educational video
column2: ""Hail Bop""'s airless
column3: stabby twang recalls a sci-fi terror sequence-- desperately trying to diffuse a ticking time bomb
column4: or escape a compressing trash compactor. The ensuing burbling synths
column5: arid Dick Dale-indebted guitar and unpredictable squelches recall the kind of landscapes conjured by the Super Furry Animals
column6: rolling hills perfect for boisterous psychedelic trips
column7: with the conspicuously blankly chanted lyrics set among hillocks and vast skies
column8: too. A potentially romantic figure ""appear[s] from the hillside... a funny look in your eye
column9: before darting off again in spite of the onlooker having been ""waiting here so long.""

column1: The scene sets the tone for an album where what appears to be a disintegrating relationship is rarely described in human or adult emotional terms; rather it's as a tricksy Rube Goldberg device where the parties race to reassemble and disassemble the partnership as part of a game of emotional one-upmanship and obstacle-planting. Former single ""Default"" is a wickedly neurotic stompbox-powered chant with voices intermittently gargling and hissing in cuckoo clock rhythm. ""We just lit the fire and now you want to put it out
column2: Dave
column3: Vincent
column4: Tommy
column5: and Jimmy chant. ""Take one for the team/ You're a cog in the machine/ It's like a default."" The itchy ""WOR"" starts with a murkily obfuscated motif from ""Misirlou""
column6: rumbling into a rubbery
column7: lurching funk that sets the pace for another competitive move: ""I took a chance on you and it's time to ring the bell.""

column1: The unrelenting chanted singing style can make Django Django sound a bit sterile and passionless
column2: building to a brassy sheen that defies the eloquent frustration of a song like ""Storm"": ""You are a storm; you are my little storm/ I watch the wind change to find out where you've been blown."" The group has been lazily compared to the Beta Band
column3: largely due to their Fife-born drummer and production whizz David Maclean being the younger brother of John Maclean. But whereas that band married Lennon-like vocal calm with bucolic
column4: occasionally piqued backing
column5: Django Django seem more akin to Hot Chip in approach: a bunch of comparative straights going doolally in a studio
column6: using their dispassionate vocal layering as the foundation from which to paint in entertainingly bold strokes. ""Firewater""
column7: a song about getting legless on booze in the desert
column8: gambols and struts like a drunk precariously skirting the edge of a campfire; ""Skies Over Cairo"" gets weirder
column9: the sound of a Saharan-influenced Kraftwerk careering over a huffing rhythm seemingly comprised of samples of recorded water. Despite jangling on past its shelf life
column10: the opening of ""Zumm Zumm"" fizzes and clanks like an ancient fairground attraction
column11: with hyena yaps punctuating oblique exclamations about unexpected
column12: never-before-seen occurrences.

column1: That same sense of vivacity can't be applied to the song that follows it
column2: ""Hand of Man""
column3: whose dull country roughage creaks out beneath a numbed appropriation of the melody from the Shins' ""New Slang"". Thankfully
column4: however
column5: Django Django picks up again with ""Love's Dart""
column6: a bandy coconut canter which urges that goals-- romantic or otherwise-- can be more than just a mirage if you keep them firmly in mind. Django Django are bursting with ideas and an intriguing aesthetic that would suggest that their own goals are very keenly defined-- the result of working on this album for over two years
column7: perhaps-- with the artwork's simplicity acting as a red herring to their boundlessly imaginative
column8:
considered complexity.

Sometimes the ""featuring ex-members of"" tag can be misleading
column2: but in the case of Serpentine Path
column3: pedigree is important. The band
column4: which debuted in February on a self-titled 7""
column5: includes the entirety of Unearthly Trance
column6: a Brooklyn-via-Long Island trio that issued a string of harrowing
column7: unpredictable doom-metal records before disbanding this past July. Bassist Jay Newman and drummer Darren Verni play the same roles in the new group
column8: while Ryan Lipynsky-- a super-prolific guitarist-vocalist also known for his work in black-metal projects such as Thralldom and the Howling Wind-- handles mic duties exclusively. The fresh element here is guitarist Tim Bagshaw
column9: a member of Ramesses
column10: a UK trio that takes stoner metal to nightmarish extremes. (The four met in 2002 when Unearthly Trance toured with Bagshaw's old-band
column11: occult-psych heavyweights Electric Wizard.)

column2: there's a crucial difference between Unearthly Trance and Serpentine Path: While the former band spiked its evil sludge with uptempo hardcore gallops
column3: dark-ambient atmospherics
column4: acoustic interludes
column5: and the occasional melodic bellow from Lipynsky on exemplary statements like 2008's Electrocution and 2010's V
column6: the latter favors a much narrower palette. Serpentine Path fixate on a single sonic idea
column7: a blend of doom- and death-metal practice (the early-90s-era NYC trio Winter
column8: re-formed as of 2011
column9: is one key forebearer) built around Bagshaw's towering slo-mo riffs
column10: Lipynsky's menacing growls
column11: and the odd creepy sample. The result is an admirably streamlined 43-minute LP-- superbly played and recorded-- that thrives on its own monomania.

column1: Opening track ""Arrows"" epitomizes the no-nonsense sturdiness of the Serpentine Path aesthetic. What's impressive here isn't the raw material; the opening sample
column2: a recitation from the Book of Revelation
column3: is straight out of the Ramesses playbook
column4: and Bagshaw's death-blues chug plays like extreme-doom 101. But the sophistication of the delivery-- the way the rhythms hypnotize even as they heave-- is anything but commonplace; it's clear that each musician present is an elite lifer
column5: sworn like a blood brother to the cause of slo-mo heaviness. Darren Verni is the MVP. Here and throughout the record
column6: his taut beats
column7: peppered with tasty snare syncopations
column8: lend an improbable sense of funk to Bagshaw's shaggy riffscapes. The sheer conviction of the performances
column9: coupled with Serpentine Path's beautifully natural-sounding production job
column10: makes ""Arrows"" feel like a new benchmark in its familiar style.

column1: For listeners accustomed to the wide array of vocal tactics Lipynsky favored with Unearthly Trance-- by the time of V
column2: he was complementing his signature raspy yell with wounded-sounding bellows and gothic moans-- his monochrome delivery on Serpentine Path might seem like a step backward. Yet given the cold intensity of the new project
column3: it's a shrewd choice. Relieved of all melodic duty
column4: Lipynsky approaches his role here as an MC might. On ""Crotalus Horridus Horridus""
column5: a portrait of a rattlesnake attack
column6: he slides in and out of step with the band's lumbering cadences
column7: accenting offbeats and punctuating the end of each verse with a nasty-sounding ""Blechhh!"" Similarly
column8: he marks the climax of ""Bats Amongst Heathens"" with a wretched throat noise
column9: more gargle than scream. Bagshaw too wrings maximum drama out of limited materials. Serpentine Path contains no trace of the eerie
column10: clean-toned moodsetting the guitarist employs on recent Ramesses records like last year's Possessed by the Rise of Magik
column11: but when Bagshaw does go for a flourish
column12: it counts: His howling harmonies on the intro to ""Obsoletion"" offer a hint of sky-kissing psychedelia amid the roiling doom magma.

column1: Modest variations in tempo and texture add intrigue to this staunchly unwavering set. ""Aphelion""-- the shortest and fastest track-- plays like a blast of rock'n'roll hedonism
column2: offsetting the bleak expanse that surrounds it; the song's stomping
column3: call-and-response chorus ought to make it a live favorite if Serpentine Path (<a href=""http://www.brooklynvegan.com/archives/2011/11/serpentine_path.html"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">""predominantly a recording project
column4: in the words of Newman) ever decides to take the stage. In contrast
column5: ""Beyond the Dawn of Time"" is as minimal as doom metal gets this side of early Sunn O))). The song consists of just four sinister chords
column6: which alternate with vast
column7: dizzying rests-- an apt evocation of the cosmic dread Lipynsky describes in the lyrics (""Shadow of eternity draping the earth/ A speck of dust in a desert of humanity""). ""Only a Monolith Remains""
column8: Serpentine Path's outstanding closer
column9: sums up the record's different strategies
column10: building from a zombified trudge to a writhing
column11: tripped-out shimmy before grinding back down to near stasis
column12: with Verni pounding out a death knell on what sounds like a blacksmith's anvil.

column2: Serpentine Path is an unapologetically straightforward statement
column3: one that's either going to sound awesomely monolithic or numbingly monotonous depending on the listener's appetite for extreme doom. But on its own terms
column4: the album is highly successful. Unearthly Trance were a band that always seemed intent on exploring new terrain; Serpentine Path
column5: on the other hand
column6: burrow deep into their chosen niche
column7: nourishing themseves on the soil and growing to hulking size. Lipynsky
column8: Bagshaw
column9: Newman
column10:
and Verni make their cramped hovel feel like a universe unto itself.

column9: heavily distorted mélange of black metal and harsh noise. It only gets worse

column3: even a 20-minute one. That first half proves the less successful
column4: though at the same time the opening three-song run may be the best thing Deacon's ever recorded. For all its jittery and hyper-percussive excess
column5: with cartoon-tribal drums the lead voice on ""Guilford Avenue Bridge"" (the breaks of which sound a little like Don Caballero playing a hoedown) and static all but drowning out Deacon's own voice on ""Lots"" (gleeful yelping in search of transcendence)
column6: this stuff flows
column7: which is increasingly one of Deacon's great virtues as an album programmer. If his earliest records could feel like various intensities slammed at you until you staggered away dizzy or elated or both
column8: he's grown much more assured at dynamics
column9: bringing you in and taking you along for the ride.

column1: And that opening run's got ""True Thrush"" stuck in the middle
column2: Deacon's most affecting song so far. Deacon's singing is clear and sad-eyed
column3: though he still can't resist digitally scrunching his voice into computer pixie noises at various points
column4: and he even throws in some angelic back-up harmonies
column5: which make an unselfconsciously beautiful counterpoint to the information-overload of the music. It's the middle of the album that fizzles slightly after the bracing crunch and buzz of the first three songs
column6: which bring new emotional dimensions to Deacon's music without totally skimping on the energy that was his earlier stuff's reason for being. ""Prettyboy"" is gorgeous
column7: undoubtedly
column8: but it's still on the level of really top-shelf video game music.

column1: It's the second half of America that promises and more or less delivers something great and new for Deacon. Where he really shoots off for parts unknown is on ""U.S.A.""
column2: the album's finale of four linked pieces. This is not the portrait of America you're probably expecting from the portentous
column3: inclusive sweep of the album's title
column4: one of those Wilson/Parks style attempts to thread many strands of American music
column5: from the conservatory to the vernacular
column6: into a cohesive pop whole. Instead it's more like a musical self-portrait
column7: albeit one on the scale of a Chuck Close painting. It's still recognizably Deacon's work; the ultra-bright buzzsaw textures would probably tip you off even if you were listening blind. It's just his biggest canvas yet.

column1: Way before Spiderman of the Rings hit in 2007
column2: Deacon undertook a half-crazed tour of the whole country via a commercial bus line
column3: just himself and his gear
column4: crisscrossing the Fifty Nifty. That's what I hear on ""U.S.A."": the sound of someone trying to recreate the awe of watching the vastness of the country unfold from the seat of a steadily moving vehicle. So the whole piece moves along to a steady motorik-style pulse
column5: even when the drums drop out. He tosses in some Copland/Ives strings as a kind of emotional thickening agent
column6: but the most prominent influence from the Serious Composers pantheon would be Terry Riley's all-night pieces
column7: where acid rock
column8: early synthesizer blare
column9: and orchestral minimalism fused into one hypnotic feeling of moving forward and standing in place at the same time. Deacon's still got too much pop and rock in him to go the full-on endlessly unfurling route. He's still got climaxes here
column10: in other words
column11: but at the same time the trip's as much about admiring the scenery as taking in the ""wow"" moments.

column2: at least during the second half
column3: is Arthur Russell's orchestral music. Reminds me in spirit
column4: of course
column5: hardly in sound. Because even when Russell was operating in Serious Composer mode himself
column6: there were often strong links to his idiosyncratic-unto-inscrutable takes on disco
column7: folk
column8: pop
column9: etc. But those pieces were still about immersion
column10: oblique narratives that build slowly from the tiniest details
column11: the evocation of distance via duration. So is America
column12: at least in that final stretch. This is still an album of big gestures and arresting noises
column13: but it's also a mistake to come to it expecting the fizzy thrills of Spiderman or even the dark communal playfulness of Bromst. Loosen up on your need for three or four minutes of bottled catharsis
column14: though
column15: and there are some gorgeous vistas to get lost in here
column16: even if
column17: yeah
column18:
that means meandering as much as charging forward with frontier spirit.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18283/homepage_large.00fd2943.jpg|Lo Fi High Fives... A Kind of Best Of...|2930.0|R. Stevie Moore|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['O Genesis']|2012-08-30 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:07:59.011127|"

A thread that ran through The Wire's recent cover feature on R. Stevie Moore highlighted how often the singer has battled against preconceptions formed about his music. The ""lo-fi"" tag is often attached
column2: even though many of his best recordings purposefully battle against the kind of tape-recorder grime the likes of Guided by Voices deliberately wield as an aesthetic tool. Moore also commented on how little he had in common with ""outsider artists"" with whom he is constantly bracketed
column3: giving a nod to the talents of Wesley Willis and Daniel Johnston while highlighting how his skills as an arranger put him in a different league. In fact
column4: as Wire writer Matthew Ingram asks: ""Why is he in the 'weird' camp at all?"" Part of the reason is the 400 or so albums he's released since the late 1960s
column5: coupled with the fact that he's still working at a prodigious rate despite turning 60 earlier this year. Anyone attempting to find an entry point into his work would be forgiven for feeling over-awed by the sheer breadth of it-- something this compilation seeks to address.

column1: Moore was born the son of famed Nashville musician Bob Moore
column2: who counted gigs as a sideman for Elvis Presley
column3: Jerry Lee Lewis
column4: Roy Orbison
column5: and Bob Dylan among his towering achievements. His uncle
column6: Harry Palmer
column7: is best known for discovering the ultimate outsider music act
column8: the Shaggs. It's difficult to sum up the work of a man with so many recordings to his name
column9: but somewhere between father and uncle lies Moore
column10: pulling in pure pop influences and rinsing them through his off-center take on the world. For a long time it looked like he would be perma-bracketed as a musician's musician
column11: the type of guy feted by other artists but barely known to the outside world. Ariel Pink has been Moore's most famous cheerleader
column12: but dig a little deeper and you'll find collaborations with Jad Fair
column13: Mike Watt
column14: and MGMT among others. Tim Burgess of the Charlatans
column15: another former collaborator
column16: has issued Lo Fi High Fives on his O Genesis label
column17: making it the latest in a string of compilations (including the Pink-curated Ariel Pink's Picks Vol. 1 from last year) that attempt to make sense of his greater body of work.

column2: of course
column3: this is a pebble skimming across the surface of that output. There are few signs of Moore's excursions into rap
column4: post-punk
column5: metal
column6: or techno. Instead
column7: the dial twitches between his knowing take on pop and his fondness for Ween-style prankster rock. Sometimes those two worlds collide
column8: most often when Moore draws his audience a little too close to anything that could be marked as ""sentiment."" On ""Find Any"" he sings of being ""sick of singing about girls because I can't find any."" But Moore tempers the feeling by turning the lyric into feeling ""sick of singing about cats because I can't find any
column9: complete with screeching ""miaow"" noises. Such lyrical rug-pulls are commonplace in Moore's songs
column10: and may partially explain the disconnect with a wider audience. Just when it feels like you can lean in to get close to him
column11: he's ready with the songwriting equivalent of one of those flowers that clowns use to squirt a jet of water into your eye.

column2: although much of his musical inspiration is drawn from a string of artists who are a lot more at ease with laying themselves bare. The influence of Brian Wilson and the Beatles figures prominently on Lo Fi High Fives. ""Here Comes the Summer Again"" is a note-perfect Beach Boys pastiche
column3: while the more impressive ""I Go Into Your Mind"" channels both ""In My Room""-style melancholy and the haunted Disney fantasias Mercury Rev were chasing circa Deserter's Songs. On the opening ""Pop Music""
column4: Moore wraps his singular commentary on pop around playing that combines shades of ""While My Guitar Gently Weeps"" with the pomp of ELO and subtle honky-tonk piano stabs. All of the above help back up Moore's claims for his skills as an arranger
column5: but it's when he steps away from self-consciously aping pop history that his work finds its unique depth. On ""Big Mistake"" he sounds genuinely lost and confused by the world
column6: digging hard into the feeling of being cut adrift from his peers and the public for so long. A yearning for wider acceptance creeps into his most impressive work
column7: a sense that he's drawing on the unusual energy created by releasing song after song into what must have seemed like a total void.

column1: But that's only a fraction of Moore's story
column2: as told by this album's diversions into power pop (""You and Me"")
column3: scruffy psychedelia (""Sentimental Ties"")
column4: and the hollowed-out Ariel Pink collaboration ""Dutch Me"". What's remarkable about Lo Fi High Fives is how instantly familiar much of this material feels. Partly that's due to Moore's ear for emulating the songwriting techniques of others
column5: but he has a way with song structure and melody that makes it feel like some of this stuff has been floating around in the ether forever. ""Why Should I Love You"" is so brilliantly simple and catchy that it has ""hit single"" written all over it (and
column6: indeed
column7: others have felt the same way). It's hard not to wonder what the cumulative affect this whole process had on Moore's psyche-- Pink wrote some pop gems early in his career (""Helen""
column8: ""Alisa""
column9: ""Every Night I Die at Miyagis"") but subsequently stumbled into success. Moore remains lodged in a gap somewhere between tiny personal victories and an utter failure to connect
column10: and it's in that tension that he produces his best work.

column1: Why are we so drawn to someone like Moore
column2: whose catalog is too vast for even the most ardent fan to fully grasp
column3: who seems intent on throwing myriad curveballs in our path just when we think we're getting to know him? The reason
column4: at least in part
column5: is that it's a disarmingly honest way to operate. Not everyone can go down the route of
column6: say
column7: Lou Barlow or Elliott Smith
column8: who were both capable of delving into an alarmingly personal train of thought every time they stepped up to a microphone. Moore has elements of that for sure
column9: but he's also unafraid of coming across as clumsy
column10: confused
column11: perhaps even a little shy. There's value in expressing the feeling that occurs when you pull back from the brink by telling a dumb joke just when you think you've said too much. And Moore has arguably said more than most. Tales of artists who never got their dues are legion
column12: but Lo Fi High Fives does enough to suggest that Moore deserves a place near the top of that particular pecking order. Thankfully
column13: he's still out there. A new album already tucked under his arm. A dreamer
column14:
still dreaming.

"|16959.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16959-lo-fi-hi-fives/|7.4|Nick Neyland

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18191/homepage_large.162a7831.jpg|Give Me My Flowers While I Can Still Smell Them|30603.0|Blu & Exile|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fat Beats']|2012-08-30 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:07:59.511088|"

Blu's No York! was one of the most slept-on rap records of last year
column2: a collection of songs so forward-thinking they helped listeners soothe the retromanic paranoia that abounded in 2011. Provided with difficult beats by a group of futuristic producers that included Flying Lotus
column3: Diaba$e
column4: and Daedelus
column5: Blu dissected the most complicated sounds
column6: seamlessly slicing through cuts on which most rappers would stumble to land a bar. It was an exciting
column7: esoteric collection. And
column8: for those of us who took Simon Reynolds' fear of future-past seriously
column9: it helped to remind us that there will always be something brand new coming around the corner.

column2: and if I weren't over my fear of NOTHING NEW HAPPENING IN MUSIC EVER AGAIN
column3: Blu's Give Me My Flowers While I Can Still Smell Them would be a cause for concern. The album was originally put out on bandcamp in December of last year and was marred
column4: as many of Blu's promising records are
column5: by a murk of fuzz and bad mixing so complete that it was basically unlistenable. Now it's back
column6: being released officially by Dirty Science and Fat Beats and while it's newly intelligible
column7: thanks to mastering and mixing
column8: the songs also sound a whole lot like five years ago.

column1: That's partly due to Blu's re-teaming with Exile
column2: who produced the entirety of his classic underground debut Below the Heavens. By reuniting with Exile (who we can thank for the mixing
column3: mastering
column4: and some scratching)
column5: Blu makes a return of the sound of his ground floor
column6: to the sweet
column7: contemplative organic soul that had fans embracing him before he started to get really and truly strange in all of the best ways. And though it's tough to criticize a rhymer as fluid as Blu
column8: I can't help but to be disappointed in a release that sounds so much like what came before.

column2: ""Maybe One Day""
column3: is an example of what's wrong. It's
column4: as always
column5: a showcase for immaculate rapping
column6: as Blu unwinds lines deftly
column7: internal rhymes building and switching on each other with extreme sophistication. But the message of the song is pedantic and reductive as Blu plays the scold
column8: ""I pity them fools
column9: zipping through the city in jewels…/ In it for the Benjamins too
column10: and so am I/ But why would I use it on fool's gold
column11: when you know your true soul shines."" This sentiment
column12: the kneejerk scorn for the heavy flaunting of wealth
column13: is straight out of the mid-naughts backpack rapper's cliché list of complaints. What's more
column14: Blu already flipped the idea on its head a year ago with the half-satirical track ""Everything OK""
column15: on which he both mocks materialism and wishes for more. And he did so over a crazy beat.

column1: Perhaps the most disappointing thing about Blu's step backwards is the way it jars against his newly evolved style. The contemplative beauty of Exile's beats fits Blu's soul-searching perfectly on Below the Heavens. But the rapper has become more versatile and more jagged
column2: stringing individually crafted phrases together so fast that their edges sometimes feel like they're cutting through the headphones. On the devout ""More Out of Life""
column3: what could be a wrathful rant against a squad following false fathers
column4: and looking to ""Malcoms
column5: Martins
column6: Pacs
column7: Chris Wallaces"" is dulled by the elegance of Exile's beat. Blu's anger tamed
column8: the song doesn't have the impact it should and he comes off like a jaded
column9: weary teacher
column10: rolling his eyes at pupils who refuse to absorb a lesson. He even gets lazy at the end
column11: just listing off the things we're dealing with
column12: ""censorship
column13: sponsorship
column14: friendships
column15: relationships
column16: slave ships
column17: minimum wages
column18: which is nearly as bad as moaning random words
column19: ""relations
column20: creation
column21: incarceration

column2: though
column3: there are always going to be songs that demand repeat listens.  One of the best on the album is ""Growing Pains""
column4: and it's here that Exile unleashes with something a little more dangerous
column5: a heavy beat with a steady melody for cruising downtown avenues. Blu comes through with a minute left and just goes
column6: torrents of syllables coming forward in service of rapid-fire storytelling about pursuing girls
column7: hanging out with his pops
column8: wanting a Casio and riding around in Cadillacs. On ""The Great Escape"" the rapper sounds rejuvenated by the presence of Adad and Homeboy Sandman
column9: the latter of whom is perhaps the only person in independent rap who can twist syllables with the same precision as Blu.

column2: on which the man himself relaxes and
column3: still rapping fast as hell
column4: relays explorations of his ancestors and past lives
column5: in between insights into his everyday life. It's his gift for these details
column6: for storytelling and poetry at Wachowski speed that makes Blu such a great rapper. But when you remove bullet time
column7: though he's still formidable
column8: Blu can't hold on to the kinetic excitement that animated No York!.

column1: I've always been conflicted about the critical instinct to ask our favorite artists for constant evolution
column2: and it seems particularly unfair to pull out one of Blu's three 2011 releases
column3: point to it as being representative of ""the future
column4: and beg for more. But Blu has a loyal legion of fans who will stick up for him
column5: and he could stand to be called out. Making albums like Give Me My Flowers While I Can Still Smell Them is child's play for two guys as talented as he and Exile are. And though this album is a beautiful
column6: well-executed listen
column7:
Blu will only really be fulfilling his potential when he starts looking toward the future again.
