column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18285/homepage_large.794bbd7d.jpg|Respect the Fly Shit|30412.0|Meyhem Lauren|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Greedhead / LRG']|2012-08-30 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:08:01.096362|"

These days
column2: people who think the state of ""New York hip-hop"" should be a pressing concern for all rap fans tend to be seen as joyless scolds or at least something pitiable along the lines of Civil War reenactors. I think they have an underrated sense of humor sometimes. Get past that story about the time they swear they saw Big L at the Pathmark
column3: and they'll likely wax nostalgic about guys like Drag-On
column4: Shabaam Sahdeeq
column5: or G. Dep-- benefactors of Big Apple abundance who
column6: seemingly by proximity
column7: came across enough hot beats
column8: killer guest verses
column9: or dope concepts to briefly separate you from $17.

column1: Meyhem Lauren's new mixtape Respect The Fly Shit comes at no cost
column2: but it feels like a kindred spirit: as evidenced by its production roster (most of the la musica is provided by Harry Fraud) and guest list (Action Bronson
column3: Heems
column4: Roc Marciano
column5: Sean Price)
column6: Lauren has some connection to a lot of what's exciting about New York right now. And Respect the Fly Shit is indeed a fairly enjoyable
column7: even quite good mixtape for reasons that have almost absolutely nothing to do with Meyhem Lauren.

column1: Lauren is hardly a bad rapper
column2: just one without much distinction. He pretty much has one kind of hammerhead flow and sounds winded whenever he has to spit at something quicker than a trudge. He also comes off less like an actual person than a search engine optimization program set to ""New York Rapper"". His first line is
column3: ""I ain't bringin' shit back
column4: New York we never left
column5: and within that same verse
column6: he drops phrases like ""hardbody
column7: ""hustle hard
column8: ""fuck hoes
column9: don't cuff 'em
column10: and ""invisibly shook."" He actually reminds me a bit of guys like Sheek Louch
column11: Uncle Murda
column12: or even 2 Chainz
column13: vets who seem more comfortable in the current hip-hop landscape where ""gangsta rappers"" aren't bionic ubermenschen
column14: but rather avid Twitter users and allowed to be goofy enough to appear in on their own joke. With every bullishly delivered threat and headslap of a punchline
column15: Lauren takes a crack at the fourth wall and leaves it open to interpretation as to whether you're supposed to be laughing at him or with him. It's about equal. You can practically see the cartoon lightbulb appearing over his Yankee fitted when he calls his producer ""Harry Embezzlement"" or describing his woman on ""Let's Hold Hands"" in the absolute least erotic terms possible: ""She was the color of an egg bagel/ You know that Simpson complexion/ Her smile caused an instant erection.""

column1: I suppose Lauren knows his strengths
column2: though. Respect the Fly Shit is a lean affair
column3: 12 tracks
column4: most of which clock in under three minutes
column5: and it's so chock-full of guest rappers that it can't help but be pretty damn good in spite of itself. Action Bronson's presence looms large over Respect the Fly Shit; he's on about half of it
column6: and most of the titles sound like they could've ended up on his mixtapes anyway (""Pan Seared Tilapia""
column7: ""BBQ Brisket""
column8: ""Grown Man Palettes""). If you have no stake whatsoever in Mayhem Lauren
column9: it's basically a Bronson EP. Still
column10: you see how easy it is for Bronson or just about anyone else here to outclass Lauren. His subject matter is no deeper than that of Lauren's -- quite literally
column11: dude's coming up with some of the hottest verses of 2012 just by talking about what he probably had for lunch-- but his  tremendous flair for outlandish boasts and tricky cadences (rhyming ""peel like an orange"" with ""leather outfit Martin Lawrence
column12: etc.) colors his personality from the outside in. Otherwise
column13: Smoke DZA
column14: Despot
column15: and Roc Marciano are in typically strong form
column16: Heems continues to evolve with flows that are simultaneously loopier and rawer
column17: RiFF RAFF crashes the party for reasons known only to RiFF RAFF
column18: and on ""Grown Man Palettes""
column19: Sean Price comes up with one of his best don't-give-a-fuck putdowns: ""Type to tote the glock and use gats/ You the type to vote Barack 'cause dude's black.""

column2: he gets to outshine some of his peers by default: AG Da Coroner is more or less a zombified take on Meyhem Lauren and quite possibly the most inept ad-libber going
column3: and whether you believe Hologram is raising the stakes or lowering the bar to an inexcusable degree
column4: I'll admit he's at the very least setting new standards for graphic blowjob jokes on ""Top of the World"". (I could tell you how and why he rhymes ""Hot Pocket"" with ""snot rocket
column5: but the tape is free; I'll leave it up to you.) Throughout
column6: the beats of Tommy Mas and Harry Fraud are perfectly suited for the roster involved-- they're plush
column7: but not expensive
column8: rugged but not necessarily raw and completely ignoring any sort of radio-rap currency without being stifling ""throwbacks.""

column1: It makes Respect the Fly Shit flow effortlessly
column2: though the consistency is more attributable to Lauren himself. You can mix and match any of his verses with these beats without doing much to change the character of any individual song. And that's the issue if you're looking to posit the relative success of Respect the Fly Shit as another win for ""New York hip-hop."" Lauren has a persona
column3: but not much personality as a rapper. As anyone who heard ""Bag of Money"" from Dr. Lecter knows
column4: Lauren is way funnier and personable ranting at the end of a track than he is putting rhymes together. Describing an in flagrante moment with a morally casual woman
column5: he stammers
column6: ""I was on the wall like I was punished… I had that face of gratification."" He explains the jarring shift of ""Let's Hold Hands"" by announcing
column7: ""We do love songs too
column8: man
column9: we love bitches
column10: and the Xs and Os at the end are
column11: ""I love you like I love my Polo leather."" He continues: ""You know how I love that butter soft (I love that jacket)."" That's some funny shit. All in all
column12: it explains why we're here in the first place and that's because Respect the Fly Shit at the very least proves that as long as Meyhem Lauren sounds like a cool guy to hang around with
column13: it can make you feel guilty about pointing out how little he brings to the party.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18154/homepage_large.77913297.jpg|Sagittarian Domain|73.0|Oren Ambarchi|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Editions Mego']|2012-08-30 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:08:01.644006|"

The best music doesn't always happen by design. There are innumerable stories of musicians stumbling across moments of inspiration while fooling around in the studio
column2: although usually these are happy accidents that merely serve to flesh out a much bigger picture. Australian musician Oren Ambarchi
column3: currently in the midst of an extremely productive run of albums
column4: simply let that kind of impulsive thinking dominate his entire work mode when putting together Sagittarian Domain. He admitted in a recent interview that he had ""no idea"" how the record was going to pan out when he went into Melbourne's Sing Sing studio to record it. At the center of Sagittarian Domain
column5: which consists of one 33-minute track
column6: is a gigantic standoff between restriction and freedom. Ambarchi had just one day in the studio to complete the project
column7: pushing a severe time limit up against his wide-open approach to recording.

column1: Fitting that distinction to his music and method
column2: essentially setting two opposing forces in motion
column3: is exactly the kind of counterintuitive approach that has served Ambarchi well over the years. At this point in his career
column4: the word ""drone"" is still commonly affixed as a descriptor to his art
column5: even though he's more than capable of turning any expectations foisted on him inside out. On Sagittarian Domain there's a great spring in his step
column6: a sense of playfulness
column7: a feeling of open-ended journey. Krautrock comes to mind
column8: just for the sheer driving repetition scooped into the heart of the track. But this isn't the taut playing of Neu! or the percussion-heavy raptures of Can. This is something altogether more baggy
column9: set in a place where the slackness at its core acts as a conduit for all the ideas siphoned into it. There's almost a jazzy tinge to the drumming
column10: like Klaus Dinger suddenly freed from all the no-fuss discipline he brought to his work.

column1: The centerpiece ""Knots"" from Audience of One found Ambarchi matching abstract bursts of noise with giddy strings
column2: a thread he partially picks up again here. Working with a three-piece string section-- violin
column3: viola
column4: and cello-- he allows the song to warp and crumple in unexpected ways
column5: pushing it toward bombast at times. Certainly there's a vast step-up in energy as he gradually affords his accompanying musicians space. By the time ""Sagittarian Domain"" passes the 20-minute mark
column6: we're in a different world from the low-key synth and guitar textures that abutted his circuitous playing in the first half of the song. The cello feels like a dark energy wrapping itself around the track
column7: set in stark simultaneous resistance to the violin pushing everything up toward the sky. It's that feeling of unlikely contiguous variants once again
column8: all feeding off an irregular force derived from Ambarchi's inclination for just trying out stuff to see where it leads him.

column2: then
column3: that Sagittarian Domain lands in a place at its end that couldn't possibly have been predicted from its beginning. Many artists who use repetition as a framework play the game of build and release
column4: stretching the loud-quiet-loud aesthetic across vast plains of land. Ambarchi does that to an extent here
column5: but he relinquishes hold at the end by sucking out most of his own playing and allowing the string section a full five minutes to stretch. If the main part of the song offers a chance to blank out the world by getting lost in pure rhythm
column6: here he gently bumps it back to reality
column7: a sad
column8: bruised
column9: lonely coda to a track that never felt like it was in the same orbit as that kind of feeling. Music often works well by building natural bridges between things-- a verse sliding into a chorus
column10: lyrics that equate sadness with melancholia
column11: bursts of guitar that make euphoria and aggression collide into one another-- but here Ambarchi shows how sharp about-turns and starkly dissimilar contrasts can be equally potent.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18270/homepage_large.5a488a12.jpg|Pink|1547.0|Four Tet|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Text']|2012-08-29 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:08:02.258355|"

In March of last year
column2: Four Tet's sole proprietor Kieran Hebden dusted off his Text Records imprint. Originally started in 2001
column3: it had only released eight titles over the course of a decade
column4: but 2011 would prove to be a busy year for Hebden. Rather than rest on the laurels and accolades for 2010's There Is Love in You
column5: he released his entry in the acclaimed Fabriclive series
column6: toured and DJed internationally
column7: and then jumpstarted Text with two plain sleeve 12""'s: ""Ego""/""Mirror"" was a Four Tet collaboration with dubstep demiurge Burial and some British bloke named Thom Yorke and ""Pinnacles""/""Ye Ye"" was a split single featuring Four Tet and Caribou's Dan Snaith (before he assumed his Daphni moniker).

column1: The former signified a decade's worth of British electronic music--running from Kid A through Four Tet and onto Burial-- while Four Tet's ""Pinnacles"" served a function similar to his 2008 EP Ringer. After the loft jazz-inspired Everything Ecstatic and a heady collaboration with noted jazz/soul/African/funk drummer Steve Reid that resulted in numerous drum-laptop improv albums and suggested that Hebden might never quite return to earth
column2: Ringer reminded fans that Hebden has always kept an ear to the dancefloor. But whereas that EP reveled in 4/4 minimal-yet-playful techno bangers
column3: ""Pinnacles"" was a decidedly more ambitious affair
column4: intermingling dubstep's wobble with an elegant McCoy Tyner-esque piano line
column5: Joe Meek guitar lick
column6: and some lasers. Perhaps spurred by the ""Thom Yorke Bump
column7: it triggered a year's worth of heady dance singles from Hebden
column8: spanning three 12""'s (with another credited to the moniker Percussions)
column9: all compiled now on Pink with an additional two unreleased tracks.

column1: ""Locked"" opens things and hearkens back to the Four Tet of old. A dusty
column2: crackling drum break that would make b-boys bob heads lopes around
column3: but it soon abuts another machine pulse
column4: suggesting an African polyrhythm about its downtempo pace. It's from this trickier rhythmic bed (with a substrata of bass frequencies) that Hebden builds up a wistful melody that evokes memories of his 2003 breakout album
column5: Rounds. The unreleased ""Lion"" follows
column6: suggesting both the earliest instances of late-80s tribal house as well as au courant UK bass music
column7: the primitive yips
column8: clipped kalimba line and speedy metabolism of the snare underpinned by a menacing drone.

column1: When the ""Jupiters"" single dropped earlier this year
column2: I was a tad underwhelmed as the overture-- while stately and lovely-- seemed to do little for the side. Yet it works better in the context of Pink
column3: providing a beatless interlude before dropping us into Four Tet's most bass-heavy and adventurous track to date
column4: nodding to Autechre at their crunchiest and 2-step at its twitchiest. It's followed by its standout flipside
column5: ""Ocoras""
column6: wherein Hebden takes what could be a skipping CD of organ music and some of Pantha du Prince's struck-bell tones and minces them finely before sprinkling atop some propulsive minimal techno.

column1: A skittering hi-hat rather than harps power ""128 Harps"" and again evokes the ""idyllictronica"" tag once affixed to Four Tet's particular strain of electronic music. ""Pyramid""
column2: originally the B-side for ""Locked""
column3: has a Model 500-worthy bassline and Hebden again deploys a voice (uttering ""I remember how you walked away"") in much the same manner as he did on ""Love Cry"". Those components alone would make this a standout track
column4: but he again pushes at such parameters and at around the four minute mark
column5: a shimmering metallophone melody worthy of Steve Reich arises and provides a break: not in the sense of unadorned drums building up tension for release
column6: but like a sun through clouds. And while Pink should not be conflated with a proper follow-up to There Is Love in You
column7: even as a singles comp it suggests that the undergrad producer circa Rounds is now post-doctorate
column8:
and Four Tet is capable of going deeper and expanding higher than almost anyone else out there.

"|17093.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17093-pink/|8.2|Andy Beta

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18094/homepage_large.d3b21253.jpg|Key to the Kuffs|30138.0|JJ DOOM|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Lex']|2012-08-29 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:08:02.930937|"

Here's a cruel twist of fate for you: A few years after catching hell for sending doppelgangers to take his place onstage as some weird conceptual fuck-around during a 2008 North American tour
column2: DOOM spent 2010 touring in Europe as the genuine article-- and then got stranded there
column3: reportedly on visa issues. Eventually
column4: he went from stranded to extradited
column5: left to make his home back in the London birthplace he hadn't lived in since he was a kid. Whether this is what really put a potential crimp in every possible latter-day planning-stages project from Madvillainy 2 to Swift and Changeable is up in the air
column6: it seems almost beside the point in this context: He's also been isolated from his family
column7: most of his friends
column8: and a significant amount of his own personal agency. It'd almost be a plot-thickening chapter in his outsized four-color supervillain persona if the real-world implications weren't so disheartening.

column1: But DOOM is nothing if not adaptable
column2: and his sense of humor is always present
column3: even when there's good reason to be disillusioned. So after tuning in to the liberating potential of his new homebase-- he recently told The Guardian that he's able to live freely ""incognito
column4: ironically more likely to be recognized with the mask than without-- he put together a fractured but widescreen picture of a cult icon in exile. Key to the Kuffs hits all of DOOM's angles
column5: from the well-documented (wise-ass shit-talker) to the underrated (political agitator) to the overlooked (sentimental romantic). And with the co-billed producer angle-- JJ being Jneiro Jarel
column6: the Danger to his Doom and the Mad to his Villain this time around-- there's the added potential to see this as another case of a collaboration providing a new facet to an already ambiguous public face.

column1: Key to the Kuffs has a persona that's a lot harder to pinpoint than Madvillainy's blunted Jack Kirby surrealism or the adult-cartoon goofiness of The Mouse and the Mask. Not that there's a shortage of either; here you get bloodshot pulp crime atmosphere and ""Regular Show"" clips rubbing elbows in the album's first five minutes. But aside from the loose DOOM-in-England motif
column2: there's not enough of an overarching theme that Jarel's serviceable-but-indistinct production can pull together. Not that cohesion's the most important thing to preserve-- it doesn't take a lot to ""get"" DOOM at this point
column3: and the blend of big-idea tracks about things like communicable diseases or Frankenfoods mixed in with rapping-for-its-own-sake is comfortably accessible without being all that bland. And there's precedent for Jarel and DOOM working well together-- Shape of Broad Minds' Craft of the Lost Art highlight ""Let's Go"" attests to that.

column1: Things have changed in the ensuing years
column2: though
column3: and Jarel's restless style has shifted from a psychedelic proto-Brainfeeder fellow traveler of Flying Lotus to something a bit more matter-of-fact on this record. For the majority of Key to the Kuffs
column4: or at least the majority that DOOM has a verse or two
column5: the beats glide along in an unobtrusive way that's more easily nodded at than nodded to. Some moments bump
column6: like the hissing new wave funk of ""Rhymin' Slang"" and ""Wash Your Hands"" or the xylophone boom-bap of ""Retarded Fren"". Others approach a subtly off-kilter weirdness
column7: like the bloated
column8: drunk-sounding tuba that serves as the bassline to ""Borin' Convo"". But they're usually the least attention-getting aspects of any given track and
column9: as typified by instrumental ""Viberian Sun II""
column10: not especially interesting isolated from vocals or sound clips. Even the two widely touted guest-spot moments feel low-key: Damon Albarn's presence on ""Bite the Thong"" is pared down to the point of almost sounding subliminal
column11: like a dub of a tunnel-bound cell phone call to an AM radio station 50 miles away
column12: while Beth Gibbons' appearance on ""GMO"" is too smothered in bass to register as much more than an unintelligible phantom melody. Khujo Goodie's 88-second Willie Isz reunion ""STILL KAPS"" leaves more of an impact.

column1: It's just as well that the beats don't overstep; every time DOOM's voice appears it takes over so authoritatively that
column2: sloppy or on-point
column3: the flow becomes more prominent than the beat he rides over. Sometimes it's borderline detrimental
column4: like the first few (well
column5: OK
column6: several) bars of his hobbled-sprint double-time turn on ""Banished"" that seem to scramble over the beat without entirely gaining his footing-- which almost works
column7: since the hyperventilating analog bass grumble is one of the few productions on the album that could be properly described as ""filthy."" And there are some signs of apparent rust or performances that sound like first takes-- he's so mush-mouthed on ""Guv'nor"" that a line where he says ""splurge"" sounds more like ""splshurghs""-- that threaten to sabotage the plainspoken-yet-crafty wordplay and abrupt turns into tight-packed internal rhymes that usually makes his voice so first-bar immediate.

column1: And yet he's no less quotable than he was in '99-- the same track that has him slurring the word ""splurge"" has him seamlessly integrating the 2010 Icelandic volcano eruption into a punchline
column2: for fuck's sake (""Catch a throatful from the fire vocal/ Ash and molten glass like Eyjafjallajökull""). He's still missile-silo deep with vocabulary
column3: and when his voice backs him up
column4: he's untouchable; there's a stretch in ""Rhymin' Slang""-- ""Rarely
column5: scarcely
column6: scary glaring stare/ Let's be very clear
column7: MCs is derriere/ As well as aware
column8: wearily
column9: just don't be nearly near
column10: you hear me? Yeah""-- that's tailor-made for dropped-jaw rewinds. The thematic tracks are heavy on the diabolical brainiac grifter guise that's fueled his post-KMD creativity for some 15 years
column11: balancing knowledge and absurdity like a master. ""GMO"" pulls out the bioengineering terminology
column12: wraps it in conspiracy-theory allusions
column13: and makes it both scatologically funny and unnerving all at once. And there's rarely been a hip-hop track like ""Wash Your Hands"" that's gotten more creative mileage out of how germ-filled the human body can be (""You like the way she shake her back area/ It's like a sex machine that make bacteria""). But the loose theme of DOOM's UK exile really hits in the homesick
column14: lovesick ""Winter Blues""
column15: one of the most heartfelt tracks of DOOM's career in a way that's funny and affecting; his line about how ""I need a handful of melanin/ Feelin' like the lamb's wool beard on your tender skin"" is disarmingly touching from a man usually considered to be an outsized cartoon alter-ego. He may have found a new creative space in his birthplace
column16:
but it'll be a relief when he finally gets back to a place he can call home.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18142/homepage_large.a1f76d35.jpg|Believe You Me|30493.0|OMBRE|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Asthmatic Kitty']|2012-08-29 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:08:03.665913|"

If there's a common thread running through the music of Asthmatic Kitty labelmates Helado Negro
column2: aka Roberto Lange
column3: and Julianna Barwick
column4: it's that both make records that sound like being alone in someone else's head. You could say this
column5: of course
column6: about a lot music and plenty of solo records in particular
column7: but there's a certain embrace of tranquility
column8: diffuseness
column9: and acceptance of solitude that links their sensibilities. The nocturnal
column10: Latin-tinged loops of Helado Negro's 2011 album Canta Lechuza (translation: owl singing)
column11: were pleasantly insomniac
column12: like what you'd listen to after everyone else in the house has gone to sleep
column13: knowing that's when your best ideas come. Same goes for the layered
column14: wordless vocal wisps out of which Barwick composed the songs on her best and most recent LP
column15: 2011's The Magic Place. Hovering somewhere between pop melodicism and ambient abstraction
column16: Helado Negro and Barwick's music reimagines solitude not as a form of loneliness
column17: but instead as something productive
column18: joyful
column19: quietly beatific.

column1: So what happens when two happy-go-lucky loners work together? We got an inkling of the answer late last year
column2: when Lange offered up his take on Barwick's ""Vow"" for her decent
column3: if superfluous
column4: Matrimony Remixes EP. Moreso than Diplo & Lunice's relatively boilerplate remix of the same track
column5: Lange's version kept something of Barwick's sensibility intact
column6: favoring cumulous atmosphere over groove. A product of nearly two years of casually jamming together in his Brooklyn studio
column7: Believe You Me
column8: Lange and Barwick's debut record together as OMBRE
column9: lives up to the promise of this remix
column10: and in some cases even improves upon it.

column2: Believe You Me sounds
column3: ostensibly
column4: more like a Helado Negro record than one of her solo efforts: Lange's casually strummed upstrokes and thick
column5: relaxed croon will sound familiar to any ears acquainted with Canta Lechuza. But closer listens reveal Barwick's contributions-- and her ameliorating affects on Lange's approach. Lechuza's fascination with blips and glitches was
column6: occasionally
column7: its downfall; Lange couldn't always work in his electro-tendencies without interrupting or detracting from the tracks' atmosphere. The addition of Barwick here actually subtracts elements from his sound
column8: often to great effect. Her weightless backing vocals steer the zero-gravity Tropicália of ""Noche Brilla Pts. 1 and 2""
column9: and add a celestial gloss to the loungey and gorgeous ""Weight Those Words""
column10: which should be played on a loop in every hotel bar in heaven.

column2: Barwick says the name ""ombre"" came
column3: simply
column4: from some chance encounters with the word and a penchant for the way it sounds. But the word's meaning (think color gradient fabrics) fits the project-- and its occasional shortcomings as well. Though their sensibilities have a lot in common
column5: certain particulars of Barwick and Lange's sounds are so different that the project sometimes feels like it lacks an overall cohesion. The Latin influence
column6: for example
column7: drops out in the second half
column8: and after a few tracks on which Barwick's featherlight
column9: wordless vocals take the lead
column10: the complete disappearance of Lange's voice feels odd. Still
column11: in its more blissful and transcendent moments (like the single ""Cara Falsa"")
column12: all earthly quibbles feel beside the point. Going back to the image conjured by the name ""ombre""
column13: seamless cohesion-- or a blending of two colors into one completely new hue--doesn't seem to be the pair's goal. Instead
column14: Believe You Me comes off as a collaboration between two dyed-in-the-wool daydreamers
column15:
finding both harmony and intriguing incongruity in their respective visions.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18097/homepage_large.3b9fa8c5.jpg|Positive Force|30193.0|Delicate Steve|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Luaka Bop']|2012-08-29 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:08:04.328846|"

Cartoons and kids' films always promised that behind the walls
column2: under the floorboards
column3: beneath a city
column4: exist perfect miniature worlds more wonderful than our own. To promote his new record
column5: Delicate Steve-- aka 25-year old guitarist Steve Marion-- hid play-buttons around Brooklyn and Manhattan for people to plug their headphones into and hear Positive Force ahead of release; hook up to one at Valentino Pier to hear Steve's chandelier psychedelia
column6: and you might believe you'd just jacked into the heart of a secret world powered by raw joy. Though Marion's real-life existence seems equally paradisiacal: He hails from New Jersey
column7: where he's part of the Smallboypants collective
column8: most of whom play in his live band. He's signed to David Byrne's Luaka Bop label
column9: spends his time taking 100-mile bike rides
column10: playing basketball
column11: or hanging out with his sonic brothers in Fang Island-- who
column12: it transpires
column13: run ""a cheese van"" in New York
column14: and named their truffle oil-infused grilled sandwich after him: Anyone for the $10 ""Delicate Cheese""? Positive Force sounds a little like what might happen if you sent Fang Island's hyperactive music on an Eastern detox retreat-- though letting them hang onto the cheese's sentiment
column15: if not its harder to digest aspects.

column2: Yeasayer's Anand Wilder said that Delicate Steve's music-- they're old touring buddies-- had made him excited about the guitar again
column3: and it's a shame that he didn't incorporate more of Steve's vivid
column4: lively playing into the limp Fragrant World. Marion is one of those rare guitarists whose instrument sings in the place of vocals: Positive Force is predominantly instrumental
column5: but you'll hear him take a breath at the very beginning to introduce his second voice. The combination of mic-ing up his Telecaster's strings and an amp
column6: then blending the two together
column7: sounds crystalline and futuristic
column8: gently boisterous and squirty. His guitar sings like George Harrison's guitar reanimated
column9: Dustin Wong's post-Ponytail solo releases
column10: the most melodic moments from Swing Lo Magellan
column11: and the effects on Julia Holter's marvelous collaboration with Jib Kidder from earlier this year. It often wheezes like old fairground organs
column12: and beams with an open-heartedness you'll recognize from the 80s sitcom theme tunes that instantly tell you happiness is on the way
column13: like ""Charles in Charge"" and ""It's Your Move"".

column2: but never predictably
column3: with more attention paid to their structure than on Marion's first LP
column4: Wondervisions. The cooing ""Two Lovers"" trickles like two tributaries
column5: one shallow and one deep
column6: flowing against each other before achieving confluence in a babbling whirlpool. The conversation between the blooming bass and sleek vocalizing on ""Big Time Receiver"" seems like the responsible voices of parents idly keeping an eye on the miniature
column7: skittering ticks and itches dancing around them. Standout track ""Wally Wilder"" is the theme to Midnight Cowboy by way of Animal Collective
column8: harking back to the early-1970s trend for harmonica melodies to replace vocals
column9: the perfect example of which would be the wondrous ""Groovin' With Mr. Bloe"". The sound of birdsong and the feel of a balmy
column10: sun-dappled garden glows throughout.

column2: it's that it's better suited as background music than bearing up to intense listening; while the guitar lines on most of the songs here are deliciously difficult to whistle
column3: they're all essentially fairly similar. And only ""Redeemer"" and the title track manage to reiterate the terrifically strong opening salvo of ""Ramona Reborn"" and ""Wally Wilder"". But for a strong run at a rapidly forming philosophy of positive vibes and inspiringly innovative playing
column4:
it's hard to want to pick holes in a record that more than lives up to its title.

"|16919.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16919-positive-force/|7.6|Laura Snapes

column3: mid-1990s career
column4: Miami noise killers Harry Pussy played most often as a trio
column5: with five musicians involved at various points. But their core was always the founding duo of guitarist Bill Orcutt and drummer/singer Adris Hoyos. The former's unmistakable car-crash sound and the latter's primal beats and soul-stiffening screams defined the group's destructive aesthetic
column6: leading Douglas Wolk to brand them ""just about the most abrasive band America has ever seen.""

column2: it's slightly misleading. Because while Harry Pussy could over-stuff speakers with bracing din
column3: they also injected space and structure into their racket. At times they sounded more like a punk-damaged free jazz group than an abstract noise machine. That's especially true of early duo recordings by Orcutt and Hoyos
column4: where the pair's intuitive interplay is clearest. When Orcutt pinches out piercing notes and Hoyos responds with snare slaps that propel him into clanging chords
column5: the result is more conversation than confrontation.

column1: Orcutt used only duo material to create One Plus One
column2: combing through over 10 hours of Walkman-recorded sessions. Along the way he grabbed some pieces that had already appeared without titles on early 7""s
column3: but he edited them anew and gave them all names. That may seem purposefully confusing
column4: but Orcutt's intent was actually genuine. He approached One Plus One as a new release rather than a reissue
column5: selecting the best
column6: most complementary material regardless of whether it had been heard before.

column2: because One Plus One is better-paced and more coherent than anything released while Harry Pussy were still together. It still has tons of clamor and dissonance
column3: and even the most welcoming songs challenge ears. But the album flows with a distinct internal logic
column4: as Orcutt and Hoyos revisit sounds
column5: work out ideas
column6: and explore what happens when they use the same moves in different contexts. So when Orcutt repeats a vibrating riff in ""Forming""
column7: it resembles a fractured Link Wray outtake; when he stretches a similar chord into a stoned drag during ""On the Couch""
column8: it evokes the Dead C applying their patented lurch to ""Forming"".

column1: Orcutt's sequencing also reveals Harry Pussy as much more than a single-gear noise band. As One Plus One winds its way forward
column2: serious drama mixes with absurd humor
column3: urgent chaos balances joyful abandon
column4: and loose asides lead to intense precision. It all culminates in ""Vigilance""
column5: originally released as a repetitive collage on a 1992 Chocolate Monk cassette. Here
column6: we get the raw source material-- a surprisingly consistent jam that suggests what Jimi Hendrix might've done if his version of ""The Star Spangled Banner"" had guided the rest of his career. Perhaps fittingly for a band that inverted rock norms
column7: such consistency means that the first Harry Pussy record that works as a conventional album happens to be a posthumous one.

column1: The Orcutt/Hoyos duo was also responsible for a previous posthumous release
column2: <i>Let's Build a Pussy
column3: which emerged in a tiny edition not long after the band's 1997 demise. As with One Plus One
column4: Orcutt provides the guiding hand here
column5: but in a much odder way. He isolates a single second of Hoyos' singing from the song ""Ice Cream Man""
column6: then stretches it into an hour-plus of abstract sound interrupted only by the ends of four vinyl sides. (Orcutt is credited with ""Mouse
column7: i.e.
column8: the computer kind
column9: while Hoyos' contribution is listed as ""Mouth."")

column1: The resulting drone holds some fascinating textures and microscopic shifts
column2: but whether you find it worthwhile music or a conceptual curiosity will likely correspond to your opinion of Lou Reed's similarly theoretical Metal Machine Music (as Alan Licht's liner notes point out
column3: all the sides of Let's Build a Pussy are intentionally the same length as the sides of Reed's infamous double LP).

column2: there's enough going on inside Let's Build a Pussy to make it a solid drone album worthy of Mego's stamp of reissue approval. But One Plus One is much more exciting
column3: and a better reminder of how vital this unique band continues to be 15 years after it broke up. Add in Orcutt's recent adventures into acoustic guitar clatter
column4: and sometime-guitarist Mark Feehan's solid solo debut
column5:
and lately it feels like Harry Pussy never left.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18146/homepage_large.90953040.jpg|Nocturne|28353.0|Wild Nothing|['Rock']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Captured Tracks']|2012-08-28 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:08:05.725209|"

""You want to know me? Well
column2: what's to know?"" asks Jack Tatum on the title track of Wild Nothing's Nocturne. The album's subtly addictive nature is such that only after a dozen listens did this anti-revelation strike me as its most revealing lyric. Tatum really does view himself as a facilitator. He drove that point home during our interview last month
column3: debunking any attempts made in the past two years to classify him as a ""personality."" This seems self-defeating for a guy who works in a style of lovelorn
column4: Anglophilic indie rock that never goes in style because it never really goes out of style
column5: and tends to favor extreme recluses or extroverts for its breakout artists. Fortunately
column6: Nocturne distinguishes itself from the perrennial crowd of dream-pop nostalgists for the same reason Wild Nothing's 2010 debut Gemini did: Tatum is simply one of the best songwriters in this field
column7: and Nocturne's significant upgrade in fidelity makes that point more clearly than ever.

column1: Whether it's better than Gemini or its EP follow-up
column2: Golden Haze
column3: only matters in the event you have room for just one Wild Nothing album in your life
column4: and you probably shouldn't limit yourself. It's hard to imagine anyone who dug Gemini jumping ship here-- Nocturne is a richer
column5: comparatively luxurious listening experience
column6: but it doesn't sound flashy or ostentatious. Even while recording with one of Brooklyn's classiest sonic interior decorators in Nicolas Vernhes
column7: Tatum granted himself only basic amenities-- live strings
column8: a human drummer
column9: better microphones.

column1: Nocturne is painted with the same colors as Gemini
column2: but the resolution is much higher. When the songs on Gemini wanted to convey vitality or physicality
column3: they were charmingly ramshackle
column4: stuffed with busy drum machines and insistently strummed guitar. If Nocturne wants for anything
column5: it's the sense of immediacy that marked highlights such as ""Chinatown"" and ""Summer Holiday"". This record is more about craftsmanship. Lead singles ""Shadow"" and ""Paradise"" feel newly urgent in a holistic way
column6: going places Tatum couldn't access in his Blacksburg dorm room two years ago. ""Shadow"" allows itself brief asides between verses to let those lustrous strings moan and swoon
column7: ""Paradise"" interrupts its glistening downer-disco for an indulgent ambient build-up. The full-bodied sound means the softer side of Nocturne gets fleshier too. Gemini relied on reverb to convey texture and depth
column8: and while there's still plenty on ""Through the Grass""
column9: the rhythmic complexity of the song's delicate
column10: interwoven arrangement plays a bigger role in making it one of the loveliest thing to be done with guitars this year.

column1: Entire labels and local scenes are dedicated to preserving the era Nocturne evokes-- lacquering the malaised vocals
column2: getting the right reverb plates
column3: and hoping that aesthetic identification is more important than writing melodies that stick. Tatum
column4: however
column5: is a songwriter first who just happens to work in this medium. His vocals are put to the forefront to give the listener a clearly marked place to return
column6: and his melodies are smoothly curved
column7: like a small divot at which the rest of the arrangements can dig deeper. The hopscotch verse melody of ""Shadow"" works in tandem with an insistent
column8: four-note motif doubled on lead guitar and violin. On ""Counting Days""
column9: a simonized harmony serves as the chorus
column10: but the little guitar countermelody that darts around it is the hook. Tatum understands the semantics of this stuff.

column1: Which makes it strange that his ambitions as a melodic tunesmith aren't matched by his lyrics. Successfully writing like Robert Smith can be just as tricky as doing a decent Morrissey
column2: which becomes clear every time Nocturne crosses an invisible line where a tiny bit of editing would pay off: ""Paradise"" contains the sensible-sounding
column3: yet bafflingly mixed metaphor ""velvet tongue so sweet""
column4: while ""Only Heather"" rhymes first and asks questions later: ""I couldn't explain it/ I won't even try/ She is so lovely she makes me feel high.""

column1: Or maybe that's the only kind of lyric that really matters on Nocturne. If there's a Heather in your life
column2: that song might be the centerpiece of your next mix. Or you might just listen to it hoping you'll meet a Heather
column3: in which case
column4: Wild Nothing is invested in the concept of wish fulfillment. This is called dream-pop for a reason
column5: and there's no logic for what drives adults to lie out on the grass staring at the sun for hours or write songs about girls with fantastical names like ""Rheya"". Nocturne gives a voice to those feelings
column6: and damn if it isn't lovely to listen to.

Matthew Dear is an illusionist. Each successive release under the Detroit producer's own name has seen him reveal more of himself as he simultaneously retreats deeper into the shadows. As his singing voice continues to take a front-and-center position in his slithery electronic pop productions
column3: it's also acquired a dark and oily air of decadence. Beams
column4: his fifth solo full-length under his own name
column5: is said by its maker to be more ""positive"" in disposition than 2010's high-water mark Black City. But don't be fooled. ""I laughed when they hit you with their sticks/ You cried
column6: goes one refrain.

column1: So the sinister hedonism continues. And while there's nothing quite as tongue-in-ear lascivious as Black City's Reznor-ian ""You Put a Smell on Me""
column2: Beams' constant neon-gray chug brings to mind a party that never ends. Synths peer through the chemical murk
column3: occasionally breaking through before getting swallowed up by clouds of grime. Basslines wobble with sickness. The song in which Dear sums up the whole vibe-- ""Take a trip on something else""-- is called ""Fighting Is Futile""
column4: and the title defines Beams' album-length experience: Dramamine be damned
column5: it's tough to pull your way out of this thing.

column1: There's been no reason to assume that Matthew Dear lives this hedonistic shit for real
column2: but Beams feels more personal. The first-person pronoun is all over these 11 tracks. Dear wasn't always comfortable being so bold
column3: either vocally and in terms of accessible songwriting. His 2003 debut
column4: Leave Luck to Heaven
column5: and the following year's Backstroke saw his voice gasping in bursts under the abstract
column6: janky techno soundscapes that are associated with his track-oriented work as Audion. The side of Dear that most are familiar with today emerged on 2007's enjoyable Asa Breed
column7: a watershed that lacked cohesion but made up for its disjointed faults by virtue of sheer pop playfulness. Black City brought all these elements together
column8: but Beams actually one-ups its predecessor in terms of cohesion. The album is Dear's most consistent work yet
column9: operating as one upward build that
column10: save for the leaden ""Shake Me"" (which feels out of place even without knowing its status as a repurposed demo that dates back to 2003)
column11: moves in the same direction until its conclusion.

column1: But consistency is a tricky thing. There are a few impressive
column2: memorable highlights here-- the steam-column elation of album opener ""Her Fantasy""
column3: the radiant confusion of ""Ahead of Myself"". But as a front-to-back experience
column4: the album doesn't exactly stay with you. In one sense
column5: it feels like a victory lap
column6: extending some of the best ideas from his strong recent run without improving on any of them. Next year marks a decade since Matthew Dear started releasing music under his own name. And given that almost every release since then has seen him pushing his close-quarters aesthetic further into new territory
column7:
Beams' relative stasis is excusable.

Don't be surprised if

column11: and then
column12: after a 16-minute closer that might be Krallice's most demanding and glorious piece of music yet

column2: when it's come to bending black metal

column10: a bassist (Nicholas McMaster)
column11: a drummer (Lev Weinstein)
column12: and two vocalists (Barr and McMaster) who approach their screams with equal gusto but very different tones. What separates Krallice
column13: though
column14: is their audacity and exactitude
column15: meaning that they generally not only trot past the 10-minute mark but also do so with songs where every bit seems rigorously composed

column1: They've never sounded as comprehensive and confident as they do on Years Past Matter. Album opener ""IIIIIII""
column2: for instance
column3: moves in fits and starts
column4: droning
column5: then roaring
column6: then washing out
column7: then galloping ahead-- all in about the first 80 seconds. The four members are synced so well and completely; McMaster's bass doesn't sit still waiting for the guitars or drums to chance
column8: and the guitars act more like complements than competitors. Listening to Years Past Matter is almost like listening to the Flaming Lips' Zaireeka
column9: where all four discs (or members
column10: as it were) are meant to be heard at once
column11: though it can be just as fascinating to try and isolate just one sound. If every band is supposed to write around its weakest link
column12: by this point
column13: it's probably best to quit calling Krallice a band. They show no such weakness.

column2: what might now be most impressive about Krallice is how selflessly the quartet seems to write and render these songs. If you're just glancing at the track lengths
column3: you might anticipate protratced solos or
column4: at the very least
column5: spotlights and showcases for Barr and Marston
column6: two of the best guitarists working right now. But even when they're furthest out in front-- as on the back half of ""IIIIIIIII""
column7: with their guitars in flinty dialogue and occasionally in dead-ahead harmony-- McMaster and Weinstein aren't sitting passively
column8: waiting for their turn to come. They push and pull at the rhythm
column9: as though to force the guitars one way or the other; in fact
column10: one of the best guitar passages here
column11: about seven minutes into ""IIIIIIIII""
column12: stems from the sort of roller coaster Weinstein and McMaster create and the way Barr and Marston are able to dip down with it and zip back toward the crest without distraction.

column1: All of those assets-- the complexity and precision
column2: the density and cooperation
column3: the rigor and the delivery-- coalesce perfectly during ""IIIIIIIIIIII""
column4: a 16-minute epic that finds Krallice pushing past the limitations of anything they've ever done. Aside from a short section near the beginning
column5: this closer is largely instrumental
column6: built on a short
column7: flicking riff that Marston and Barr stretch
column8: contract
column9: and subsequently spin into the strangest shapes. Led by Weinstein's versatility
column10: the song's pieces seem to form a cycle of interconnected circles
column11: where each section capitalizes on repetition and variation before shifting seamlessly into the next one. Krallice have never sounded so ecstatic before
column12: so perfectly delirious with the strength of their own designs. Like all of Years Past Matter
column13: its finale is great on first listen and increasingly tremendous on repeat. It's strange to admit it
column14: but when this 16-minute beast snaps shut
column15: I generally just play it again
column16:
giving the blur one more chance to blossom into clarity.

column2: comprising Bryan and Douglass Enas

Replace ""broccoli"" with ""Jesus"" and ""cheese"" with ""Mary Chain"" and you're getting close to the charmingly monomaniacal focus Stagnant Pools bring to their debut
column6: Temporary Room.

column4: ""Frozen""

it's not a sound or even a feeling that Temporary Room advances as much as a disposition that's encoded in the song with the most self-fulfilling title of all: ""Consistency"".

Swans are a band that conjure primal forms of power: thunder and lightning
column2: fire and brimstone
column3: master over slave
column4: predator over prey. Their earliest albums came out in the wake of New York's no wave scene
column5: a loose
column6: radical contest to see who could make rock'n'roll sound as ugly as possible while still retaining the rhythms and forms that made it rock'n'roll. Swans
column7: not central to the scene
column8: countered with the possibility of wiping out rock altogether. The result was something that sounds sort of like monks chanting in front of a jet engine. Frontman Michael Gira once compared being in the band to ""trudging up a sand hill wearing a hair shirt
column9: being sprayed with battery acid
column10: with a midget taunting you""-- a description that could just as easily describe listening to them.

column2: Swans went through a goth phase
column3: incorporating sparkly synths
column4: reverb
column5: acoustic guitars
column6: and other signposts of what most people would call ""music."" But whenever things felt too comfortable
column7: Gira would flatly drop lines like
column8: ""You never say you know me when I'm inside you
column9: or
column10: ""I'm so glad I'm better than you are."" Beauty and ugliness have never been as relevant to their music as the possibility of turning music into a space of confrontation. In the parlance of reality television
column11: Swans aren't-- and never have been-- here to make friends.

column1: After a nearly 15-year break during which Gira focused on the dark Americana project Angels of Light
column2: Swans reformed. Since then
column3: they've released two albums
column4: one studio (2010's My Father Will Guide Me Up a Rope to the Sky) and one live (2012's We Rose From Your Bed With the Sun in Our Head). ""[The reunion] is not repeating the past
column5: Gira said in 2010. He is currently 58 years old and often photographed in a cowboy hat
column6: not smiling. At two hours
column7: The Seer is among the group's longest studio albums and
column8: in a sweeping gesture that only the most confident and egocentric artists can pull off
column9: it manages to expand on their sound while simultaneously summarizing everything they've ever recorded before.

column1: The band's current palette includes a whole trunkload of acoustic instruments: bells
column2: accordion
column3: clarinet
column4: dulcimer
column5: a chorus of bagpipes
column6: and what's referred to cryptically as ""handmade violin thing."" With the exception of some amplifier distortion
column7: the album puts incredible emphasis on the human body's capacity to beat the shit out of an instrument in a far more satisfying way than machines ever could. (As an instructive gesture
column8: Gira spends the first four-and-a-half minutes of ""Mother of the World"" panting in rhythm.) Noise has never been as much of a concern in Swans' music as pure dissonance; of the way certain combinations of notes literally cause the air to vibrate more violently than others. At its most chaotic
column9: like the climax of ""The Seer""
column10: the band doesn't just sound aggressive
column11: it sounds like it's bursting apart.

column1: The tracks on The Seer aren't songs but incantations
column2: riffs piled on riffs shifting and evolving for as long as half an hour at a time. Sometimes Gira sings; often
column3: there's a zombie-like chorus behind him. One section fades into the next in ways more reminiscent of a soundtrack than an album
column4: and even relatively contained tracks like ""Lunacy"" start and end with winding
column5: immersive passages as the band comes to a boil. Like airplanes
column6: Swans take their taxiing and descent as seriously as their flight.

column2: the album draws a jagged line through a universe of serious
column3: apocalyptic music
column4: from country blues to free jazz to drone and the brutal
column5: hypnotic guitar rock Glenn Branca and Sonic Youth made while Gira was still moaning into the void. A big group of guests are important here. Former Swan Jarboe contributes
column6: as do Karen O
column7: and Ben Frost on my personal favorite credit
column8: ""fire sounds (acoustic and synthetic)."" The bigger the group
column9: the more familial the feeling and the more heightened the illusion is that the music is not coming from inside its players but existing
column10: like a spirit
column11: somewhere outside and between them.

column1: In the same way it would be hard to get the full experience of a good movie by only watching half of it
column2: The Seer demands its two hours. To paraphrase something the author Ben Marcus said in a trenchant conversation with Jonathan Franzen about the value of experimental fiction
column3: it is not a record for someone deciding whether or not they'd rather be listening to music or playing paintball. Of course this doesn't mean you need to peel off your own skin while listening to enjoy it. It has made my experience of cleaning the house
column4: for example
column5: feel very
column6: very consequential.

column2: they've been somehow tied to whatever ""dark"" genre was most culturally prominent
column3: but The Seer affirms what they really are and what their legacy will probably be: A psychedelic band that rejects the musical template of psychedelia the 60s gave us. Vision has always been a metaphor for both political counterculture and religious mysticism. Prophets
column4: pulling back the veil
column5: ""seeing through"" things in an interest of revealing what they believe to be the raw
column6: burning truth-- this is what Swans have always been about
column7: and what The Seer seems more explicitly occupied with than anything they've ever done before.

column1: Gira had come out of art school
column2: and even Swans' most mature sounding music is rooted in the kind of catharsis through self-negation that was at the conceptual heart of 70s performance and body art. One piece from his student days involved him being blindfolded and led naked into a roomful of strangers with a tape player strapped to his body
column3: playing a prerecorded confession of his sexual desires. The piece's coordinators had found women willing to do the same. The crux of the piece was Gira and the stranger crawling around in the room until they found each other
column4: at which point
column5: they'd have sex.

column2: the pain of catharsis is always in service of elevating to some higher plane of being. Granted
column3: most people probably prefer to find this in exercise and not public sex
column4: but when sifting through Swans' apparent bleakness
column5: it's important to recognize that their goals are and always have been to remind us of the ways extreme states of being
column6: however intense
column7: a unique kind of blessing. One of their live albums was called Feel Good Now

column9: Swans bluntly suggest
column10: you'll be dead.

column1: Is this music primal? Yes. Intense? Absurdly so. On ""A Piece of the Sky""
column2: Gira sings that ""the sun fucks the dawn."" Why the sun can't just come out normally is unclear. But there's still room for music like this
column3: music that claws its way unapologetically toward wherever it thinks answers might be hiding. After all
column4: without Icarus and his wings
column5: we might never know how high the sky went or how hot the sun got. For 30 years Swans have challenged the boundaries between beauty and ugliness
column6: music and noise
column7: catharsis and abuse. To borrow a verb from their own violent
column8: polarized world
column9:
The Seer is the album that transcends them.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18149/homepage_large.4c70f996.jpg|A Thing Called Divine Fits|30530.0|Divine Fits|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Merge']|2012-08-27 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:08:10.179317|"

column2: Britt Daniel attended a Handsome Furs show and struck up a conversation with the band's co-leader
column3: Dan Boeckner. He half-joked that the two should start their own band
column4: which shouldn't be surprising. If you squinted
column5: you'd swear that ""Modern World""
column6: most indie fans' first taste of Boeckner via Wolf Parade's 2005 debut
column7: could've been a Daniel performance. Five years later
column8: on ""Written in Reverse"" and ""Got Nuffin""
column9: Daniel tried on a ragged
column10: blues-derived yowl that seemed pulled straight from Boeckner's own boozy playbook. The comparisons go on: Both frontmen are masculine but not macho. Both can sell lyrics like
column11: ""When you believe
column12: they call it rock'n'roll
column13: and
column14: ""it was a torch driving the savages back to the trees
column15: with utter sincerity and no trace of cheese. When Boeckner found himself without a band after the Furs' 2011 dissolution
column16: it only seemed right to join forces. From March to May of this year
column17: the two decamped in a Los Angeles recording studio with New Bomb Turks drummer Sam Brown
column18: keyboardist Alex Fischel
column19: and producer Nick Launay to knock out A Thing Called Divine Fits.

column1: At a time when bedroom artists are free to release .zip archives of whatever was on their mind last week
column2: and inter-album dead zones are marked by interest-maintaining live ""sessions
column3: a project like Divine Fits might feel like a decadent 1970s version of that precarious line in rock lore between restless creativity and sheer indulgence. Though he's adamant to distance himself <a href=""http://www.spin.com/articles/divine-fits-chat-about-lame-supergroups-and-their-very-real-band"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">from the Paleolithic term ""supergroup
column4: for Daniel
column5: the project would seem to tip toward the indulgent. His primary band is not only commercially successful
column6: but it's been cruising at a creative peak without dipping for more than a decade now. His contributions to Fits testify to the fact that with Spoon
column7: he owns an indie rock lane so completely that anyone who even ventures over to the left side of the piano risks having to pay a royalty.

column1: None of Daniel's contributions are as risky or instant-classic sounding as the best Spoon songs
column2: but I'm not exactly complaining. B+ Britt Daniel is still really good. ""Flaggin a Ride"" (is there a more Classic Rock song title?) seems to be written about Daniel asking Boeckner to collaborate
column3: over a rhythm track that sounds like something he's been sitting on for years. On the co-penned ""What Gets You Alone""
column4: Daniel backs Boeckner's lyrics with a tune that merges the hard driving ""Jonathan Fisk"" with the acoustic shredder ""Sister Jack"". Daniel also provides the album's only cover
column5: a version of the Boys Next Door's goth classic ""Shivers""
column6: which he wears like a glove.

column2: however
column3: the stakes feel much higher. A career collaborator
column4: he's played the glammed-out hesher to Spencer Krug's yowling mystic in the permanently hiatused Wolf Parade
column5: and allowed Alexei Perry's art-damaged electronic wizardry to drive Handsome Furs into straight-up synth-pop territory by the time of that group's 2011 swan song. Whereas Spoon is the model of indie rock stability and consistency
column6: Boeckner's career has been rewarding in its unpredictability. He more than rises to the occasion. A Thing Called Divine Fits might seem the Platonic ideal of indie rock collaboration
column7: but the most memorable moments have Boeckner's signature.

column2: swaggering ""Baby Get Worse""
column3: the guy who penned ""This Heart's on Fire"" mixes artistic and romantic separation anxieties
column4: pleading
column5: ""my heart was beating in and out of time."" On the taut
column6: pulsating opener ""My Love is Real""
column7: Boeckner adopts Daniel's gift for space and concision
column8: while the song's refrain (""My love is real/ Until it stops"") manages to be both highly practical and vaguely threatening. Love dies
column9: but the question of who does the killing is left unanswered. The suicide of Russian futurist poet Vladimir Mayakovsky and Roman Polanski's dark relationship psychodrama Knife in the Water both make cameo appearances for good measure
column10: and the song's over in less than three minutes. On the other end of the spectrum
column11: the stripped-down sincerity of ""Civilian Stripes"" is an achingly pretty acoustic number detailing the quiet dignity of rejoining the straight world. Boeckner pins his heart on his sleeve while Daniel stays in the cut
column12: contributing only a minimalist piano bridge between the two verses. It's a perfectly sequenced quiet moment for the album
column13: and ranks among the quickly growing list of Boeckner's finest performances.

column2: A Thing Called Divine Fits can seem at first blush like a one-off vanity project
column3: two experienced mechanics building a hot rod in a garage over a few weekends
column4: or two NBA players meeting up for summer pickup ball. Daniel and Boeckner both claim it's an ongoing project
column5: however
column6: and rock fans should hope they stick to their promise. Like Mary Timony teaming up with two-thirds of Sleater-Kinney for Wild Flag
column7: it's a match too good to be true
column8: and-- particularly considering the sad state of Modern Rock in 2012-- far too promising to let die.

Beanie Sigel recorded This Time in a matter of weeks

column3: 2005's The B. Coming
column4: which he recorded in the time remaining before he served a year and a day for federal weapons charges. Things weren't exactly rosy for the Philly rapper back then
column5: but in the rearview they look like salad days: He was still affiliated with Roc-A-Fella
column6: still privy to a house-production roster that included Just Blaze. He hadn't yet lashed out at his former benefactor and label boss Jay-Z
column7: isolating himself with a series of diss tracks that sounded more like weepy drunk dials than insults. Few have fallen as hard or as far as Beanie.

column2: then
column3: This Time is poignant
column4: not least of all because Beanie still sounds like himself: one of the hardest-hitting
column5: soulful
column6: and eloquent rappers of the last 15 years. The production surrounding him on This Time isn't just cheap-sounding
column7: it's unimaginative
column8: rote and generic
column9: like Beanie prepared his verses ahead of time and then spent an afternoon matching them to random instrumentals sitting on his hard drive. He has always quoted Biggie liberally
column10: but some of these raps are more Biggie quote than Beanie verse. It's a rushed affair from start to finish
column11: and it mostly serves to demonstrate the degree to which this great rapper has isolated himself.

column2: his voice cuts through all of this static. Beanie raps with bruising force and sneakily creative cadences
column3: and his verses are things of beauty on paper as well. He writes with hard economy about his two great subjects: poverty and desperation
column4: pointing out to listeners the ""teddy bears where niggas got took out"" on his streets
column5: letting his gaze fall on the old heads ""sitting on crates
column6: taking 40s to the face."" He once memorably told listeners that he ""ate sleep for dinner"" most nights
column7: and he has always written about scarcity with the vividness of someone who recalls that hunger still: ""He can't hear what they teaching him in school
column8: 'cause his stomach too loud
column9: screaming
column10: 'I need food
column11: '"" he raps on ""Bang Bang Youth"".

column1: For a rapper who has always let us into his darkest
column2: innermost thoughts
column3: however
column4: from the harrowing scared-straight prison classic ""What Ya Life Like"" through ""Feel It in the Air""
column5: This Time is disappointingly skimpy on personal details. He briefly acknowledges the ups and downs of the last few years on the title track-- ""I went from caviar dreams to champagne sippin'/ Back to Four Lokos/ Four wings fried crispy""-- but apart from that
column6: This Time is full of bars that Beanie could have written at any point in the last two or 10 years. Beanie has always threatened your life with more loving detail than just about any other rapper
column7: and for connoisseurs of goonery
column8: there are memorable lines here
column9: like this helpful tutorial he provides on ""Bad Boy Mack"" on how to distinguish him from Craig Mack: ""He put flava in ya ear/ I put a laser to your head."" ""No Hook""
column10: which nicks its reflexive hook
column11: awkwardly
column12: from the Jay-Z song of the same name
column13: is first-class face-scrunch music. But to emerge from the hole his career has fallen into
column14:
Beanie needed to have dug deeper. This Time mostly serves as a reminder of why he's troubled more than why he's great.

The last time I thought about Nathan Fake was earlier this year
column2: courtesy of a vaguely unlikely prompt in the form of the Hot Chip single ""Flutes"". Although a typically direct pop song in the Hot Chip idiom on paper
column3: ""Flutes"" is a queasy and uneven thing on record
column4: a transformation achieved mainly thanks to its careful use of a sound that I had previously mentally filed under Fake's name in my head. That sound-- a gently keening psychedelic wail
column5: deployed via dial rather than sample trigger-- hallmarked the early Fake single ""The Sky Was Pink"" and instantly provided him with something not many electronic musicians ever get; an original claim in the ongoing electronic music sound patent wars.

column1: It's a natural tendency for listeners to reduce some electronic musicians to signature sounds or moments in our heads
column2: which is why
column3: even eight years after ""The Sky Was Pink""
column4: I wouldn't be at all surprised if that particular sound was still the first thing that came to mind for lots of people familiar with Fake's work. Following on 2006's effervescent Drowning in a Sea of Love and 2009's rougher-edged Hard Islands
column5: the newly released Steam Days probably won't do anything to change that
column6: nor will it do much to get Fake out of the (now ironically) decaying ghetto of bucolic
column7: pastoral electronic music that he helped re-colonize in the latter half of the last decade. But if the small refinements here are anything to go by
column8: it's hard to imagine that Fake cares much about any of that at all.

column1: If Drowning in a Sea of Love exhibited a pre-occupation with fizzy synth melodies and Hard Islands with naked
column2: almost brutal
column3: rhythms
column4: Steam Days is all about the synthesis of those two sides. With its glowing
column5: organ-led refrain and clattering percussions
column6: opener ""Paean"" establishes a marriage between melody and rhythm that more or less stays intact throughout. ""Old Light"" and ""Harnser"" offset coarse drum patterns with tasteful dollops of melody. Meanwhile
column7: with its psych-tinged synths and counterbalanced time signatures
column8: single ""Iceni Strings"" aims to strike the same notes of gut-wrenching unease as ""The Sky Was Pink""
column9: albeit in a slightly more muted fashion.

column1: This low-key approach runs throughout Steam Days and inadvertently adds up to make a comment on this particular genre of electronic music. In a context removed from any sort of cultural relevance or baggage
column2: you could reasonably argue that this is Fake's most well-rounded record to date; the bigger question is whether such small refinements to such an established
column3: well-trodden genre should merit attention from anyone other than diehards at this stage in the game. Never mind that a few of the track titles sounded like they were produced by a nostalgic IDM fake track name generator (""Sad Vember"" and ""Warble Epics""-- gah)
column4: it's telling that the two highlights here (the komische synth burner ""Rue"" and hip-hop inflected ""Neketona"") are the ones that most readily evoke the ghost of those longest of shadow-casters
column5:
Boards of Canada. Bottom line is that this is hugely referential music made for what feels like a dwindling subset of fans; I hope those guys still have some wistfulness in the tank.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18145/homepage_large.a9feed73.jpg|Poor Moon|30182.0|Poor Moon|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sub Pop']|2012-08-27 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:08:11.910488|"

Poor Moon carries much more weight than your typical indie rock debut. A ""supergroup"" only in the most local sense
column2: this Pacific Northwest quartet represents a who's who of acts regional and national: Singer/guitarist/primary songwriter Christian Wargo has played with Pedro the Lion and Danielson Famile
column3: Casey Wescott with Crystal Skulls
column4: and Ian Murray and Peter Murray with Seattle un-Googleables the Christmas Cards. But let's not bury the lede: The closest and weightiest association is with Fleet Foxes
column5: which claims both Wargo and Wescott as prominent members.

column1: It's inevitable that Poor Moon will be compared to Fleet Foxes
column2: which would be a daunting prospect for any band but especially for an offshoot. Their aesthetics and approaches are strikingly similar
column3: right down to the gentle reverb and some of the record-collection touchstones: Crosby Stills & Nash
column4: Judee Sill
column5: Buffy Sainte-Marie
column6: to name a few. Every song on Poor Moon turns on some sonic flourish or instrumental shift that occasionally comes across as showy but more often than not works well to give each song a distinctive identity
column7: whether it's the chimes and celeste on ""Bucky Pony"" or the whistled birdsong of the too-precious opener ""Clouds Below"". There are certainly moments that sound suspiciously familiar
column8: like the reverb-swaddled vocals on ""Holiday"" or the soft crash of drums and guitar on ""Same Way"". Poor Moon either shows how closely Wargo and Wescott hew to the Fleet Foxes approach or demonstrates how essential they are to that band's celebrated sound.

column2: Wargo
column3: however
column4: lacks the specificity of Robin Pecknold's outdoorsy self-reckoning
column5: which has lent Fleet Foxes' history-mining efforts a strong sense of purpose and poignancy. By contrast
column6: Poor Moon sound gauzier of mission
column7: as though re-creating certain pop-historical sounds was their endgame. Lyrically
column8: Wargo tends to get bogged down in barely told stories and overarching concepts
column9: like the overly familiar afterlife of ""Heaven's Door"". Musically it sounds like they're snoozing the Strawberry Alarm Clock
column10: but strangely there's no heft to the idea of paying ""for the sins that I love too much."" At least he sneaks in an offhand Grateful Dead reference when he admits
column11: ""Got the friend of the devil living in my soul.""

column1: Wargo's lyrics are fine but largely ignorable
column2: which may have less to do with the words themselves than with how they are delivered. He sounds like an adenoidal Art Garfunkel
column3: his voice high and clear and precise. That's not a slam or anything; Garfunkel was
column4: by nearly everybody's estimation
column5: a better singer than Simon. But there's not a lot of emotional range there
column6: no strain to accentuate a thought or a feeling
column7: just a drowsy introspection that runs the length of the album somewhat monotonously. In other words
column8: it's hard to view Poor Moon as anything but a side project-- not worthless
column9: but dramatically overshadowed. Lord knows there are tons of similar enterprises in rock history
column10: some crummy (Tin Machine
column11: SuperHeavy) and some rivaling their members' main outlets (the Postal Service
column12: the Dead Weather). At the moment
column13: Poor Moon lies somewhere in between those two poles.

column1: But there is promise here: This full-length reveals a unit much surer of purpose than we heard on Illusion
column2: the free EP the band released earlier this year. These songs are gutsier in their arrangements
column3: more surefooted in the songwriting
column4: and more certain of the band's identity. ""Waiting For"" may be the band's boldest and most heraldic chorus
column5: at once assertive and-- thanks to Wargo's delicate vocals-- retreating. At times there is an intriguing disconnect between the tone of the lyrics and the tone of the arrangements
column6: and that dissonance can be jarring
column7: even invigorating: ""I couldn't keep it silent
column8: I didn't know that sadness could be so violent
column9: Wargo sings on ""Pulling Me Down""
column10: but neither the music nor the melody sounds sad or violent. Rather than coming off as gutless
column11: that contrast bends the tune's exclamation point into a disquieting question mark.

column2: whose harmonies and chord progressions recall Foxes but whose momentum flutters off into the air. It's a rather abrupt and unceremonious conclusion that does little to suggest a shape or story in the album. Poor Moon turns out to be a wisp of a record
column3:
intentionally light and certainly promising but also oddly-- and perhaps ironically-- weightless.
