'Experimental']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['4AD']|2012-08-21 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:08:12.494161|"

Ariel Pink's music began its strange journey early in the last decade
column3: as a CD-R lying on the floor of Animal Collective's tour van. Before then
column4: he'd been heard by almost no one
column5: despite that he'd recorded hundreds of songs
column6: by himself
column7: in what sounded like a windowless dungeon. The quality of those early recordings was poor
column8: but something shone from the murk: Pink became the first artist signed to the band's Paw Tracks label
column9: which reissued his album The Doldrums in 2004. The path of his career since then has been wayward and strange
column10: culminating in the highly professional Before Today in 2010. But there are through-lines. Whether you tuned into his world during the Paw Tracks era or after Before Today's ""Round and Round"" became an indie anthem
column11: you probably sensed an intriguing off-note lurking in the L.A. home-recording savant's music.

column2: the boundless sunshine of 1970s AM pop grows queasy
column3: even malevolent
column4: splitting the difference between a grimace
column5: a smirk
column6: and a smile. Even at its loveliest
column7: his music radiates a mesmerizing sense of bad faith: Pink often incorporates humor into his songs
column8: but it's hard to be sure if you're in on the joke. He may express seemingly sincere sentiments in one moment while mocking them in the next. In his most compelling material
column9: these impulses curl around each other until his ""fuck you's"" sound like ""I love you""
column10: and vice versa.

column1: Before Today was Ariel Pink's breakout record
column2: a leap to a new stage from his cult beginnings that made his skill as a songwriter and craftsman clear. Free of the lo-fi grit that characterized his Paw Tracks material
column3: you could suddenly hear his uncanny knack for fusing together unlikely parts with no visible seams. Mature Themes
column4: Pink's grittier
column5: gristlier
column6: and funnier follow-up
column7: clarifies that Before Today was not a sign of things to come but rather just a signpost along his unknowable path. The production has hardened
column8: as if Pink has found a midpoint between the warped
column9: warbly sound of his tape releases and what he can now afford. The songs themselves
column10: while still catchy
column11: are often opaque
column12: antisocial
column13: and confounding. The mood of the record veers closer to the melted emotional nowhere of The Doldrums' ""Good Kids Make Bad Grown Ups"" or the arch piss-take of Worn Copy's ""Artifact"".

column2: some have pegged Mature Themes as an alienating move meant to prune Pink's flock back down to the diehards. But the album is too rich for that straightforward reading. Here
column3: even his puerile sentiments remain generously melodic and lovingly wrought. ""I'm not real and I won't call you
column4: he croons on the title track
column5: over a melody that climbs upward so gracefully it sounds like he's vandalizing a Shaker hymn. It might be one of the truest lines he's ever sung. But the Elvis Costello-like rising-action of the chorus
column6: which takes the phrase ""I wanted to be good"" up the scale
column7: is an expression of love
column8: pure and simple.

column1: ""Only in My Dreams"" is another example of his singular songwriting mind: Listen casually and it's a Byrdsian pop tune
column2: but sit down at a piano to map out it's details
column3: and you'll lean back
column4: baffled. If taken apart
column5: no one but Pink would be able to reassemble it. It's this talent that links Pink to past practicioners of outsider music-- R. Stevie Moore
column6: Frank Zappa
column7: Ween. Like those artists
column8: Pink looked at the puzzle pieces of a pop song and figured out jarring new ways they fit together
column9: mingling affection with ironic commentary and intellectual distance. ""Kinski Assassin"" opens with Pink singing nonsense in a stentorian voice not far from a 1930s radio drama: ""Suicide dumplings dropping testicle bombs."" Then
column10: he chimes in with something silky and romantic: ""We'll always have Paris."" The lyrics don't make any more sense together than the music behind them does
column11: but they glide smoothly into each other
column12: conveying a strong sense of internal coherence. It's the kind of bewitching almost-logic that drives people to endlessly re-watch David Lynch's Mulholland Drive or Inland Empire.

column1: But don't look to Pink's lyrics for clues
column2: because they offer few ways to emotionally engage. ""The bad breath of a cross-eyed goat/ Eating children for a Monday morning
column3: go the opening lines of ""Driftwood""
column4: intoned with the seriousness of a Druid. On ""Symphony of the Nymph""
column5: he speak-sings the song's title in an exaggerated scientist voice straight out of Thomas Dolby's catalogue over a backing track located somewhere between ""Monster Mash"" and ""Werewolf Bar Mitzvah"". On ""Farewell American Primitive""
column6: the sentiment that comes through most clearly is
column7: ""Fuck it."" It's moments like these that forcefully remind you: There's nothing operatic at stake in Pink's music. It's a Chinese finger trap.

column1: When The Village Voice interviewed Pink in 2010
column2: he suggested that he'd lost the ability to make music the way he did in his earlier
column3: more prolific days. But Mature Themes is as vital as anything he's ever recorded: Even the throwaway ""Schnitzel Boogie"" fails at being one-dimensional
column4: playing instead like something McCartney might have worked on for the fifth side of the White Album. This seesaw between sincerity and insincerity is the fuel that drives Pink's music. It's the riddle that creates his cult
column5: and it's the reason everyone will continue to pay attention to him
column6:
no matter how many faces he pulls.

"|16936.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16936-mature-themes/|8.5|Jayson Greene

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/18186/homepage_large.fbb63cd8.jpg|Life Is People|23481.0|Bill Fay|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Dead Oceans']|2012-08-21 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:08:13.039506|"

You don't need a history lesson to love Life Is People
column2: the third proper album by British singer-songwriter Bill Fay. If you've ever enjoyed the records of Pink Floyd or Randy Newman
column3: Spiritualized or Wilco
column4: the dozen gems here move between similar poles of spartan grace and outsized grandeur. The organ-abetted lilt of ""The Healing Day"" suggests Jeff Tweedy and Jay Bennett turning the page toward happiness a decade ago
column5: while the gospel choir delivering the mantra of ""Be at Peace with Yourself"" might make you scan the credits for a J. Spaceman acknowledgment. The flinty ""Empires"" is a piano-led political tune written from a distance and with a dark
column6: Newman-like wit
column7: where the world's biggest timbers eventually yield to the teeming underbrush beneath. Its warped tones and terse delivery suggest Roger Waters coming back to Earth. Beautiful
column8: patient and poignant
column9: Life Is People is an expert singer-songwriter album
column10: as dependent upon keen insight as it is upon meticulous arrangement.

column1: But a history lesson makes Life Is People that much more meaningful. Bill Fay is 69 years old
column2: and he hasn't released a proper studio album since his second
column3: 1971's brilliant and acerbic Time of the Last Persecution. He'd stumbled into a recording contract with the Decca Nova/Deram imprint. As he admitted to WFMU in an interview last year
column4: labels at that point scooped up an abundance of acts
column5: hoping that at least something would turn into a best seller. ""Somebody told me at the time
column6: he said
column7: ""that their policy was to throw as many pieces of mud as possible at the wall
column8: and hope that some would stick."" Fay's records didn't stick
column9: however
column10: and neither did he. Deram dropped Fay and
column11: in the 41 years since Persecution
column12: he's recorded new material and consistently written new songs but never finished a complete record. Music
column13: as he also told WFMU
column14: was a private family affair for him as a child
column15: with his aunts and uncles playing together and his mom occasionally sitting down at the family piano; he performed several times
column16: but largely it seemed that
column17: after stumbling toward fame through music
column18: he wanted to keep the stuff to himself.

column2: though. Based only on the strength of those first two records and reissues
column3: sporadic batches of leaked demos
column4: and a terribly teasing collection called <i>Tomorrow
column5: Tomorrow and Tomorrow
column6: issued 30 years after it was recorded
column7: Fay's cult standing grew. Wilco covered ""Be Not So Fearful""
column8: the gorgeous affirmation from his debut
column9: and convinced Fay to join them onstage in 2007 and later during a 2010 Tweedy solo set. Then
column10: last summer
column11: Fay returned to a London studio for the first time in three decades with American producer Joshua Henry
column12: a lifelong Fay fan who'd barely been alive for 30 years. With a band comprised of younger studio players and Ray Russell and Alan Rushton
column13: who'd joined Fay for Persecution so long ago
column14: they recorded the bulk of Life Is People in a little less than a month.

column2: back to the present: Life Is People doesn't feel at all like a late-life afterthought from a cult hero. Pointed and urgent but never pushy
column3: Fay's songs offer pleas for redemption in a world drunk on its promise
column4: coupled with a reassuring contentment for simply having lived this life. Fay chastises the way generations have refused to learn from their history
column5: even as we stare into devices that allegedly offer all the answers we'd ever need. On the other hand
column6: ""Be at Peace With Yourself"" extends existential reassurance-- that is
column7: as Fay offers behind a tabernacle-sized mix of organ and choir arrangements
column8: whoever you are is probably good enough. That's a thought echoed on ""The Healing Day""
column9: a tender Revelation hymn that depends upon the belief that some cosmic help is always on the horizon. ""Every battleground/ Is a place for sheep to graze
column10: Fay sings during one his most eloquent bits ever. ""When it all comes tumbling down/ All the palaces and parades.""

column2: ""The Never Ending Happening"" and ""This World""
column3: provide a crucial bridge between Fay's indignation and optimism. On the former
column4: Fay's voice hang's worn but resilient above a simple
column5: elliptical piano line; in these perfect four minutes
column6: he considers death
column7: God
column8: birth
column9: bird song
column10: and war cries as one continuum. He's happy to have been involved
column11: he admits
column12: to have his tiny narrative shape a much bigger story: ""Just to be part of it/ Is astonishing to me."" The record's pop standout
column13: ""This World"" springs from the somber end of ""The Never Ending Happening"" as if to offer the message that
column14: appreciative as he may be
column15: Fay isn't done quite yet. He and Wilco's Jeff Tweedy trade the verses and share the chorus

column17: Etc."" here

column2: a number of serpentine stories and bittersweet circumstances have revitalized the careers of musicians who
column3: for whatever reason

column5: soul singers like Bettye LaVette
column6: Solomon Burke
column7: and Charles Bradley found ways to turn long flirtations with fame (or abject failure) into real or revived careers with new records on indie imprints. Thanks to collaborations with young producer Kieran Hebden
column8: drummer Steve Reid finally became more than a footnote of rock and jazz history; when Bert Jansch linked with Drag City and Devendra Banhart
column9: the inspiration to Led Zeppelin and what had become New Weird America met a fresh generation of listeners. Life Is People and the tale that accompany it are strong enough to do the same for Fay

column14:
and the work of a lifetime—confirms its maker's own thesis.

Jerry DeCicca is a Midwestern songwriter the same way that Patterson Hood is a Southern songwriter or that Robin Pecknold is a Pacific Northwest songwriter. Ohio is in the Ohioan's blood
column2: so naturally it's also in his sharp
column3: understated lyrics: the culture
column4: the terrain
column5: the people
column6: the place of the place. Occasion For Song
column7: the latest full-length by his band the Black Swans
column8: is perhaps his most geographically defined album yet
column9: a long drive through the state's haunted sites. Over there's where a friend died. Years ago he buried his sister's pet crab near that tree. ""Played mailbox baseball three miles from here
column10: he sings on ""Where Are You Tonight?"" ""I never got caught but the guilt never disappeared."" His Ohio is a land of inescapable memories
column11: with a trigger for reminiscence-- some long-past occasion for song-- on every street corner. DeCicca is a careful
column12: precise songwriter
column13: but the songs don't necessarily sound written. Instead
column14: they seem like they occurred to him naturally and ineluctably.

column1: Perhaps the biggest trigger for him in the entire Buckeye State is a diving board and swimming pool in Portsmouth
column2: down on the Kentucky border. There are likely thousands of pools like it across the country
column3: but this one-- which appears on the cover of Occasion For Song-- is special: On a sunny day in the middle of summer 2008
column4: Black Swans violinist Noel Sayre jumped off that diving board and into that pool
column5: and somewhere along the way suffered a massive heart attack. He died a few days later. It's impossible to overstate the impact that occasion has had on the Black Swans' music since then
column6: but DeCicca addresses it directly for the first time on ""Portsmouth
column7: Ohio"".

column1: The song is not just a standout on the album
column2: but a standout for 2012. Absenting himself from the narrative in a way that prevents it from being mawkish or maudlin
column3: DeCicca adopts a third-person perspective as he relates not just the death but the full life of his friend: ""Nobody's supposed to die three days before the 4th of July
column4: especially while the sun's still in the sky
column5: he sings
column6: mustering the necessary stoicism to make it through the line. Even if you never met Sayre
column7: and for that matter even if you've never heard the Black Swans before
column8: it's hard not to be moved by this tune
column9: whose power derives from its measured storytelling and hushed tone.

column2: however
column3: is more about DeCicca than Sayre. It's more about living with death than about death
column4: although the Black Swans do pose some disquieting questions about mortality. There are dark threads stitching these songs together
column5: unapologetic admissions of extreme introversions
column6: alienation
column7: aimlessness
column8: resignation. On ""Basket of Light""
column9: he confesses
column10: ""I was hungry
column11: I was dry
column12: I walked a cliff called suicide."" And that's the leadoff track. The whole thing might be dour and morbid
column13: but DeCicca has lately been indulging his fascination with country music
column14: which has opened his songwriting up considerably over the past few years. It was perhaps most prominent on 2010's Don't Blame the Stars
column15: which had the giddy-up of prime Roger Miller. If that song had the jumpy feel of long days on the road
column16: Occasion For Song sounds like even longer days at home.

column1: DeCicca's veer toward country is aided by the Black Swans themselves
column2: who back him with subtlety and sympathy. Chris Forbes' electric guitar adds pointed commentary to ""Basket of Light"" and ""Portsmouth
column3: Ohio""
column4: while Jon Beard's organ adds an undercurrent of concern
column5: reinforcing the sad truth that time cannot be reversed and tragedy cannot be averted. If Occasion For Song is about rising out of a dark period in life
column6: the band makes it clear that music is the impetus for that hesitant recovery
column7: especially on ""Daily Affirmation""
column8: with its agile banjo solo and its bright energy to contrast with darker
column9: quieter songs. For all its grave intimations
column10: Occasion For Song exhibits a true joy in creating and playing music
column11: in finding the right notes and the right words. It's a complex
column12: even contradictory record
column13:
not just the Black Swans' best but one of the most incisive and moving mediations on life and the loss of it in recent memory.

Carol Kleyn got her start in the early 1970s
column2: playing Ren Fests and community fairs
column3: busking on street corners for loose change and whatever professional advancement she could muster. In 1976
column4: she had made enough to fund her debut album
column5: Love Has Made Me Stronger
column6: which was reissued on Drag City last year. By the time she got ready to record a follow-up at the tail end of the decade
column7: she said
column8: ""I'd developed a following at the faires and on the street corners
column9: and felt like I'd actually earned the title: Harpist/Singer/Songwriter."" That's her writing in the liner notes for the reissue of her second album
column10: 1980's Takin' the Time. It's a telling statement
column11: not only because this humble
column12: self-taught musician asserts her identity so forcefully
column13: but primarily because it reveals exactly how she thought of herself. She was first and foremost a harpist
column14: a vocalist second
column15: and lastly a songwriter.

column1: Both of these reissues bear out that impression and especially that order
column2: which is not to say that Kleyn was a deficient singer or songwriter. It's just that the harp dominates
column3: as much by its size as by its sound. Kleyn toted the thing everywhere
column4: and the sight of the diminutive
column5: sunny-faced California blonde hauling such an instrument
column6: her dog trustily at her feet
column7: must have left a visual impression on passers-by as strong as the music she played. How odd
column8: then
column9: that Takin' the Time begins not with the sounds of her folksy plucking and strumming
column10: but with the rambling riff of a full band. Produced by her former romantic and musical partner Bobby Brown (whose Enlightening Beam of Axonda ought to be next on Drag City's reissue schedule)
column11: Takin' the Time places Kleyn in a variety of settings
column12: and the most disarming is at the front of an electrified rock group.

column1: It's not necessarily a bad sound for her
column2: although her voice does get lost in the relative squall of ""Jethro"". But the band sounds a bit prim
column3: as though hesitant to cut loose with such a delicate voice at the fore. And still
column4: Kleyn manages to make the title track sound sweetly pastoral
column5: as she sings about the small pleasures of domestic life as she lived it: ""Making love in a yellow school bus/ Tall eucalyptus around us."" Even when she deals in hippie ephemera-- one song involves a unicorn
column6: another invokes ""the song of the harp""-- Kleyn can be a disarmingly descriptive lyricist
column7: evoking the world around her in softly concrete imagery.

column2: which
column3: especially on the second side
column4: creates an intimate space for Kleyn. She's accompanied solely by what sounds like a thumb piano on ""How Long Till Forever""
column5: and a flock of sympathetic seagulls joins in on ""Prayer"". What initially sounds like steel drums darting around the island rhythms of ""Sailor Take Me"" soon reveals itself to be Kleyn's harp
column6: a clever and startling sonic transformation made all the more impressive by the fact that it sounds undoctored.

column1: By the time the needle starts circling the label on the first side
column2: the band has packed up its gear and left the stage
column3: leaving Kleyn mostly alone to accompany herself on harp. Here's where she truly shines
column4: as the staccato plucks and pastoral glissandi of the instrument nicely contrast her sweetly high-pitched vocals. Adventurous and wide-eyed
column5: Takin' the Time is nevertheless much more professional and consistent than Love Has Made Me Stronger
column6: yet it lacks the homemade aesthetic of that debut-- the impression of a young artist finding her own unique voice and style-- and therefore much of its offhand charm. Still
column7: Kleyn proves a warmly intuitive and self-possessed musician
column8: and some of the best moments here are also the smallest and humblest: Pay attention to her vocals as she sustains her notes on ""She Lost Her Crown""
column9: striking a homespun vibrato that buoys the verses. Or listen to the way her voice cracks subtly as she soars up to a high note on ""Prayer"". Moments like these make Takin' the Time sound like the work of a lively personality
column10:
one who obviously loved hauling that harp around and seeing what she could do with it.

column8: repeat

Blur have spent most of 2012 toying with our heartstrings. First Damon Albarn announced that
column2: after a performance at the Olympic Closing Ceremony Concert in Hyde Park
column3: the long-lived
column4: notoriously volatile band would be calling it a day. A few weeks later Albarn backpedaled and said that wasn't necessarily the case (""Some days I feel one way and other days I feel the other.""). Then
column5: in what felt like a definitive mark in the ""stay together for the kids"" column
column6: they released a pair of singles. Preliminary sessions were underway for a new album; then the album was scrapped. So
column7: when the band insists that that Hyde Park performance
column8: now immortalized as a live album called Parklive
column9: will indeed be its last
column10: they can forgive us for feeling a little skeptical. And dizzy.

column1: Hurried out to iTunes a day after the Closing Ceremony show and following a recent avalanche of archival releases
column2: Parklive comes to us as speedily and inevitably as a Usain Bolt 100-meter victory. Still
column3: thanks to the clear and appropriately bombastic mix
column4: Parklive certainly doesn't sound like a rush job. In fact
column5: judging by all the tweets from the cheap seats complaining about Hyde Park's soundsystem (and the boos audible to my ears when Albarn asks early in the set if they can hear him in the back)
column6: Parklive sounds even better than the real thing. It's a transcendent and exuberant 25-song set
column7: capturing the infectious energy of a 21-year-old live band still riding an impossibly prolonged peak-- Albarn has to make an age-appropriate revision to the lyrics of ""End of a Century"" (""The mind gets dirty/ As you get closer... to 50"")-- and a city still gleeful and staggering from that post-Olympic high. Following the recent release of the career-spanning Blur 21 box set
column8: at a moment when the band's legacy is in the process of being revisited
column9: argued
column10: and revised
column11: it's hard to imagine the serendipitously timed Parklive not ousting the competition-- namely 2009's All the People or the two live performances included on Blur 21-- to become Blur's definitive live release.

column1: From the tone-setting and rowdy opener ""Girls & Boys"" onward (the only hint that it's not actually the golden Brit Pop year of 1994 is the subtle
column2: faintly poignant past-tense Albarn sneaks in: ""Love in the 90s was paranoid"")
column3: the set is heavy on the sort of pop anthems that fit the crowd's celebratory
column4: post-Olympic mood. There are plenty of fittingly direct explicit addresses to their home city
column5: from a rousing version of Parklife's ""London Loves"" (""This song is called 'London Loves'. And WE LOVE LONDON!"") right through to a call and response chant of ""London!"" during the penultimate ""For Tomorrow"". Suffice to say that when Phil Daniels comes out to bark out his iconic lines in ""Parklife""
column6: this is a crowd that remains in a sustained state of apeshitness for the whole three-and-a-half minutes.

column2: of course
column3: have a back catalog full of songs to fit all sorts of moods
column4: but what makes Parklive a better listening experience than some of their other live recordings is how cohesive the entire set's energy feels. Much of the credit here should go to the formidable
column5: too-often-unsung rhythm section that is Dave Rowntree and Alex James: They keep even the set's moodiest material here bobbing along with a brisk
column6: agreeable gait. There are a few moments when it doesn't quite work (this comparatively buoyant live version of ""No Distance Left to Run"" doesn't hold a candle to the original)
column7: but overall the affect is positive: Check out the way the band teases out the latent pop sensibility of 13's atmospheric ""Trim Trabb"" and ""Caramel""
column8: adding a new dimension to the songs.

column2: though
column3: come from the songs that fall somewhere between anthemic stadium pop and smudgy mood pieces. Even an insomniac's obsessive YouTube expedition to listen to every live version of ""Beetlebum"" ever (trust me) would probably not uncover a version showcasing a better vocal from Albarn
column4: let alone an instrumental finale that rises to the occasion quite like Graham Coxon's squalling solo does here. Elsewhere
column5: the brassy
column6: pitch-perfect closer ""The Universal"" showers the crowd with generous handfuls of sonic confetti
column7: and live favorite ""Tender"" is
column8: as always
column9: divine. Coxon's bluesy refrain
column10: ""Oh my babyyyy
column11: has become the ""Freebird!"" of Blur shows-- you can hear some strains of it travel
column12: request-like
column13: through the crowd while the band tunes up for another song earlier in the set. Backed by gospel singers

column15: but the audience feels like the frontpeople on this 9-plus-minute rendition as they steer the mantra-like refrain rippling through the park. Tens of thousands of voices strong
column16: it's still got an intimacy about it

column18: greatest campfire singalong ever.

column2: but live albums are about a little more than a band; they document a moment too. The band was smart to rush the digital release last week

But in the off chance that this is the last we ever hear from Blur

it's hard to imagine a band going out with a more triumphant victory lap.

New Zealand's Opossom are an excellent indie pop band whose excellence is so narrow they seem less a band than a sleekly designed indie pop delivery system. The 10 songs on their lightly grooving
column3: lightly melancholic debut
column4: Electric Hawaii
column5: are all pretty in almost the exact same way: pitched at the same breezy
column6: cool
column7: Xanax-blue mid-tempo shuffle
column8: with lead singer Kody Nielson laying his creamy
column9: sighing voice atop in precisely the same way. If the drummer has mastered another drumbeat other than the ""Tomorrow Never Knows"" one

column11: and immediately afterward
column12: they spit-smooth this stray lock back in place and carry on. It's an unsexy but rewarding approach: You might not need all 10 of these songs in a row
column13: but any one
column14: two
column15: or three of them would make for pleasant company.

column1: Nielson is the brother of Unknown Mortal Orchestra's Ruban Nielson

column7: for example

column1: The vaguely Wes Anderson-styled video for ""Fly""-- quirky scientists
column2: quirky experiment
column3: quirky UFOs-- cements the overall impression left by Electric Hawaii
column4: that you could have stumbled across Opossom on MTV in the late 90s or early 00s
column5: when a band could still surface with a memorable
column6: narrow sound
column7: an eye-catching video
column8: and have a hit or two. (My mental Rolodex slots them somewhere north of Rooney's ""Blue Side"" and somewhere slightly south of Space's ""The Female of the Species"".) To Opossom's credit
column9: there are several potential versions of that hit here: ""Fly""
column10: ""Blue Meanies""
column11: and ""Outer Space"" all seem equally viable. There is a lot of craft to admire in the songwriting
column12:
and in the perfectly sepia-tinged production. But Electric Hawaii is an album that's easier to bop your head to while idly imagining the technology commercial it could soundtrack than it is to engage with.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/18263/homepage_large.4d416ab2.jpg|How to Live With a Phantom|30643.0|Shintaro Sakamoto|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Other Music']|2012-08-20 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:08:20.738483|"

column2: it helps to start with Todd Rundgren. Like Rundgren
column3: Sakamoto started his career with a psych-pop garage band before decamping into the studio and striving toward making the Platonic ideal of pop music by himself. The trajectory is the same
column4: though while Rundgren only lasted about 2 years with the Nazz before releasing a string of idiosyncratic hermit-pop LPs through the 1970s
column5: Sakamoto led the great Yura Yura Teikoku (Japanese for ""The Wobbling Empire"") from 1989 through 2010 before releasing his solo debut this year. Like so many Japanese acts of the past few decades
column6: Yura was huge in its home country
column7: but only registered a cult-act blip stateside (though DFA quietly re-issued an LP on its Death from Abroad imprint in 2009). The impeccably produced lounge-pop of How to Live With a Phantom seems destined for a small-but-ardent listenership.

column1: Sakamoto produced and played many of the instruments on Phantom
column2: conjuring the image of Rundgren-as-golden god secluded in his hotel room of the Something/Anything gatefold photo. But while it's easy to imagine Sakamoto laying down conga tracks while adjusting board levels with his big toe
column3: Phantom's vibe more closely evokes the anonymous band downstairs in the hotel lounge
column4: playing for weary business travelers and soundtracking the early moments of an ill-fated hookup. He sounds less like a passionate frontman
column5: in other words
column6: and more like some sort of Japanese Bryan Ferry
column7: with songs suggesting the pop formalism of Rundgren and Steely Dan--and occasionally Juan Garcia Esquivel's Space-Age Bachelor Pad--sung in Japanese
column8: with a glassy
column9: purposeful distance between musician and listener.

column2: though
column3: and you start to hear the echoes of past pop moments when localized groups of musicians started incorporating influences on a global scale: the late 1960s Tropicalia moment in Brazil
column4: and especially the mid-1990s Shibuya-Kei movement in Sakamoto's hometown of Tokyo. This is the quiet genius of Phantom: it incorporates so much
column5: yet remains as willfully aloof as the mannequin Sakamoto poses with on the cover (or
column6: if you like
column7: his pose in the center of this older Yura Yura promo photo).

column2: sure
column3: but far from sanitized. Granted
column4: many readers likely see this distinction as a choice between Plain and Diet Plain
column5: but if you've come this far
column6: you know it amounts to much more than the narcisissm of minor differences. Phantom not only feels self-aware
column7: but for something that sounds like it was it was recorded in the ""Rockit"" house
column8: it's got a sense of humor as well.

column2: I was hooked when the ""Shakedown Street"" guitar showed up in ""Mask on Mask
column3: and my affection was only further solidified via that song's conga run
column4: Sakamoto's lovely melodic bass leads
column5: and-- wait for it-- his squealing sax solo. About the time of the second flute break in ""Dancing With Pain""
column6: or maybe when the aquarium air pump sound effect kicked in during ""A Stick and Slacks""
column7: or perhaps it my fifth run through the opening track's Getz/Gilberto nod
column8: it became clear that the album's purposeful artificiality is much more in line with Beck than say
column9: S1m0ne. Maybe this is Shintaro's way of honing a new skill: playing with phantoms without tipping over into the uncanny valley.

To begin to understand where Jessie Ware is coming from
column3: let's look at her stuck between an acoustic guitarist and an MPC beat pusher in the back of a London taxi. As part of the simple
column4: self-explanatory ""Black Cab Sessions"" web series
column5: the 27-year-old British singer recently took her place in the middle seat and proceeded to offer a nuanced live take on ""Wildest Moments""
column6: a slyly epic ballad from her debut album
column7: Devotion. In such tight quarters
column8: she's not quite sure where to look-- at her bandmates
column9: outside to the street
column10: or directly into the camera-- her head on a controlled swivel. She's capable of blasting the back window out with her voice
column11: which consistently strikes blue notes somewhere between Sade and Whitney
column12: but she holds back
column13: well-aware of her unplugged environment. The performance is seriously moving
column14: and yet Ware lets loose a few brief grins and a slight laugh
column15: as if to say
column16: ""All this is quite ridiculous
column17: don't you think?"" And that's Jessie Ware: a devout realist making the most of her pop-star dreams-- and her commitment to both sides of that equation turns Devotion into a uniquely soulful masterclass.

column1: If you've half-slept through just one episode of a reality-television singing competition over the last decade
column2: you're probably somewhat privy to Ware's trajectory. The one-time theater kid started out as a backup singer before nearly giving up her musical aspirations to be a journalist. But then
column3: thanks to a montage-ready twist of fate
column4: she ended up singing lead on melodic bass producer SBTRKT's 2010 single ""Nervous""
column5: which led to a solo label deal
column6: which led to Ware being forced to take the spotlight. But oftentimes backup singers are off to the side for a reason
column7: and the hard truth is that's where they will be most productive; there are only so many lead roles in the world of pop. Considering her self-described ""boringly sensible"" outlook and the doubt pinging around her brain (""I had to get past the idea of
column8: like
column9: 'Who gives a shit about what I'm gonna fucking write a song about?'"")
column10: Ware sounds more like a supporting player on paper. But then you hear her voice
column11: and any and all limits start to fade into the distance.

column1: Singing over futuristic electronic tracks like ""Nervous"" and dubstep producer Joker's ""The Vision""
column2: Ware sounded strong
column3: but also somewhat overshadowed by the showy bleeps scurrying around her. Devotion
column4: however
column5: marries her natural gift with throbbing instrumentation that breathes life into every single turn of phrase or sensitive vocal embellishment. The tempos bounce lightly
column6: the drama escalates
column7: the synth-laden ambience cascades like so many postcard waterfalls. This is smoldering music
column8: its smoke bewitching enough to make the original fire more or less irrelevant.

column1: The record was largely produced by three men-- Dave Okumu of UK art rockers the Invisible
column2: Bristol electronic upstart Julio Bashmore
column3: and singer-songwriter Kid Harpoon
column4: who co-wrote songs on Florence and the Machine's Ceremonials-- each leaving his distinct mark without distracting from the whole. Okumu's tracks
column5: especially opener ""Devotion""
column6: are dark and dense
column7: hinting at passion's underbelly with each deep bass hit; Bashmore's are more airy and upbeat
column8: primed for classy dancefloors worldwide; Kid Harpoon offers the most festival-ready songs-- big hooks
column9: bigger drums-- like ""Wildest Moments"". Tying the disparate sounds together are Okumu
column10: who co-produced and played many instruments on nearly every track
column11: and of course Ware herself
column12: who co-wrote all but one song. Her voice is a marvel throughout
column13: often gaining power by holding back or briefly teasing its scope while staying faithful to melody over melisma. Her words are in tune with this refinement as they chronicle the in-betweenness of love
column14: dismissing easy pleasures for feelings that are more hard-won
column15: confusing
column16: and frightening.

column1: Take the most classically ""pop"" song here: the weightless ""Sweet Talk""
column2: which modernizes Whitney Houston's late-80s effervescence à la Beyoncé's ""Love on Top"". On its face
column3: the track is all endless dimples and mesmerizing lips
column4: but then the verses sink in: ""Don't keep me with the kisses
column5: there's never any there when I need
column6: pleads Ware. She knows she's going to fall for the smooth nothings once again
column7: though
column8: and lets the keys try to cover the inevitable regret
column9: which plays out on ""Running""
column10: where Ware starts
column11: ""Your words alone could drive me to a thousand tears."" The title track
column12: with its foreboding murk
column13: gives whiffs of a seance as Ware asks
column14: ""Ready to love but do you want it enough?/ Can we find a way to bring it back again?"" Given the track's perfectly rendered storm clouds
column15: you get the impression she already knows the answers. The idea of running comes up often on Devotion
column16: and it's clear that Ware isn't interested in the sprints-- when it comes to love
column17: she's angling for a marathon. And she knows marathons can be really fucking tough.

column1: Talking about her childhood aspirations earlier this year
column2: Ware told me
column3: ""It's so unattainable to be a singer. I'd watch 'Top of the Pops' and think I could never do that. And I didn't look like a pop star compared to the people I used to watch on MTV like J.Lo or Destiny's Child."" As a middle-class Jewish girl from South London who's closer to 30 than 20
column4: she's still nothing close to a cookie-cutter R&B breakout. Her success thus far-- and its likely continuation thanks to Devotion-- is a testament to both her talent and budding songwriting skills
column5: as well as the wide-open field that is modern R&B
column6: where a sensitive soul like Frank Ocean can make a star-in-a-box like Chris Brown look about as relevant as a dial-up modem. ""I'm just having fun and trying to pretend I'm a pop star
column7: said Ware
column8: talking about her high-style videos. And while embellishment and theatricality is still a coveted and worthwhile pursuit within the pop realm
column9: the beautiful thing is that
column11:
Jessie Ware doesn't need to pretend more than anyone else.

If the intent of reissuing Ride's first two LPs was to change the group's reputation of being the perennial runner-ups of the shoegaze era-- the human foil to the divine My Bloody Valentine
column3: a great band rather than a legendary one-- then this campaign has been a miserable failure. Mostly because the truth wins out: ""The Story of Going Blank Again"" contains the following quotes from the members of Ride: ""It's a steady work process
column4: which is a great way to do an album
column5: ""It was fun
column6: it was a team effort
column7: ""I think it was the closest together as a band we ever were. There was no tension
column8: no conflict. Everything just seemed to work.""

column1: Ride didn't bankrupt Creation Records; in fact
column2: they partied with Alan McGee. They never advanced the image of being hermetic visionaries; they had to force themselves to stop socializing with other bands. They never disappeared for years on end and would later release some universally reviled trad-rock albums that doubled as applications to open for Oasis
column3: or in the case of Andy Bell
column4: to be in Oasis. But on Going Blank Again
column5: Ride managed one thing MBV never accomplished after Loveless and probably never will: facing the crippling expectations and making a tremendous follow-up record.

column1: It might not change the narrative surrounding Ride
column2: but hopefully it does raise the question of why Going Blank Again is assumed to be the contrarian's choice for the band's true masterpiece. Some of it is pretty understandable: Going Blank Again is a noticeably lighter affair and lacks the monolithic heft of its predecessor
column3: which is readily apparent from their respective album art. I mean
column4: compare the two covers
column5: which one looks like the classic to you?  Perhaps more crucially
column6: Going Blank Again was without a movement
column7: the UK looking to move past shoegaze towards something more personality-driven
column8: though it wasn't clear quite what yet.

column2: Ride could be included in that. Many lesser bands followed in Ride's wake
column3: and ""Leave Them All Behind"" is as close as a mission statement that you're gonna get from a band whose lyrics are mostly nonsense. Bell and Mark Gardener's guitars somehow got even louder and it can initially register as Nowhere Plus
column4: but it also sets the tone in how Going Blank Again would distinguish itself. ""Seagull"" started Nowhere with a peal of feedback and six minutes of trebly squall that only revealed its layers when played at tinnitus-inducing levels. Blessed with Alan Moulder's crystalline production
column5: the salutation of ""Leave Them All Behind"" is a reverberating Hammond organ and an extremely punchy drum break from Loz Colbert
column6: which acknowledge the two encroaching threads of influence of the band: the first of the Who
column7: reflecting Ride's increasing stadium-readiness
column8: the latter acknowledging the influx of hip-hop and funk breakbeats into UK rock.

column1: It might be meant as the valedictory speech of shoegaze
column2: but it isn't actually shoegaze at all
column3: not in the sense where the genre's main goal was to obliterate or obscure. Every single element of ""Leave Them All Behind"" is voluminous
column4: but not just in sheer loudness: It's overwhelming
column5: not oppressive
column6: and the sonic expanse is even more mindblowing with this remastering job. Bell and Gardener's barnstorming guitars
column7: Steve Queralt's girder-thick bassline
column8: and Colbert's Moon-sized drum fills all could fill canyons individually
column9: yet never once does it sound like something other than four guys in a room
column10: which explains why Ride was pretty much the only band of their ilk that was as good live as they were on record. That said
column11: the inclusion of the Live at Brixton DVD is mostly notable for its stupendously dated visuals.

column1: The band adamantly demanded ""Leave It All Behind"" be the lead single
column2: and it reached No. 9 in Britain
column3: their first Top 10 hit. This would seemingly bode well for Going Blank Again's fortunes considering the next single was the giddy
column4: nonsensical ""Twisterella"". Drawing from the same sugar-spun power-pop of labelmates Teenage Fanclub as well as the cuts from The Stone Roses equally influenced by acid and ecstasy
column5: it was rightfully described by the band as their ""ace card."" Yet it was a baffling flop on the charts and Ride released no more singles from there on out.

column2: too
column3: as Going Blank Again should have been able to take advantage of its depth and diversity
column4: its main trump over Nowhere. You get Television-styled guitar interplay and Bell and Gardener's most tossed-off lyrics on ""Not Fazed"". ""Chrome Waves"" shot for ""Unfinished Sympathy""
column5: but landed somewhere closer to Seal's ""Crazy"" and was all the better for it. ""Leave Them All Behind"" has an equally colossal bookend in ""OX4""
column6: though the addition of four bonus tracks from the Leave Them All Behind and Twisterella EPs are hardly an unwelcome appendage (particularly ""Grasshopper""). And there are the goofy pop songs like ""Twisterella"" which arguably worked against Going Blank Again's legacy
column7: and even the band will admit the flower-child spoof of ""Making Judy Smile"" isn't its best work.

column1: Because the typical selling point of shoegaze-- there's classic pop under all that noise!-- doesn't quite explain what Ride excelled at. Speaking on the origin of ""Mouse Trap""
column2: Bell observed
column3: ""occasionally you discover a chord sequence that you'd be quite happy to play for two hours non-stop."" There's about eight or so of those on Going Blank Again. Even with Ride's aim to integrate more true pop songwriting
column4: much of Going Blank Again wisely follows the wake of the immortal ""Vapour Trail""
column5: which rode out a single gorgeous progression for nearly its entirety
column6: its only flaw stopping at four minutes instead of eight. More and more
column7: I think the true impact of hip-hop on Ride wasn't evident in Colbert's drum fills so much as their seeing chord progressions as rhythmic beds as much as melodic ones
column8: the way a rapper might treat a breakbeat. As such
column9: Ride proved to be a band that operated in largesse more than finesse: simply building on these perfect chord changes for five minutes at a time with stretched out vocal harmonies
column10: a brief shift of a couple of bars into a minor key
column11: erratic tempo changes toward the thrilling end of ""Cool Your Boots""
column12: bent soloing on ""Leave Them All Behind""
column13: a 12-string riff breaking up the middle of ""Mouse Trap"". The pleasures of Going Blank Again are cumulative
column14: and if you simply love the sound of guitars-- clean ones
column15: distorted ones
column16: overdriven Leslie amps
column17: Les Pauls
column18: Rickenbackers
column19: whatever-- this is about as indulgent as it gets.

column2: but Going Blank Again feels more similar to the recently reissued version of Sugar's Copper Blue than anything that's strictly identifiable as shoegaze.  It's certainly reckoning with the aftermath of Loveless and an awareness of Nevermind
column3: if not necessarily its influence. But they're both records that feel welcome 20 years later
column4: because while their more famed peers have influenced hundreds of pale imitators
column5: these more approachable records feel strangely undervalued. Because really
column6: what was the last new band to bear the influence of Sugar or Ride? Not even in strict sonic similarity
column7: since it's hard to imagine the brassy acoustic guitars you hear on ""Chrome Waves"" ever coming back into vogue. But more in how there's an unfortunate void of very loud
column8: very catchy
column9: and very polished guitar bands that aren't ashamed of commercial ambitions.  You can learn a lot from Going Blank Again: Come up with four chords worth repeating for four minutes
column10: hum a pretty melody
column11: overdub the guitars
column12: overdub them again
column13: and make the drums even louder. It's not the stuff of legends
column14: but we need great records
column15:
too.

On last year's official debut album
column3: Schlungs
column4: Norwegian disconauts Mungolian Jet Set sought to frame their debauched
column5: corpulent psychedelia within snappy
column6: jaunty songs
column7: with mixed results. The problem was partly the sheer number of wacky curveballs
column8: but more crucially
column9: the collective's self-expansive sonic approach was too frequently reined in to allow the indifferent songs to speak
column10: when any listener could have told the group that they were arrangers first and songwriters second. Arriving less than a year later
column11: this follow-up assemblage of new tracks
column12: collaborations
column13: and remixes for other artists can't help seeming corrective
column14: though when what requires correcting is so obvious that just seems like pragmatic good sense. Of course
column15: like any hasty reversal
column16: this opens up its own succession of problems
column17: though perhaps less in the sense of flaws or shortcomings than issues that Mungolian Jet Set still need to work out
column18: a feeling of incompletion to the story at odds with the group's unmistakable production style and the music's readily apparent surface pleasures.

column1: The shift is apparent from Mungodelics' first track
column2: a remix of Jaga Jazzist's ""Toccata"". Built around iridescent
column3: shimmering chime loops
column4: and featuring a starry-eyed
column5: bittersweet central melody reminiscent of Superpitcher
column6: the widescreen instrumental is at once gargantuan in scope and unusually focused
column7: irresistibly sentimental yet utterly serious. As with recent releases from fellow Norwegian Todd Terje
column8: ""Toccata"" suggests a fascination with the vaguely new age proto-techno of Steve Reich's Music for 18 Musicians and perhaps Manuel Göttsching's E2-E4. It also suggests that Mungolian Jet Set have rediscovered that their maximalist aesthetic is best deployed in the service of depth rather than (or as well as) breadth: While the arrangement may be spare in conception
column9: its shifting layers and vaguely ominous echoing glimmers resemble a magic eye picture
column10: the smallest shifts in emphasis revealing fascinating new vistas.

column1: The balance of Mungodelics continues to distance itself from last year's album. At a stretch
column2: ""People on Strong Stuff""-- with its unnecessary guitar solo and declamatory
column3: occasionally tuneless vocal somewhere between Jim Kerr and Dave Gahan-- could be a Schlungs outtake
column4: but the groove is sturdier
column5: trackier
column6: a constantly uncoiling web of multi-tiered
column7: syncopated rhythms. Throughout
column8: what largely replaces zaniness is an obsession with build that recalls erstwhile progressive house hero Sasha
column9: and even a restrained tune like the group's remix of Unni Wilhelmsen's ""Revolving Door""-- dreamy disco-house redolent of the Meanderthals-- cannot help but spiral upward on ever-unfolding swirls of keyboards and percussion
column10: a rising but never-quite-cresting wave of blissed out introspection.

column1: This relative lack of climaxes is startling when compared to the group's past work
column2: giving Mungodelics the feel of deep
column3: shadowy valleys of arrangement finesse
column4: nestled between three brief
column5: glorious peaks. After ""Toccata""
column6: the next highpoint is ""Smells Like Gasoline""
column7: a Moroder-esque tech-house tune of metallic synth chords and scintillating echoes that
column8: after four minutes of teasing build
column9: unleashes a house piano vamp of almost melancholy perfection
column10: only to almost immediately subside into eerie dub-techno percolations that unexpectedly revive the early work of German minimal duo MRI
column11: but with added rippling wind chimes. This kind of left-turn does not so much reward as require headphone listening
column12: where you're close enough to the beats that both extraversion and involution register as an enveloping wall of sound. Other settings I've tested
column13: from the car to the living room
column14: allow this music to slip too comfortably into the background for long stretches (something you could never have accused Schlungs of doing
column15: for better or worse)
column16: but whereas the nine minutes of ""Mung's Picazzo"" can sound overstretched and aimless in such environments
column17: a ""close reading"" can seem almost gripping
column18: the tune's meandering groove taking on the portentous air of a thundercloud always on the verge of bursting.

column2: with its closer ""The Dark Incal"" Mungodelics ascends a third pinnacle that inverts entirely the appeals of its opener
column3: offering up maximalist and shamelessly emotive tribal trance-house reminiscent of Booka Shade's ""Mandarine Girl"" in both sound and scope
column4: a preposterously grand gesture built out of meticulous details worthy of the North Korean Mass Games. All that is loveable or lamentable in Mungolian Jet Set's music is right here. It's overblown melodrama
column5:
and you can see through it if you want to. But why would you want to?

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18172/homepage_large.79550527.jpg|Sounds of the Syrian Houran|30597.0|Dabke|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sham Palace']|2012-08-17 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:08:22.576600|"

When Sun City Girls' Richard and Alan Bishop (as well as a few close allies) commenced transmitting world musics via their Sublime Frequencies label back in 2004
column2: it was a flummoxing aural experience for many music critics
column3: no matter how adventurous their palates might be. Across the label's intoxicating early run-- covering everything from Burmese skronk to Laotian folk to North Korean prop-opera-- it revealed a modern world (of) music that was as intense and surreal as anything imaginable in the Western music canon. The label even brought audiences vital modern acts like Tuareg guitarist Bombino and the astounding family band Group Doueh
column4: not to mention the brusque
column5: poker-faced Syrian pop vocalist Omar Souleyman via tours of Europe and the United States.

column2: fellow Sublime Frequencies conniver Mark Gergis started up yet another imprint called Sham Palace. The label's first order of business was to reissue a rare 60-minute cassette from Souleyman onto vinyl. With five Souleyman titles now available in American shops
column3: this would appear at first to be an example of flooding the marketplace. Only
column4: the double LP featured a king cobra of a track in the 30-minute version of ""Leh Jani"" (a truncated version of which appeared on SF's Highway to Hassake album). For those who had thought that the Sublime Frequencies catalog already exposed the rawest of sounds to be found in such far-flung locales
column5: the Sham Palace record suggested that they could in fact always get deeper and harder.

column1: So it follows with this compilation of 1990s-2000s dabke music
column2: a staple of wedding ceremonies
column3: and judging by the sounds of this compilation
column4: the aural equivalent of vodka-Red Bulls: jittery and buzzing Bacchanalian dance grooves that are slightly metallic in tone. And while Souleyman hails from the northeastern part of Syria (his dabke featuring the bouzouk)
column5: this compilation culls its sounds from tapes released in the southern region Houran
column6: ranging from Damascus in Syria into Jordan and west toward the Golan Heights. It's here that Gergis traveled about
column7: recording live from the mixing desk at such raucous wedding parties in the region. And once again
column8: the Sublime Frequencies folks explore the music of a region that doubles as a Western media hot topic
column9: gratefully offering neither context nor analysis. Instead
column10: we have only the music.

column1: The notes state that this region of Syria jumbles together Syrians
column2: Bedouin
column3: Palestinians
column4: Jordanians
column5: and more
column6: yet however acute the ear for noting regional differences might be
column7: they are soon overwhelmed by the drone of the mijwiz that snakes through all seven of the songs. A double bamboo reed that's shrill
column8: adenoidal
column9: jolting
column10: fly-buzzing
column11: and ensorcelling with every swing of circular breath
column12: the mijwiz is foregrounded in such wedding songs.

column2: the sound was balanced between the reed
column3: handdrums and vocal chants. But when the drums went electronic in the early 90s (read: hip-hop)
column4: the mijwiz-- much like the guitarist and lead vocalist scrambled to do amid jazz's big bands-- also went electric so as to remain out front. And now modern dabke interweaves sampled and mic'd mijwiz melodies
column5: making for tightly interwoven melodic lines from the doubled mijwiz and synth. So the tone on Faraj Kadah/Ashraf Abu Leil's seven-minute dabke ranges from finely minced beeps to breathlessness to a tone not unlike the bleat of a sore-throated calf. Ahmad Al Kosem's fierce songs have their titles translate as ""Love Is No Joke"" and ""I Will Grieve Until I See Her Again""
column6: fine wedding themes both. And amid an album full of tough and coarse male vocal plaints
column7: my favorite remains the utterly bizarre chipmunk voices that crash the wedding of Mohamed Al Ali's contribution.

column2: the Sublime Frequencies family presents a snapshot of a region only just reaching our ears via the Western news media and tales of international crisis (see their compilations of Iraqi and North Korean music
column3: for example). It's a complicated situation
column4: one not easily gleaned from reading the Times or Al Jazeera
column5: and rather than comment
column6:
Gergis and crew offer us a brief yet very human glimpse into a people all too often abstracted by the 24-hour news cycle.

Years before he became known to younger generations as a grinning
column2: gray-haired fixture at the Academy Awards
column3: perpetually nominated for life-affirming musical contributions to whatever Pixar blockbuster came out the year before
column4: Randy Newman created tangible three-dimensional worlds in the space of two-minute songs. Matthew E. White was among those who got lost in those worlds
column5: rubbing shoulders with the funny and fucked-up characters that Newman created out of a singular mix of spite and empathy. White became so obsessed with Newman that he eventually tracked down the 60-something singer-songwriter at his Los Angeles home
column6: and handed him his own CDs. It was
column7: in a way
column8: a passing-of-the-torch in reverse.

column2: his debut album
column3: Big Inner
column4: might very well be an attempt to re-create Newman's 1974 concept album about southern otherness
column5: Good Old Boys. Inner is certainly southern
column6: it's definitely other
column7: and the songs collectively tell the kind of story that always appealed to Newman
column8: about painfully human creatures yearning for spiritual transcendence and finding that their own flawed
column9: flesh-and-blood selves always seem to get in the way. But where Newman was among the most literary of the late-60s/early-70s post-Dylan generation of singer-songwriters
column10: White's primary mode of expression on Inner is musical. With his background in jazz arranging and natural grasp of American roots music
column11: the native Virginian has positioned himself at the head of a corps of young and veteran musicians-- including Bon Iver's Reggie Pace
column12: Phil Cook of Megafaun
column13: and David Hood-- determined to revive long-lost record-making traditions in the service of re-imagining psychedelic music as gospel hymns.

column1: Big Inner is the first product of Spacebomb
column2: a production entity and record label with a house band composed of White
column3: bassist Cameron Ralston
column4: and drummer Pinson Chanselle at its core. (There is also a sizeable horn and string section
column5: and a choir.) The idea is to bring artists to White's Richmond
column6: Virginia
column7: headquarters-- essentially the attic of a house on the west side of town-- and arrange their songs in the mold of velvety 70s soul
column8: laidback New Orleans funk
column9: and cosmic country-rock
column10: with a special emphasis on vintage-sounding instrumentation and sweaty intimacy.

column1: White introduces Spacebomb as a fully realized aesthetic right away on Inner's opening track ""One of These Days""
column2: which has the pulse of Willie Mitchell's productions for Al Green's magical run of early-70s LPs. White and his band play softly but not without purpose; their grip on the central groove remains steadfast even as a procession of ghostly funeral horns enter the picture to send the song in a pleasantly disorienting direction.

column1: He revisits this subtle uneasiness between beauty and chaos throughout Big Inner
column2: as the songs lyrically explore the ecstasy and agony of religion
column3: and how it can explain away the mysteries of the universe
column4: but never permanently. The stately gospel number ""Gone Away"" is mired in death
column5: with the lord's mysterious ways offering little in the way of consolation. White sings in a pained murmur about how ""we cling to the cross with tremblin' and fear
column6: because we know the end will inevitably come. If ""Gone Away"" pulls you into the darkness
column7: the sinewy bass line in ""Big Love"" implores you to dance away the knowledge of impending mortality. ""Let's begin to spiral
column8: White says
column9: and-- as gospel music is intended to do-- he makes that universal ""sinking into the unknown"" feeling seem uplifting.

column1: Randy Newman's gift was making his snapshots of racist rednecks and drunken asshole romantics seem like actual people
column2: rather than the creations of a wise-ass Angeleno preoccupied by southern culture on the skids. White's gift on Big Inner is taking sounds created by actual southerners and turning them into figments of his musical imagination
column3: which he bends and shapes into bottomless columns of ethereal soul. The final song on Big Inner
column4: the nearly 10-minute ""Brazos""
column5: wraps with White and his choir repeating a mantra about how Jesus is our friend and can deliver us from ""life's crushing blow."" Whether that's truth or fiction is irrelevant; in the magical moments that White creates
column6:
it's the wonderment that matters.

Say what you will about Yeasayer
column3: but up to this point in their career
column4: their music hasn’t been easily categorized as ""unremarkable"". It’s invited opinions-- loud ones-- from supporters and detractors alike.  Since their tracks are based on similar qualities-- spirited
column5: can-do lyrics
column6: sweeping harmonies
column7: and deliriously stacked arrangements-- there's been almost no middle ground separating their excellent run of singles (""2080""
column8: ""Tightrope""
column9: ""Madder Red""
column10: ""O.N.E."") from their catastrophic face-plants (""Mondegreen""
column11: ""Rome""). Now that's changed. Yeasayer's third album
column12: Fragrant World
column13: is their first and only consistent LP. It not only proves that Yeasayer can make an unremarkable song
column14: but that they can make 11 of them in a row.

column1: Fragrant World marks another transition for a band whose sound appears to be in constant flux
column2: and initially
column3: it can make you miss the ""old"" Yeasayer. There's a significant change here. While All Hour Cymbals and Odd Blood sounded nothing like each other
column4: they reflected Yeasayer's surroundings at the time
column5: the maximalist grab-from-anywhere approach that defined ambitious East Coast indie rock. They were in the lineage of TV on the Radio and Animal Collective when those bands they were still psychedelic and tribal
column6: and they brought to mind the track-stuffing
column7: techno-hippie approach of MGMT or Gang Gang Dance in a pop mood. Fragrant World
column8: on the other hand
column9: is a decidedly minimalist affair. Its album cover might suggest otherwise
column10: but Yeasayer have not gone dubstep or witch house
column11: although the occasional undulating bass wobble and ticking hi-hat suggest they're going for something a little more trunk-rattling this time around. On the whole
column12: the stylistic range is far narrower
column13: and the geographic one much wider
column14: as Fragrant World sounds like it's trying to jockey alongside miniaturists such as Grimes
column15: Purity Ring
column16: or the xx-- acts that make music that sounds simultaneously tiny and fragile enough for iPod shuffles and scalable to subwoofers.

column1: None of which plays to Yeasayer's strengths. The leaner sound puts the focus squarely on their lyrics
column2: and their overall disposition hasn't changed along with their sonics; Fragrant World can feel painfully self-aware. A typically curious juxtaposition occurs over the  phased chords of ""Blue Paper""
column3: when Anand Wilder sighs
column4: ""She used to walk on concrete/ Now the sidewalk isn't green enough for her/ Says she misses Mother Earth."" Later on the squelching ""Devil and the Deed""
column5: he mocks
column6: ""You could never handle if she was into magic/ You could never stand it/ She couldn't speak your language."" The robotic bump 'n' grind of ""Longevity"" is a new look for Yeasayer
column7: but the only real friction is that of a square peg plugging into a round hole: ""My girl says that all the rain promises is to give life to the seeds/ Live in the moment/ Never count on longevity
column8: sings Chris Keating. It's the sort of thing people say with alarming frequency in Yeasayer songs and absolutely nowhere else.

column1: Songs here often take an advisory tone
column2: and the lack of grounding becomes more pronounced whenever Yeasayer get topical. The overkill of EQ filters makes it nearly impossible to identify the folk hero or the shtick on ""Folk Hero Shtick""
column3: with ""The emperor's standing naked/ How much longer can he fake it?"" failing to serve as any sort of guidance. Likewise
column4: witness ""Reagan's Skeleton"" imagining right-wing oppression as a ""Thriller""-like phantasmagoria.

column2: did the lyrics of ""2080"" or ""Ambling Alp"" get in the way? With those songs
column3: Yeasayer managed to overwhelm the listener with an undeniable melody and sheer psychedelic swooning. Though their previously hyper-colored records were also self-produced
column4: Fragrant World is curiously thin. It goes beyond the arrangements. While the hooks of ""No Bones"" and ""Devil and the Deed"" slowly grow on you
column5: each hits a point around the three-minute mark where you might expect a pivot
column6: a bridge
column7: or some new texture. Instead
column8: they just end meekly. This quality is most noticeable on lead single ""Henrietta""
column9: which works a melodic bassline
column10: and the sort of elastic groove that powered Odd Blood's best tracks. Yet after only two minutes
column11: it cuts out and spends more than half of its time playing catch up with the first Neon Indian album.

column1: Credit where it's due-- Yeasayer are ambitious enough to do something other than write ""2080"" sequels
column2: even though they have every incentive to do just that. But unlike the erratic
column3: occasionally captivating
column4: and always bold <i>Odd Blood
column5:
Fragrant World rests in a tentative middle ground.

If grunge was supposed to have killed off hair metal
column3: it did a crap job of it. Nirvana and Pearl Jam somehow begat Creed and Nickelback
column4: who demonstrated how truly boring rock music could get when stripped of glamor
column5: fretboard wizardry
column6: and glass-shattering falsettos. While the Strokes and the White Stripes were instantly deified by music critics for bringing a certain looseness and swagger back to rock'n'roll at the dawn of the 2000s
column7: the Darkness arrived on their coattails embodying what the masses really want from their rock bands: glitz over grit
column8: anthemic joy over disaffected cool
column9: unitards over skinny jeans.

column1: A mega-selling sensation back home in UK
column2: the Darkness' 2003 debut Permission to Land was a more modest phenomenon in America
column3: cracking the Billboard Top 40 and selling 500
column4: 000-plus copies. And even if their ingeniously titled 2005 follow-up
column5: One Way Ticket to Hell… And Back
column6: failed to make as great an impact on either side of the pond-- leading in part to an unceremonious breakup and
column7: more lamentably
column8: Hot Leg-- the Darkness were very much a harbinger of how rock'n'roll would be recycled/revived in pop culture through the decade: Guitar Hero
column9: Rock of Ages
column10: Tony Soprano enjoying possibly his last meal to the sound of ""Don't Stop Believin'"".

column1: So when Samsung needed a dormant early-2000s rock band to star in their Galaxy Note Super Bowl ad last February
column2: they sure as hell didn't go for the Vines. Coming in the wake of a 2011 UK reunion tour
column3: that commercial-- featuring newly moustached but ever-bare-chested lead shrieker Justin Hawkins-- served as a suitably shameless American reintroduction to a proudly shameless band
column4: and a good chunk of the viewing audience could be forgiven for thinking the ad was another example of a one-hit wonder shilling their old song to pay new bills. But despite exploiting all means necessary to stage their comeback
column5: the Darkness are actually more interested in selling records than tablets: Hot Cakes marks the return of the original lineup that recorded Permission (including fu-manchu'ed bassist Frankie Poullain
column6: who checked out shortly before One Way Ticket)
column7: with no less a pomp-rock master than Bob Ezrin behind the mixing board.

column1: Justin Hawkins may be the face and attention-seizing voice of the Darkness
column2: but the heart of their sound lies in his guitar playing
column3: which offsets brother Dan's Angus Youngian raunch with the sort of rich
column4: harmonic solos that Tom Scholz used to slather on Boston records. And despite the band's love of heavy metal histrionics
column5: Hot Cakes furthers the notion that the Darkness are
column6: in essence
column7: a very slick power-pop band
column8: one that's as beholden to ""Peace of Mind"" as Piece of Mind. But even with its generous supply of candy-coated riffs and easy-flowing melodies
column9: Hot Cakes still goes down like lukewarm Eggo waffles: comfort-food familiar
column10: but sapped of the frisson that made the Darkness special.

column1: What always kept the Darkness from degenerating into Steel Panther-grade Sunset Strip parody was Justin Hawkins' flair for emasculating his band's crotch-rock thrust with self-effacing absurdity-- like the way ""Growing on Me"" worked as a soundtrack to both blossoming romance and STD diagnosis
column2: or how his courtship strategy on ""Friday Night"" involved making a date for badminton. Notwithstanding Hawkins' ear-piercing exhortation to ""suck my cock"" on the origin-myth intro ""Every Inch of You""
column3: Hot Cakes mostly swaps out the singer's singular musings for pat
column4: broad-stroked sentiments about not stopping (""Nothin's Gonna Stop Us"")
column5: hanging on (""Keep Me Hangin' On"")
column6: and everybody having a good time (""Everybody Have a Good Time""). The band's upcoming European tour with Lady Gaga thus makes perfect sense-- not just because both value Queen-scaled spectacle
column7: but because they both also deal in the same sort of self-esteem-building fortune-cookie philosophy.

column2: the one time the Darkness truly assert their peculiar personality on Hot Cakes is when they cover another band's song-- and not just any song
column3: but Radiohead's ""Street Spirit (Fade Out)""
column4: that crucial
column5: transitory track serving as the gateway from the futurist Britpop of The Bends into the band's first dystopian masterpiece
column6: OK Computer. The Darkness
column7: however
column8: simply hear it as the greatest song Iron Maiden never wrote
column9: translating the original's dreamy intensity into a battlefield-conquering rallying cry
column10: powered by a steel-grinding locomotive chug and Hawkins' stratospheric cry of the chorus (not to mention a clever quote of Radiohead's ""Just"" for good measure). But beyond merely subjecting this sacred cow to a good rogering
column11: the 80s-metal makeover brilliantly blurs the line critics like to draw between Serious
column12: Respectable Rock Bands and Silly
column13: Ridiculous Rock Bands. The Darkness may not care to join the ranks of the former
column14:
but it takes a considerable amount of craft and artistry to reduce Radiohead to the latter.

Kurt Feldman is a sensualist among sensualists. The Brooklyn musician's day job consists of sitting behind the kit for the Pains of Being Pure at Heart
column2: Slumberland revivalists that first gained attention by building a time-traveling rocketship for all those bookish
column3: next-gen indie-poppers who had never heard of Rocketship. A few years before that
column4: though
column5: he was a member of unheralded
column6: neo-shoegaze outfit
column7: the Depreciation Guild
column8: a band that kicked things off by merging brittle chiptune textures with six-string swarm before arriving at the blissful
column9: comfortable conclusion that
column10: if the style itself ain't broke just yet
column11: there's no need to fix it.

column1: The projects that Feldman's been involved with over the last half-decade have been almost exclusively beholden to past sounds
column2: so it shouldn't come as any surprise that Ice Choir
column3: his mostly-solo endeavor following the Depreciation Guild's dissolution last year
column4: once again finds him looking back with reverence. This time
column5: though
column6: the source material is different-- as well as a little surprising
column7: considering his largely rock-heavy background-- as Ice Choir's debut LP
column8: Afar
column9: teems with the lush
column10: swooning textures and big-money eccentricities of 80s pop and new-wave. Granted
column11: when written out
column12: that description is ripe for suspicion; various forms of independent subculture have spent the last few years as Inuits with an internet connection
column13: consuming and discarding the 80s' every cultural facet until the decade itself resembles an imprint of where an animal carcass once lay. Some of the cannibalism has taken place under the guise of sincerity
column14: while a lot of it has reeked of cynical opportunism.

column2: however
column3: it's very difficult to believe that Feldman
column4: who wrote and produced the album by himself
column5: is anything but totally serious about this new path he's travelling on. He doesn't just orbit around the usual reference points (Spandau Ballet
column6: the jittery brightness of Jam & Lewis-produced R&B
column7: OMD's more mainstream material)-- he nails them spot-on with an impressive and loving faithfulness
column8: the only thing separating ""then"" from ""now"" being that I'm pretty sure nobody was gazing at a glowing computer screen while listening to ""If You Leave"" back in 1986. The crude
column9: intentional cheapness that accompanies many a nostalgia-mining DIY act nowadays is avoided thanks to Feldman's own glossy production sheen
column10: as well as the deft mixing hand of Jorge Elbrecht.

column1: Elbrecht and Feldman are something of kindred spirits
column2: since the former's band
column3: Violens
column4: are capable copyists as well; given Elbrecht's commendably warm and distant self-production on Violens' second LP
column5: this year's True
column6: he's an obviously inspired choice for collaboration. Same goes for Chairlift's Caroline Polachek
column7: although her brief cameo on Afar's twinkling closer ""Everything Is Spoilt by Use"" briefly disturbs the environment around her before slipping back into perceived
column8: unmemorable nothingness. Not exactly her fault
column9: though
column10: since Afar's hermetically sealed environment owes greatly to the singular voice of its creator. As a vocalist
column11: Feldman impossibly smacks of another uncanny genre-hopper
column12: Scritti Politti's Green Gartside. Kurt Feldman's voice is rubbery and capable as it races alongside the quick-footed patter of ""Bounding"" and trickles down the lovely synthetic waterfalls of ""Teletrips""-- but it also retains an aromatic lightness
column13: the same sort of wonderfully overpowering perfume that's caused many a listener to fall in love with Gartside's most affecting vocal performances.

column2: though
column3: and not just because Gartside's status as a fascinating
column4: thoughtful pop innovator is
column5: at this point
column6: inimitable. As far as this sleek
column7: lovely new sound of his is concerned
column8: Kurt Feldman's got all the parts required
column9: but he hasn't quite figured out how to perfectly put them together yet
column10: to create songs as indelible as the ones immaculately fashioned by his heroes from the past. That's fine
column11: though
column12: because even Afar's most sketchily drawn material suggests that there's greater potential lying ahead-- and
column13: besides
column14: history has practically proven that he's bound to improve on what's here
column15: since the Depreciation Guild's swan song

column17: was richer and more complex than the 8-bit daggers of 2007's debut In Her Gentle Jaws (the former also yielded the project's finest stroke of post-adolescent romance
column18: ""Crucify You""). The past isn't just on Feldman's mind-- it could be very well on his side
column19:
too.

The murky
column2: primordial drone rock that Guardian Alien make is difficult to talk about directly

column8: lightens
column9: surges

column2: which formed in 2010

column4: transcendence-focused efforts. Its main member is Greg Fox

(They have currently opted for a brutal drum machine that almost works as a bleak meta-joke about his irreplaceability.) Lead singer and guitarist Alex Drewchin of the psych-pop band Eartheater claims heavy influence from Sufi mysticism. Turner Williams
column7: Jr.
column8: performs on a woody
column9: note-bending zither instrument called a shaahi baja. Other sometime members include guitarist Bernard Gann

column11: and bassist Eli Winograd

column1: The single composition that is See the World Given to a One Love Entity looks as aimless as a screensaver on the surface
column2: but the outfit maintains a light-fingered grip on the music's pulse
column3: steering it through extended soloing passages without slackening the album's basic through-line. The record glows with the intensity of their shared concentration. It is an experience to be taken whole or not at all: There is about as much use in noting the music's developments as there is in narrating the details of an acid trip. An upsetting asphyxiated baby-goat-like noise at about the 21:20 mark surfaces from the bottom of the music's texture
column4: floats to the top
column5: and sends a shiver up your spine. Then
column6: it stops
column7: the drone closes back in
column8: and the music's serene bubble reforms.

column1: If there is a single thing to take away from the totality of See the World
column2: it is the sheer joy of hearing Greg Fox drumming again. If you think of drumming
column3: somehow
column4: as mechanically rhythmic
column5: or purely muscular

column7: in other words-- Fox might be a good gateway drug out of this line of thinking. His drumming has a harp player's nuance and inner voicings. The album's pulse never overly complicates itself

column9: wide-eyed approaching-Gorgon horror of Swans

they can take on more colors.

column1: While Katie's post-P.S. Eliot life has taken her toward stark
column2: acoustic storytelling

column11: as a whole it still suggests writers who learned a thing or two about melodic punk poetry from Jawbreaker or the Promise Ring. The album's first cut

column5: seedy motels

column8: Crutchfield muses on one of young adulthood's most essential truths: ""You and me don't earn much pay/ But you and me got enough to get away/ If we want to.""
