column3: in particular
column4: conveys a real sense of post-college disorientation and uncertainty. ""Moving back here/ Feeling too self aware
column5: he sings
column6: emotively. ""I keep thinking/ Is this as good as it gets?"" Elsewhere he sounds pissed off (the rocket-fire ""Crashing"")
column7: and his guitar solos
column8: though accomplished
column9: also show restraint. On the soft-strummed downer ballad ""Empty Head""
column10: he sounds like J Mascis without the mountains of noise: ""It's sad to want it back/ My time again/ It's not like anything was better then."" For a record that on the surface seems characterized by its outpouring of energy
column11: it's beguiling to find that the saddest Swearin' song is also one of its most memorable.

column1: A sappy verse-trading love song seems inevitable for Swearin'; the immensely hooky ""Just"" works due in no small part to Crutchfield and Gilbride's ability to paint evocative images. Crutchfield recounts sticky skin and streetlights and a first encounter with love
column2: and later her internal musings are matched by Kyle's simultaneous self-loathing: ""I came in empty and I broke the lock/ It's dark around me/ Overslept and I'm alone a lot/ No one's asking."" It feels like a film that flips between scenes. For all the parallels to twee pop of the 1990s
column3: and the many bands who have drawn similar indie rock reference points in recent years
column4: Swearin' favors direct expression over style
column5: something Crutchfield articulates early on ""Fat Chance"": ""An artist's mind is stimulated by the aesthetic/ And I don't know about art/ But I think your music's shit."" That line could alienate some listeners
column6:
but it's refreshing to find a group that sounds sincerely as though it's got nothing to hide.

The smart money says the title of Bloc Party's new album is a reference to the fact that it's the fourth album made by the original four members. Less likely is the possibility that it's also an acknowledgement of the four contentious years that have passed since their last LP
column2: Intimacy
column3: which included rumors that the band was breaking up or even considering moving on without Kele Okereke. The implicit solidarity pledge makes sense since the bulk of Four is built from the same elements as 2005's Silent Alarm
column4: by far their most popular album-- sharp
column5: pugilistic dual-guitar interplay
column6: Okereke's S.O.S. vocal mannerisms
column7: a jittery human rhythm section rather than a drum machine. But everyone appears to have lost a slight but significant step over the past seven years
column8: and Four conveys the experience of watching an athlete reliant on explosive physicality realize that his body is betraying him.

column1: Take ""He Begins to Lie"" and ""Team A""
column2: the sort of Bloc Party songs that once could have stopped and cut on a dime but now just awkwardly slam into the chorus. Too often on Four
column3: Okereke and Russell Lissack forgo serrated guitar hooks for blunt grunge riffing
column4: and the rhythm section has become a wholly reactive entity
column5: unable to push a song if and when the melodies fail. While Okereke's voice is recorded curiously low and subject to numerous filters throughout <i>Four
column6: he's still ""got it"" to an extent: His unhinged belting saves the otherwise unmemorable ""3x3""
column7: and a spirited ""we can feel it in our bones!"" cuts through the plodding ""Kettling"". But otherwise
column8: the effort's there without the inspiration
column9: and when he peppers his lyrics with hashtag hopefuls like ""snitches get stitches
column10: ""the empire never ended
column11: ""let me show you how we do in my hood
column12: and ""you can be the one percent if you wanna!"" his sloganeering morphs into something closer to non sequitur.

column1: But even if they don't have the physical stamina to properly recreate Silent Alarm
column2: that's no reason to hold them back. Bloc Party started to prove that they were becoming more adept at being lovers than fighters
column3: and past highlights such as ""I Still Remember""
column4: ""Blue Light""
column5: and ""Signs"" were gushing love songs as spirited and gripping as their ones about gas prices and such. While Four is just about there rather than noticeably bad most of the time
column6: any suspicion that its biggest crime is not being as good as Silent Alarm can be quelled by the utterly dumbfounding ""We Are Not Good People"" and ""Coliseum""
column7: which respectively find Bloc Party breaking their rusty cage and running to touch
column8: peel
column9: and stand at the intersection of MTV ""Unplugged"" and ""Headbanger's Ball"". There's nothing wrong with finding new influences
column10: but it's unfathomable that these were two of the best 12 songs they came up with over the span of an Olympiad. That said
column11: they are the only times where Bloc Party actually sound like they're having as much fun as they want you to think they are.

column1: It's all unconvincing because out of the post-punk Class of 05
column2: Bloc Party were the ones voted ""most likely to succeed"" while the likes of Futureheads and Maximo Park were actually out partying. Bloc Party's 2007 album A Weekend in the City was personally revealing
column3: sonically bold
column4: and sorely underappreciated
column5: and while Intimacy was rushed and not particularly strong
column6: it at least had a sense of direction. Combined with Okereke's actual dance-focused solo album The Boxer and his work with Hercules and Love Affair
column7: it's clear Silent Alarm was a launching pad
column8: not a nest. Maybe that's the message of this record's best song: ""V.A.L.I.S."" describes the kind of man you hate to see your ex with
column9: one that plays by the rules and has things figured out. Okereke tellingly admits before Four's sole effortlessly catchy hook: ""He's not the real me."" It's ultimately debatable whether or not Four is the ""real"" Bloc Party
column10: but revisionist history isn't supposed to be a duller version of the real thing.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18133/homepage_large.1e45a26e.jpg|Melodica|383.0|Blackalicious|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Black Mines']|2012-08-15 00:00:00|1994|2016-06-11 17:08:28.390240|"

Blackalicious released their debut EP Melodica on Solesides in 1994
column2: when West Coast indie rap was in the midst of a Pharcyde/Aceyalone/Hieroglyphics-driven peak. By the time Gift of Gab and Chief Xcel finally got around to recording a follow-up
column3: the label they were on had dissolved
column4: and underground hip-hop's independent-label ranks had become uncomfortably crowded. But 1999's A2G EP
column5: as well as that year's Nia
column6: caught on anyway
column7: and eventually that first release of theirs started taking on the mythical ""early classic"" status that elusive
column8: pre-fame records get when they start getting
column9: say
column10: $75 rare. Four of the EP's seven tracks eventually made their way to the 2000 compilation Solesides Greatest Bumps
column11: which had the maddening effect of revealing that at least some of Melodica was great while the rest leaving plenty to the imagination.

column1: This re-release of Melodica is the first official digital edition
column2: as well as the first effort to consolidate all the tracks
column3: instrumentals aside
column4: that made it onto both the Solesides original and Mo Wax import editions of the EP. As a reissue
column5: it's definitive
column6: but as a time capsule
column7: it's crucial: As an early installation of what would be one of California's most prominent components of the scene
column8: Melodica is an appealing example of what independent rappers could pull off once they got the notion that they didn't have anyone else to answer to but themselves and their fans. This is conscious-minded
column9: lyrically technical underground hip-hop at its rawest and
column10: sometimes
column11: at its most over-the-top ridiculous.

column2: that doesn't sound like a warning
column3: but the appeal of this stuff does hinge on an ear for the kind of elaborate bombast that plays chicken with self-parody. The hyperactive unpredictability of Gab's delivery can be overwhelming
column4: especially when he delivers avalanches of fast-spit assonant wordplay that seem to defy punctuation. (Anyone that transcribes ""Lyric Fathom"" or ""Rhymes for the Deaf
column5: Dumb and Blind"" while using line breaks is doing it wrong.) But while it's trendy to crown this style as ""lyrical lyricist"" stuff
column6: there's some real ankle-breaking work here; at some points he approaches doing for syllables what Thelonious Monk did for notes
column7: bending emphasis and pulling clutch-rupturing gearshifts in his flow that draw more whiplash victims than any peer West of Pharoahe Monch.

column1: And while super-technical performances like his berserk turn in ""Deep in the Jungle"" bring the flash (""Gifted when I'm lifted off a spliff hit/ Reminisce shit
column2: riff with dipshits/ This shit is the misfit style of the gifted/ I'm a whiz kid
column3: get a whiff kid"")
column4: Gab's more laidback
column5: downtempo moments-- ""Swan Lake""
column6: ""Attica Black""
column7: ""Changes""-- show that he still had a talent for building relaxed
column8: breathable verses as well. That skill works with the other
column9: most prominent quality of his voice-- the burbly
column10: nasal tone that sounds amiably mellow even when he's preposterously threatening to ""rip off your arm and throw it in a stew"" or some similar bit of battle-rap goofiness. His vocal tone has always been one of Gab's more relatable qualities-- even if it trips him up occasionally
column11: lending an unintentional flippancy to the alcoholic hard luck story ""40oz for Breakfast"". When it really works
column12: it lends this odd sense of humility that undercuts his diabolical words and gives weight to his modest ones. There's a line in ""Swan Lake"" where he admits that he's ""not sayin' I'm the baddest but I know I got potential""
column13: a modest shrug that would sound disingenuous from any other voice. Here
column14: it's as empathy-provoking as the bit where he's really bummed about getting burned off a $20 bag of shitty weed.

column1: Blackalicious' potential was fulfilled by the time those two '99 releases hit college radio rotation
column2: but those records carry the consequence of making some of the production on Melodica sound fairly first-draft by comparison. Not all of it
column3: granted: ""Swan Lake"" is a neat bit of cratedigger streamlining that merges three different early 70s soul-jazz covers of the Stylistics' ""People Make the World Go Round"" in its structure. And the rare
column4: out-of-the-vaults ""Changes"" is an immersive dose of lo-fi psychedelic soul with a murky yet hard-hitting drum break beneath.

column1: Both of those tracks featured DJ Shadow co-producing with Chief Xcel
column2: while the EP's other best beats-- the fuzzed-out acid-funk ""Rhymes for the Deaf
column3: Dumb and Blind"" and the minimalist
column4: ""Song for My Father""-quoting ""40oz for Breakfast""-- were the results of Shadow working alone. Considering Chief Xcel is the producer who'd later give us intricately heavy beats like ""You Didn't Know That Though""
column5: ""Passion""
column6: and ""The Craft""
column7: not much here really knocks on his side of the table
column8: and there's a couple questionable loops-- the comedic horns and disjointed sampled hook of ""Lyric Fathom""; the lounge-act organ on ""Deep in the Jungle""-- that are almost annoyingly dissonant. But there were better things to come
column9:
and so Melodica is worth its place in history.

In a recent interview with The New York Times
column2: veteran comic Chris Rock addressed the practice of grading comedians by their small-stakes performances in low-profile clubs
column3: their effective warm-up routines. ""When you're workshopping it
column4: a lot of stuff is bumpy and awkward... [A comedian] is essentially in the gym
column5: he said. ""You're mad at Ray Leonard because he's not in shape
column6: in the gym? That's what the gym's for."" I immediately considered the career of Lil B
column7: an artist who refuses-- or is flatly unable-- to trade his metaphorical treadmill for the ring. He exists in an unapologetic state of workshop. His best mixtapes are still bad and his worst mixtapes are still good
column8: because they are all so delightfully bumpy and awkward. There is still no endgame
column9: which makes Lil B at once the most exhausting
column10: unmanageable
column11: and-- even though his catalog is wildly uneven by all standards-- the most reliable artist we have.

column1: For those out there who haven't kept up with his inhuman pace
column2: here's a quick rundown of what Lil B has churned out in his workshop since he last appeared in these pages:  The #1 Bitch mixtape
column3: which samples ""The Imperial March (Darth Vader's Theme)"" and includes the appetizingly titled Based Freestyle ""Ima Eat Her Ass"". The Basedprint 2 mixtape (no first volume necessary). The hilariously gruff Trapped in Basedworld mixtape. A highly confusing hour and a half of instrumental ""classical music"" called Choices and Flowers. Another installation of his Flame mixtape series
column4: this time in honor of the color green. Four more mixtapes
column5: each 16 tracks or more. An 855-song Based Freestyle compilation for which you'd need to carve out five gigs of hard drive space and hours to complete. It is staggering: You could listen to no one but Lil B in 2012 and never once long for new material. His workhorse stamina makes Curren$y look like a sprinter.

column2: Obama Basedgod-- a title uttered on ""I Own Swag""
column3: a track off God's Father and one of his most marketable to date-- is perhaps his most straightforward
column4: rap-rap release since 2011's I'm Gay (I'm Happy). As you might expect from a release referencing a United States president
column5: Obama Basedgod tackles social ills the only way Lil B knows how: through a free-flowing and meditative lens
column6: wobbling between heartfelt and absurdist winking. But more often than not he's heartfelt here
column7: openly confessing his day-to-day worries with more specificity and less theatricality than we're used to. ""I ain't got no fuckin' problems/ Actually I'm lyin'
column8: man
column9: I got a lot of problems
column10: he raps on ""Government Imported""
column11: a track that lifts the beat from Jay-Z's ""This Can't Be Life"".

column2: Lil B stokes nostalgia for the Diplomats' or Hov's heyday with sped-up soul and Motown singles throughout. He's been so freewheeling in recent months (""Bitch
column3: I'm a cow
column4: swag!"" A song rapped in Spanglish called ""Gato Gato""! A tribute to NYU students!) that it's revelatory to hear him discuss something as simple as his own financial troubles. ""Freeway trips and I ain't have no money/ You can look me in my eyes
column5: I look fine/ I practice every day to hide the pain inside
column6: he raps on ""Freeway Trips"". The prismatic title track
column7: on which he raps
column8: ""Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious/ Dump his head in the car/ Dump his body in the ocean"" is misleading in its whimsicality.

column2: Obama Basedgod is often downright boring
column3: joyless
column4: and indistinguishable from hours upon hours of the rapper's throwaway material. If Lil B whittled his work down to a best-of compilation he'd have several top-shelf rap albums; nothing from Obama Basedgod would appear on it. But I much prefer the gentle view from inside his workshop to the possibility of a polished final product that excludes a mixtape like this one. Lil B is the poster child for the John Lennon-coined cliché of ""Life is what happens to you while you're busy making other plans"" in that he refuses to make plans at all. His work is all process
column5: full of unedited life. Obama Basedgod is ultimately an insignificant piece to the Lil B puzzle
column6: but that's the point-- without the excess
column7:
the dependable comforts of the curious hum of his machine would fade to black.

The pictures that accompany LuckyMe's entries in the Glasgow-based imprint's solid mix series feature women
column2: mostly captured at club nights and parties-- eating cupcakes
column3: wearing garish corpse paint
column4: pretending to eat money
column5: and so forth. (The women featured in the photos are credited and ""thanked
column6: presumably to make it explicit that exploitation is not the name of the game.) The message is clear

column9: the increasingly hip label's had a few reasons to keep the taps flowing. Several productions from canny dance cipher Machinedrum's EP released at the top of the year
column10: SXLND
column11: were used as backing tracks by perpetually buzz-cresting mer-rapper Azealia Banks; just last month

column1: So there's quite a few eyes (and ears) on what LuckyMe's next move is
column2: and as it turns out
column3: it's a bit of a curveball: the debut release from Vienna musician Clemens Bächer
column4: who twiddles the knobs as Cid Rim when not collaborating with fellow Austrian beatmaker Dorian Concept. Bächer's a percussionist by trade who tutors and performs in the free jazz realm for a living
column5: so it follows that his productions are heavy on rhythmic patterns that sound slightly off-kilter and disorienting. Snatches of organic fills stud the background of ""Six Hundred""'s punchy synths
column6: while ""A Fall Four Two"" is practically a drum kit solo in slow-motion
column7: with warm tones and what sounds like mallet instruments filling out the leftover space. In Bächer's hands
column8: almost every instrument-- right down to the high-contrast synths and vocal samples smattered throughout the record-- turns into a weapon of rhythmic assault. At times
column9: it's fun to lose yourself in his beat maps
column10: even if the migraine-causing potential while listening is frequently high.

column2: for all its relative busyness and occasional aggressive textures
column3: Bächer's work feels very small in stature. Maybe this is partially because
column4: despite its running time of 36 minutes
column5: LuckyMe has branded this release as a ""micro-album."" Even doing away with what people are calling this thing
column6: though
column7: Cid Rim often sounds handmade and intimate
column8: a more playful variation on what comes from the bedroom-IDM types that make up the roster of U.S. boutique Ghostly International. Even the boldest-sounding material here-- the upward build of ""Manage Expectations""
column9: ""Danger Ranger""'s vocal swarm-- carries an air of restraint
column10: as if it's sitting on a bench near a cliff instead of standing on the edge. The prevailing narrative that's emerged in the last 12 months when concerning Bächer's peers is that of maximalism
column11: where productions most closely resemble setting off an entire fireworks display all at once. While there's plenty going on with Cid Rim
column12: the sense of closeness and propriety makes it out of step in the current landscape
column13: an admirable facet that suggests Bächer's not afraid to march to the step of his own drum kit.

column2: it says something that the standout on Cid Rim is not an original production
column3: but a remix of the album's leadoff cut
column4: ""Draw""
column5: courtesy of Dorian Concept. DC's remix first appeared on Rustie's scene-defining BBC Essential Mix earlier this year
column6: and among the two hours of total aural insanity
column7: it was definitely a highlight
column8: so it's a total treat (and worth the price of purchase alone) to hear the cut's cartoonish
column9: boss-mode synth stomps-- which sound so sharp and tangy
column10: while retaining plenty of menace-- coated in non-radio-rip HD glory that does it justice. Bächer should take heed
column11: though
column12: that it's not necessarily a good look to be shown up at your own function
column13:
so maybe the next time around he'll adopt some crude brashness of his own.

The concept of American black metal
column2: or USBM
column3: has undergone a number of changes throughout its dawn in the late 1980s/early 90s. After leaping and bounding from the raw violence of San Francisco's VON to the primitive hatred of Chicago's Heidegger-referencing Judas Iscariot and Oakton
column4: Va.'s politically unsavory Grand Belial's Key
column5: then spiraling inwards into Xasthur's and Leviathan's yawning one-man Calif. voids and the foundation-shattering entity that was San Fancisco's atmospheric time-stretchers Weakling-- USBM has somehow ended up
column6: at least in a stereotypical sense
column7: somewhere between Berkeley and Brooklyn.

column1: California is the more prolific of the two
column2: having given us Fell Voices
column3: Ludicra
column4: Bone Awl
column5: Volahn
column6: Ash Borer
column7: and by extension
column8: now-OGs Fauna and Wolves in the Throne Room
column9: as well as perhaps the most important American black metal band of all. Weakling's influence in particular cannot and will not ever be given enough credit in terms of the crop of bands that surfaced in the mid-to-late 2000's
column10: and it's nice to see that their legacy continues to sink its claws into newer acolytes. They're an easy comparison
column11: but it wouldn't be such a lazy move to automatically cite vocalist/guitarist John Gossard and co. in a USBM review if 2000's landmark LP Dead as Dreams weren't hardwired into the framework of seemingly every release with even a bit of blackness about it.

column2: Calif.
column3: quintet Ash Borer
column4: however
column5: are far from a Weakling ripoff-- they're not even a Wolves in the Throne Room ripoff
column6: or any sort of ripoff at all. While creating a sound that is distinctly American in execution
column7: the band's five members pull together to impart their own distinct sonic sensibilities onto their winding
column8: droning sagas; there is plenty of doom and gloom lurking beneath their second album Cold of Ages' malevolently sharp black metal riffs and grating howls. The nearly 17-minute-long opener
column9: ""Descended Lamentations""
column10: is a cold
column11: eerie offering
column12: chaotic and intense
column13: populated by harrowing melodies and desperate
column14: heaving wails. Ash Borer's accentual use of keys adds just the right touch of Northern chill to the proceedings
column15: especially during the track's opening moments. Meticulously timed and purposefully varied
column16: ""Descended Lamentations"" veers between hypnotic and harrowing; it wouldn't make sense as a shorter composition
column17: and each second has its purpose. ""Phantoms"" carries on into murkier territory; the chords are less bright
column18: the tempo slower
column19: the mood darker. The pace picks up
column20: as it always does
column21: and ""Phantoms"" rages against the dying of the light before sinking back into silence. The soft to loud dynamic is alive and well
column22: and translates nicely into Ash Borer's somber

column1: ""Convict All Flesh"" starts out drowning in reverb and droning along in single notes
column2: shuddering along as a dead man's crawl until a flurry of blastbeats appears and reanimates the doomed soul. A choir of sweet-voiced angels-- aka Jessica Way of San Francisco's Worm Ouroboros-- appears to intervene on his behalf
column3: but the Devil's after his due
column4: and no one is exempt. Roaring into the void
column5: hopeless and bereft
column6: Ash Borer are not a happy band at the best of times
column7: and when they really step back and allow the darkness to seep through
column8: it doesn't get much more lightless. Finaly
column9: closer ""Removed Forms"" is muted
column10: strung out along a single note and voiced by that same choir of clear
column11: high female voices until panicky chords signal the beginning of the end and all hell breaks loose. The last few minutes are entrancing
column12: and well worth the wait.

column1: Borrowing doom metal's syrupy pace and despondent air
column2: cozying up to distorted fuzz and droning reverb
column3: and refusing to veer too far from their ragged black metal core
column4: Ash Borer are many things at once
column5: and nothing but themselves. Their much ballyhooed earlier material (demos
column6: 2010's excellent split with Fell Voices
column7: and their 2011 self-titled LP) deserved the hype
column8: but with their second long player
column9: things have taken a darker turn. Their debut was rife with the slick
column10: crystalline chords that makes USBM sound so ""pretty
column11: but this time
column12:
Ash Borer have gotten their hands a little dirty: Cold of Ages is a big leap forward for a band that had already started out a few steps ahead of the pack.

An eponymous record is the kind of thing most bands get just one shot at. Fleetwood Mac had two. The band's self-titled 1968 debut was the product of what was
column2: at that time
column3: a London-based blues-rock four-piece fronted by guitarist/vocalist Peter Green; the second came out nine albums later
column5: and solidified their iconic lineup. Up until then
column6: the group had cycled through members
column7: gradually transforming into a more stable pop-rock unit. Christine McVie joined in 1970
column8: and a few years later
column9: they landed in Southern California where they hooked up with Lindsey Buckingham and Stevie Nicks
column10: folding in the meticulous pop theatrics and smoky confessionals that would make for three of the band's best-loved albums-- Fleetwood Mac
column11: Rumours
column12: and Tusk-- which tend to overshadow what came before.

column1: So if you're noted music supervisor Randall Poster and you're looking to pay tribute to a major rock'n'roll band for a Starbucks-sold cover-songs compilation
column2: there are much less slippery subjects than Fleetwood Mac. Just Tell Me That You Want Me aims to span Fleetwood Mac's whole existence-- not just the culturally ambient early Buckingham/Nicks stuff but also the murky hinterlands of the band's 17-album catalog. Given that scope
column3: it's a mission that
column4: when limited to just 17 tracks
column5: is all but destined to fail.

column2: Poster is one of the best in his field: He's been behind all of Wes Anderson's soundtracks
column3: as well as Todd Haynes' I'm Not There
column4: for which he wrangled three dozen artists' to take on the Bob Dylan songs over two discs. His Rave On Buddy Holly homage (released last year
column5: also via Starbucks' Hear Music label) was serviceable
column6: but drew from a catalog curtailed long ago. But Fleetwood Mac's songs are already so fully formed-- not just intricately-wrought as studio productions but
column7: as with many of the selections presented here
column8: fully ground into the collective mind of its target audience. Covers are tricky things; there's not so much a thin line between stenography and blasphemy as a wild rocky gulf of bemusement and horror and inexplicable pleasure.

column1: The record's first few tracks proceed with an admirable sense of reverence. There's no discernible order to the sequencing
column2: but the first is also the oldest Mac song present: ""Albatross""
column3: an instrumental that was a hit for the band's original incarnation
column4: is rendered huge and gasping by the Lee Ranaldo Band and J Mascis. Antony's faithfully elegiac take on ""Landslide"" comes next
column5: almost cruelly; it would have been a shame to bury it at the end
column6: but it just seems unfair to the artists tasked with following it. Lykke Li's ""Silver Springs""
column7: a few tracks later
column8: is the only other cut that competes; swathed in reverb almost thicker than the song's own emotional chainmail
column9: the track slowly builds up around her-- harmonies and menacing tambourines and a generally crushing fuzz-- but she stays so calm
column10: as if she herself is summoning up the storm that's enveloping her. She retains much of Nicks' torn-up

column1: The back half of the album is loaded with electronic material
column2: which isn't a bad idea in theory
column3: though none of it is particularly effective. In a reworking of ""Straight Back""
column4: from Mirage
column5: Washed Out blows out the original's disco-flocked production

column7: the second act seems designed as background music for suburban teen mall shoppers.

column1: Then there's the unfortunate mismatches: The New Pornographers did just about what you'd expect to the jaunty ""Think About Me""
column2: though it's hard not to yearn for what they could have done with ""Tusk"". That track was given instead to DFA Records' Crystal Ark

column1: Some of these tracks work only so long as you can push all memory of the originals from your mind. If I'd somehow never heard the original cut of ""Rhiannon""

column3: though

column5: stunned rage

column9: like the little swirl on the top of your Dairy Queen soft-serve. And what's true for her version is true for the collection as a whole. The original is a seduction; this is food-court flirtation.

column1: The fact that the collection is a bit of a mess is a shame

which rings true as ever: ""Never have I been a blue calm sea/ I have always been a storm.""

People tend to obsess over North Carolina's Spider Bags
column2: a nominally identified garage rock band that sputters into broken-down country and spirals into high-flying psychedelics from a firm base of petulant
column3: propulsive
column4: and fun three-minute rock tunes. To wit
column5: Titus Andronicus frontman Patrick Stickles used to perpetually call them the greatest band in the world. Some years ago
column6: when a DJ friend who'd moved several states away returned to the Carolinas for a weekend
column7: she learned that the Bags were performing at a nearby haunt and canceled all of her impending plans. In her mind
column8: at least
column9: the best local band ever-- the one with the shout-out-loud anthem called ""Waking Up Drunk"" and the frontman
column10: Dan McGee
column11: who sang about his demons with a conviction that made them the crowd's demons
column12: too-- were playing
column13: and she simply had to be there. And as colleague Marc Masters recently quipped online about the band's compulsive tunes
column14: ""And now to listen to Spider Bags & Apache Dropout constantly
column15: even when I'm not listening to them."" As their name implies
column16: when Spider Bags hook into you
column17: it's hard to shake the hold.

column1: The first two Spider Bags full-lengths depended on diversity. 2007's A Celebration of Hunger creeped through country turns that had more to do with Townes Van Zandt than whatever Little Steven plays on his show (""Lonely Man"" is the band's secret stunner) and occasionally climbed into the alt-country molds of Drive-By Truckers. The blistering rock'n'roll tracks were only part of the picture. They were more prominent on 2009's Goodbye Cruel World
column2: Hello Crueler World
column3: but there was still much more to be heard than fuzzy
column4: frenzied barnstormers-- banjo songs
column5: Crazy Horse-sized epics
column6: sad-eyed duets and baby-please pleas.

column2: the band's third album and their first for North Carolina imprint Odessa Records
column3: is their most stylistically cohesive to date. Rolling through 10 tracks in less than 35 minutes
column4: it delivers would-be rock hit after hit
column5: shifting away from that template only for the record's closing third. That's not to say that Shake My Head is stylistically stripped at all; rather
column6: those variations are woven into the charging songs rather than separated from them. ""Shawn Cripps Boogie""
column7: for instance
column8: is a xylophone-dotted instrumental played by a half-dozen guitarists
column9: but its almost post-rock surge and otherwise playful countenance make it feel less like a departure or deviation than a great if wordless Spider Bags tune. With McGee's mix of don't-leave-me protestations and fuck-you-then imprecations
column10: ""I'll Go Crazy"" is nothing if not a country song reworked for a rock band drunk on the idea of soul harmonies. ""Friday Night"" is surf music for the town's slouch
column11: too wasted to go to the beach with his friends and too sad to go home with his memories. Spider Bags have finally fit all their interests and eccentricities into one tight
column12: identifiable set. Shake My Head might not be their most surprising or inventive album to date
column13: but it's certainly their most irrepressible
column14: a record that seems suited and able to land its charms with a lot more people.

column2: since Shake My Head is the product of a band at a curious crossroads in its own history: After two frustrating experiences with full-length release schedules and press cycles

column4: too
column5: releasing a slew of unimpeachable 7""s but ultimately slowing the pace as an on-the-road
column6: in-the-studio work force. Co-founder and bassist Gregg Levy headed back to New Jersey
column7: committing to rejoin the band for tours while they recruited another bassist
column8: Steve Oliva
column9: to assume the role locally. When they headed west to Memphis to finally record Shake My Head
column10: Levy flew down to split bass duties with Oliva. Perhaps in recognition of that strange lineup situation
column11: Spider Bags used the Memphis sessions of Shake My Head-- and the long
column12: guest-heavy overdub process that followed-- as an excuse to invite a horde of friends over to the studio and capture a party as they made a record. The jangling if jilted ""Simona La Ramona"" pairs fuzz bass from Memphis legend Jack Oblivian with the distant Theremin peal of Chapel Hill songwriter Billy Sugarfix
column13: while opening blast ""Keys to the City"" hinges not only on multiple charging guitars but also backing vocals from
column14: as the liner notes put it
column15: ""The City of Memphis."" As you might expect
column16: the space around these songs is often filled with laughter and false starts and chatter not necessarily intended for the microphone-- friends
column17: hanging out
column18: sharing the spirit of these songs and probably spirits
column19: too. It's a sad-eyed celebration record.

column1: That atmosphere fits McGee's songs. He is a writer
column2: after all
column3: who is best when extending empathy for the dispossessed
column4: when he-- a married father at the helm of a great rock band-- writes about and for those who don't have it so good. Sure
column5: there's nonsense written into these lyrics
column6: too
column7: but McGee's perfectly able to express misery in an economical phrase or two. ""I'm a dog
column8: baby
column9: without an owner
column10: he sings on ""Simona La Ramona""
column11: bouncing into the rhyme with hope for the future. ""I can't keep a phone/ And I can barely pay rent/ And the car I own/ I only really own the dents
column12: he offers during the brilliant ""Shape I Was In""
column13: a breezy
column14: organ-backed tune that seems to treat despair like a necessity of life
column15: not a reason for exasperation. Above sizzling guitar lines
column16: boogie-woogie keys
column17: and flickering tambourine
column18: ""Standing on a Curb"" opens with what might seem to be a dismissive image of McGee ""waiting on some girl."" But as the song unfolds
column19: we learn that the person he's waiting on doesn't matter as much as the general feeling of being specifically sad about loving someone who could care less what curb you're standing on
column20: or if you're able to stand at all. The anxiety overruns any ambition he's ever had. ""I don't have anything else to do
column21: McGee admits. ""I'm looking at a picture of you.""

column2: of course
column3: he beats the shit out of the photo. Hell
column4: what else could he have done? And what else could you do
column5:
besides commiserate with and sing along to a record that turns problems into a party you'll wish you had attended.

Even when he's trilling in his signature falsetto
column2: Jukebox the Ghost frontman Ben Thornewill enunciates his lines with an exaggerated theatricality
column3: and the band's pop hooks arc with bold
column4: glossy grandeur. All of which means that listening to a song by the peppy piano-pop Brooklyn trio feels a little bit like stumbling unexpectedly into a Broadway musical (let's say Movin' Out; singer Ben Thornewill sings like a man who owns a Billy Joel record or two) at that precise moment when everyone breaks into song. If you're the sort of person who can suspend the necessary cynicism when this happens in the movies
column5: then maybe you'll go for their brand of hyperactively hooky power-pop. But if you have ever wondered such apt questions as
column6: ""How do these people know all the words?"" or ""When did they find the time to practice these dances steps?"" and ""Why wasn't I invited to the practices?"" you are probably the sort of person who should steer clear of their latest record
column7: Safe Travels.

column1: Drawing inspiration from piano-driven singer-songwriters (Thornewill cites Harry Nilsson as inspiration for the sparse closer ""The Spiritual"")
column2: synth-tinged power ballads
column3: and blue-eyed soul
column4: Jukebox the Ghost occupy a niche carved out by the continued cult success of Ben Folds' solo career
column5: though they lack his goofball wit. Bite and humor (and some other qualities that would earn the Nilsson comparison) aren't exactly in their wheelhouse
column6: and instead the tone of their music has only one setting: excessive earnestness. See
column7: for example
column8: ""Oh Emily""
column9: which is probably the most maddeningly passive-aggressive break-up song you'll hear this year. ""Oh
column10: Emily
column11: you're a funny girl
column12: and I didn't mean to break your heart
column13: guitarist Tommy Siegel sings with an apologetic shrug over a rosy glow of synths. ""But I'm lost in love with everyone."" That is
column14: of course
column15: a cloyingly euphemistic way of explaining how you fucked up
column16: and the overall sound of Safe Travels suffers from the same problem: It's paralyzingly afraid to offend.

column1: Safe Travels tackles themes of mortality and maturity (I know this because there's a song called ""Adulthood"")
column2: especially during its ballad-heavy middle section. Like the gospel influenced ""The Spiritual""
column3: ""Adulthood"" is actually a highlight. It's about the death of Thornewill's grandfather from lung cancer (""In my lungs I still feel young/ But my body won't play along"")
column4: and it benefits from a specificity of feeling. The similarly thuddingly titled slow-burner ""Dead""
column5: on the other hand
column6: relies too heavily on vagueness
column7: cliches
column8: and dorm room stoner philosophy to be genuinely moving. ""And if you're dead
column9: Siegel wonders at one point
column10: ""How do you know if you're really dead?""

column2: well
column3: let him wonder. Maybe this is an aptly deep thought for Jukebox's target demographic
column4: which is probably not going anywhere: As long as there are college freshmen who think Passion Pit are ""too weird
column5: people who prefer the ""Glee Version"" to the original and ABC TV producers looking to do segments about hip indie bands in Brooklyn
column6: there will be an audience for bands like Jukebox the Ghost
column7: who at least do this unoffensive brand of power-pap serviceably. But if you’re too much of a realist to believe in trick lighting
column8: happy endings or choreographed emotion
column9:
Safe Travels will probably leave you wishing for riskier terrain.

The Slumberland Records revival that's been happening over the past few years is a story of past and present. Renewed interest in the label is partially due to a new generation of bands (the Pains of Being Pure at Heart
column2: Crystal Stilts
column3: Veronica Falls) that have put out solid records on the California-by-way-of-D.C. imprint; it's also been kindled by reunion shows like Slumberland's 20th anniversary concerts and this year's Chickfactor 20 gigs.

column1: But even in the midst of all this nostalgia and revisiting
column2: certain gems of the label's back catalog remain unplundered. One such record is 1995's Everyone Must Touch the Stove
column3: which up until now was the sole LP from Washington
column4: D.C.-area trio Lorelei. It remains overlooked because it doesn't quite fit the narrative: In most corners
column5: ""Slumberland"" is still considered a synonym for ""dreamy"" or even ""twee
column6: but the immersive Stove is full of creeping
column7: diffuse post-rock nightmares. Still
column8: the fact that Lorelei haven't been one of the touchstones of the label's revival and continued influence shouldn't come as much of a surprise: they were misunderstood in their (very brief) heyday
column9: too. In a 2009 interview
column10: guitarist/singer Matt Dingee recalled something that happened when the Wedding Present's David Gedge
column11: a demigod of the early-90s indie pop circle
column12: caught a Lorelei show. After their set
column13: Gedge said to him
column14: ""I like your guitar sounds and everything
column15: but for me it's about writing songs.""

column1: Patient listeners will certainly echo Dingee's response: ""But we have songs."" Though their local compatriots included D.C. contemporaries and labelmates Black Tambourine
column2: Whorl
column3: and Lilys
column4: an appreciation of Lorelei demanded slightly different ears. A shoegaze influence is the common denominator in all these bands
column5: but Lorelei were more interested in creating detailed post-rock textures than melodic pop hooks. Drummer Davis White and bassist Stephen Gardner erect steady yet fluid supports for Dingee's distorted reveries
column6: in which elements of emo
column7: jazz
column8: and math rock occasionally bubble up. There are moments on Stove
column9: like ""Throwaway""
column10: that recall the kind of magic that post-rock sorcerers Disco Inferno were conjuring around this time across the pond: Dingee's guitars melt
column11: morph into sirens
column12: and blend with muffled voices picked up via radio frequencies. Which is another way that Lorelei went against the grain. A lot of DIY bands were interested in stripping their songs down to their most minimal elements and letting the seams show. Lorelei did just the opposite: they were three ordinary dudes casting large shadows and projecting epic illusions. Listening to Stove and their sprawling Asleep EP
column13: it's still hard to believe that there were only three people in the band.

column1: Lorelei dissolved and reformed under equally ordinary circumstances. In the mid 90s
column2: Dingee moved to California
column3: and a couple of years ago he moved back to the D.C. area; the band got back together just in time for the Slumberland 20th anniversary shows in 2009. Now
column4: almost two decades after their debut full-length
column5: comes their second LP
column6: Enterprising Sidewalks (most apt song title: ""Sorry For the Patience"")
column7: on which Lorelei's sound is as challenging
column8: immersive and adventurous as ever.

column1: The years have cooled off some of their emo leanings
column2: as they must. Compare the surreal
column3: off-kilter romanticism of Stove songs like ""Newsprint"" and ""Windmill"" (""She smiled as he placed his warm hands on her apple cheeks/ He places his foot in the corner of her mouth"") with Dingee's dry
column4: mock-bureaucratic delivery on ""Outside Through the Keyhole"" or ""Hammer Meets Tongs"" (""What we need's a better management plan/ And an enterprising sidewalk""). But in the moments when Dingee's vocals feel too monotone
column5: his strings pick up the slack-- as ever
column6: his guitar playing is far and away the most expressive element of Lorelei's music. ""Majority Stakes"" crescendos with soaring
column7: steely noise that transforms into aqueous arpeggios
column8: while the expansive ""Three Interlocking Screens"" gives the band space to experiment with all sorts of textures and tones. The tighter pop numbers are there too (""Wound Up""
column9: ""Sorry For the Patience"")
column10: but as ever Lorelei are at their best when they take the time to unfurl their more impressionistic ideas.

column2: hear another and I'm bored to tears
column3: Dingee drones on the album's most biting track
column4: ""Let Go of Our Ego"". Though it doesn't direct its malice towards anything or anyone in particular
column5: it could perhaps serve as a commentary on a few cultural concepts that have cropped up since Lorelei last put out a record: reality TV
column6: ""indie fame
column7: or internet-fueled overshares. The chorus certainly feels like a retaliation against that last one: ""I've got nothing to say today
column8: to you or anyone you know."" But as fittingly unceremonious and ego-free a record it is
column9: Enterprising Sidewalks proves that that statement isn't so. Even if it doesn't quite match the heights of Everyone Must Touch the Stove
column10: Enterprising Sidewalks gestures towards the more obscure corners of the band's (and the label's) back catalog
column11:
showing the next generation of Slumberland fans that the vault holds more than just sweet dreams.

column2: Roxy Music enjoyed enormous critical and commercial success
column3: but even so
column4: they and their art-school rock were admired more than trusted. American critics snipped at leader Bryan Ferry's arch romanticism
column5: while the Brit press considered the models Ferry squired and the suits he doffed and dubbed him ""Byron Ferrari"". Almost everyone affirmed that the band were great
column6: while disagreeing as to when

column8: the great achievement was 1982's farewell

column10: to the early
column11: playfully experimental albums Roxy released when Brian Eno was in the band
column12: playing androgyne peacock to Ferry's tailored lothario. Whether you see their development between those points as progress or cautionary tale
column13: it's easy to let this contrast define the band.

column6: Ferry invented a pop star. A sybarite with a plummy

column8: gliding through his own songs like they were parties he'd forgotten arriving at. A flying Dutchman of the jet set

column5: and more laconic ways. They restarted well. The glowering

column7: in particular

column9: a fatal difference. There are also moments

column11: where the entropic gloss is a feint to let heartbreaking loneliness get in close and floor you. The ultimate late Roxy Music song
column12: oddly

column14: released after John Lennon's murder. Here genuine loss is paid tribute by studied melancholy

column5: and that experimentation gave the early Roxy their identity. He's easier to spot on their flashy

But For Your Pleasure is a greater testament to Eno's importance: it's hard to imagine an album that better exploits the tension between two fast-diverging creativities. Its best tracks play games with sincerity and emotional tone: the preposterous schmaltz of ""Beauty Queen"" resolving into real anguish
column8: while ""In Every Dream Home an Heartache"" lurches from creepiness to hilarity. Speculating on what would have happened if Eno had stayed with Roxy Music past two albums is wistful fun. But once you've squeezed nine-minute krautrock jam ""The Bogus Man"" and light-footed pop manifesto ""Do the Strand"" into the same space

column6: the gothic folly of ""Tryptych""
column7: the gentle reflection of ""Three and Nine"". None of these survived the three-year gap. The box set has two discs of non-album material-- singles
column8: mixes and edits-- including all the instrumentals they put on B-Sides. Relaxed studio goof-offs (""Hula Kula""
column9: ""Your Application's Failed"") give way to portentousness (""South Downs"") as Ferry

column12: and it's a shame. There were trade-offs

column14: swooning radio choruses-- ""Dance Away""
column15: ""Oh Yeah""
column16: and ""More Than This"" fully deserve their thrones in AOR Valhalla.

column3: and the weariness of hedonism-- will be pop-relevant as long as self-conscious twentysomethings get famous

column5: usually wonderful and more affecting that you might have expected. But it's also fascinating as the story of a gradual hardening of an elegant
column6: enigmatic persona

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/18232/homepage_large.7e331341.jpg|Pink Keys|30454.0|Alice Cohen|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Olde English Spelling Bee']|2012-08-13 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:08:35.723354|"

After a very quiet 2011
column2: the curious Brooklyn label Olde English Spelling Bee is relaunching with Alice Cohen's second full-length of 2012. Since the 1970s
column3: she's fronted numerous groups
column4: some of which had brief flirtations with commercial success: Philadelphia funk outfit Fun City
column5: new wave also-rans the Vels
column6: or the Roadrunner-inked grunge act Die Monster Die. Cohen is almost certainly the only artist to have been on the same labels as Nickelback and Oneohtrix Point Never.

column2: while Pink Keys sounds like a perfect fit within OESB's body of sci-fi synth pop
column3: Cohen's considerable history doesn't form a part of any greater narrative for the label. It's simply a hooky
column4: immersive
column5: and occasionally goofy record of people sounding like computers and computers making imperfect sounds-- the chewy basslines
column6: Linn drum machines
column7: and marshmallow synth tones certainly qualify it as ""retro
column8: but it's hard to imagine a time when it could have sounded futuristic. ""Dead Leaves in Milk Glass"" takes its title as sonic inspiration
column9: brittle acoustic guitars and a miniaturized synth run suggesting Nite Jewel's recent forays into merging coffee shop balladry with a kosmische fetish
column10: but with stronger melodic presence. Elsewhere
column11: Pink Keys situates itself in a middle class of 1980s electronic pop: Typically we hear bands recall the absurdly expensive studio creations of the time (Twin Shadow
column12: Ice Choir) or go to the opposite end and embrace the crudest technology possible (the Soft Moon
column13: Black Marble). The songs on Pink Keys are built with impressive machinery
column14: but the kind that risk failure. On something like ""La Fete Etrange""
column15: what could easily pass for pompous hair-metal licks get turned into blunt synth blurts
column16: charming with minor malfunctions. There's a slight awkwardness to the purple funk of ""Silent Movie"" where the synths don't bounce quite right
column17: but it nonetheless finds its own groove.

column1: Pink Keys possesses not so much with a personality as it does a presence. Cohen stacks and refracts her nasal
column2: youthful vocal lines
column3: which tumble over each other and harmonize imperfectly. Beyond her contributions
column4: the album is a community affair
column5: enlisting the help of mixer Chris Moore
column6: percussionist Thor Harris
column7: and lo-fi R&B recluse Autre Ne Veut. As trivial as these connections might initially seem
column8: Cohen stands to benefit from any sort of grounding. Pink Keys occasionally lapses into the kind of crystal visions that make perfect sense solely to the people who come up with them-- witness the hook during the cosmic honky-tonker ""Mauve Mood"": ""Too much static on the astral phone in a mauve mood and a lilac zone."" There is also a song called ""Salamander's Tale""
column9: which at least has a title that gives you fair warning of what to expect from it. I think Cohen gets it
column10: though. On ""La Fete Etrange""
column11: she sings
column12: ""I'd like to walk around in your world
column13: but I can't live it for you
column14: and while it's just a little nonsensical
column15: it's something of an M.O. for Pink Keys-- to create your own personal world
column16:
and acknowledge the risk that its rules might not make sense to everyone.

'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2012-08-13 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:08:36.434409|"

The R&B twin sister duo Nina Sky are not an internet success story in the traditional sense. Their audience has not grown in size since their 2004 major-label debut album sold over 300
column3: 000 copies. It has in fact shrunk considerably
column4: so much so that the group's two albums since then-- 2010's The Other Side and now Nicole and Natalie-- have been self-released. But as their audience has boiled down
column5: Nina Sky have gained the freedom to experiment
column6: to chase their slippery notions of pop music around the globe. In doing so
column7: they threw themselves into strands of pop-- dancehall
column8: reggaeton
column9: R&B
column10: UK bass-- that have long interacted with each other. There were various delays and abruptions along the way (especially with their aborted 2007 album Starting Today)
column11: but the duo could teach a class on how sustain the integrity of your art after being dropped by a major label.

column1: Nicole and Natalie finds Nina Sky dabbling in radio-ready Europop. It turns out that
column2: too
column3: suits them just fine. The album wedges a midpoint in between the headrush dance-pop of Robyn
column4: honorary European Kylie Minogue and the brooding
column5: dance-inflected R&B of someone like Dawn Richard. The album's shortcomings aren't rooted in anything aesthetic
column6: but simple math: At eight songs
column7: Nina Sky needed to hit just about every single one out of the park. Unfortunately
column8: their aim isn't always true.

column1: Saccharine ballad ""Starting Today"" opens the album in a bizarre place-- it almost feels as if the tracklist was accidentally flipped. Worse
column2: though
column3: is the song itself. It's meant as an empowering break-up kiss-off
column4: but the sentiment is sorely underwritten. It instead comes off like a failed early-00s graduation tear-jerker. ""Comatose"" (""Let's keep going till we're comatose"") is similarly thin-- its twinkling
column5: weightless beat is a waste of progressive Brooklyn producer Brenmar
column6: and neither sister has the voice to carry the song. The same can be said for ""Never Kissed You""
column7: another downtempo track that just drags along. The beat
column8: produced by R&B veteran Salaam Remi

column1: The willingness to extend beyond beat-matching and showing off a personal bounty of unreleased dubplates

column4: aka Steve Bishop

column3: as Bishop stretches his legs and dazzles by weaving cut after choice cut seamlessly. The writeup that accompanies the LuckyMe mix refers to his mixing style as ""techno-tight

column7: I still check my iTunes to make sure it didn't freeze. The overall mood varies from hard-hitting to spacious to enormously elegant

column11: and you're locked.

column1: Possibly the most exciting aspect of Fabriclive 64 is how it functions as a fascinating survey of what's been taking place in the ever-mutating UK bass scene over the past few years. It's not comprehensive (with the ever-changing face of bass
column2: how could it be?) but its selection of sonic permutations-- the colorful swarm of SBTRKT
column3: MikeQ's heavy-hitting ballroom fire
column4: Night Slugs co-head Bok Bok's house-infused work with Dutch producer and Rush Hour affiliate Tom Trago-- more than communicate the scene's constantly shifting eccentricities. Referring to Fabriclive 64 as a snapshot
column5: though

column7: as the dusty UK Garage of Dem 2 and Steve Gurley's gorgeous 2-step rework of Basement Jaxx's ""Red Alert"" (easily the mix's most surprising source of elation) fit perfectly alongside more current fare. So there's history here
column8: represented both distantly and in the type that's been made before the eyes and ears of those who have been watching over the last few years.

column2: though
column3: would be unjustly ignoring just how much fun it is to listen to
column4: how easily and pleasantly it moves

An ironic occurrence regarding the meteoric rise of what the mainstream media calls ""EDM"" is that the massive popularity accompanied by the boom has only caused folks to draw deeper lines in the sand. <i>Here's my music
column6: the real kind
column7: enjoy whatever it is you're listening to. That isn't what you're calling it-- this is more like what you're referencing
column8: and you probably wouldn't get it
column9: anyway. This snobbery has existed in the dance community for eons (and its gatekeeping fires have been stoked by the wonders of the internet
column10: naturally)
column11: but it seems especially dangerous-- and
column12: it must be said
column13: staunchly classist-- in recent times. I'd like to think that anyone would like Fabriclive 64. Not because they'll learn something
column14: or because it's impeccably hip. Simply
column15: rather
column16: because it's good music
column17:
and it doesn't take a genius to see the value in that.

When war drove him from Sierra Leone to New York
column2: Janka Nabay was one of the most popular musicians in his homeland. He'd been one of the primary performers in the revival and fusioning of bubu music
column3: an ancient folk form that had survived the 18th-century introduction of Islam to the country. At a time when the Sierra Leonean music scene was dominated by imported forms
column4: and especially reggae
column5: the old bubu rhythms injected an energizing shot of local flavor into pop music. For a time
column6: Nabay used to his music to speak out against the country's spiraling civil war
column7: but when rebels co-opted his music during their destructive drives into rural villages
column8: he found himself with few options but to leave.

column2: he searched for collaborators while working as a fry cook
column3: and found them not in the Sierra Leonean ex-pat community
column4: but in Brooklyn's indie rock scene. The Bubu Gang
column5: Nabay's backing band on En Yay Sah
column6: comprises members of Skeletons
column7: Chairlift
column8: Highlife
column9: and Saadi
column10: and their method of collaboration was simple: Nabay showed them the rhythms he was working with and the songs he'd written
column11: and he turned them loose. Jon Leland's drums hold down the heavily syncopated bubu beats
column12: the music's strongest tie to tradition
column13: and the rest of the band cooks up a backing for Nabay that sounds so intensely modern it's practically futuristic. Guitarist Doug Shaw plays no rhythm
column14: instead adding color to the music with mildly psychedelic leads that focus on melody when Nabay isn't singing and recede to tonal washes during the verses.

column1: Nabay's weathered but agile voice is the kind of instrument that would likely sound at home on a sparse field recording
column2: so it's curious how well it integrates with Jason McMahon's sleek-toned bass and Michael Gallope's bright
column3: tropical keyboard sounds. The integration is helped by the backing vocals of Syrian-born Boshra AlSaadi
column4: who sings answering phrases to Nabay's leads and functions essentially as part of the rhythm section. Her repeated vocal line on ""Ro Lungi"" becomes the song's primary hook
column5: complementing and reinforcing the keyboard phrase that serves as the other hook and gives shape to Nabay's rapid-fire lead vocals.

column1: Nabay sings in four languages on the record: his native Temne
column2: a syncretic combination of English and African languages that originated in Western Hemisphere slave communities called Krio
column3: and small amounts of English and Arabic. It reflects his country's complicated history
column4: as well as his own emergence into a wider world from his homeland's small music scene. Bubu music is ancient; En Yay Sah offers a powerfully modern
column5:
cosmopolitan introduction to its complex and vibrant rhythms.

column2: the long-running project of Brendan Perry and Lisa Gerrard
column3: are inextricably linked to the 4AD that defined a different generation. Not the current one of Bon Iver or Grimes
column4: but the one of Bauhaus
column5: This Mortal Coil
column6: and the Cocteau Twins-- 1980s art goth of a particular kind. But neither label nor their bands sought that tag. And since Dead Can Dance's music incorporated sounds from around the globe and across the centuries
column7: the description seems particularly limiting. Anastasis

column9: finds Dead Can Dance firmly in their comfort zone
column10: at a time when neither Gerrard nor Perry should feel they have anything left to prove.

column1: Dead Can Dance always avoided a curatorial or purist approach to global music
column2: and that trend continues here. They're as open to new technologies and recording possibilities as they are to ancient instruments like the yangqin and the bodhrán
column3: but they also eschew the collision of samples and beats that often defines other experimenters in the field. But over time
column4: the influence of Brendan Perry and Lisa Gerrard has reached far and wide. From Future Sound of London's early techno landmark ""Papua New Guinea""
column5: which samples Gerrard's voice
column6: to cover versions by bands such as arty metal types the Gathering and the more experimentalist impulses of recent bands like Prince Rama-- not to mention Gerrard's own now extensive work on a wide variety of film soundtracks -- Dead Can Dance's approach to sound has resonated widely.

column2: Anastasis is a logical progression from the band's mid-90s albums as well as Brendan and Gerrard's respective solo work since. There's nothing here quite as jawdroppingly melodramatic or proclamatory as old classics such as ""Anywhere Out of the World"" or ""Host of Seraphim""
column3: where Perry and Gerrard's vocal strengths were matched with the sense of vast spaces
column4: agog and in awe. But Anastasis often comes close
column5: especially with the concluding ""Return of the She-King"" and ""All in Good Time"". Gerrard's breathtaking vocal range remains strong
column6: while Perry's deeper
column7: ruminative voice still feels less like a singing brogue than a calm invocation of ancient knowledge.

column1: The split between Perry and Gerrard's singing parts remains distinct not only vocally
column2: but for the different subjects each explores. That could be a stumbling block in other hands
column3: but always seems to bring out the best where these two are concerned. Perry's forthright mysticism on songs like ""Amnesia"" and ""All in Good Time"" return to the origin of the band's name
column4: the idea of awakening a greater consciousness. On strong opening ""Children of the Sun""
column5: strings
column6: crisp rolling drums
column7: and elegant keyboards suggest an ancestral
column8: courtly ritual
column9: though lyrically Perry runs the risk of creating a naive paean to flower power. Yet it's precisely his controlled delivery and lack of irony-- even with a nursery-rhyme nodding couplet like ""All the queen's horses and all the king's men/ Will never put these children back together again""-- that transforms the song into something with palpable force.

column4: substituting comprehensive language with a melodic
column5: exploratory rapture conveyed by her range alone-- defines her lead performances in turn
column6: first appearing to the full on ""Anabasis""
column7: her rich warmth flowing across everything from strings that suggest Egyptian orchestras to electric guitar to
column8: at one breathtaking moment
column9: near silence.

column1: There's a suffused steadiness that steers the album

column4: the beguiling sway of ""Opium""

It's a universal pop truth that songs about the thrill of the club rarely live up to the urgent abandon induced by a night's hard dancing. Two years ago
column2: Swedish duo Niki and the Dove-- aka Malin Dahlström and Gustaf Karlöf-- struck a rare and peculiar seam with the release of their debut single

column4: Ease My Mind""

column6: Dahlström pleads
column7: ""I want to forget
column8: I want lights to blind me... I want to disappear
column9: imploring the DJ to let calm flood her soul by playing a jam that takes her back to a time laced with romantic triumphs. ""DJ…"" is spectacular because it doesn't just feel like a song made for your own euphoric moments in the wee hours; rather
column10: it's a force that bolts your heart to Malin's and forces it to pulse along with hers. Two years in the making
column11: Niki and the Dove's debut album
column12: Instinct
column13: has a borderline greedy hit-rate where all 12 of its songs (not counting the two bonus numbers on the U.S. release) manage to be equally arresting

column20: history-making passions.

column3: and 11 of these 12 songs have already been given away for free online
column4: or released in EP form. Only the dramatic oriental strut of ""Love to the Test"" is truly new (though new versions of previously heard songs are present)
column5: a full-bodied seduction where Dahlström catches a guy's eye across the room
column6: sasses him into giving her his number along with the time
column7: then calls ""Touchdown!"" asking
column8: ""Are you ready for this woman?"" hand undoubtedly on hip. The lack of new material does make Instinct feel like a consolidation effort
column9: perhaps aimed at grasping for the continued attentions of newer fans
column10: but that's certainly not a complaint. If anything
column11: it's a justification of sorts for the sea of Björk comparisons that's followed the duo since the beginning. Although invoking the Icelandic innovator is usually ham-fisted shorthand for ""kooky woman pop
column12: there are plenty of experimental leanings here-- and in Niki and the Dove's live show-- that suggest a weirder future for the pair
column13: in similar fashion to how Björk began her solo career in the mid 1990s.

column1: There's not quite an ""It's Oh So Quiet"" on Instinct
column2: but there are plenty of enormous
column3: joyous moments that come close enough to that sensation
column4: with plenty more going on than in your common or garden banger. The victorious ""Tomorrow"" opens the LP
column5: followed by ""The Drummer""
column6: where a high-pitched sonar blip needles through thundering synthesizer sashays
column7: Dahlström's drum-like heart powering her assault across a topography of nerves and difficult decisions. ""The Fox"" jabs like a razor-sharp ballet
column8: bloody cello chopping beneath gloaming synthesizers as Dahlström asks a four-legged beast to bury to bury her fears so that she might sleep. The dark grind of ""Under the Bridges"" transports her back to a dark and dangerous zone on a city's edge where a friend confesses a secret that remains untold. It doesn't matter what it is-- there's something about the visceral
column9: elemental nature of Niki and the Dove's production that takes you right there
column10: shivering and pulling the collar of your coat close as wind whips under the viaduct.

column2: too
column3: where you're a gooseberry gamely drawing hearts in the window condensation as the protagonists get ""married in a taxi
column4: Dahlström steeling her heart against getting too attached by invoking the scorn of Stevie Nicks circa Bella Donna. It's not difficult to spot the fact that the situations described in most of Niki and the Dove's songs take place at night
column5: which is rarely a zone of abject fear for the characters within
column6: but a canvas against which to conquer anxieties and triumph romantically. On the soft
column7: Prince-like stroke of ""In Our Eyes""
column8: Dahlström sings
column9: ""I'm the night now
column10: but I will shelter you
column11: as if she's a wise sage offering protection. If the night is an embrace in which to seek succor and work out complex thoughts
column12: then the nightclub of Niki and the Dove's breakout hit seems by default a kind of transcendental

column15:
that they've made an album against which it's easy to imagine having similar experiences.

If there's one thing that unites ""King Tim III"" with the latest thing to show up on DatPiff
column2: and covers nearly every major rap movement in between
column3: it's the idea that the person holding the mic demands to be heard. The MC could be the runner-up in a liar's contest or the realest thing alive
column4: a complex abstractionist or a to-the-point all-hooks shouter
column5: a callow youngster or a restless veteran. And no matter what
column6: that mic is in that hand because someone needs to present an identity to the world. What they almost never do
column7: by necessity over just about everything else
column8: is deliberately obscure that voice. Burying it in the mix
column9: dialing it down to a background murmur
column10: running it through contradictory
column11: vague themes that seem ambiguous in intent and delivery: these are things that threaten to cut an MC off from a real human connection with an audience
column12: especially a newly arriving one that's taking a chance on a relative newcomer based on hearsay and association.

column2: Raw Money Raps
column3: breaks that cardinal rule repeatedly. And that this leads to a fascinating enigma of a record rather than an alienating slog is some kind of minor miracle. Jae comes with an enthusiastic co-sign from Flying Lotus
column4: and the L.A.-via-Chicago producer/MC has the sort of classic demos-to-indie-breakthrough career path laid out that should continue to do him good when it comes to cultivating his more self-directed experimental tendencies. But Raw Money Raps isn't one of those easy-access phenom artifacts that explodes out of nowhere and spawns a sea of instant-cult hashtags. It's the kind of record that seems engineered to throw people off
column5: keep them wondering
column6: and make them try and connect some dots of stylistic influence that lead into places that don't entirely seem attached to anything else.

column1: Jae seems to fit in the context of a producer-as-MC rather than vice-versa. His tendency to focus more on beat tapes than lyrical exploits early in his career has led to a style that uses his production as a filter that he channels day-to-day concepts through until they become something more personal. With the exception of ""Cat Fight""-- a Flying Lotus beat that rides on chipmunk vocals
column2: head-swimming strings
column3: and distorted Pam Grier clips that resembles a Madlib track so closely it almost feels like an inside joke-- Raw Money Raps is a fine demonstration of how far Jae's willing to push experimentation in hip-hop production while still leaving something recognizable in his wake.

column2: ""Tourist""
column3: and ""Greetings"" have the familiar base of Left Coast blunted sample-driven abstraction
column4: but it makes the loops' seams even more fractured
column5: turning straightforward beats into slightly-off rhythms that expand the traditional boundaries of hip-hop meter with their elasticity. The stuff that hews more closely to modern digital-meets-analog production does so subversively. Like how ""Guns Go Off"" takes the staggered build-up that usually gets saved for a track's intro and makes it the entire backbone. And while we're thankfully past the point where classic-rock allusions are necessary to sell a hip-hop record's psychedelic bonafides
column6: the pre-Dark Side Pink Floyd-style keyboard-and-piano haze of ""Ignorant Mask"" and the VU-adjacent distorted twang in ""One Herb"" reveal another fitting branch in his production lineage.

column1: Jae's character as an MC can be just as slippery. This is an artist who frontloads his album with universal-enough statements
column2: like the make-ends-or-else observations of ""Guns Go Off""
column3: the spiritual-minded
column4: salaam-delivering ""Greetings""
column5: and the youth-struggle pull of ""Leaders"". But he gets gradually more idiosyncratic
column6: until by the end he's delivering rambling half-heard conversations about King Kong tactics (""Guerilla (Evolution Pt. 1)"") and proposing myth-killing for the sake of community solidarity (""Hercules Versus the Commune""). Things start going deep into the outer reaches at about the halfway mark
column7: where ""Money and Food"" leads into ""Wires"". The former track is one of those self-conscious club-rap pastiches that might sound like it's goofing on the tropes of the style if it didn't sound so much like Jae's actually wanting to sincerely try it on. The latter is a reverbed-to-oblivion swoon of off-beat delivery that sounds like it's being reeled off inside a waterlogged nuclear reactor; you can make out maybe half his lines
column8: if that. If you're a fiend for quotables
column9: you might get frustrated. There's this quality to his voice that makes it impossible to separate it from the music it's embedded in
column10: or the words from the beats. And it sometimes means recalibrating your ears so the non-verbal aspects of the music take precedence and you open yourself up to let the actual lyrics sneak up on you. It's hip-hop as dream logic.

column1: Jae is just as interested in treating his voice as an instrument to be manipulated as he is in actually putting literal messages across
column2: and if that makes what could be his more allusive moments frustratingly vague
column3: it clicks well as sheer music. His voice itself is a bit low-energy
column4: but in a way that actually has some personality to it. And in doubling itself up with pitch-shifted shadows
column5: running it through grainy home-tape murk or swaddling it in shuddering bass
column6: that voice gets an edge to it that hints at deeper things beneath even the most well-worn clichés. Raw Money Raps is immaculately constructed as identity crises go
column7: and there's an uncontrived honesty that feels more like someone working through a multifaceted outlook on life than testing his options for which crowd to play to. Even if you have to strain to catch that voice
column8: its presence still has weight and meaning
column9:
whether it's unfiltered consciousness or some elusive subliminal subtext. A lot of people talk loud and say nothing; Jeremiah Jae finds strength in the inverse.

It's hard to imagine music less in tune with indie rock values (or just plain rock values) circa 2012 than whatever it is the Locust is doing on Molecular Genetics from the Gold Standard Labs
column3: a collection of obscurities that packs 44 songs into almost as many caterwauling
column4: grinding
column5: ugly-ass minutes. Screeching bursts of arrhythmic synth noise? Microseconds of groove suddenly obliterated by a minute of hairy blast beats? Torturous polyp-producing screams? Fucked-up time signatures that would give migraines to all three members of Rush? These sounds are not doing big business on the summer festival circuit.

column1: Not that greedy-eyed A&R men were grooming the Locust for stardom 15 years ago either
column2: but weirdly I knew a lot of people who saw them as the fashion-conscious and crossover-hungry version of the hardcore underground's ultra-violent streak. With scene politics blessedly in the rearview of my life
column3: this take seems patently insane to me now. Maybe it was the goofy onstage costumes or the knowingly kitschy packaging. Because otherwise
column4: how could anyone listen to this stuff and think ""sell-out"" unless they'd fallen so far down the extreme music rabbit hole that anything less than total sensory assault felt like pop?

column2: canny marketing might be the only explanation for how these guys
column3: as ferocious and uncompromising as any of their peers
column4: found themselves as the deranged cousin to the screamo explosion of the early 21st century. This was music so intrinsically alienating that it could only ever hope to appeal to a small coterie of pain-addicts and assorted other masochists. One did not buy records by Spazz or Crossed Out or even the Locust because they wanted to make nice with their wider peer group. Here's how your ""standard"" Locust tune goes: The band screams and bashes for a few seconds
column5: pulling tricky extreme metal moves with a hardcore band's looseness and brute force. Then everything drops out for a goofily sturm-und-drang breakdown
column6: or keyboards that sound like incidental music from some schlocky 1950s sci-fi flick. Some more bashing and screaming
column7: and we're out in less time than it takes to microwave a defrosted frozen burrito.

column2: occasionally they throw the creepy-crawly electronics up front or at the rear for a change of scenery
column3: which with stuff this potentially monochromatic is important. From this collection: ""Moth-Eaten Deer Head"" comes over like a horror movie in miniature
column4: the shift from the intro of wheezy keys to the full-on roar of the song itself being the moment where the protagonist throws open the bedroom door to find the whole place drenched in gore. Best is when they actually solder the electronics into the flesh of the songs. ""Well I'll Be a Monkey's Uncle"" opens with a shrill announcement from some alien Emergency Broadcast System
column5: but it's also got one of the record's best riffs
column6: even if it happens to be played on a tortured synth set-up.

column1: All of these four-dozen-plus blasts from the id are head-wrecking
column2: dizzying
column3: pick your disorientating adjective at will. And not just because they're usually over before you can grasp any sense of their herky-jerky structures: It's because the Locust still try to pack as many mood swings
column4: tempo shifts
column5: sonic zigzags
column6: and genre curveballs into their briefer-than-brief running times as possible
column7: all while never letting up on the aggro and abrasion. ""How to Become a Virgin""'s ridiculously fast stop-start drumming still manages to punch some of heavy rock's traditional catharsis buttons. They even manage their own bug-eyed take on the multi-part rock epic with ""Flight of the Wounded Locust""
column8: operatic and positively indulgent at almost three minutes long

column1: Calling these songs ""obscurities"" is a bit of a joke in itself. They may have been released on relatively hard-to-find vinyl at the time
column2: but they're only a few shades more primitive than stuff on 2003's Plague Soundscapes
column3: the album that found them listed on the same accounting ledgers as Tom Waits. The Locust's later stuff may have enmeshed the electronics and the grind with a little extra finesse and ambition
column4: and it was certainly recorded a hell of a lot better
column5: all of which meant you could almost mistake them for a spazzier and less Hot Topic-friendly version of the Blood Brothers. Not so much here. Sometimes the murk on Genetics means the painful high-end chirpiness of the keyboards is the only thing with any definition
column6: and they're not much interested in reaching out to the kids so much as musically smacking them around. But their basic attack on their quasi-major albums remained the same as on their first album: 1998's The Locust
column7: collected here
column8: which was ""underground"" thanks to both its label and the fact that it sounds like it was recorded at the bottom of Buffalo Bill's basement.

column1: The Locust clearly know that the only way to avoid coming off like novelty music for grindcore kids is to play both sides of their shtick as straight-faced as possible
column2: and with as much brutalist conviction as they can muster. Which isn't to say it still might not hit you as novelty music
