column8: and slightly more ""accessible"" albums. For those of us who delight in gross-outs and wacko caterwauling and oppressive noise for its own sake

Genetics is a lo-fi and hideous laugh riot.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/18183/homepage_large.3e765c84.jpg|Nothing Bad Will Ever Happen|28127.0|Dignan Porch|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Captured Tracks']|2012-08-10 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:08:40.842175|"

Here's the elevator pitch for Dignan Porch: Did you like indie rock in the 1990s? Great
column2: they do too. Enjoy. Because you can name the first 10 bands off the dome that fit into your idea of what ""indie rock in the 90s"" meant
column3: and something on Nothing Bad Will Ever Happen will probably sound like each one of them. But they can't exactly be pegged as 90s revivalism
column4: because that term implies not just worship
column5: but a kind of evangelical zeal that Dignan Porch lack. You can argue how much they ever courted a traditional idea of ""success
column6: but it's absurd to say Pavement or Guided By Voices or Yo La Tengo ever lacked ambition or failed to convey their own personalities within their music. Dignan Porch don't have a grip on those things quite yet. So this feels like rock music that abides by ambient's goal of creating a respectful and effective alternative to silence. No matter how much care and craft went into it
column7: you ultimately feel like its creators intentionally are trying to avoid being noticed.

column1: Nothing Bad Will Ever Happen is technically the second record made by Dignan Porch
column2: but the first in which ""Dignan Porch"" refers to a five-piece band rather than main singer-songwriter Joe Walsh. The production gets a significant upgrade from wooly fuzz to ""scruffy
column3: keyboardist Hayley Akins' vocals become a welcome counterpoint
column4: and the songs are allowed to meander amiably. It's actually fascinating just how baseline Dignan Porch get here: Nothing Bad Will Ever Happen certainly doesn't sound expensive
column5: but by no means is it lo-fi. It's hummable
column6: but the melodic progressions most of these songs follow failproof them. You can make out some of Walsh's lyrical themes-- drugs
column7: girls
column8: general bummer-ness-- but rarely do they follow an emotional trajectory. Walsh's vocals in and of themselves are indicative of an everyman middle ground. He's occasionally obscured by the production
column9: but not in a way that appears to be a conscious atmospheric choice as opposed to one determined by the record's budget.

column2: it just comes down to Dignan Porch writing songs that are no better or no worse than most of their peers. ""Picking Up Dust"" and ""Darkness"" are equally jaunty and scuffed-up in a manner that's expected of something on Woodsist
column3: where they'd be undoubtedly overshadowed by Woods' idiosyncratic production of the same kind of material. The guitar leads on the sunburned ""Pink Oil"" recall maybe five different tracks from On Fire
column4: but the song as a whole lacks a real sense of place or perspective. And of course
column5: a UK band making predominantly American music on a hip indie label has to reckon with Yuck's pitch-perfect debut from last year doing this exact thing with stronger hooks
column6: more distinctive lyrics
column7: and musicality with far more body and resistance.

column1: It'd be nice to know what moves Dignan Porch as artists as opposed to mere listeners
column2: but they don't seem all that caught up in giving much of themselves. If Dignan Porch happen to find you as opposed to the other way around
column3: it's a pretty easy record to make the best of. They're the opening band you actually kinda enjoyed even though you showed up too early by mistake
column4:
the album you half remember liking when it was playing in a friend's car.

column1: The first and most important thing about the soundtrack to David Lynch's surreal 1977 cult film masterpiece is that it's not like any other soundtrack in your collection. This is no ""music from and inspired by"" set and it doesn't gather orchestral cues from the film's score. Eraserhead is a sound track (two words) in the literal sense. It contains 38 minutes of the sound that accompanies the 89-minute film's picture. When you are listening to this LP
column2: you are hearing a movie. And it works
column3: because Lynch and his late collaborator
column4: Alan Splet
column5: had a rare ear for the immersive and emotional possibilities of sound. The sound design in Lynch's films is consistently brilliant
column6: brimming with details that enhance the mood and further the narrative. And here on Eraserhead-- Lynch's first feature
column7: most personal film
column8: and in many ways the strangest movie he ever made-- his and Splet's aural genius was already fully formed. Working with the analog technology available in the 1970s
column9: they created a richly textured and evocative world.

column1: The narrative details of Lynch's movie aren't essential to this set
column2: but they do help to put the album into context. Eraserhead tells the story of Henry Spencer
column3: a strange and quiet man with bushy hair who goes about his business in a parallel universe with a skewed relationship to our own reality. The streets in Henry's neighborhood are empty and dark
column4: but you can hear dogs barking in the distance and you feel like something unpleasant might be lurking around every corner. Somewhere out of sight
column5: enormous boilers and blast furnaces are constantly churning
column6: belching soot into the sky and pushing tendrils of steam into cramped one-room apartments. It's a lonely
column7: menacing place
column8: modeled in part from Lynch's memories of his time living in a rough neighborhood in Philadelphia. Eventually
column9: Henry finds that his girlfriend Mary has given birth to...what
column10: exactly
column11: is never clear. ""They're still not sure it is a baby!"" she cries at one point on the soundtrack. Lynch and Splet render this setting with a varied mix of creaks
column12: rumbles
column13: hisses
column14: and roars. Theirs is a place of polluting industry
column15: clacking trains
column16: dangerous electrical whirrs
column17: and a screaming infant from the unknown.

column2: you could file Eraserhead next to the ice cold drift of Thomas Köner's Permafrost
column3: the tape-heavy pieces found on the first Godspeed You! Black Emperor album
column4: the subliminal voice and sound-effect rumble of Robert Ashely's Automatic Writing
column5: and the fuzzed-out radio transmissions of Music for Nitrous Oxide-era Stars of the Lid. Throbbing Gristle's ""Hamburger Lady"" channels a comparable nightmare
column6: the swampiest and most decayed bits of Brian Eno's On Land might be found somewhere inside this world
column7: and you could imagine the metallic drones of Nurse With Wound's Soliloquy for Lilith leaking out of Henry's floorboards. Eraserhead is dark ambient
column8: in other words
column9: a few years before that term had come into wide use. And despite its origins as the sound component of a film
column10: it works terrifically well as music
column11: provided your definition extends to the artists mentioned above. You'll hear some funny dialog about things like ""man-made chickens"" here and there
column12: delivered in that distinctively Lynchian sing-songy deadpan. But the album as a whole is something you sink into
column13: a shadowy vision of a frightening place.

column2: two more traditionally musical elements are found on the album. One recurring motif is the use of solo organ pieces from the 1930s played by Harlem jazz legend Fats Waller. The creaking organ tones
column3: played by a man from years ago on a wheezing mechanical device
column4: form a natural complement to the sound effects; they cycle in and out
column5: bringing to mind a cracked memory of another time or place that never quite comes into the focus. And then there is the song ""In Heaven""
column6: sung in the movie by a tiny woman with disfiguring acne who lives in Henry's radiator and serves for him as a source of warmth and comfort. ""In Heaven"" developed a life of its own outside of Eraserhead
column7: most famously in the indie rock world when it was covered first by the Pixies and then
column8: later
column9: when incorporated into Modest Mouse's single ""Workin' on Leavin' the Livin'"".

column1: ""In Heaven"" still fascinates because of its ambiguity. It's both deeply creepy and somehow a little bit uplifting
column2: never quite sure if it's celebrating life or death. On this vinyl reissue from Sacred Bones
column3: it's also included as a 7""
column4: the flip side of which is an instrumental piece in a similar style laid out by ""In Heaven""'s composer
column5: Peter Ivers. Taken all together
column6: this beautifully packaged reissue is a thorough and complete presentation of Lynch and Splet's soundworld
column7: complete with photos and stills from the film set on heavy card stock. It takes something moving and important that is in danger of being lost and bring it to a new audience
column8: which is exactly what a reissue should do. And there's something reassuring about knowing that Lynch's ""haunting dream of dark and disturbing things"" lives on
column9: finding people willing to put it on the turntable and make their own pictures.

Every year
column2: there are dozen or so classicist rock bands that make records that are virtually identical to II
column3: the latest by Brooklyn power-pop trio Nude Beach. So far in 2012
column4: the two best examples come from opposite ends of the world: The fine Leaving Atlanta by Georgian tunesmith Gentleman Jesse
column5: and the spirit-lifting self-titled debut by Australia's Royal Headache. You know the reference points for this music: mid-period Replacements
column6: early Elvis Costello
column7: all-eras Tom Petty. These records exist at the intersection of middle-American punk and heartland classic rock. No matter what is happening in the rest of the world musically
column8: there are always people-- mainly young
column9: scruffy-haired white guys
column10: though women sometimes get in on the act
column11: too-- who write snappy
column12: no-frills three-minute pop-rock songs
column13: and then package them into 10-song
column14: 30-minute records. It has nothing to do with being fashionable. Certainly
column15: the world doesn't necessarily ""need"" more records like this
column16: which is why they eventually tend to languish in record-collector obscurity. But arguing against the continued existence of this music is like saying they shouldn't make new kinds of beer. Why limit the production of what is
column17: first and foremost
column18: a populist pleasure producer
column19: even if the variation among new products is minimal?

column2: the exact right combination of simple
column3: chunky chords required to create The Perfect Rock Song That Makes All Other Rock Songs Irrelevant has not yet been achieved. Surely
column4: this is what has motivated Chuck Betz
column5: Ryan Naideau
column6: and Jimmy Shelton as they've played and recorded as Nude Beach for the past four years. II is a record created with the belief that a trebly guitar riff
column7: a no-bullshit drum beat
column8: and a heart-melting chorus can still rip out the hearts of hopeless romantics young and old. Thankfully
column9: Nude Beach are skilled enough as songwriters and unskilled enough as musicians to re-affirm this belief yet again.

column1: II came very close to being one of those highly enjoyable power-pop records that end up locked inside some local scene somewhere. It was the latest in a series of self-released records distributed by the band on cassette and vinyl at shows in and around Brooklyn. Nude Beach's profile was raised this past spring during a tour with the Men
column2: and after the initial pressing of 500 copies was sold out
column3: Other Music Recording Co. stepped up to give II a wider release.

column1: Those who picked up II after catching Nude Beach in concert were rewarded with a record that faithfully preserves the group's unpretentious bar-band charms. While Nude Beach self-identify as punks
column2: II is more akin to pub rock
column3: the roots-driven movement that pre-dated the Sex Pistols in mid-70s England. Elvis Costello had connections to that scene
column4: and My Aim Is True is an obvious touchstone for II-- particularly ""Keep It Cool"" and the beery bear-hug that is ""Cathedral Echoes""-- but Nude Beach don't aspire to Costello's erudite lyricism or furious posturing. This is good-time
column5: forget-your-troubles music whose primary subject is the pure
column6: uncut joy it inspires. The album-opening ""Radio"" is made for the very thing the title references
column7: barreling forward with an enthusiasm ideal for car stereos and rolled-down windows. ""You Make It So Easy"" is an affecting slow-dance number conjuring the memory of a million other slow dances
column8: both real and imagined. ""Love Can't Wait"" is the scrappy Tom Petty knock-off
column9: delivered with enough affection and endearing awkwardness to make the thievery not only forgivable
column10: but almost heroic.

column2: again
column3: is that this kind of record is like the city bus
column4: and there's likely another carrier of endearingly disheveled hooks already looming around the corner. As likeable as the album is
column5: there's no saying it won't get out-maneuvered by the next garage band that bashes out a half-hour of blue-denim melodies. What Nude Beach have on their side is songwriting ability and an unshakeable work ethic. That scrappy corner-tavern rock record coming on the horizon might very well be made by them
column6:
too.

The veil of anonymity works for acts like the Weeknd and Burial
column2: for whom emotional or sonic dehumanization is a major part of their musical appeal. But when Manchester's the 1975-- then known as the Slowdown-- dropped ""Sex"" last year with no contact info whatsoever
column3: I immediately had two thoughts. The first was
column4: ""Someone still makes music like this?"" The second was
column5: ""How exactly are they supposed to score a record deal?"" since ""Sex"" was a suspiciously slick
column6: born-ready anthem that was simply waiting for a stadium to fill.

column1: The 1975 have since revealed their names
column2: started a Twitter account
column3: and gone legit with their first EP
column4: Facedown. They're still a band graced with a gift for heart-on-sleeve theatrics but an unsteady hand at presentation. The title track is a fine intro
column5: a wash of ambient guitar and low
column6: patient harmonies that usually herald a band's ""atmospheric"" second LP. It leads into ""The City""
column7: where drum machines are maxed out
column8: confidently thumping like the best Big Pink singles do
column9: adding a preternatural ability to be unimpressed with the possibilities of a night out.

column1: Rather than building on ""The City""'s momentum
column2: the EP's second half tacks on two consecutive ballads
column3: the overall torch song-to-burner ratio on Facedown settling at an unwise 3:1. It starts to feel like less of a complete statement than a version of the 1975's potential debut where the singles went missing. ""Antichrist"" has ambition but only a vague sense of what it's reaching for
column4: and you can get away with leaning on a word like ""capricious"" in a hollowed-out showstopper if you're Brett Anderson. Murky closer ""Woman"" makes it clear that the 1975 shouldn't feel any rush to grow up
column5: at least not if it means edging towards Jeff Buckley worship as they do here.

column2: but a promising one
column3: hence why having background information on the 1975 works in their favor-- they've been playing together for a decade
column4: and each member is between the age of 20 and 21. It makes sense that they're musically together
column5: but still grasping for their sense of self. Facedown to a certain extent proves ""Sex"" wasn't a fluke
column6:
but all the attendant trappings of being the 1975 are still yet to be sorted out; they spent 2011 trying to fool us and they'll continue to be a band worth checking for if they decide not to fool themselves.
